text: I became very sick eating here. Last night I had 3 tapas (Squid, Pulpa and Scallops). All were delicious and I had past positive experience at Jaleo. Within one hour of eating there, I became severely nauseated and vomited all food from dinner. I was very sick, went to sleep and am fine now. I see no other explanation (usually strong stomach, no fever, no flu, no other food or drinks to explain). I cannot say which tapa was the culprit, but food safety should be high on the list. I hope this posting leads to a review of the procedures at Jaleo. I wish I could have gone back to talk to the manager, but am heading out of town now.

Normally my friends and I don't settle for mediocre food, but it was 1 am on a Saturday night and we just needed a snack before continuing our girls night out at the Marquee. 

tiny portions, kinda bland, and out of 7 dishes, we could hardly pinpoint any signature creations from that experience. 

Think Disneyland prices with the same disneyland kinds of food quality.

Came here for some late night snacks after a day of hanging out by the pool. We had some pizza around 5, so we weren't super hungry by the time we came here, around 9. I love the tapas concept and thought the food was fantastic, but it was really expensive (e.g., $14 for a martini). We spent around $170 with tip for two people. Really steep considering we didn't eat as much as we normally would have. I enjoyed the croquetas and goat cheese. Also enjoyed the mini fried shrimp with fried egg dish.
Just finished an AMAZING meal. This place is So Good. The food just blows me away. Every bite is so unique and packed with flavor. Makes me want more.

New to Vegas, I took the advise of my neighbor and decided to give Jaleo a try because I LoVe tapas.  We went on a Saturday night, so it was crowded and loud.  It was so loud I could hardly focus on reading my menu, but nothing that a cocktail couldn't tame.

We tried what felt like the entire menu...Veal cheeks, paella with squid ink and shrimp, little grilled cheese sandwiches, stuffed pasilla peppers, a fried egg with caviar...and the list goes on and on.  The only thing I wasn't a huge fan of was the veal cheeks.  I'm not sure if its because it was the last thing we ate and I was already full, or if I just didn't like the flavor.  Actually I think it was because there was a little tiny calf mooing in my ear with every bite...I'm pretty sure that's what ruined it for me.

With as many restaurants as Vegas has I'm not sure if this is a must go back to next week kind of a restaurant, but I'm sure I will be back eventually.

Went last night. Was worried that wouldn't be enough food from all the reviews. We did the tasting menu which was 55/pp. It was great. Got to try 10 dishes each and included dessert. Was plenty of food ! Highlights were paella,chicken fritters and tomato bread. Dessert was delicious. Service was very good! Definitely would go back.
The setting is very hip and pretty casual.

This was my favorite restaurant of my Vegas trip.  I've always loved spanish food since a family vacation when I was 14, so when I saw there was a tapas place in the hotel we were staying at, I knew we had to go.  We didn't have a reservation (story of my life) so we ended up at the little bar in front of one of the prep areas.  This ended up being really cool since I actually saw one of my dishes being prepared- more on that later.  
         Our server was great- she had a lot of solid recommendations, including the gin and tonic.  It's my boyfriend's favorite drink, so we had high hopes which were completely met and exceeded.  Delicious!  The sphere of ice was awesome too.
    We started with the salmon tartare and salmon roe cones, which were reminiscent of those we had at The French Laundry- not as good, and slightly fishy for my taste, but my boyfriend enjoyed them.  Next the spanish omelette and gazpacho.  The spanish omelette was good, but only average.  The gazpacho was AMAZING though.  While we were waiting I noticed the cook in the prep station in front of me delicately placing tomatoes and sprigs of something green- using tweezers(!)- into a dish.  I commented on how cool that attention to detail was, and two minutes later that dish appeared in front of me, ready for cold soup to be poured over it!  The soup was fantastic, the perfect melding of all the flavors, not too spicy and salsa-y, not to greasy and oily.   I would have been totally happy eating several bowls of this the entire meal.  We also got the shrimp saut√©ed in garlic, grilled asparagus and raw salmon.  The shrimp and asparagus were as expected, good, but not incredible.  The salmon was my boyfriend's favorite part of the meal.  It was sliced paper thin and spread across the plate.  I have no idea how they sliced it so thin but it was wonderful.  
     All in all a great meal- I wish I had been hungrier so I could have tried more things.

I love the food here, we've been twice and both times the dishes were excellent , however I wish their boqadillas were more authentic.  Ever since we went to Spain I've been craving Boqadillas but these were nothing like the real thing.  service was excellent and it's in the best casino so great atmosphere.  Overall I would go back again and again

I am torn between 2-3 stars.  In actuality, the food at Jaleo reminds me of being in Spain.  Their sangria is very, very well made.  I was actually surprised that it has the acidic tang with a spicy finish.  Most sangria in the States is usually watered down red wine with heaps of sugar and citrus fruit for a more exotic presentation.  

We had the carne asada which was nothing to write home about.  It was a hangar steak sliced and served with a pepper confit.  It was about 4 ounces for $14...not worth it at all.  

What was interesting is watching the chef make the paella with a wood burning open kitchen.  This created a very aromatic scent to the restaurant.  I ordered the paella iberico, which included pork ribs.  The paella was deliciously prepared and I was impressed by the saffron flavors every bite had.  I was VERY disappointed to have only two pieces of pork ribs that were about 1 inch in length and had mostly skin.  This plate costed $32 and honestly, it was really worth about $6 because it was only rice.  

If the plates were more substantial, I could have given Jaleo 4 stars.  Lack of meat in paella dish is a sin and rarely ever forgiven.  I give it 3 stars (mostly for effort) for the execution of authentic Spanish cuisine in the middle of Vegas.

Loved this place! Visited it with a reservation while in LV at a convention. We were there on a Monday night and it was PACKED! They specialize in Tapas and everything we had was good, or better. The food tasted very fresh which is huge for me. I also want to add we had great service. Check them out.

Tapas is great, it's fun and you can order a bunch of different things and share it with everyone at your table. Semi small orders that are reasonably priced for a high scale tapas restaurant. Some of my favorites were the gazpacho with tomatoes, cucumbers and peppers, the liquid olive dish was amazing!.. I could probably eat a whole plate of just that. The fried dates in bacon were delicious but the presentation was unappetizing. (Order it and you'll see) Not EVERYTHING that we ordered was 5 stars but there were a few that were absolutely delicious and I will definitely be going again and trying the rest of the things on the menu. I hope that I can try at least every dish on that menu at least once! Already planning my next trip to eat here!

Delicious, delicious, delicious. Only negative was that some dishes took a little while to get to the table. But when they got there...my word and stars! Bacon wrapped dates and the spicy chorizo were the highlights.

Make a reservation. Order the sangria! One carafe will fill about 6 glasses. Everything on the menu was delicious! Really enjoyed the scallops and beet salad. The only thing our party wasn't fond of was the fried wonton thing with cod filling drizzled with honey. The description sounded tasty, since everything seems to go well with honey.  I was expecting actual fish inside but it was more of a cream with a strong fishy cod flavor, unexpected but not in a good way. I grabbed one and it actually had nothing inside, so I was basically eating a chip with honey over it. That dish didn't ruin the overall experience. Great service, the waiter was helpful, and so were our bus boys. They were quick and attentive. Didn't get to try the paella bc our party was too small but it sure looked good, you can see it and smell it cooking in the back! Skip the buffet and come here for a lighter meal packed full of flavors and options!

Other than having to wait about a half hour past our 8pm sat nite reservation...this place was great...from Bocadillo sandwiches with Iberico ham and manchego to the pork sandwich sliders and pork stew....all awesome...the lobster tail paella was just ok.  We got out of there with wine and tip for about $70/head...not bad for Vegas...I'll be back...

A little noisy for a date, but it looks like a good place for drinks with friends. We started at the bar with a half carafe of sangria and a gin and tonic. I didn't like the sangria as much as I thought I would. It just tasted like red wine to me. The gin and tonic was really good, but it is expensive. :(

We ordered the garlic soup, dates with bacon, monk fish, patatas bravas, brussel sprout salad, and the lamb ribs. We wanted to get the paella instead of the ribs, but they only make one type of paella each night and it happened to be lobster. If you have food allergies make sure you ask your waiter about it. Their seafood stock uses crab meat so I couldn't eat it...really disappointed about that, but what can you do. 

The only thing I disliked was the monk fish. It was too sour for my taste. Everything else was great! My favorites were the lamb ribs and the patatas bravas. The meat on the ribs was juicy and had an awesome crust. The patatas bravas is interesting. It's fried potato slices with tomato and garlic sauce but they are SO good...but it is kind of weird to remember one of the highlights of your meal being what was essentially potato chips.
Overrated, overpriced, and at best, an average tapas place. Good things: The atmosphere was terrific, and the service was very good. bringing food in a sneaker was a turn off.

We eat at the best restaurants around the country and Jaleo just made it to the top. The tapas was amazing - the tomato bread elevated traditional tapas to its very best and I only hope to be able to taste that perfection again.  Then the waiter kindly offered us the rabbit and chicken paella and since we were celebrating my birthday we decided to splurge and get some. At first  we thought the $25 price tag was a little expensive but then we tasted it and realized what a bargain we were receiving! Their paella was smile and perfect in every way.

I couldn't possibly recommend this restaurant more - it was amazing!

We went with a very large group (14) and had arranged for a private room, upon arrival we were seated in the middle of the restaurant.  The food was a preset sample menu that was around $100 per person, half of us left hungry...tiny samples...nothing memorable.  The highlight was the paella which was too salty...and they ran out of rabbit.  A couple of dishes were fine but again nothing memorable....they also ran out of a few dishes.

Drinks are overpriced their signature gin & tonic came with tonic syrup with club soda...my wife hated it as the tonic syrup was used up quickly.  She barely had any of it and asked for a replacement which they flatly denied....our bill was over $2k you think you'd be able to get the drink you want.

Our waiter was pretentious as was the whole experience....the highlight was their gin and tonic sorbet sounds good but tastes like melted sorbet soaked in gin...simply horrible.  The chocolate flan was good but of course they had to make it unique by dumping olive oil on it.  We all enjoyed our one spoon of the flan (14 people shared essentially one scoop).  I guess I'm not sophisticated enough to understand. 

Avoid this place plenty of better places to drop a few $100 for dinner....I gave it a second star because our group made it a good time.

Had dinner here in May 2016 during our 'staycation' (that meant - no traveling out of the country vacation). 

The server explained the restaurant serve tapas - small dishes to share at the table. We had tapas in Spain and Portugal, so we were excited - and probably overexcited as the server had to warn me that I might have ordered too many dishes for the two of us. 

The food was good but could have been great had the chef been less liberal with the finishing salt. The finishing salt were big flakes of salt which overwhelmed everything. When we realized after the first dish that the finishing salt was the culprit in making our food so salty, we picked out the flakes in subsequent dishes. 

The Patatas Bravas was delicious, and despite being a pretty big portion for tapas, we finished every morsel. The paella of the day (cooked in a big pan in the dining room) was iberico ribs, and it was so fragrant and delicious, I could have eaten another order even though I was stuffed. 

Service was great. Will definite go back when in Las Vegas.
Underwhelming, tiny portions, poor presentation, slow service, overpriced. But that is just my opinion. Some might love it, so try it out for yourself.

The food was okay.  VERY expensive.  Service was atrocious.  Sangria was terrible.  Paella was spat out by all who tried it.  Dried out rabbit with lots of pinbones.  Bleccch.

They make the sangria to order so you get to see what's in it.  Cheap red wine, a little brandy, and a slice of orange.  $10?  Really.  This was unlike any sangria I've ever had.  Undrinkable

It was the service that really torpedoed our experience here, though.  It took us a half hour to get our first round of drinks.  We had to flag down the manager and have hime take our order.  Our server was a frazzled mess.  He was staring at the computer in the service station literally the whole night.

I got his attention at one point and asked if I could order a drink.  We were a group of 8 and no one had a drink yet.  I asked for a glass of tempranillo and he took off without taking anyone else's order.  Another member of our party managed to flag him down 10 minutes later and he tried to do the same thing!  Take one more person's order then fly away.  TAKE EVERYONE'S ORDER AT THE SAME TIME!  It was insane.  We spent well over a thousand dollars for 8 people.

I've eaten at Bazaar in LA, Jose Andres' other west coast foray into high-end tapas and it was one of the greatest meals I've ever experienced.  This place was a real let down.

There was so much that was wrong.  The fried dates in a shoe on the table.  Not cute or appetizing.  The sangria was absolutely awful.  Service was non-existent.  We wanted to order dessert but didn't have time since it took us so long to order and receive food and drink.  Paella inedible.  The room was way too bright.  I can't really even convey with words how sucky our meal was and how ripped-off we felt when we got the enormous bill.

The manager heard us grumping about the meal and didn't offer anything to try to turn the tide of negativity.  I think he was used to it.  Most other tables in our vicinity seemed disgruntled.  One table walked out ant the manager tried to get them to pay for the food they ordered and never got.
I've had tapas in San Sebastion and Madrid but none as good as these. This place is as good as it gets in every respect

So yelp let me down on this one. 

I was expecting to get a trendy atmosphere, great food and good drinks. We did not get that. 

We arrived about 5 minutes before our reservation. We waited for about 15 minutes and then were seated. We were seated in the booths that were open to the hotel. They were WAY too close together. We may as well been dining to the people next to us because we could hear everything they said. We ended up talking to the couple next to us and they were very nice but still, not what I was looking for. There were also a table of people sitting at at table right outside the restaurant. They had their children playing on the foozball table and they were screaming and making noise and basically ruining our dinner. Not that it was quiet to begin with. The music was way too loud. 

So a HUGE thumbs down for the atmosphere. I guess I am just too old for trendy. 

We ordered the tomato bread, the cod empanadas, the manchengo queso, and the boneless chicken wings. Our waitress said that there was a chicken special that was so much better than the chicken wings so she would bring that instead. I did not object but I should have. 

The tomato bread was yummy. $6 bucks.

The manchengo queso was an actual small slice of cheese with some dried fruit. I was thinking I was going to get some sort of yummy dip. Nope, a small piece of hard cheese. Wow Chef! Did they teach you that in culinary school?  I suppose queso does mean cheese in Spanish so it is my fault for assuming. $9 bucks

The cod empanadas were more like wontons to me. They were fried with pureed cod inside and honey drizzled on the outside. The taste was decent but the texture made me want to gag a little bit. 

The boneless chicken wings. These chicken wings cost $18 dollars for 4 of them. While I was eating them, I was thinking.."These are not any better than Buffalo Wild Wings." NOT IMPRESSED. If those were sooo much better than the other ones, I would have hated to taste those. 

My husband ordered a glass of scotch and I ordered a bramble (house specialty drink). They were $12 bucks a piece.

Our bill came to about $90 dollars because after those food fails and the noise, we decided to leave and go somewhere else. We were still starving. The plates are ridiculously small for what they charge. And here's the thing. THEY AREN'T THAT GOOD. I don't get it. 

We will never step foot inside that place again. What a disappointment.

I had high hopes for this place. Service was pretty bad to the point they forgot for 30 minutes about an order. Food was pretty salty like this review. I can understand slow service if it's packed but it was pretty empty.

Had dinner here last night with 5 other people.  The food is amazing and would come back again.  We had the red wine sangria, Tichi's gazpacho, Pan de cristal con tomate fresco, Ca√±a de cabra con higos (Murcia) A soft, semi-sweet goat's milk cheese paired with raisin walnut bread and fig jam, Idiaz√°bal con membrillo (D.O. Idiaz√°bal, Basque Country and Navarra) A smoked, nutty-flavored sheep's milk cheese paired with quince paste, Endibias con queso de cabra y naranjas, Jam√≥n ib√©rico de bellota Ferm√≠n, Arroz a banda con gambas, Croquetas de pollo, Tortilla de patatas cl√°sica, Pulpo asada con crema cebolla, Gambas al ajillo,  Calamar rellenos a lo Pelayo, Selecci√≥n de embutidos and 2 different types of desserts to share.  We had several more dishes but I can't remember the names, glad to have remembered the above.

Disappointed with the food. Last trip I walked by but decided to have sushi at Blue Ribbon instead.  I should have considered that an omen and not bother trying it this time around.  

The tapas are not in par with Jos√© Andr√©s' standards at Bazaar.  Nothing is truly memorable or worth mentioning.

The highlight of the nights were the two desserts we ordered. Next time I am in town I will skip dinner here and go for desserts.

Disappointing.  We were blown away by his other restaurant, Bazaar at SLS in LA, so we had high expectations. 

Snobby hostess: we came on a friday night with an 815 pm reservstion which wasnt needed as it was half empty.  we arrived and stood in front of the hostess as she was doing her own thing.  She looked up and gave us a greeting that felt like, "hi I guess I have to acknowledge you because you're standing in front of me"  We told her we had a reservation and said she would help us.  Then some other lady came by and she started talking to her.  We stood there awkwardly as they chatted. Luckily another hostess came by and said, "did you need any help" to which I said, "oh thanks well that other lady said she'd help us.." to which said lady responded with disdain, "oh yeah you can seat them."

Decor:  we sat along the front edge of the restaurant:  one halfside of the table were chairs and the other half were cushioned benches with a backrest that went only halfway up your back.  It was awkward cuz if you wanted to rest your back you had to slouch big time.  Basically seating was awkward.

Now to the food:  my gawd it was underwhelming.  We wanted to be blown away with unique flavor combos that would make us cry.

1.  Chicken dish (see picture).  This was the waiters wife's favorite and to us it was forgettable.  Bland and boring in flavor, texture and presentation.  The jerk chicken at The Wicked Spoon buffet was even better.

2.  Chorizo (no photo):  if you're going to serve chorizo at non fast-food restaurant, It better be mind blowing.  I've had way better from Mexican fast-food.  There was some white sauce that accompanied it that didn't make it any better.  This dish was one of the waiters favorites.

3.  The lamb (see photo):  best lamb I've had.  It was refined.  Well cooked well.  Good light flavor.

4.  Patatas Bravas (see photo):  tasty but I've had different variants of this dish.  Nothing special.

5.  "Fried chicken" (see photo):  recommended.  It's like chicken casserole that was deep fried in bite size pieces.

6.  Goat stuffed peppers:  amazing.  Mind blowing not quite.  But finally something creative and with interesting flavor combo.

Would I come here again?  It would not be my first choice.  I would rather go to bazaar or the spanish tapas restaurant in Aria or firefly.
I loved Jaleo. Dinner was amazing, service was spot on, great decor, delicious sangria. Overall an A+ experience.

This is not a restaurant for good food, let alone good Tapas.. It is more for people watching. Great ideas with presentation (tapas in a shoe??) and seating, however the food was poor and the portions were very small.  The Paella for example was maybe 1 cup.  What happened to Paella being serve in the pan it was cooked in???? For the price you are paying there are so many other great choices in Vegas. Sorry Jaelo... I would give you no stars if I could.
Absolutely incredible. Very nice server and felt welcome with kids. Food is outstanding.

Omg wonderful service and food! The vegetarian paella is the best I have ever had! Great venue for vegetarians and non vegetarians. Loved the drink menu as well. THe service is really good and I love the bell and yelling of paella every time they cook a big batch of paella. So festive. The decor is nice also. From the outside it doesn't look like much but the inside once you sit down is cute and modern. definitely will go back!

I saw Hose Andreas many times on TV, looks like a very friendly and cool guy, so I was looking forward to our visit to Jaleo. After we had dinner at his place, which was unimpressive, I got to meet him in person - very arrogant and unpleasant man. Disappointed. Will never watch his cooking shows or go to his restaurants!!!

Un-effin-believable! Fantastic food! Some of the best dining I've ever had. Quite expensive, as far as tapas go. However, the menu is extensive, and the quality of food is top notch. The service was good, and the atmosphere is nice, as long as you aren't on the extreme exterior of the restaurant. LV is very expensive for quality dining, but this place can be cheaper, if you limit the # of dishes you order. If I ever go back to LV, I will certainly come back to Jaleo.
Really Fantastic Medley of flavors. A couple of the mixes didn't completely hit the mark but for the most part a lot of new and tantalizing sensations to the palate! Really a great experience.

I really did not like this restaurant, and neither did most of the people in my party. We had 6 of us and couldn't decide what to order so we did the chefs tasting menu. Usually I love this because it gives the chef a chance to showcase his best dishes-- if these were the best dishes then I would not like to see his worst. Everything was salty and unoriginal. I would not come back.

Love, love, love this place! Sat at the bar on a recommendation from a friend, and had a great evening. Our bartender, Jose, was fantastic and made some awesome drinks based upon our personal preferences. He even ordered an array of tapas for us and everything was delicious.

We were there after 8pm on Sunday night, and the bar wasn't overly crowded so we got to chat with all the bartenders and some of the staff. Everyone was great.

My friends and I were in Vegas, and decided to grab a quick bite to eat.  I had no idea who owned this restaurant...but when the olives came out, I thought, "this tastes like Bazaar in LA."  Sure enough, I realized it was a Jose Andres restaurant.  The food was amazing...and service was great.  We sat up at the communal bar area, so it was fast and casual.  The Pan con tomate tasted like the ones I ate in Spain.  

I also of course had to order Jam√≥n Ib√©rico de bellota Fermin, which was heaven.  This is a must, because it is freshly sliced paper thin but packed with flavor.

We also ordered the bacon wrapped dates (yum!) and Patatas bravas (delicious).  I know there have been a few complaints of this place being overpriced- which it may seem to be in a strip mall and being so casual...however, in comparison to what you pay at Bazaar for Jose Andres, I think it was all very well worth it!  I also think it was the most authentic Spanish food I have eaten.

EXTREMELY SMALL PLATES, now I know this is tapas but this was smaller than your average tapas in my opinion! We ate without a reservation and sat on the outside of the restaurant by the "foosball table".  That was cool, we chose not to sit at the foosball table but right next to it because we had our 7 month old son who was in the stroller. Sitting where we sat it was not intimate and there was a feeling like you were a tad excluded from the restaurant itself. I was not impessed at all with the tapas, but my husband liked it very much; so maybe it is a tastebuds thing. I am not saying this restaurant is horrible, but in my opinion it was just ok. We did not order drinks so I am not sure if there is a full bar or not so I marked not sure... Our waitress was very nice but for the  taste, I feel you can do better in Vegas.

sorry, this place is all about nothing...the girl at the desk is not nice...had a reservation for 830 showed up at 810...was seated at 840...the food was terrible!!!! the shrimp in tomato was awful, the sauce was equal to that of chef boy ardee....the brussel sprout salad was awful, the bread with cheese on top was just that...the skirt steak was awful...the waitress was miserable...seriously dont recommend!!

So, so glad my husband and I stopped into Jaleo at the Cosmopolitan for drinks before dinner (at another restaurant) on Sunday, June 23.  We loved Oyamel in D.C., so this was a treat.  The place is beautiful, and there were some insanely great smelling paellas cooking in the large, open fire pit in the middle of the restaurant.  Everyone we met was lovely to us - which doesn't always happen in Vegas.  We had drinks and great conversation with Johnny at the bar (ask for him!  you won't be disappointed)  He explained the flash freezing to make dark rum ice cubes and some of the other interesting things they do at Jaleo, answered all of our questions, was utterly charming, PLUS! we even got to try a taste of the rabbit and chicken paella (WOW).  The only regret is I wish we'd stayed for dinner after!

Cool place! Cool decor! Beautiful servers!
Creative food (in mini-mini portions)
Service SUCKS!!!

Go for a drink and some olives, move on to the next place.

We lived in Washington DC for two years and Jaleo was one of our favorite restaurants. We recently went to Las Vegas and because of our fondness for the Jaleo in DC we made a reservation for the Jaleo in Las Vegas. 

The d√©cor at the Jaleo in Las Vegas is very contemporary, which fits it since it is in the Cosmopolitan Hotel. We ordered the Patatas bravas, whose name and description was exactly the same as our favorite dish in DC. To our horror, instead of deliciously pan fried fingerling potatoes topped with a yummy garlic aioli and a spicy tomato sauce that we get at the DC Jaleo, out came a bowl of potato chips with a garlic aioli and a tomato sauce squirted on top of them. This was the first of many disappointments of the evening.

Long story short, we will not be going back to the Jaleo in Las Vegas.  With that said, we are looking forward to going back to DC and visiting the fabulous Jaleo there.

I rarely write yelp reviews but feel that my review may be helpful here. I'm shocked that this restaurant is getting a 3.5 yelp average (which typically means a mediocre restaurant), as I just had one of the best meals of my life here and for a price that was incredibly reasonable. I eat out a VERY nice meal almost every week for work travel and compare this restaurant to that set. The dishes at Jaleo were creative with astonishing and successful combinations of flavors and ingredients.

I had:

1. Beet salad (best I've ever had by far)
2. Wild mushrooms with potato puree (delicious)
3. Shrimp saut√©ed in garlic (plate-licking good)
4. Spinach with pine nuts, raisins, and apples (simple but loved it)
5. For desert, flan (a masterpiece, sensational)

Also had a nice glass of wine and coffee. I was stuffed and the pre-tip bill was only $65, which I considered a bargain given the amount of food and the quality.

A sense of the creativity-- the beet salad was served with beets three ways (raw, boiled, & fried). Any of these 5 dishes, I would have raved about at another restaurant. To get 5 such dishes in one meal blew me away! I can't wait to go back.

Other comments/suggestions: The restaurant is busy and a bit clubby in feel, so it's loud though it may vary somewhat depending where you sit. The food comes out when ready, so if you want to stage your meal (e.g., appetizers then main), order in stages, not all at once. With such a large selection, it can help to ask for the waiter's favorites and the most popular dishes across the menu.

This absolutely deserves a 4.5 rating on yelp; I've yet to go to any restaurant that I felt deserved a 5. 

Overall - loved it, highly recommend it, and wish they'd open one in LA!

I have eaten at Jaleo twice...and both times GREAT service.  The gin and tonic oysters are a must try!  The ambiance is great and I love how you can see them prepare food if you sit at the bar.  This is GREAT place to go for drinks and a small bite.  But if you SUPER hungry and on a budget I would go elsewhere.

The food was just OK. Our expectations were high since we've dined at Jose's restaurants in DC and other tapas restaurants in NYC (Tia Pol, Boqueria, Casa Mono).  
-Patatas Bravas - Dericious!
-Chistorra envuelta en patata frita - Ok
-Setas al ajillo con La Serena - Bland
-Ensalada de coles de Bruselas con albaricoques, manzanas y jam√≥n Serrano - I'm not a salad person but this was pretty good.
-Gambas al ajillo - Good. Make sure you ask for toasted bread to dip in the garlic sauce.
-Pulpo a feira Maestro Alfonso - Bland
-D√°tiles con tocino 'como hace todo el mundo' - Ok. The bacon was overpowered by the dates.

Pop in for a quick bit after a 14 hour Grand Canyon bus tour around 10pm Monday night. This place was packed...
Ordered 7 items including 1/2 carafe of Sangria, bill came to $120 before tips.
Gambas al Ajillo (prawns) good sauce, prawns nice size I think there were 5 or 6 for $14
Carne Asada, grilled to a nice medium $16 (ok nothing special)
Pollo Croquettas, crispy on the outside and a nice creamy silky chicken on the inside. good
Canelones with pork and fois gras. Can't really taste the fois gras, taste like salted potatoes added to the pork. OK, not terrific
Rossejat...angel hair pasta pealla with prawns. This is my favorite dish. It's like angel hair pasta that's been cooked with prawn soup base. A steal @ $15Yummy for my tummy.
For dessert we had the flan. Very smooth texture. Pricey @ $12
Finally the Sangria we ordered had quite a kick. Not enough fruit for me but the taste is right. $25.00

Last time we were in Vegas we were there for our honeymoon so we ate at e by Jose. We absolutely loved it, but it's not exactly a dinner you need to do multiple times. So this time around we decided to stop into Jaleo. 

We came in during social hour on 9/29/16 after eating a few plates at Scarpetta. We sat at the bar and got an order of calamari and the potatoes bravas. I ordered sangria and my husband asked the bartender, Stephen, for advice on a vermouth. The vermouth Stephen picked out was so amazing I ordered one once I was done with my sangria. We had a lovely time enjoying a few drinks and chatting with Stephen. The couple next to us ordered the jamon iberico la bellota and it looked so good we decided to order it as well. I also ordered a glass of wine, since Albarino is my favorite wine style and hard to find. The iberico may be expensive at $35 an ounce, but it is absolutely worth it. The tomato covered bread it comes with is somehow equally to die for. 

We left Vegas on Saturday 10/1 on an evening flight. Since we needed to pick up our checked bags at Cosmo before leaving for the airport, we decided it made the most sense to eat dinner at Cosmo. We would up going to Jaleo again because it was that good. We got two of the iberico sliders, a few cheeses, and...the jamon iberico la bellota again...I figured, when in Rome. It's not really something we can get at home. We finished with the gin and tonic dessert which was light and ephemeral. I enjoyed a few glasses of wine and my husband tried a few sherries. 

Everything we had here was amazing. The bar service on the second visit was a bit abysmal at first. But halfway through Stephen came back into work and made sure we were taken care of. Guy deserves credit for being a great server with awesome knowledge of their bar/food offerings and great customer service skills!!

Second times I am here.  It was a year ago when I first had dinner here.  That meal was expensive which cost me $500 for a party of four.  Tonight's dinner is more reasonable but maybe I am not that into Spanish food and I feel it is just usual.  Not as the first time when I tried it, that memorable.  The service is always good and the decor is wonderful.  But I will probably go try some other fancy restaurant if I am in town next time.
A fun place for dinner @ the Cosmopolitan, Vegas Strip. Strongly recommend The Paella , tortilla de batata and the chocolate custard dessert.

Jaleo is probably my favorite restaurant at the Cosmopolitan.  The design of the restaurant is fun, modern, upbeat.  The aroma of Paella fills the air and gets the stomach excited right as you walk in!  They offer some exclusive Cavas from Spain that are so crispy and satisfying.  I love Tapas and being able to have a lot of little plates give you the chance to sample a larger variety of dishes.  The stuffed piquillo peppers were outstanding !!  

My only complaint is some of the tables are way too close to each other, so if you are a party of two, it can feel like you're having dinner with the table next to you.

In a word... extraordinary!

The service was a little slow, but once those incredibly delicious little plates of Spanish wonderfulness starting arriving, I wasn't really paying that much attention to our server. I could have eaten two or three plates of the carne asada... I've never had beef that good (and I am a confirmed carnivore).  And the flan? Where do I begin? Superb.

Can't wait for my next trip to Vegas... this place is definitely on my Top 5 list!

I am so very disappointed with Jaleo.  I actually wanted to eat at a Tapas restaurant in Aria but decided on Jaleo.  The waitress was amazing but....I have had better Tapas.  Everything we ordered was not even up to par except for the Gambas which was okay.  The squid was smaller than a dime mixed with beans, so there was approx. 7 tiny squids.  The crab croquette's texture was like tuna & the worst of all the idea of placing the croquette in a small paper bag inside a "tennis shoe"... it was actually disgusting. Green beans with goat cheese was just okay.  Paella with ribs could have been better if they cooked the rice.  Sangria was great but seriously for $54?  We have been to Tapas all over.  Frankly, years ago we tried Firefly....should have listened to YELP!!

Jaleo - if you like Tapas - and you're and Vegas this is must!  Please try the world famous shrimp - the cauliflower with dates and olives outstanding!  Our server Mary was awesome - and kudos to Dave - GM - the olives were amazing!
We tried like 20 different things on the menu between a group of 8 of us and every single thing was delicious. The atmosphere is fun and our server was awesome! Will be coming back for sure.
Had fabulous late meal here including, cannelloni, salad, oysters, bacon wrapped dates.  Great ambiance and service!

We ate at Bazaar in Miami so I was excited to try his place at the Cosmopolitan. The restaurant, visually, is very exciting. Lots going on and you can view all the food being made at various stations. The problem was, there were so many employees and the pace was so frenetic, that nobody ended up knowing who was responsible for which table. Our waitress took our order and then we never saw her again. That was ok, however then someone would stop by (eventually) having noticed our water glass was empty. They would say they would address it, zoom off and never come back. Then another of the dozen or so workers standing / running around would come by and say they would get us water. And then finally someone would. It was pretty bizarre. We watched 5 separate people bus and re-dress the table next to us. The food was fair, a few dishes were great - but the constant movement of bodies (without much end result) around the restaurant was a huge distraction. If you're going to have that many people working, nobody should sit with an empty glass or in need of more silverware for 5-10 minutes.

Great place to have a bit upscale dinner and converse with a group. Gin tonic is delicious and so are sangria. Really happy with cheese platter and ham that has apparently been fed acorn and aged 4 years. Service was on point and he was able to paint the picture with words.

The only disappointment was the patatas bravas which is "deconstructed" and not like in Barcelona. But that's the Vegas twist. The paella was good, also non-authentic, but delicious. Choose the cheese board for dessert -- AMAZING!!
One of the better tapa joints in Vegas.  Although, don't know what the heck happened.  They got rid of a bunch of their original dishes which were amazing!!!  Drinks are pricey but yummy...

Had several dishes including lobster paella. It was pricey, portions were small and flavor was off. It was way too salty. I would not recommend this place. Been to Jaleo in Bethesda, MD and it is much better.

This restaurant experience was very disappointing. Me and my Sig other went here for lunch, excited to try a Jose Andres restaurant. 

We started our meal with the signature gin and tonics, which were the best part of the meal. They were infused with different spices, clean tasting, and herbal. Worth the $20 in my opinion. We then ordered a bunch of tapas: fried dates wrapped in bacon, house made chorizo, patatas bravas, and octopus salad, and a Spanish spring roll (rollito).

The breading on the dates obscured the natural caramel flavor of the dates. It also detracted from the usual salty-sweet combo I'm used to with this appetizer. This is the first time I have been served this dish fried, I'm not keen to try it again.

 The patatas bravas was so disappointing. They used waxy potatoes instead of a starchy variety, so it never got crispy like the dish should be. The romesco sauce also tasted more like bland ketchup than the rich, tangy, creamy sauce it should be.

 The octopus had an off flavor to it --it tasted like old tuna. It was tender but lacking an flavor. It was served with bland boiled potatoes and a dash of smoked paprika. It needed herbs or vinegar to wake it up. 

The spring roll was filled with potatoes and chorizo which needed seasoning--not enough chorizo in the filling to compensate for the under salted potatoes. The Apple mustard that it was served with was amazing: sweet and spicy. I wish I could have had it with every dish--it would have considerably improved their flavors.

The best dish was the housemade chorizo. It was seared with cider which gave it an addictive sweet, salty and fatty flavor. It was served on top of creamy pea puree 

All in all this place has dissuaded me from ever buying a Jose Andres cookbook. Very overrated. You could easily make better at home.

Service was non existent. The hostess was on her phone busy replying to texts while we stood there watching her while  waiting to be greeted and seated. We ordered the paella which ended up tasting more like dollar Chinese fried rice.  There were hard pieces of rice in almost every bite.  The portions of the paella were smaller than I'm used to being served. The upside was the gazpacho, which was extremely flavorful and ended up being the highlight of the meal.
Food tastes great, but when the say "small plates" they mean it. Bring your wallet or don't bring an appetite.

Took my 2 sisters and wife here for my big sisters bday. Ambience and service were great. Food not so much. Few of the cooks must have been heavy handed on the salt that night. Everything was too salty and I like salt. Probably going to give it another try though. Egg and onion omelet with uni was my fav dish.  Sangria and cocktails were really good.

We came in for a drink & tapas. Dylan was a tremendous help with the wine   He was extremely knowledgeable about Spanish wines and pairing it with tapas.  Recommend this restaurant for an afternoon stop.

The lunch is bad .... It dont be worth the price 30$ ... no way. and the service is soso...
the worst thing is I filled 9 (15%) tips because i feel soso but they add the tips to 20% themselves. Asshole..

Service was magnificent. Cannot say enough about the food - croquetas are exceptionally authentic.

We went around 5pm, not too busy but was picking up when we left.  Highly recommend it, I will definitely be back.
Rare combination of perceptive and proactive service from manager Michelle.  Turned a difficult evening into a wonderful dining experience.  Just awesome.

What a great surprise this was. I saw the 3 1/2 stars on Yelp so I was a little hesistant but being that i was staying in the Cosmopolitan our group decided to try it out. Turns out this place rocks. I've never been the biggest fan of Spanish tapas but this place had the best I've ever had (that incudes Spain). Probably because they had their own twist to what was being served but everthing we ordered was just outstanding  and the presentation of the food made it look like pieces of art. I'll be back.

My wife and I were in Vegas for a few days and we always wanted to try Jos√© Andr√©s' restaurant. We lived in Spain for 5 years, so it was a nice way to go back to those amazing flavors.

Well I have to admit that the experience has been so disappointing!

At first we were very enthusiastic because the place has a really great vibe but the waiter ruined the whole experience.
I am not talking about the waiter who seated us, brought the menus and took the order who was actually very nice but the waiter who served us.

We were sitting in the main area where there is a colorful couch surrounding one side of the room. The waiter poked my wife on the back to pass the plates from behind instead of coming to our table...he was so rude, bored...he didn't say a word (Enjoy the food for example ???...). If you don't like the job, just don't do it...

We were going to order more food but we decided to pass after the third plate was brought to us by the same guy and in the same way.

Food was not that great either...I really don't know what the amazing Jos√© Andr√©s chef would think about a raw tortilla or over fried calamari...

I know that "bad nights" happen...but there is nothing worse than wanting to try a restaurant for so long and be disappointed after all!

After this experience I will never go back...If you pay that much money (nearly 40 dollars for 3 TAPAS plates!!!), you expect much more.

@ hostess stand our party of 5 was told you only have the table a hour ok??
Sat down server said" everyone should order 2-3 items each they are served tapas style. Each friggin "small plate" was= 13-17$!!
We ordered drinks & before they came .. Left.. Crazy

We went there with high expectations and they were all met with flying colors.  We ordered the shrimp in garlic sauce.  Yum yum. That's the best dish. The endive with orange and nuts were great.  The skirt steak was excellent.  The pork sliders were awesome.  I'm not a burger fan, but it left a sweet and savory taste on my palate that made me want to come back.  The paellella of the day was with duck....too salty.  I wish they had the seafood paellella, but you can only have what they made that day.  The flan has the right balance of rich creamy sweet and citrus from the ice cream and orange.

I would definitely come back to try a few more things on the menu.  The service was nice with the right amount of attentiveness.

The bill came out $126 for 2 people that makes me smile.  It's very decent for an upscale restaurant.

Highly recommend this restaurant

Being a Tapas aficionado, we were very interested in trying the "New Style" tapas offered at this new Tapas restaurant. Jose Andres didn't disappoint. There were so many outstanding dishes to tantalize our taste buds. Memorable were the Ferran Adria olives, worth another visit just for this plate. Pollo ajillo had an intense flavor that burst in your mouth but looked nothing like the traditional version. The service was exemplary, food arrived on the table when requested, the only reason that we had to give four stars is that it is a very noisy location.

Extremely overpriced and small rations. Paella was undercook and lack of flavor.

Service was horrible and management needs improvements.

The chistorra is the one you find in the stores in L.A., the mussels were ok but the sauce was flavorless, the croquetas ok but small and the tortilla de patatas I make it much better at home

I am from Spain and I am always looking for real spanish restaurants, this will be a little Bar in Madrid with not a lot of public due to the quality of the food.

I also experienced the same at Baazar, Jose Andres is the new type of chef that fells short in every aspect but due to the celebrity status everything works.

Tapas is not upscale is just casual over beers and wine, cheap and lot of options that you order by units.

In a restaurant like this you serve rations that are bigger than the tapas and everybody can taste.

Do not recommend at all, I am sure that after a while the restaurant will be gone with the trend.

Service - 7
Atmosphere - 7
Food - 8
Vegetarian Friendly - 6
General Awesomeness - 7

I can't say much about the bacon wrapped dates due to my vegetarianism, but I will say the waiter who solely monitored our water glass was top notch.  All the veggies were great and the tourists seemed to behave themselves.
This place is so amazing . Why does anyone else even make food ? It's a reason to come to Vegas . I mean really
We had a very wonderful experience here. Loved the tuna and the potatoes dish but really everything was great.

Totally over priced for teeny, tiny plates of not so good food and a rude waitress.  The one star is for the chef who cooked the skirt steak perfectly.  The skirt steak was the size of half of a dollar bill.  For the price, I could've gone somewhere else and gotten an entire skirt steak, much more friendly service and a more pleasant atmosphere.

Will not go back and will never recommend it!

Take your used  shoes off of my table
I don't think that's nice

I keep falling for famous chef-branded restaurants. The service was great, but the food is overpriced and average. Also, there was an odd smell floating throughout our meal. We think it was a dirty rag used to clean nearby tables.

Service here is very poor, there are long periods of neglect and abandonment.  The servers literally disappear and are never seen again. 

The dishes are tiny tapas style and come out so slowly that if you go in a group, half of you will pretty much starve to death.  Food quality is hit and miss - some dishes are absolutely incredible, others surprisingly bad.  

For some reason the temperature at the restaurant is set to below freezing, which makes being there really uncomfortable.  I felt like grabbing the manager and saying: look, this is the Cosmopolitan, do you not see all these poor women sitting here half naked and shivering?  You need to shut the bloody AC off!

They have a foosball table outside which doubles up as a dining table for six.  It is a super fun idea and a super impractical one at the same time.  The seats are shaped like saddles so there is no back support- there is in fact very little bottom support - you kind of hover in mid air half the time trying not to fall off completely - much like being on a real saddle I suppose!  Best of all, the poles in the table provide a great opportunity to file a lawsuit against the establishment since you can easily stab and seriously damage the person sitting across from you if you're not careful.  

Been here twice but I don't think will be back again; at their prices it's just not worth it.  Even if I end up with a bunch of the better dishes, it's simply not a relaxing enough environment to make the experience fully enjoyable. 

Okay, rant over.

After years of seeing Jose Andres on TV, I finally got to try some of his food and I was not disappointed. My wife and I ordered the chorizo with papas, 1/2 carafe of sangria, jamon of the tomato garlic toast, tempura shrimp, onion tortilla espanola and a spinach salad. All of the dishes were balanced and well executed. I really enjoyed the shrimp and the toast tasted exactly how I've had it in Madrid. The sangria was perfect for me and light enough for my wife to enjoy it. The only bummer was that the chorizo was a tad spicy and it caught you off guard, since I don't see Spanish food as spicy. Overall it was a great experience and I would highly recommend it to my friends.

Jaleo is a small chain of tapas restaurants by Jose Andres.  I've eaten at one previously in Washington DC and found it to be above average.  This outlet in the Cosmopolitan has a great atmosphere with a large open cooking pit.  

While most of the menu is tapas, they offer full portions of Paella.  They offer several different types, but you are limited to those that they have prepared at the moment.  It is prepared in a very large pan on the open cooking pit, so it isn't made to order unless you purchase for a group (I believe it was 8 or more).

I tried a chicken and wild mushroom paella.  It had good flavor, but was rather dry.  I was there early for dinner (5:00), so perhaps it had been on the heat too long.  The paella ran around $25.

While this experience was rather mediocre, based upon my experience at other locations, I'd still give them another shot at tapas.

I have been here twice. These tapas are not like anything I have in Spain, but who cares, it is all good. Some reviews complain that it is expensive, but most decent restaurants in Las Vegas are. 
The food was all excellent and the service impeccable. One note. On one dish, the waitress used the term " for an additional charge, we can put black truffles on top".  If a top notch restaurant says that, you know it is not a nominal charge. $16.00 is what it worked out to. Not a complaint, but an observation.

Pros: Out of this world fried eggplant with honey (must order); To die for pan con tomate!!!!! 

Cons: very small portions, average serrano ham, don't think you're getting fried potatoes when you order patatas bravas (I won't ruin the surprise for you). 

We wish we would have tried the paella but they weren't serving the one we wanted.....great atmosphere!

Went for dinner, sat night. Very tasty. No resv. They took us in right away. Sit at a table near the front. Very good people watching.  Had a combo of the garlic shrimp, veal cheeks, hot asparagus in red sauce, fried pasta with shrimp.  Good presentation, flavorful, would def go again. 

Try the house cocktail of sake,wine, soda, with fresh berries.

Server was a bit clueless about the menu or food but the taste outweighed her deficits.

Gin tonic was great.  I am Spanish, and I was stunned by the creativity behind some of the reinventions of the most traditional dishes. The ensaladilla rusa was just great, and so was the torrija. If anything, I would mention that I think that he deserves a better location. The place looks like a side walk-in on a mall upper floor...but that is looking for something to say. It's a job well done!
Looks nice from outside. Food was blah. Had no flavor. Everything was so oily...will not be returning...still hungry going to eat at secret pizza.
Had a late dinner yesterday at Jaleo with a group of 5 and everyone truly enjoyed the amazing food! Everything we ordered was awesome and the desserts were the crowning glory! Will be back!

Read lots of reviews and gathered recommendations and ended up at Jaleo for late dinner.  The hostess was very nice and offered me a seat at the bar with no wait time.  The bartender was very friendly and helped to explain the menu.  Figuring the Paella would take a long time (states 45 minutes on the menu), I quickly got the order in.  I was figuring on munching on some of the starters and working my way up to the finale.  Nope, the  paella came in like 5 minutes.  Timing was a little off don't you think?  I was also thinking.......great this thing has been sitting and was just re-heated........unfortunately it kind of was.  The rice was a little under cooked for my liking and barely warmed through.  The lobster was the same as far as temperature, however it was cooked perfectly and tasted very sweet.  The sauteed shrimp was nicely cooked and very light.  I also tried the chorizo wrapped with potato, and (if I remember correctly) patatas bravas.... both of which were good, but slightly oily.  Overall I had a nice time and enjoyed the food.

Terrible service, server never showed up, food was ok, nothing out of the ordinary....
the table next to us got their meal comped because of the same issue.
the oysters gin & tonic, they sound good but flavor was awful....also, sangria had no flavor....

Overall, terrible experience, we'll never go back.

How many ways can a restaurant use Jamon Iberico. More than I could eat for sure, throw in some serrano, skirt steak (which I am trying desperately to duplicate at home) a veal cheek so tender that a slight touch with your fork splits it and you have a memorable meal. Service was outstanding, wine list all Spanish and the best damn gin and tonic I have ever had, and I cannot stand drinking gin and tonics. 

Favorite dish (outside of the jamon di Iberico) was the Brussel Sprouts with apple, fennel, serrano served warm. I suggest going with people you know as its all shared. If you want Paella order early as it sells out and can be 45 minutes before the next version is available. There are 5 or 6 types and they are made in rotation or for groups of 6 or more. 

My complaint - I am tired of Croquetas. They may be traditional buut no matter where I have them, I really hate them and unfortunately Jaleo is no exception. Maybe they are not my food type as everyone else seems to love them. Maybe it's because we Americans see then as "safe" when compared to other items on the menu. Live a little y'all
The vegetarian and seafood tapas is an experience in itself. Brilliant food, great atmosphere for a group of friends.

Surprenant restaurant de tapas dans le tr√®s bel Hotel Cosmopolitan de Las Vegas . Les tapas sont originales et excellentes . Comptez 3 environ par personne. Service excellent √©galement . Prix 80 dollars par personne environ vin inclus.

I was so excited to try this restaurant. It came highly recommended from a friend. I love all the booth seating, colors and patterns & the music gives a fun vibe. The menu is a little intimidating because I wasn't sure what a lot of things were but our server Mario had great knowledge of the menu. He gave amazing recommendations of cocktails and food walking us through the menu.
     I ordered the Sangria and it was so refreshing. We started with the goat cheese and raisin walnut bread topped with fig jam. If you like goat cheese be prepared to taste the best you have ever had! One of the most popular dishes the toasted ethereal bread brushed with tomato. Don't even think about it just order it! Next we had the shrimp with saut√©ed garlic. I'm not a huge shrimp fan but wow. It was delicious. Is it bad that I could have eaten just a bowl of the saut√©ed garlic?! Lastly the spicy chorizo wrapped in crispy potato with alioli. My boyfriend literally said "OMG babe what are you doing hurry up and eat this!" He was right my taste buds were mind blown. 
    I was truly blown away by my experience here.  Coming recommended from a friend I knew it would be good but he didn't say... basically it will be one of the best Spanish restaurant you have ever been to! Mario was great, the wait staff was super attentive. I can not wait to come back again and try more things on the menu! Jos√© Andr√©s you created a restaurant like no other be proud!

Went to Jaleo with high expectations. Ordered various tapas and the "paella feast".  There were one tapa that we enjoyed. The radicchio with goat cheese. The bread that came with the garlic was also decent. The other dishes were either unremarkable or excessively salted. The paella and the octopus were two that were over salted. The rice had a nice bite but the salt overwhelmed the dish. Very disappointing. All you could taste were essentially the salt. Expected much more from an Jose Andres branded restaurant. The ingredients of the paella were also unremarkable: chicken and mushroom. The other tapas and dishes we had: the skirt steak, the gazpacho, garlic shrimp and others were unremarkable. Don't have high expectations if you go. The sangria was also unremarkable.
Not great ordered seafood and disappointed. Don't get the seafood! Maybe drinks and meat would be better.  nice ambience though. Open fire where you can watch things being cooked.

The food here was fantastic....the only problem was there wasn't enough of it!  I went with 6 people and we loved every bit of the food, but the bill was more than $400, and we left there to go to the pizza place next door.  I give it two stars because the food was good, but the best part of the whole meal was the gin and tonics.  By far, this is the best drink I have ever had in my life.....You MUST get this drink if you go to this restaurant.  Just keep in mind that there is a great pizza place in the alley next to the restaurant.

We made sure to make a reservation on a Saturday night to dine here.  We arrived before our reservation and were asked to wait.  It is oneof those places where unfortunately, you feel that if you are not within close proximity to the host staff while waiting for your reservation they will conveniently overlook you and handle the people who are in their face, even though you have a reservation.  We are finally seated next to a long table that looks like a bachelor party of men in their 30s. This table distracted our server throughout our time there.  The wine and drinks lists on the IPad is "cutting edge", yet not all kinks with this have been worked out. We ordered a bunch of different small plates.  Friends enjoyed the cold almond and garlic soup.  The paella was just ok.  The lobster salad had some zing.  Egg with caviar was rich with good flavor. This is a trendy spot with potential to be a lasting restaurant with improvements in service.

Love all of Jos√© Andres' restaurants but Jaleo is the only place to get your authentic Paella. Made fresh every 30 or so minutes. Chicken croquettes are a must eat too! Always busy around dinner time.

I can't say enough good things about this place. The menu was a little overwhelming, so we asked the waitress to order for us. We ate for over an hour, it was all delicious and for 5 people with drinks the bill didn't even end up being all that bad.

My husband and I ate here on our last day in Vegas for his birthday.  My husband was born and raised in Spain so he is very familiar with tapas style food.  Unfortunately, undercooked, sliders which contained pork were raw, pink and mushy when we sliced into it. The rest of our meal was delicious, especially the croquettes.  Unfortunately, my husband had already eaten 1/2 the slider before we realized it was raw and had later had stomach problems which kept us indoors for a few hours on our lasday in Vegas---:( really disappointing.  The waiter was really kind and professional and the ambiance was nice.  We would not return though, as raw meat with pork in it can definitely get you sick and in this case it unfortunately did.
The main dish Paella tasted and looked like Chinese fried rice, the Paella at Wicked Spoon(Buffet) actually tasted better than here.

i have eaten at the Jaleo in DC and LOVED it.  so i was excited to visit the Jaleo in Vegas.  i was disappointed to say the least.  the service was horrible...we had reservations and didn't get seated for almost 40 minutes.  and no one apologized even when we voiced our impatience.  the service continued to get bad.  we didn't see our waitress for almost 20 minutes and didn't get our water glasses filled for almost that long as well.  the server forgot to put our order in for the paella and it was at our table an hour after we ordered it.  and once it came to the table it was cold, overseasoned, and crunchy.  the couple next to us kept getting the wrong dishes from our server.  i would excuse the poor service if the food was out of this world.  everything was oversalted or overseasoned.  with the exception of the spinach salad which was completely bland.  i hope Jaleo gets with the program.  i am a big fan of Chef Andres' restaurants and i want to see him succeed.

Horrible. Salty croquetas. Salty and undercooked paella. How do u get these two items wrong?!? And how do u justify the prices and the portions for terrible food?? I have never eaten at a place and been so utterly disappointed.

I've never given anyone just one star so congrats to them on that.

Went to Jaleo for my daughter's birthday, as she was craving a Paella... Being Latin and having enjoyed traditional Paellas in Spain, we expected something very good and typical of Spain, given the hype, price point and location of this modern restaurant.

Of the seven types of Paellas, only two were being served. We were shocked when they brought small, salad size plates with brown rice and three shrimp... ¬ø?   Real Spanish Paellas are so different, so colorful... Where was the saffron, the rest of ingredients that give Paellas their flavor? And $30 or $35 for this amateur dish?  Wow...

As I observed the other tables, with gringos who had no idea what a Paella should look like or taste like, I could understand the success of this restaurant.

But, if you are in the mood for a real Paella, this is not the restaurant for you.  Sorry to be so blunt.

I'm in Vegas 3 or 4 times a year for work or vacation and I'm always looking for new places to eat. On vacation with my wife in September (2012), we went to Jaleo and had our minds blown!! This place is pricey, but worth it.The whole experience was amazing - the food, the service, the big open kitchen, the drinks - I can't wait to go back. Highest quality ingredients and cooked in a very unique way. Both of us are thinking we'll have to go at least 2 or 3 more times to try all the amazing dishes we saw on the menu.
Way to pricy for what you get! Food was just ok, kind of bazaar place overall.

We ordered the:

1) Fried dates wrapped in bacon - overdone (a bit disappointing)
2) Grilled hanger steak with piquillo pepper confit - cooked just right and very juicy
3) shrimp saut√©ed with garlic - bring some gum because you're going to need it after this dish, but still worth it
4) Seared scallops with romesco sauce - i love scallops that just melt in your mouth, also well prepared

Good vibe and atmosphere.  Service is helpful with menu suggestions and drinks are strong.

Can't say I'm impressed with the Cosmo food scene. There's better tapas at Firefly. The hidden pizza joint next door is a more satisfying meal. 

The Cosmo better step it up food wise. It's highway robbery for very so-so quality food. They obviously want more of a vibe than a great place to eat. Great food gets return customers. Everyone on that 3rd floor are in for a surprise in a year from now....

I've eaten twice at Jaleo and it has been fantastic both times. The wide range of dishes is incredible, everyone found something great. 

My favorites are the Serrano ham on almost bruschetta, the garlic shrimp and the grilled asparagus. I absolutely recommend Jaleo at The Cosmopolitan and will be going back soon!


- Addressing a comment below - we never had any trouble with water service. He promptly offered bottled or ice water and they came by refilling water constantly.

Jaleo was a really fun place to go with friends. Tapas is always cool, and the cosmopolitan was my favorite hotel in Vegas. I loved the tomato bread! It tasted so fresh. The garlic shrimp was also fantastic. Definitely a fun place! Make sure to make a reservation though because this place gets crowded and the wait is LONG!

Went here again last night. We had the Pork and Foie Gras Cannelloni with bechamel sauce and black truffle again. Still as good as ever and very yummy. Also, had the empanada cod brandade with honey, interesting, probably not my favorite but the cheese had a definite cod flavor which was unexpected or if it wasn't cheese it was very cheese like in texture. Also tried the eggplant and roasted red peppers, this had a very intense roasted flavor, and was good although I would preferred this as a bruschetta. And of course had to get the Iberico ham croquettas, I could eat these all day, although my cholesterol would not be happy if I did. 

I will say that my experience this time was not as good as last time, not due to the food but as it was very loud in the dining room in part due to a loud group of tourists one table over and the loud music wafting in from the hall area. I had to yell to communicate with the people I was with. Also, the waitress missed one order I placed, but they quickly brought it over once I drew their attention to it. I still think, that the food is far better than Julian Serrano, next door to the Cosmo, for the same price.

With the exception of the Carne Asada the food was terrible.  The rice dishes were overly salted and the rice was undercooked.  The only plus about this place was the staff.  I would not recommend it to anyone.

Total scam. We came for tapas, and ordered four plates. One of them was patatas bravas, which turned out to be a bag of potato chips (with the bag!) covered in tomato sauce and mayo. The waiter did tell us that this dish "is not traditional but rather consists of thin potatoes" . That's called potato chips, 20c/bag. The beef sliders were salty and full of fat- no other flavors. Their "signature shrimps" were mildly cooked and had little flavor as well.
When the bill came, they also double counted each of our drinks.

Wow, major disappointment. I've been to Bazaar and while I was not completely impressed with the taste of the food there, the presentation was always whimsical and creative. Here, there is neither taste nor presentation.

The best dish of the 16 or so the group of us tried was the "pan con tomate" (bruschetta), which is really sad b/c it's just toasted bread with tomato & olive oil. The only other dishes I tolerated were the foie gras canalones, the mushrooms & the veal cheeks. 

Everything else was bad. The chicken fritters presented in a brown shoe was like a slap in the face. The crab and potato dish (under "jose's way" on the menu) was disgusting, it came served with basically with an entire jar of mayonnaise plopped on top of extremely salty crab meat. The squid was absolutely flavorless. The octopus was overly seasoned with paprika. The paella tasted like baked spaghetti. The endives didn't taste fresh. But, the dish that REALLY pissed me off was the patatas bravas. I was expecting potatoes or something creative--I was NOT expecting a bowl of store-bought-tasting potato chips with 4 strands of mayo and chili sauce drizzled on top.

No one in my group thought the food was good. And we won't be back.

Went to Jaleo Friday night with a group for dinner before going out.  We ended up at one of the tables outside of the restaurant, which I'm sure started us off with a completely different experience than we would have had if we had dined in the restaurant.  

Our group was 7 girls and none of us were particularly hungry.  We ordered 8-10 tapas plates.  Each one that came out lacked in presentation (the chorizo looked like sausage I could have bought at the grocery store, cut up, put on a place and set out at home), was very small (and that's coming from someone who lived in NY for years), and really, nothing we had was exceptional.  The food was alright, nothing to write home about or bother going back for and I didn't like the sangria at all. 

They also didn't have the lobster paella, which we knew we wanted to order.  They didn't have any of the paella, but said if we wanted one we could order an entire pan, which was 6 servings ($30-56 a serving).  Oh, and heads up, the paella takes 45 minutes, so if you want to order it, know that right off.  

All in all, we just expected a lot more.

We went here for our wedding anniversary. My husband is from the northern region of spain so we have expectations when it comes to tapas and spanish food In general. Unfortunately these were not met! Can you believe this tapas restaurant doesn't serve bread with anything! We ordered the jamon iberico and it showed up at our table without bread, shocking! We also ordered the tortilla (Spanish omelette), thIs to our our amazement was just scrambled egg! Not a potato or onion in sight! if you want good authentic tapas go to firefly on paradise!

Great tapas!! Go for the Octopus salad and cod croquetas. Friendly staff, music was kind of loud which does not bother me. 
Will def be back!! Decoration is very modern and RED... LOL... Loved the energy!!
Over priced, bad service.  Tiny portions, avg tasting, will not be back!

I was really looking forward to this place and felt let down big time. The service was excellent BUT the food was not what I'd expect from the prices they charge. It was just "meh" in my book. Not bad or anything, but I would never come back again because the prices don't match up with the food.

Since I am Spanish, I wanted to try this restaurant and was highly disappointed, I recommend "FIRE FLY"  so much better; this place is a RIP OFF; I have taste better TAPAS for the price. I CAN MAKE A BETTER PAELLA FOR SURE!!!!
Save your money all you are paying for is the real state..

Dinner at Jaleo was a true culinary experience. Everything we ate was delicious. My husband chose the Chef's five course seasonal tasting menu and I ordered a few tapas selections from the main menu, all of which we shared. The service was impeccable! We would highly recommend Jaleo to any foodie.

Given my love of some of Jose Andres' other restaurants, I had high hopes for Jaleo.  Jaleo, sadly, did not live up to its billing or my expectations.  Portions were exceedingly small, prices were high, and flavors were muted . . . not a good combination for a celebrated restaurant.
  
I love tapas and thus was excited to try lots of different plates.  On my visit I tried the King Crab with diced peppers, the Serrano Ham, the Gin & Tonic Oysters, the Patatas Bravas, the Shrimp saut√©ed with garlic, the Squid & Shrimp Paella, the Seared Scallops with Romesco Sauce, the Pork Sausage Stew, and the Grilled Skirt Steak with Piquillo Pepper Confit.

Most of the dishes I tried were good but not great.  That being said, The Gin & Tonic Oysters were unique and pretty good as was the Patatas Bravas.  Rather than severing traditional Patatas Bravas, Jose Andres provided his own take on the dish which consisted of potato chips covered with a romesco ketchup and aioli.  The star dish of the evening was the Grilled Skirt Steak with Piquillo Pepper Confit.  The steak was cooked perfectly and was beautifully accented by the Piquillo Pepper Confit which provided just a touch of heat and a wonderful roundness of flavor.  Too bad the portion was minuscule and gone in four bites.

If you temper your expectations Jaleo shouldn't disappoint you, . . . just don't go there thinking you'll be getting a dining experience akin to Zaytinya.

Great atmosphere, great service and the dishes are fun and well prepared. I usually never order risotto at restaurants because it's never any good but I was pleasantly surprised at every single dish here! Perfect place to dine with company.

The most original tapas we've ever had! The liquid olives were amazing, they literally melt in your mouth- there is absolutely no need for chewing! 

The GM was very helpful and charming! 

My husband and I adored this place! 

We will be back!

what i liked: 
over easy fried egg with caviar, toasted bread with roasted tomato and anchovy, and the braised veal cheeks... i also had the iberico paella. solid.. the dishes were pretty simple, but you can taste every ingredient all at heightened levels.. i wish i would have paced myself while waiting for the paella...

we were kinda rushing to catch a show. our server went above and beyond to accommodate..

It was the Wednesday before New Year's Eve and my family and I were looking for a place to grab a late meal, around 9:30 PM or so.  Although we didn't have a reservation anywhere and were a relatively large party (seven of us), we figured it was late enough that we wouldn't have to wait much longer than 30-45 minutes for a table.  My wife and I and our siblings have lived in Manhattan for the past several years, so we were happy to see the list of restaurants at the newly opened Cosmopolitan.  We've been to Blue Ribbon (both Bakery and Sushi), Scarpetta, and Milos in NYC, enjoyed them all, and were confident that the other restaurants in the Cosmopolitan would be of similar high quality.  The first restaurant we saw when we got off the escalator that led up to the dining floor was Jaleo.  It looked great.  An open kitchen sat in the back of a bright and lively room.  The menu was interesting and the dishes sounded delicious.  Philadelphians, imagine a more casual Amada.

We settled on Jaleo and so my wife approached the hostess and asked her if she could accommodate our party.   The hostess looked at my wife and me.  It was immediately clear the calculations that were going through her head: are they good looking enough? do I like their clothes?  do I want them in my restaurant?  Just to give fellow Yelpers some context: my family and I are a reasonably good looking people by any measure and we were dressed casually but neat (ex. Business casual-jeans and no jacket for me).  The hostess glanced back into the dining room and pretended to weigh our options.  "Sorry, I don't think we will be able to seat your party tonight."  A large empty table was at the front of the restaurant directly behind the hostess.  "What about that one, is that being held?" my wife asked.  "Oh it's not being held," the hostess replied, "but that table would be too small, and also we don't have enough chairs.  And we're closing at 11PM."  The table was set up to seat four, could obviously comfortably seat six, but believe me, in NYC, would have sat eight.  My wife pointed out additional chairs that were unused by guests at other tables.  Another hostess, trying to be more helpful, scurried off to look for a couple more chairs.  The head hostess did not move.  "I'm sorry there are just no chairs and we're closing in an hour, I really don't think we can seat you tonight."  We went back and forth like this for about five minutes, the hostess eying us up and down the whole time.  

After a while, we left.  I hope at some point the hostess realized that she missed an opportunity for her restaurant to make more money (a group of seven, willing to dine at a table that usually seats four, which probably couldn't be filled the rest of the night).  Actually, scratch that, I hope she stays dumb the rest of her life.  Anyway, we went to Scarpetta instead, where the food was great, the service was better, and nobody made us feel like we were a lesser class of human being.

I ate here with a group of girlfriends on a weekend night when we were in Vegas for a bachelorette party.  It has a trendy hip ambiance located in the Cosmopolitan Hotel. The Piquillos Julian de Tolosa were amazing & they have a pretty extensive wine list.  It's a great option to come with a large group & split a bunch of plates.

Tasty food. Beautiful decor. Warm, friendly bartender who knew the menu like a pro. Wines by the glass were exceptional. We got stuck late and this place was open until 12 and treated us like royalty. Cannot wait to come back!!

I was so excited to have my first tapas meal.  We had a reservation and were seated quickly.  Its a lovely and lively atmosphere.  

Our initial order consisted of toasted bread brushed with tomato (Pan de cristal con tomate), ham (Lomo ib√©rico de bellota Ferm√≠n), cheese (Rey Silo Rojo con albaricoques y almendras) and shrimp and lobster (Croquettas de mariscos).  All of these were fine, however from here things went downhill.  

We ordered a paella and a carnes (Paella de pollo y setas silvestres and Chorizo casero con pur√© de patatas al aceite de oliva).  Both of these items we so incredibly salty they were inedible.  They were horrible.  I expected the ham plate we had earlier in our meal to be salty, but it was nothing compared to the paella and chorizo.  Our server asked if there was anything wrong and we stated that the items were too salty.  She took the items away and asked what else we would like.  We asked for the check.  My mouth was ruined from the extreme saltiness.  Imagine my surprise when the check came and the two items we didn't eat were still on the bill!  At this point, my husband just wanted to leave, so he paid cash and we left.  

I left with a bad taste in my mouth, literally and figuratively.  Also, left hungry despite paying $140+ for the meal and drinks and tip.

This place is nasty. Everything was way too salty. We ordered the seared scallops in romesco sauce. Can you believe that the sauce was bland compared to how salty the scallops were?? The scallops were as salty as the fried bacalao. The paella valenciana with chicken and rabbit was tasteless.
