Pan con Tomate y Jamon Serrano: A classic Spanish dish and great way to open up your taste buds is the Toasted Bread with Tomatoes on top with Serrano Ham, drizzled with a touch of Spanish Olive Oil. The heavenliness is in the crunchy carbs married with soft, acidic texture and creaminess of fat. it sates all senses and leaves the appetite wanting more...

To balance the meal a bit, we ordered a Salad, the Remolacha con Citricos: Salad of Red Beets + Citrus +La Peral Cheese + Pistachios + Sherry Dressing.  The salad was balanced and harmonious with that unique flavor that Beets have with a mild acidity that was pleasant.

A great little dish to get at Jaleo is the Mixed Olives, Aceitunas Rellenas y Aceintunas Ferran Adria:  Olives stuffed w/ Anchovy + Piquillo and Ferran Adria Liquid Olives.  This little number is awesome with drinks; salty, briny and bathed in luxurious Olive Oil, both traditional and avant grade version entertain the palate, as wells the mind.

There are so many dishes at Jaleo that are so awesome and deserve special recognition; the Sunday Roasted Pig and the Lobster Paella to name a few.  But due to timing issues, we weren't able to order those, so the highlighted dish is a special favorite in the seafood category, Calamares en su Tinta: Basque style Squid Stew with Ink.  I'm a firm believer that that this may be the best, softest Squid that I have ever had; the Ink sauce was so savory in conjunction with the lime colored concoction which I wasn't' able to recognize, but relished it with fervor. I can't say I remember it with Ramps and Micro Greens but it's added value in any case.

It was truly hard to tear ourselves away from Jaleo, but we were on a mission to explore and more needed to be done.  So down the hatch with our last sip of Sangria and moved On To The Next One (Hold up freeze. Somebody bring me back some money please....)

This place caught my attention as we passed by one night because it just look like a fun cute place to go.  Then a co-worker posted pictures and was raving about it, so when I found out girlfriends were coming into town, decided to take them here and was so glad I did.  Everything was yummy.  My favorites were the lobster paella, endives, chicken fritters and hazelnut cake.  Thought the chorizo wrapped in potato would have been better, it was just okay.  And it was our first time to discover a clementine drink, which was fun.  I think overall a fun place to go to with friends or on a date.  Liked it so much, planning on taking my husband back there!

There are a lot of higher-end restaurants on the strip, but this is one that's worth seeking out, especially if you're with a group of friends.  It's noisy, bright, fun, and not intimate at all, but the food is as tasty (and creative) as any Tapas restaurant I've been to.  

When we sat down they handed us an iPad-like tablet with their wine list.  Not really a wine person but I am easily amused so I had fun perusing their wine list this way.  The waiter did recommend a Rioja that we both liked.

Highlights of our meal include the Jamon Iberico, the Serena con membrillo, and the berenjenas con miel de ca√±a al estilo Malague√±o (fried eggplant).  Oh, and the croquetas.  Actually, everything off the fried section of the menu was incredibly delicious.  The only flop of the night was the Tortilla de patatas (omelet) which was flavorless.

My wife & I spent about $150 including drinks, desert and coffee, and left feeling very full & happy.  Highly recommended.

I'm not a picky person by any means but this place is a complete ripoff with a pretentious vibe and rude/unhelpful staff. Confused on what we were ordering (since our waiter was so helpful, not) one of our appetizers arrived as a bag of potato chips with tomato sauce drizzled on top...REALLY!? I would have preferred to throw the money I wasted here right in the trash. Save your money and go elsewhere!

I really wanted to like this place, since my friend raved about it. We came here around 5pm, the place was pretty empty, we were seated right away. From the looks of it, the restaurant was overstaffed... waitstaff standing around and looking into the distance. Maybe they partied too hard the night before... i don't know! After sitting around for a good 15 minutes without anyone coming up to us we finally had to flag someone down. Since we were newbies to such cousine, we expected our server to explain the menu.... well the server/manager just briefly went over the menu w/out going into details about the items we wanted to order. He said everything's good on the menu. Ok whatever. 

Keep in mind these tapas are TINY, so don't come here with a big apetite; before we could even finish our tiny dish the plates would get picked up. When my friend finally mentioned something to the busboy to leave the plate, his reply was "are you serious?!" . A great way to make a customer feel comfortable is to question the customer. 

I really wanted to enjoy this dining experience, however the SERVICE was terrible and pretty much ruined it for us.
Great tapas!!! Creative food! I try to have a different dish every time I go and I've been happy with every dish!

Since I just had a bad experience at Julian Serrano's, I figured I'd better give a shout-out to the tapas place I wish I had gone to. We have eaten here twice (once as a couple and once in a group of 16, great service both times), and will again. I like the lively open kitchen atmosphere, excellent service and attention to detail. And the jamon Iberico- how can so much flavor be packed into molecule-thin slices. We experimented with how tiny a bit we could dissect out and still get the wow: almost invisible bits still sparking savory deliciousness. 

Paella rotates depending upon the whim of the chef; two types are always available. This is a bit problematic, as we have missed the seafood paella 3 times, but it does allow proper preparation in a HUGE pan over an open fire by a dedicated paella preparer or two. Thus, whatever type they make is worthy.

We were seduced by the anytime availability of several types of paella at Julian Serrano, and learned that it's just not as good that way. There is a reason Jaleo does it the way they do, and it's worth it. So don't worry if your dream paella isn't on the menu, you may well discover a new dream.

I was there in December when the place had just opened. Everything ran smoothly and the service was great.  It was pretty lively and energetic in there with people filling the entire restaurant. Not a quiet place but a good place for drinks and tapas.

Everything we ordered was fantastic. I even had some pulpo (octopus)! The jamon was delicious and imported from Spain, I believe. Mmm. The sangria was also very, very good.

They ran out of a bunch of the desserts we wanted so they eventually ended up comping the two desserts we finally selected that they did have.

The food also inspired me to visit the bazaar in LA. If you're in LA, check it out -- I think it's even better than Jaleo.

On the pricey side - I believe for about 5-6 tapas and some sangria it was around $125. If you have the cash to spend, it's totally worth it, though!

Best meal we had in Vegas. Great waitress, recommendations from the manager, delicious shareable tapas, with not a mediocre one in the bunch. The bacon-wrapped dates were to die for! Good sangria, too!

My experience here was just okay. You definitely don't come here if you're starving unless you're up for ordering 10 or more dishes. LOL. We walked around trying to find the right restaurant, so my buddies finally decided on this place. I'm really not much of a tapas person, which is still the case after this experience. I thought everything was pricy for the amount you get. The Paella was good, but the serving size is quite rediculous. It was ordered with meat, but came with 3 small pieces. We ordered several dishes, but I'll refrain from reviewing them as I don't remember what each of them are called, and couldn't care less about looking them up. I guess this will be the last of my tapas experience. I just felt like the food wasn't worth the price they charge. Next time i need a fix similar to this one, I'll get something cheap and donate the rest of my money to a charity. 

Oh...& who charges $6 for an iced tea?!?! No sweetner too!!!

DONE!

An excellent Spanish restaurant with a broad but not intimidating menu, and all dishes prepared in an interesting and even exciting way. For example, the staple of tapas restaurants, the patatas bravas -- hard to describe, but included not only the traditional tomato-based sauce, but also a sort of creme part -- you'll see it when you try. But the real standout was the ensalada rusa. My dining companion, a Spanish literature PhD who has lived in Spain for months at a time, said it was the best she'd ever tasted. 

Excellent food and excellent service. But there was another aspect of the dinner that I have to comment on.

On a Saturday night in midsummer, being at this restaurant is not just a dining experience, but a theatrical experience as well. As anyone who goes to Las Vegas on a weekend quickly realizes, it's sort of like Comic-Con if Comic-Con were about cisgendered displays: everyone is in a costume, of sorts, that emphasizes the degree to which they feel they best express their gender identity. And this was just as true at this restaurant as on the sidewalks of the Strip. Seated in the dining area were a number of pre-bridal parties of all men and all women, each displaying to the max their gender certifiers and clique behaviors. One party of 16 women seated at a long table, headed by a young woman in a bridal veil (!) wearing a freaking BANNER that said "BRIDE-TO-BE," was described by my dining companion as "the Last Supper staged as a quincea√±era." Watching them gab to one another, take pictures and selfies, stare at their phones for the results, give each other fond (or cutting) looks, was fascinating. This was merely the largest party of costumed youths. So if you come to this restaurant on a Saturday night, forget about tickets to a show -- this is all the show you'll need.

No. Just no. Unless you would like to have your entire weeks worth of sodium allowance in one bite of food, I would absolutely never ever recommend this establishment. We had a few things, all very disappointing. The sodium content overpowered the actual flavor of the food, and to top it off it wasn't cheap. So, in short I would not recommend eating here.

So, my wife and I tried to go tapas style food for once. Jaleo is located on the Third Floor in the Cosmopolitan. First thing I wanna say is its a very nice resto. When they lead you to your table, you will pass the station where they cook those expensive paellas. We got the Eggplant Malaga style ($9), Rossejat ($20), Gambas Al Ajillo ($16), and Spanish Flan with 'espuma' of Catalan cream and oranges ($12). The eggplant dish was pretty much 3 donuts stuffed with eggplant and honey drizzled over. It tasted good but paying 9 bucks is way overpriced. The Rossejat was like (filipino reference alert) pancit with small shrimp and a spoonful of mayo. It tasted ok but I wouldn't order that again. The Gambas were best tasting with the garlic and tomato sauce. The sauce was so good that I had to use the complimentary to finish it (hey, it was $16). The flan was good with the oranges and something crunchy that they put on the cream to give the dish some crispy texture. Would I come back again? Yes I would but only to try the paellas. Note: They have 5 paellas but 2 of the 5 are only available daily (heh?). Im glad to try Jose Andres's food but eating tapas style here comes with price.

We had a nice time here. We were going to be climbing at red rocks the next day so didn't partake of the alcohol, and our server was cool about it...the tapas we had wasn't the best choices as a grouping but we enjoyed them. The omelette, called tortilla patatas, was one we liked due to the carmelized onions. They did a good job preparing it. We also had the mushrooms, setas al ajillo, which were tasty. We also had butifarra, which was a sausage stew. Decent enough but nothing spectacular. 

Love the ambience and the open kitchen, an overall a great place to people watch and relax. We'd come again and try the drinks next time.

I've had this place bookmarked for some time now. Then two ladies we were talking to in the airport told us they went there and how good it was so that reeled the hubby in. We went on a Sunday and sat at the bar. Caio was our server and he was awesome! Very helpful. We ordered the anchovies which were on some Spanish bread, grilled lamb, bacon wrapped dates, a tiny plate of paella to sample, the roast pig and my absolute favorite the egg and cavier! Hands down the egg was my favorite! But I do have a mad love for eggs, the lamb had the best flavor and the anchovies were definitely something I would order again. Wasn't too crazy about the dates, they were mehhhh. The paella was super tasty but I'm hoping to try it with the chicken and rabbit next time. The hubby and I both loved this place, pricy but worth it.

I

Gazpacho and steamed mussels were AMAZING. Octopus was ok, nothing too amazing. Portion sizes are sized so that multiple dishes are ordered. Service was helpful and friendly; little slow though. Must try!

Our meal started off pretty weak with a soggy tortilla patata, teeny chorizo and a salty paella. I was really disgruntled and ready to leave, but we gave the waiter a chance to suggest food and he made some great choices. After a spinach salad, sliders and some lovely goat cheese we felt satiated. It was definitely not worth the $100 a person though.

I heard about Jose Andres from Washington DC, and decided to try out the food while I was gambling.. luckily we won a bunch of money and blew it all on food. 

The ambiance was fast paced, noisy, friendly, colorful, just unique. I loved the yuca chips, and decided to try something exotic like a Rabbit short-rib dish. It was delicious. Flavors were different enough, and the Sangria was out of this world.

Our waitress was very attentive! Supposedly his DC restaurant has even better food, and they changed the menus up a bit for Vegas. 

In any case I loved the restaurant, the food and the atmosphere was spectacular, can't wait to try out his other restaurants!!

If you are in the market for overpriced appetizers, don't feel like talking to your date (the restaurant is so loud, conversation is virtually impossible), and don't care much for superior service..this is the place to be! 

Modern decor, sleek lines, and simplicity make up this restaurant's design. It's an open eating area where passers by get a full view of all restaurant patrons and their parties. 

If you could have just thrown in a screaming child at the table beside us, that would have completed the excessive noise level quota for the evening...Loud music, restaurant staff hustle and bustle, people talking over each other, it was impossible to hold a conversation even with the person sitting right next to you. 

Two people, fixed menu came to approximately $150. Doesn't sound bad for a "Cosmopolitan" dining establishment, right? Well, let me run down the "list" of items I consumed for my $75 worth of food: 

An (as in, one) olive 
A (as in, one) bite of beet *cringe* salad 
(2) potato and onion fried thingies (served in a shoe; weird) 
(3) bites of desert 
(3) glasses (small) of sangria 

As filling as my $75 meal was *insert extreme sarcasm here*, my friends and I ended up in a drive thru line later that evening..

Service was fantastic, food was subpar. 

Boyfriend and I opted for the "Jaleo Experience" tasting and I personally don't think it was worth the price at all. I've had much better tastings at the same price point. I have also been to the Jaleo in Washington DC which far surpasses this one in terms of the quality of the dining experience. 

Almost every dish we received was over-salted. Nothing stood out as particularly memorable, though we made the most of it and enjoyed trying new things we typically would never order. 

Our servers were great, taking the time to explain each dish and being very prompt with any requests we had. It was a shame the food wasn't as nearly as enjoyable.

With so many other great restaurant options on The Strip (and even in The Cosmopolitan alone), pass on Jaleo.

Jaleo - Ja-Leo = Hell No 

Salt. Salt salt. All the food came out super salty.. No flavor. Had to send 3 plates back and just had to leave midway through. Still hungry. Had high hopes for great taps a paella in this place. Leaving with a nasty taste and a WTF IN MY STOMACH.

Debbie and I had a rocking time at Jaleo in the Cosmopolitan Hotel.

We were seated promptly and courteously and the open room was a pleasure.

David, the Assistant General Manager, made our nite....showing us the Paella Pan seated over a glowing, orange open fire....close up....and then we couldn't resist the aroma of that wonderful seafood flavored rice.

Two server gals were right on the money.....and gooood natured. They gave us just the table that we had asked for....looking out at the crowd and the hip, Cosmopolitan Hotel decor.

Debbie marveled at the black garlic soup (with egg) and we both devoured the patatas bravas, flavored with a wonderful red sauce.

Spanish tuna tapas (on crisp flouta) and bacon wrapped chorizo kept the sangria fueled tapas orgy going.

Having just returned from Madrid (tapas at La Chata), the Bourne District in Barcelona....and the "No. 6" tapas charmer in Sevilla.....we were not expecting to be bowled over in Las Vegas.

But, we were......and are looking forward to visiting Jaleo once again...and smiling all the way thru.

In the past I mentioned that this place supplies me with some of the best meals ever - so when we made reservations on this trip to Vegas - this was the meal I was looking forward to the most. 

It was disappointing. I'm not sure what changed between now and then - but the food wasn't life changing like it had been in the past. The cheese sampler was great, but staples like patatas bravas, tortilla Espa√±a, and chorizo were satisfactory - but nothing special. The chorizo wrapped in patatas historically was my favorite (I think last time we ordered 2 orders) but this time they were not as crisp and a bit on the greasy side. When we cut into the tortilla Espa√±a, oil oozed out making it flavorful but too oily. The best dish was the lamb lollipops. 

The food, while still good, has seemingly slipped a bit since I came here last and I can't help but sing it a star from this time around.

Hearing all the hype really put my expectations high for this place, but I ended up being disappointed. The staff, ambiance, and location is great! The food...not so much. I ate about $200 worth of food and the only thing I liked was the deep friend dates wrapped with bacon. Overall, not worth it.

What the hell is wrong with you people, 3.5 stars?  Jose Andres is as good as it gets when it comes to spanish tapas.  

Pork skirt steak!  When have you ever seen pork skirt steak?

You really can't go wrong here.  Sliced jamon, croquettes, paella, steak, you just can't go wrong.  So delicious.

Spanische Tapas sind ja normalerweise einfache kleine Gerichte, die man in den Bars in Madrid, Sevilla oder wo auch immer in Spanien zum Bier, Wein oder Sherry serviert bekommt. 

Jaleo adaptiert dieses Konzept f√ºr die Gourmet Cuisine und das Ergebnis kann sich mehr als sehen lassen. Denn nat√ºrlich erf√§hrt man hier tolle und auch ungewohnte Geschmackserlebnisse. Aber durch das Tapas-Konzept bestellt man nicht nur ein paar G√§nge, sondern pro Person 4 bis 5 Tapas. Und da man alles problemlos teilen kann, kostet man an einem Abend 10 verschiedene wirklich tolle Gericht. 

F√ºr alle, die Gourmetk√ºche lieben, ist das perfekt. Wenn auch nicht unbedingt preiswert, aber f√ºr schnell und g√ºnstig ist das Jaleos auch der absolut falsche Laden.

I came to Jaleo for my bachelorette dinner party, looking forward to spanish tapas. Now given that Jaleo is at the Cosmopolitan on the strip, I was already anticipating high prices. What I didn't anticipate was: finding it difficult to find the restaurant since it wasn't marked well at all, very tiny portions for what they charged, and no sensitivity to food allergens. 

First off, it took my group a bit to find the place, with the restaurant not marked properly. Our confusion was resolved when we stumbled on it and they told us we had arrived. We only saw markings for China Poblano, so the confusion never really went away. 

After we sat down and started reviewing the menu, we started asking the waitress questions about the menu. Thankfully we brought up my allergy to shell fish because the whole fried section of the menu was hands off, even if items didn't have shell fish in it. Turns out they fry everything in the same oil - chicken, dates, shrimp... not a best practice they should continue. 

The dishes I was able to eat were good, but honestly, the dishes did not go far at all. Due to the fact I was expecting a nicer atmosphere and not having half the menu eliminated from eating because of the frying issue, the lack of food on the small plates really through this place over the edge for me. I would definitely recommend other restaurants in the Cosmopolitan over this one: Holstein's - excellent burgers, Comme Ca - excellent french bistro and STK - good steakhouse.

What a pleasant surprise! I've been to this place a couple of times years ago and I never thought that highly of the place. However, I came here the other night with my girlfriend on a date and I couldn't have been happier we did.

Place is very open speed and nicely decorated. Ambiance is very hip and casual. Nice place to grab drinks or a small bite before heading out for the night. 

Service:
This is where they really suffered. Within a span of 5 minutes, we had three different servers come over to go over the menu with us and ask our drink order. We were very confused because after the first server, we thought that was our server and gave her the drink order. So to have two more people come by showed they had no sense on anything about the tables. The crazy part was it continued throughout the night. I swear we had seven different servers!! The communication between them was terrible because they had no idea about what we ordered and our orders were all messed up!
The dinner should have taken two hours tops - ended up being a three hour dinner as we sat there waiting for food we had ordered at start of the meal. 
They comped our desserts and drinks because of the delay in the orders and mess ups - which was very nice of them. 


Food:
We ordered a ton of food! The food here is fantastic! Especially after just coming back from Barcelona, Spain. I appreciated the food so much more!

We ordered:

Sangria - good

Tomato Bread - Bomb

Ham, goat cheese, fig bread - Bomb!

Beet salad - Great!

Scallops - Delicious! 

Shrimp - Awesome!

Dates - Bomb!

Seafood croquettes - Meh, not my favorite

Short Rib Paella - Great flavor - meat was on bone and not much of it. Hard to eat. 

Lamb - small but great flavor

Steak - Really good!

The mousse dessert dish - So good!!


Food is fantastic! Small portions with high prices, but great flavor! Great scene! Service - poor. Overall great place
Overall just ok. Best dish were the egg and caviar, garlic shrimp, squid and beans. Service was subpar. Server ignored our request multiple times in regards to our shaky table.  Won't be returning.

Some very inventive items (liquid olives), some very tasty items(chicken fritters), some just ok items (mushrooms over pur√©ed potatoes) and some items that were a miss (Brussels sprouts- odd mix of very sweet orange and barely cooked sprouts). Knowledgable and friendly wait staff. Would go back but not so extraordinary that I NEED to go back.

Was in Vegas over the Thanksgiving weekend and stopped in with some family friends.  First impression, elegant without being snobby.  A pretty casual atmosphere within an upscale feeling.  On to the food, we started with a charcuterie plate that included delicious ham from Spain along with some other cold cuts.  We paired that with a cheese plate that had some goat cheese (dont knock it till you try it) along with some bleu cheese and fruit, absolutely delicious!  

We ventured out into the rest of the menu, we tried the calamari stuffed with pork (awesome), the grilled octopus, some small (tapas people) cones stuffed with raw salmon & roe and raw tuna along with other ingredients I cant recall, the cauliflower, brussel sprouts, and a spanish egg/potato pancake of sorts (also awesome) then the potato with mushrooms.......you get the picture we tried almost everything but the paella.  You can order what ever paella they have that day (our choices were veggy or chx/mushroom) or you can choose from 8 types but must order a whole pan (feeds 8)

Our server was attentive, very knowledgeable on the menu and friendly.  Only small knock was pricing, but given that its Vegas and were in a casino I guess its all relative.  All and all, it was a very pleasurable dining experience and would recommend anyone to go there.  I know I will go again when I'm back.

Simply amazing experience. The food is top notch, the staff even more so. Pretty much tried as much as we could, and enjoed it all with a bottle of wine...everything kept getting better each course. Dont be an impatiant, whiney, jackass, sit back, soak up where you are, and try some perfectly executed food.

Oh man we had such high hopes for this place.  We came here for a business dinner with 8 people and it was such a let down.  Last year we did this same dinner celebration at Bazaar Meats and it was amazing!  So we thought we try another restaurant by Jose.  BIG MISTAKE.  

Our server was Max, hands down probably one of the worst servers I have ever had in my entire life!  He was sooo slow.  We sat and it took at least 20 minutes to get our first drink.  He then told us about the Tapas menu, we ordered based on his recommendation. First round of food took 20 minutes, we then finished all of our food, and the next round took ANOTHER 20 minutes.  This was the theme of the night, the restaurant itself was pretty slow so no excuses on the kitchen.  Dessert took 40 freaking minutes.  Tapas is supposed to flow with a pattern, not waiting 20-30 minutes in between.

We asked Max each time what is taking so long and his response was always 'Don't worry its coming.  Everyone was so disappointed to the point where nobody was even talking to anyone at our table from being so bored waiting on food and drinks.  Our drinks would sit empty for 30 minutes at a time, nobody ever came by to even ask!

If you do decide to take the plunge here make sure you don't get Max as your server, i would highly recommend simply not wasting your time / money at Jaleo!
Went as a group of 4 and everything everyone ordered was on point and flavorful. Their salad, Tapas, appetizers. We did the 25 per person selection and it was perfect.

Truly awful.  To begin with the noise level in the place is uncomfortably loud, and the booth tables and benches are hard wood with no cushions. 

We ordered a bottle of wine based on the waiter's recommendation as something light that would go with all of the food choices.  Nope.  It was heavy like a cabernet, not light like a pinot noit.  It was downhill from there.  

We started with some cheese and breads which were okay but terribly over priced.  Next was the white asparagus which came out soggy and tasteless.  It was like eating baby food it was so mushy.  We ordered some ham which was okay but it had no condiments with it so it was unappealing.  Ordered the shrimp and calamari paella (took 30 minutes to prepare) and the shrimp arrived undercooked/almost raw.  We could not eat it and asked to speak to the manager about the quality of the food that evening. He apologized and didn't charge us for the paella because it wasn't edible, which was the right thing to do.  

This was the worst meal we've ever had in Las Vegas, and also one of the worst we've had anywhere in a very long time.

This place is over-hyped and overpriced.  Go to Bar Masa if you want a fabulous meal with small plate choices.
Worst overpriced tapas I've ever had. The shrimp was delicious, although everything else was average to sub-par.

Let's start with the few cons:

One has to ask for water, was never offered water/poured water without asking, even after a long duration of our glasses being empty.
They don't fill water to the top of the glass, and the glasses are rather average sized for water glasses so that kinda sucks.
Wines/drinks are pricey for the 'most part.'
Our waiter, while initially attentive, after we placed our order, we did not see him towards the end of our meal.  We would have ordered another bottle of slightly overpriced wine, if we had seen him.  Their loss.  
Chicken wings were nothing special.  Bar food chicken wings are on average, better tasting.
Seating arrangements are not the most comfortable, as for most of our night, we were seated pretty close to two other couples.  We made friends though, but in the event we had not, it would have been more of a con.

Pros:
Great variety of wine.
Great food, especially the caviar on organic egg.
Had a few 6 dollar glasses of wine (white and red) options.  We opted for a 30 dollar bottle of wine, which was quite good.
Modern and energetic. 
Quick getting to our seats, friendly host.
Some decently priced food options in comparison to other restaurants at the Cosmopolitan/like-restaurants.

While at first glance, it looks like more cons than pros, the great food really made it 4 stars.  Fun experience to try new food and not feel craycray for ordering 6 menu items for 2 people.  

K Rating: B+

Eh.

I was expecting a one of a kind restaurant from Jose Andreas. Instead, service was below average, inattentive. Interesting tapas choices. Food seemed overall very salty including the paella.

Hoping to try √©. Maybe it'll be more of the quality I expect from an Andreas establishment.

Dining at Jaleo was our "gourmet splurge night" during this particular Vegas visit. We were about 10mins early for our reservation on a Saturday night, so we did have to wait. We were supposed to sit at a booth but some random people had stolen it from us - boo! Luckily there was no more delay to getting us seated at this busy, loud restaurant. Our waitress was very informative and was great at letting us know what was and wasn't available for the evening. Each dish arrived quickly and the presentation for each one was remarkable!

Croquetas de pollo (Traditional chicken fritters) - this arrived in a shoe. Yes - a shoe. Aside from the quirky presentation, the fritters were delicious - creamy and comforting, as if someone took a chicken stew and fried it up into fritter bits!

Bikini de jam√≥n ib√©rico, queso Manchego y trufas (Pressed sandwich of ib√©rico ham, manchego cheese and truffles) - honestly, none of us said a thing while eating this. It was good, but we were probably expecting a little more. It felt too simple.

Ca√±a de cabra con highs ((Murcia) A soft, semi-sweet goat's milk cheese paired with raisin walnut bread and fig jam) - I could've eaten a whole log of this cheese on a whole loaf of the walnut break with a whole jar of that jam.

Salm√≥n crudo con huevas de salm√≥n (Salmon tartare and salmon roe cone) - another favorite that stood out from the rest! Strong and fresh with a great combination of textures!

Arroz con costillas de cerdo ib√©rico de bellota Paella (Made with the ribs of the legendary, black-footed ib√©rico de bellota pigs of Spain) - This plate was meant for 2, but really it would be for 1. Luckily it was enough for all of us to get a good taste of the flavorful rice, mushrooms and pork!

The following were good and flavorful but not that exciting (in my humble opinion): Gambas al ajillo, Pollo a la parrilla con queso Valde√≥n y mostaza, Jam√≥n serrano Ferm√≠n

We ordered enough and were stuffed! Our evening of Spanish tapas was delicious - gracias Chef Andres!

Jaleo definitely isn't the Bazaar, but it's still a pretty great restaurant by Jose Andres. 
In fact, I was really surprised to see some of the items I've had at the Bazaar  on the menu at Jaleo.
The waitress recommended that we order 2-3 dishes per person; we had 4 girls, and this is what we ordered:

1. Tortilla de Patata: Spanish omelet with onions and potatoes. Really fluffy omelet.  My friend who loves Spain and Spanish food really enjoyed it, especially since she has had such a hard time finding traditional Spanish Tortillas here in the States.

2. Garlic Shrimp: The sauce was really good, but this dish wasn't all that memorable

3. Patatas Bravas: Jose's version of this traditional Spanish bar food. Basically potato chips topped with spicy tomato sauce and garlic alioli. Really delicious combinations of flavors and textures.

4. Croquetas de pollo:  Chicken fritters SERVED IN A REAL SHOE! just like the Bazaar used to. I was so disappointed to learn that the croquetas at the Bazaar came in 'fake' shoes now. So i was so excited to see these come in a real shoe! The croquetas were AMAZING as well.

5. Rossejat: A paella type dish with pasta, shrimp and squid. Served with an amazing garlic alioli. Definitely comparable to the Rossejat at the Bazaar.

6. Grilled Quail: served with a really great apple puree and pinenuts.

7.Bikini de jam√≥n Ib√©rico, 
queso manchego y trufas: Pressed sandwich with iberico ham, manchego cheese, and truffles. BEST THING WE HAD ALL NIGHT!

8. Olive Oil Ice Cream: Another dish that is also served at the Bazaar. Really interesting combo of flavors. Highly recommend it for adventurous palates and grapefruit lovers. 

9. Sangria: Great, but nothing I haven't had before.

Also, this place deserves 5 stars for their service. Our waitress was so sweet and attentive! I had really wanted to try the flan too, but they ran out! It wasn't even that late! I'll definitely be back to try it next time I am in town :)

I hate to say this about any restaurant, but hands down this the worst overpriced food I have ever eaten. 

A friend and I had reservations for a late (9 p.m.) dinner on a Saturday night. We were a bit late, but were seated promptly anyway. The place was PACKED ... and really, really loud. We were led to a small table near the back of the restaurant.

Service was prompt and our waiter, Mario, was friendly. He offered a few suggestions, and really seemed to be pushing the (pricey, $56) Arroz a banda con bogavante (AKA lobster paella). So we bit, along with an order of the Croquetas de pollo (chicken fritters served in a tennis shoe), a Berenjenas con miel de ca√±al estilo Malague√±o (fried eggplant), and Vieiras con salsa de romesco (seared scallops), washed down with a half -carafe of the house sangria. 

The server had warned us that the paella could take about a half hour to make and that we should prepared to wait. Meanwhile, he poured the sangria, which was absolutely yummy. Much to our surprise, the paella arrived within 10 minutes of ordering - ahead of the other dishes. Also surprising: It was barely warm, was full of charred bits and contained very little lobster (yes, there are three lobster parts presented on the plate, but they contained only a small amount of meat, which also seemed a bit undercooked). For $56, this was an absolute disappointment. We didn't even finish the dish. 

The rest of the plates arrived within 15 minutes. The chicken fritters looked promising. But, when I bit into one of the piping hot finger-shaped fritters, I was met with a molten, smooth, tan filling inside. The only thing I can compare it to was the consistency of pureed, jarred baby food (and it kind of tasted like that, too). I actually had to wait for the fritters to cool down a bit, which firmed up the consistency and at least made them more palatable. But overall, they were just gross. Revolting, actually. I'm cringing as I write this just thinking about them again. 

Same went for the eggplant: Lightly breaded (as the menu describes) they are not. The batter used to fry them was obviously thick, almost like a tempura batter (which is what the four, half-moon pieces looked like - puffy and large). Again, when hot, the eggplant was almost molten and oozed out of the breading. In no way did it resemble eggplant. Again, it firmed up upon cooling a bit, but was still sort of weird. 

The scallops (all two of them, for $15) were pretty, but I'm not sure they were entirely cooked in the center. They felt kind of mushy, which was not appetizing. 

By far, the best plate of the evening was dessert: Flan al estilo tradicional de mam√° Marisa con espuma de crema Catalana (classic flan), which was one of the best interpretations of the dish that I've ever had. The flan was velvety smooth, reminiscent of panna cotta. It was garnished with a vanilla-bean whipped cream and a small scoop or orange sorbet. I could have eaten that all night. 

But a woman cannot live on flan alone! Which is why I would not ever consider returning to this restaurant. The food was terribly disappointing. And unless you're into shouting your entire dinner conversation while feeling as though you're trapped in a sardine can, the ambiance leaves something to be desired.
The best paella I had in a long time!! Food is amazing!! The flavor are just to die for .

Service and food was impeccable. I'm very impressed to say the least. I'll be coming back and Bringing my friends. From the paella to the flan it was amazing. Every bite I tasted was on point. I'm very impressed.

I had met Jose Andres last year as he was working on a collaboration with my former boss, so I was excited to go to one of his restaurants.  Jaleo was magnificent.  I loved the modern vibe, the wood-burning fireplace, and the atmosphere in general.  Even though I was a bit jet-lagged (we had just arrived earlier that day), my taste buds were awakened by the culinary masterpieces we experienced in tapas form.  

The fried eggplant with a drizzle of honey had a delightful texture and were unexpectedly good.  I never thought that vegetable would be so good in a zeppole-like incarnation but it worked.  We had a savory spinach dish (I forget the name) which was quite good, but was outshined by the goat cheese with a bread that reminded me of Eli's raisin pecan crisps.  I wish I could have that for dinner tonight, but such is life.  The paella, our final small plate, had both rabbit and chicken, and was flavorful and not overly oily.  I tried a bite of the flan with oranges for dessert, which also did not disappoint.  

Jaleo made me rethink the way I seldom go for tapas, and has given me the intense desire to try some of Jose's other eateries.

Two friends and I chose to eat here for lunch and had a great tapas lunch. They specialize in gin and tonics and I had the best one of my life here. 

The stuffed olives were amazing as were the bacon wrapped dates, tuna salad, gazpacho, salted cod, anchovies, and shrimp and lobster fritters. 

I would absolutely return here for lunch or dinner.

Cannot stand people that complain about the price of a restaurant. What they fail to see is the amount time and technicality it took to execute some of these plates. If you can't afford to splurge do yourself a favor and eat at the goldn nugget, I hear they have an all you can eat dinner buffet. Seriously people......

Came here on a Saturday evening with reservations for a group of 9 and were seated right away. 

Since its tapas, we ordered: 
3 patatas bravas: mini potatoes with spicy tomato sauce and aioli - must get!!
2 paella verduras de temporada: traditional paella w/veggie - must get!!
2 piquillo rellenos con setas: stuffed piquillo peppers with Cana de Cabral goat cheese and seasonal mushrooms - must get! 
Pan de cristal de con tomate: toasted slices of uniquely crispy ethereal bread brushed with fresh tomato - good 
1 cheese platter 
Sangria 


The service was great, the waiter/ress' we're all super attentive. The food comes out super quick after ordering! 

Jaleo definitely lived up to its hype for the entire group

During this visit we enjoyed the lunch fixed menu...house salad, gazpacho, and mushroom and chicken paella.   Gazpacho was fresh, bright and flavorful while salad focused on simplicity and acid.  The paella was a suitable treat and we normally enjoy it adorned with multiple proteins, but this straight forward version left us wanting more.

We were throwing our friend a surprise bday dinner in Vegas and his gf knew just the restaurant; Jaleo. It was delicious and fancy enough to provide a satisfying meal but had enough variety in food and was fun enough to give an entertaining and delicious experience.

There's a lot of choices at Jaleo so be glad that it's tapas. The portions aren't huge so I'd suggest ordering at least 2 plates per person. I remember the paella, croquettas, and steak being delicious, but everything else was great too.

Our experience was brought to the next level because of our excellent waiter, Justin, who explained the menu to us and made great recommendations. He finished our dinner by giving the bday boy a porron. If you don't know what that is, Google it up! In short, it's a flask with a spout that you try to drink out of while keeping the porron as far away from you as possible. We had so much fun with the porron the rest of the night! We just walked up and down the strip refilling it as we went. A solid end to a solid dinner.

So we decided to hit up this eatery since we were going to see Bryan Ferry at The Chelsea last Thursday.  We love us some Spanish tapas and if it's a Jos√© Andr√©s joint, you'd think the chances are high that it would be outstanding, right?  Well, not so much.  It was.....underwhelming at best.  Food really was average and not exciting.  Here's what we had:

Pan de cristal con tomate: similar to a bruschetta - it was a bit on the salty side

Coca con erizos de mar: interesting combination of uni and bacon but didn't blow our minds

San Sim√≥n con garapi√±ado de frutos secos: good cheese but didn't really pick up the smokiness; nicely combined with the brittle though!

Jam√≥n ib√©rico Fermin:  deliciously porky and oily, just like a good jamon should be

Chistorra envuelta en patata frita: solid but nothing extraordinary; the chorizo was nice and spicy

Datil√©s con tocino 'como hace todo e mundo':  honesty, I've had far tastier iterations of bacon-wrapped dates 

Pulpo a feira Maestro Alfonso: this octopus dish was cooked perfectly but...lacked any noticeable flavor.  Almost like it was not really seasoned.

We were provided two additional plates compliments of the chef but I cannot remember exactly what they were.  Funny enough, they were the highlights of the meal along with the flan and pan con chocolate we had for desserts.

In the end, we just felt the "wow" flavors weren't there.  And at a fairly high price point, we expected more.  Service was professional and personable but uneven.  The attentiveness could have been a bit more especially considering we were there at 5 PM and there weren't many customers.

Honestly, Firefly LV is far better, in food, service, and price.

Jaleo, you pleasantly surprised me. Although I can never accept the fact of paying $14 for a small chicken breast is justifiable here. I still have to admit, the food was freakin' spectacular! And there was entertainment, and people watching, and flames! Every time a Paella was ordered they rang a bell and yelled out PAELLA!!!!!!! 
Between my boyfriend and I, we shared about 7 small plates, and I probably could have added 3 or 4 more, but I knew our bill was already at about $150 with our $5 sprites and $6 shirley temples. I had to try it when they said it was "homemade grenadine". Good, but not $6 good. 
On the menu, all of the dishes are in Spanish and some are a bit confusing, but the staff is super helpful and knowledgeable. A couple that stood out to me were the stuffed roasted red peppers with goat cheese, the garlic shrimp, and the chicken croquettes served in a shoe. There was not anything I tried, that I would not eat again. My only complaint is the prices. $20 for 2 scallops? I get it. Were at the Cosmo, it's a Jose Andres restaurant, but I want to come here and be able to drop $100 including a tip and have my other half and I leave stuffed. That will never happen. 
So yes, it is good, yes you will enjoy yourself. It is simply a matter of opinion if it's worth it to you. To me, places like this should have locals specials, or a local night. At the same time, maybe they don't want to cater to us locals. They have enough going for them to live off tourism. 
I will return, but only on a special occasion or at the request of a Paella.

Iberico is outstanding as you would hope, pretty amazing Spanish wine list ... Don't order the egg and caviar it is a waste of money.

One of our favorite items was actually chorizo wrapped in potato ... Kinda a pig in a blanket throwback.

Not sure I would waste a dinner in Vegas on this place ...

well, my expecation was high for an expensive tapas restauarant by a world famous Chef/Restaurateur like Jos√© Andr√©s. the decor was fun-swank but for the price the menu was just OK. the acorn-fed pig ham they serve is tasty but lacking bang for the buck. A significant factor in the overall lacking experience was the layout of the restaurants at the Cosmopolitan. It felt like an overpriced food court that lacked the intimacy I expected from a swank hotel like Cosmo. The food was decent but resembled an expensive gimmick on the rich success of Tapas dining.

Man, I was disappointed by this place.  I love tapas.  It's amazing how you can pack a ton of flavor into a small plate and enjoy that with your friends.  We tried the chef's selection thinking we'd get the best of the best and maybe some nice surprises.  We also tried the wine paring to go with it.  
The food was just not very exciting.  Maybe one of the 10 dishes we sampled got me excited.  The rest were pretty average.  Slightly oily fried shrimp... beet gazpacho... an egg and caviar dish that was just joyless.  
The wines were adventurous even if some of the selections were curious choices.  
Service was nice and friendly and the chefs brought some dishes to the table to prepare for us.  Overall, with so many great restaurants to choose from, I left feeling like it was a waste of a night out in Las Vegas.

Love love Jaleo! Best food we've had in Vegas. We had multiple tapas & finished off with a wonderful chicken & mushroom paella. The atmosphere is trendy yet casual. We'll definitely be back to try the rest of the menu.

Ten?  Fifteen?  Twenty?  I lost count of all the glorious courses we were served while dining (in a large group, mind you) at Jaleo last week.  Lucky enough to snag a reservation for 12 on short notice (thank YOU, Jose), we traipsed in to Jaleo and put our trust in the server's hands.

For the most part, that was a good idea.  He concocted a tapas tasting menu of literally ten plus courses, including the best of the best (marinated mussels, fried bacon-wrapped dates, and pesto-infused monkfish) and some not-so-standout (fried eggplant, goat cheese-dappled endive, and fried shrimp were all just OK).

Top this off with two - TWO! - lobster courses (an incredible steamed version with jasmine foam and marinara, and a decent-but-nothing-to-write-home-about seafood paella) and we were stuffed, satiated, and impressed.  The sparkling white sangria, though a bit light for a cocktail of its own, paired well with the salty and spicy foods throughout the meal.

If you have a big group of adventurous (read: willing to eat raw, spicy, seafood, cured meats, and any arrangement of vegetables) eaters, you will NOT miss with Jaleo.  My boyfriend and I agreed that this is the type of eating that makes Vegas a can't-miss culinary destination, and Jose Andres a well-reputed celebrity chef.

I went in here without looking at the prices . Now I don't mind paying for what the food's worth . But I didn't like the dishes we got . I payed $24 for a dish of 6 grilled chicken pieces . And I wasn't even impressed with it . My bf got the chicken that came in the shoe , those were good but we weren't impressed enough to stay and try more of the dishes honestly . Our bill came out to be 70 basically for appetizers . Like I said , I don't mind the prices for good food . But this wasn't worth our time & money . I wish I had gone to STK better lol .

I'm actually surprised that the ratings are so low! The food is innovative, visually appealing, and delicious (pan con anchovies is a must try and the pasta paella was exquisite)! The perfect trifecta! The service is exceptional as well. Our waitress was friendly and attentive. When she checked in on me, she gave me a slight rub on my back which I thought was cool because I felt like a friend not just a customer. The chefs were friendly (I sat at the bar) and funny. One of them entertained us all night. And when we dropped a spoon, he hurriedly found a replacement in an instant. 

Although the bill ended up being a little bit on the pricey side, it was well worth the many dishes I tried. If you've never had tapas before and is in Vegas, I'd highly recommend Jaleo.

First of all I wanted to commend the crew on their impeccable service here - they really know how to make you feel special. Somehow this always makes the food taste better!
All of the tapa choices for the evening were picked out by our server - how could we say NO to all of her choices -Foie Gras baked with black truffle, prosciutto bruchetta, brussel sprout citrus salad that will knock your socks off, lobster paella, green apple fennel & fig salad, bacon-wrapped figs, exotic cheeses...did I get them all?? WOW - it was richly fantastic. I have discovered a white sangria - and even got the list of secret ingredients!
This was a true delight and epicurean journey!

ATMOSPHERE // The environment itself is quite top notch, but that's more of a compliment to the hotel, not the restaurant. The slick idiosyncrasy of The Cosmopolitan continues through Jaleo. I loved all the design details from the typographic front gates to the piecework bull mounted on the wall and chicken tots served in a shoe (surprisingly cute and not gross idea). If you're lucky enough to have arrived with good company as I did, the restaurant's open layout and interesting tidbits allows for a good night of rousing conversation. My own party aside, I found the dining staff to be quite full of themselves, or rather, brainwashed by the supposed amazingness and sadly mislead by what a standard portion size is. I give them part of the blame for setting false customer expectations.

FOOD // The food really fell short of 3-stars. I've been to different small-plate kind of eateries before and Jaleo neither measured up for it's priciness in ingenuity nor taste. We took a while to figure out what to order because we were informed by our group of comrades who had a reservation before we did that the portions were fantastically small and the food not all that great. One friend honestly, and repeatedly, told us to get up and flee the place before it was too late. Could it really be that bad?
sangria :: This was a good choice. Served with fresh slice of citrus, chunk o' watermelon, and some mint. And one will need some amount of vino to make up for everything else. 
lobster paella :: We expressed concerns about hunger satisfaction so the waiter suggested the paella as a good way to fill up. The lobster paella had good flavors, but was rather salty (like most of the food). 
fried bacon wrapped dates :: Bacon wrapped anything is always good and ever better when it's deep fried. 
chicken fritters :: They're like tater-tot sized pot pies. 
garlic soup :: This was the worst. It tasted like you took the packet of Chicken Top Ramen seasoning and poured it into a cup of lukewarm water and then dropped an egg in there. The waitress gushed about how the egg is cooked at exactly 63 degrees and gave me a stony stare when she caught me rolling my eyes. I apologize that your soup sucked. 
chilled almond & garlic soup :: Interesting combination of flavors. Much better than the other soup, but that isn't saying much. 
kurobuta pork jowls & scallops :: I ordered this and it was microscopic for $14. A few slivers of unmemorable pork and maybe half a scallop total. I can get this for $6 at a Japanese izakaya. 
desserts :: We ordered 3 with components like olive oil ice cream, flan, and chocolate mousse. Again, nothing I think is worth mentioning. Do we sense a pattern?

All in all, the food didn't impress me in any way, especially factoring in the price and portion size. We had a party of 7 and with 2 carafes of sangria, 3 paellas, plus about 10 small plates, it ended up being $51/person. Jaleo is like dating a rich bitch: she may look nice and spout esteem, but it's all shallow and will set you back more money than it's worth. If you're looking to settle down for a better meal, check out the pretty girl next door to the strip instead at Firefly [http://www.fireflylv.com/].

This was about as fine a meal as we've had in a long time. We sampled eight plates and each was better than the next. Mussels, cheese, jamon sandwich, gazpacho soup, skirt steak and wonderful chocolate dessert. Remarkable. We could have probably eaten all night had we not needed sleep.

Go to this place, buckle your seat belt and loosen you belt buckle. This is going to be a fun and tasty ride!

Really enjoyed it.  We ordered for two:
*Gazpacho-great flavor.
*Ajo blanco- interesting chilled soup with crab.  The soup alone was slightly sour.  It definitely tasted better with a grape or raisin piece with each bite.
*Ostra gin and tonic- yummy oysters
*Empanadillas de brandada de bacalao-  I did not know what brandade was and was expecting something akin to boccailitos (Puerto RIcan Cod fritters).  these were even better than I thought they would be!
*Remolacha con c√≠tricos- Love beets
*Salmon tartare and roe cone- a little saltier than I would prefer, even though I love salmon roe.
*Bocadillos with Iberico jamon- good, filling.
*Traditional flan- good for sharing, though you probably want your own.
*Sangria- refreshing.  
*Jasmine tea- good at first, then tastes overbrewed when you get to the rest of the pot.
Service was good.  It was starting to slow down after we got there.  
Prices were reasonable.  Portions are small, and the server is very clear to mention that in case you are not aware of what tapas are.  
I was very excited to eat at a Jose Andres restaurant and would eat here again in a heartbeat.  Now to start saving up to eat at the Bazaar.

Don't order too much at once. Today's paella was SUPER salty and shrimp was overcooked & rubbery. Manchego dishes were excellent. Asparagus was nicely done and crunchy. They used to have a potato chip dish and it was so great! They now use diced potatoes that bring out a different element - YUM.

Very suprised at Jose Andres , not that I expect him to be overseeing things but it could be much better. 
I liked the layout of the restaurant, that's about it. 
The Sangria was watered down red wine. The "Jose's gin n tonic $17" was nothing special. Pulpo $12 for 10 nickel-sized pieces was served with no seasalt at all, I would've added my own if there was salt around anywhere. I asked for some bread and got three triangle pieces, ok . Then I saw $3 on the check for bread ???? 
The Paella Iberico was extremely salty $36 for a Tapa. 
Two people $251.00 plus tip. 
Very overpriced for what is served.

My wife and I went to Spain in May and we saw Jaleo as a chance to revisit some of the culinary magic that is Spanish food.  They delivered.  Iberico jamon alone brought it all back, but everything was superb.  The endivias con queso de cabra y naranjas are INSANELY delicious, as are the d√°tiles con tocino 'como hace todo el mundo' (FRIED.  DATES.  WRAPPED.  IN.  BACON.).  The chicken croquetas were very good but left me wanting pork croquetas instead.  The restaurant is located in the stylish Cosmo casino resort and is visually very appealing.  The customer service is impeccable.  A fantastic dining experience and the perfect choice for our romantic night out in Vegas.

I'll give 'em one more star if they lose the shoes.

Busy Friday night so my expectations start low as I never know what type of service I will receive. My night is winding down as the babysitter awaits relief so I figured a quick trip to a trendy spot in Cosmo is just what the doctor ordered. We chose Jaleo as we have always been a fan of Jose Andreas and it's always good to see a loud-ish crowd enjoying the F&B till wee hours. We asked the hostess if there was a two top available and she let us know it would be a twenty min wait but the bar had open seating. Since I prefer my meal to be picked out by the staff with the most knowledge the bartender would be natural selection. I let him know we wanted to try a few small bites and he guided us to the Shrimp, the Octopus, the Cones of deliciousness and Jose's Taco ($22 wasted forever for one bite of cavier and iberico ham).  Everything was incredibly tasty however the Taco was a joke.  It tells you something about their typical pre-shift when a staff member suggests the "special" or the priciest item on the menu. The overall ham and eggs was "salt with more salt".  I started the meal expecting four to five star food and service and left with a five star bill but three star service. Not a great combination. I would try them again as there are good delectable bites.

We came, we saw, we ate...and ate...and ate.  We arrived as a large party of 50 and the service we received matched that of a group of maybe 4 or 5.  The waitstaff was attentive and on top of things the entire evening.  

As for the food, it was top notch.  We had a variety of tapas and dishes that had the entire group raving.  My favorites included the salt potatoes, garlic shrimp, snap pea salad and vegetarian paella which was served in a pan the size of a small car.  It was spicy, flavorful and worth a try.  From what I was told, the house Sangria was also a high point.  Overall, a fantastic spot in a fabulous hotel!

The drinks are by far the best part of the menu! They have $20 gin and tonic options as well as other cocktails that range from $14-$20 a glass. Our table loved the sangria, which came as a pitcher and cost $50. The food was amazing! Small plates including the paella, so be prepared. All of the tapas were in the $10 and up range and they suggest 3-4 per person. Ask for Paul, he is fantastic!

Worst experience I could have imagined. Reserved the private room for my best friends bachelorette party dinner a month in advanced and when we arrived we were told they just gave it away. We were instead sat almost in the hotel area with a food court vibe. I was humiliated being the made of honor and the one that organized the dinner. They completely ruined my friends special night and hardly acknowledged what they had done and didn't even do anything to try to show they cared even slightly.  I have never been so upset. This place is a joke and the food is not good either.

Fantastic tapas. I've been for a date night and with a big group of guys. It can be super busy, but I've had good service. The ham, chicken fritters, garlic shrimp, roe cone, and grilled lamb were all fantastic. I've had one of the paellas a couple years ago, and I remember liking it, but don't remember specifics.

Jose Andres is probably known best for his whimsical, molecular gastronomy creations at The Bazaar (including Saam Room) and Minibar, but he does cook a lot of more traditional fare as well - Jaleo is his version of the Spanish tapas restaurant of his homeland.

The menu is vast, covering over 75 items across meat and cheese plates, land, sea, fried items and paella. Paella are made in a separate paella pit within the main dining room, allowing all diners to watch an impressive display while the paellas cook. Apparently the ventilation system alone cost $1 million, preventing all of the smoke from suffocating diners. Clearly, paella is serious business.

I've dined at restauarant-within-the-restaurant √© by Jose Andres and left impressed. This would be my first visit to Jaleo proper.


Butifarra Casera Esparracada homemade pork sausage stew with mushrooms and pearl onions
Carne Asada Con Piquillos 'juli√°n De Lodosa' grilled skirt steak with piquillo pepper confit
Chorizo Casero Con Pur√© De Patatas Al Aceite De Oliva homemade traditional chorizo with olive oil mashed potatoes and cider sauce
Setas Al Ajillo Con La Serena saut√©ed wild mushrooms with la serena potato pur√©e
Tortilla De Patatas Cl√°sica spanish omelet with potatoes and onions
Coliflor Con Olivas Y Frutos Secos saut√©ed cauliflower with dates and olives
Croquetas De Pollo traditional chicken fritters
Costillas De Cordero Con Romesco grilled lamb ribs with romesco sauce and green onions
Empanadillas De Brandada De Bacalao 'empanada' of cod brandade with honey
Arroz Con Costillas De Cerdo Ib√©rico De Bellota made with the ribs of the famous, black-footed ib√©rico de bellota pig
Jos√©'s Tuna Salad a salad of preserved tuna, mayonnaise, shallots and hard boiled eggs on flauta bread
Flauta bread brushed with fresh tomato, extra virgin olive oil and Jam√≥n Ib√©rico
Gambas Al Ajillo the very, very famous tapa of shrimp saut√©ed with garlic
Vieiras Con Salsa De Romesco seared scallops with romesco sauce

My favorite dish had to be the lamb ribs, imbued with a nice smoky flavor. Tender and kind of fatty, these went down easily with the subtle heat of the romesco. Another favorite was the chicken fritters served in a shoe (fun yet awkward). Crispy on the outside and hot and fluffy on the inside, these had a delicious chicken and potato flavor to them. The skirt steak carne asada was another popular item at the table, with the tender piece of steak complemented well by sweet piquillo peppers. The paella had a bunch of very crispy bits from the pan (slightly controversial among the family), but I liked the texture and depth of flavor it brought to the dish. Overall I liked the paella, but I wanted more meat - the few pieces we had were on the bony side.

Less successful was the flauta with jamon iberico. The bread was very chewy (felt kind of stale) and the prized ham got lost in the mix. The Spanish omelette was another I wouldn't order again; the egg-potato-onion mix was a little bland and boring.

We shared a couple of desserts to complete the meal.

Flan Al Estilo Tradicional De Mam√° Marisa Con Espuma De Crema Catalana a classic spanish flan with 'espuma' of catalan cream and oranges
Pastel De Chocolate Y Avellanas chocolate cake with hazelnut praline ice cream and salted caramel sauce

Both desserts were simple and satisfying. The very light flan, scented with vanilla bean, was my favorite and an appropriate end to the Spanish meal. Chocolate lovers wouldn't be disappointed by the chocolate cake, however.

I found the meal at Jaleo to be good. Nothing stood out as extraordinary, but the restaurant offered a good to way sample a bunch of different Spanish flavors. I'm not sure I'd return for a full meal, but it's a great place for a few drinks/bites before heading to the club (Marquee) or a show.

TGIF dinner for two in Vegas was sin city goid at Jaleo at the Cosmopolitan hotel.

Sangria red half at $25.00 was good but not great and a bit over price but it's vegas :/ The paella Valenciana with chicken and rabbit was very very good and I would order again on my next visit:) The iberico bellota with the tomato bread was super good! The  pollo croquetas was very good. The fideau negra con pulpo (octopus) was salty this night...bummer:( the dessert was a yummy flan al estilo 

Service was bit confusing bcuz we had a few different severs and changed without being notified, therefore, could NOT establish a repoire with the server and that's an important part of dining....where I come from:/

Total bill was $184.40 with a $30.00 tip so $214.40 was grand total - a bit steep but the vegas strip is over-priced and usually under delivers...what saved the dinner was my hot sexy date and the damn good paella Valenciana:)

Came here thinking it was China Poblano (oops), and sat at the bar since I was by myself. I asked the bartender for some recommendations on non-seafood items and he pointed me to two dishes...

Canelones Tradicionales De Cerdo Y H√≠gado De Pato Con Salsa Bechamel (pork and foie gras canelones with bechamel sauce) - this looked like two enchiladas when they came out covered in cheese. It didn't taste anything special and the meat just tasted like random meat with no foie gras in it. Boring dish in terms of flavor

Setas Al Ajillo Con La Serena (saut√©ed wild mushrooms with la serena potato pur√©e) - This could have been a MUCH better dish if it wasn't over seasoned. Way too salty.

Overall, very unimpressed with the two dishes I ordered. I might come back to try something else, but definitely not those two dishes.

I've been to Jaleo about 4 or 5 times now. I really love this place. It's in the Cosmo, which is the best hotel/casino on the strip right now. It's on the restaurant level, and it's sort of "open-air" which gives it a really cool vibe. The scenery is amazing both in the restaurant and outside walking by or lining up for Marquee. The food is spectacular!! The selection is amazing. What more can you say? 

The only critique I have is that service is sometimes unpredictable. I've even had waiters be really attentive at the beginning of the meal, and then disappear half way through. So they could try working on that. However, that doesn't deter me from giving it 5 stars. Go check it out for yourself!

1. SALTY. Is this place trying to pickle humans?? EVERYTHING WE ORDERED WAS WAY TOO SALTY!! Ordered 4 dishes and we had to return one of the dishes (Rossejat negra con Cigala) because it was simply inedible. The others were still generally very salty although we were too hungry to pass up. But we are currently regretting the decision because almost 12 hours later, we are still parched from the amount of sodium in our systems. You know it's not just us when the customers sitting next to you are complaining about the same thing and returning their dishes, too. 

2. GENERALLY HORRIBLE COOKING. Saltiness aside, the food was generally not made well. 
(a) Brussel sprouts were torn apart into pieces and presented with citrus fruits as a summer-y salad type dish. Cute efforts, bad execution. The pairing failed and I was left with one of the most weird Brussel sprouts ever. 
(b) Paella rice was 3/4 of the way done and so some portions of the rice were crunchy and undercooked... If you are a tapas place, you'd think paella is like their bread and butter...
(c) Salad was way too sweet and the dressing was almost like some kind of fruit juice or syrup...
(c) Lobster? What lobster? When one of the dishes with lobster came out, we were presented the skinniest pieces of "shrimp" that had almost zero edible parts, that was way below the acceptable level of any shell fish presentation. Apparently Norwegian lobsters are supposed to be small and skinny, but still I think the Yelpers should be informed that this should be their expedition: hardly any meat.

We left the restaurant still really hungry but not able to go get other food due to extremely salty internal situations... Sad.

Very disappointed.  Probably not the best restaurant choice for lunch.  We were told by the server that they did not serve any meats, just the jamon iberico.  My niece and I both ordered sandwiches.  We were told that it would take 20 minutes because they made the bread from scratch.  My sandwich of manchego cheese and jamon iberico was okay, but I had better in Spain where I used to go at least twice a year.  My niece ordered the veggie sandwich, and all it had was a sliver of wilted lettuce (for $18!).  The service was non-attentive.  We figured because we did not order cocktails like the waiter was suggesting.  I was embarrassed because my niece was visiting from out-of-state, and I was the one who suggested Jaleo.  I thought I could try Jaleo first before joining some friends who were going to Bazaar Meat.  No, will not go any further on Jose Andres, sorry, and will not recommend to anyone!

3.5 stars? Really? No. Just no. 
We ordered Pan de cristal, Pallela Valencia, Coliflor con olivas y frutos setas, Mini pepito de iberico and Jamon iberico Fermin. As well as a few cocktails. 
Everything was amazing, no improvements possible I think.

I've been here numerous times because (being born in Spain,) I've never found a Spanish restaurant aside from Jaleo that offers authentic recipes without putting some type of American twist on it. Also, Jaleo is my favorite restaurant in Las Vegas so I make sure that every time I'm in town I make a visit. 
Atmosphere is really cool, I love their bench seating and I love that the restaurant is conveniently across the escalator when you reach the 3rd floor of The Cosmopolitan. The restrooms are out of the restaurant around the corner and down the hallway so it's best to make sure you go before or after you go eat. 
Service has always been decent. Best service I've received goes to Mary because she always does an amazing job and really makes a difference in your experience. This last time I went, I had another waitress named Kristin and I'm not sure what happened but she decided to not come back to our table entirely. Not sure if she forgot about our group but she was still in the restaurant serving others. There wasn't even a manager on staff to fix the problem so that was my only bad experience here.
Now to the important part, the food! Come here if you want authentic Spanish food. I always order the Gambas a la Jillo (Garlic saut√©ed shrimp) and the Chicken Croquettes. The shrimp used to be better the first few times I had it because they used to add some type of tomate sofrito (refried tomato) and that recipe was amazing. Now it's just the big garlic shrimp and a small long loaf of bread. Chicken croquettes come in a shoe (it's what they do here) and they are pretty spot on if you've eaten them in Spain. 
Note: tapas are SMALL so it's best to order a few of what you want. If you want a huge plate of food you can go hit a buffet but I assure you, authentic Spanish recipes can't be beat and Jose Andres has done a great job at keeping authenticity.
Endivias con queso de cabra y naranjas VERY yummy, Best Fried Dates I've had, manchego apple salad was tasty. Lobster Paella was disappointing. Great service! I will be back!

How do you choose a restaurant on the Las Vegas strip when there are so many stellar ones?  This one came as a recommendation from a trusted foodie friend.  He was spot on.  

My husband and I had a delicious and fun late night dinner here.  The energy was great, not too loud to talk, but vibrating and exciting.  The service could have been a little more friendly, but that's my only complaint.  The wine list comes to you on an iPad, and unfortunately, I'm not a Spanish wine expert, so I picked a Rioja, one I am familiar with.  It was nice and decently priced.  We moved on the the olives - the liquid olives - you HAVE to try them.  They look and taste like Kalamata olives, but they are completely liquified.  GENIUS!  The pan con tomato, the gazpacho, so fresh and delicious.  My husband had some cheese (not a fan of cheese) - he loved it.  We went on the chorizo wrapped in a potato chip deep fried - YUM.  Then to the boneless chicken wings and carne asada.  Amazing flavors and textures.  For dessert we had the olive oil ice cream - I'm a sucker for anything olive oil - with grapefruit grenata.  

I read the other reviews, and some of them are spot on - yes, this is tapas, small dishes that let you taste everything.  My husband and I each ordered 4 plates, plus shared dessert.  We didn't leave hungry, and we weren't disgustingly stuffed.  The price was actually quite reasonable, even by Vegas standards.

I'm a huge fan of Spain, so I had to eat paella for my birthday dinner! Made a reservation for 13 the night before and they booked it for me. Such a great staff! Everyone was inviting and so nice when my entire party arrived. Their decor is unbelievable and being in the Cosmopolitan just makes you feel luxurious automatically. The price tag of the dinner was a bit unexpected , but I wouldn't change a thing. My friends and family had a great time and the food hit all the right tastebuds. Side not: I left a few birthday gifts behind and the wait staff the very next day kept them safe for me. I can now cross off eating from a celebrity chef off my bucket list!

Great tapas selection! Disappointed they stopped serving their stuffed dates though they were the best in town, I will have to fill the void with their chicken croquettes served in the shoe. Firefly may have them beat though on their sangria, besides that best tapas in town!

Went here last night for the second time. We had the pre-fixe menu and it was absolutely wonderful! You get 11 courses and each one was even better then the one before it. It was a wonderful way to get a taste of a lot of the dishes. The portions were generous, verging on amost too much. Come hungry. The sangria is delicious. Great service, cool atmosphere. We had an early dinner because we were going to a show so there weren't a lot of people when we got there but it filled up fast. I'd make reservations.

Jos√© Andres has a number of restaurants in the US, and the main Vegas outpost is Jaleo, located in the (new) Cosmopolitan.

Lynn & I went with her brother, who -- despite living in Vegas -- has never eaten here.  At some point, however, he's learned to turn the ordering over to his big sister and her husband (that would be me), and so off we went . . . 

We were told that the lobster paella would be about 40-45 minutes, so of course we ordered that immediately . . . and it was the first dish to arrive at our table.  Good news:  it arrived within 10 minutes.  Bad news:  it arrived within 10 minutes.  Let me explain:  

I thought I had ordered an array of tapas, salads, etc. and it would culminate with the paella.  Having it arrive first threw the progression of dishes I had in my head out the proverbial window, but the paella was so damned good, who cares???  

Next arrived the plate of green olives stuffed with anchovy and piquillo peppers, and paired with Ferr√°n Adri√† "olives" -- little "balloons" of liquid (Kalamata?) olives that burst in the mouth, filling you with that wonderful olive deliciousness.  Amazing!  And for someone who deeply regrets never dining at El Bulli, this was a REAL treat!

Served with that was the Selecci√≥n de embutidos -- a selection of cured meats (Jam√≥n Ib√©rico de bellota Fermin, Jam√≥n Ib√©rico Fermin, Jam√≥n Serrano Fermin, Lomo Ib√©rico de bellota Fermin, and house-made Chorizo Palacios) paired with their Pan con Tomate.  Delicious, flavorful, and indeed somewhat magical.

Next to arrive was the Manzana con hinojo y queso Manchego (a sliced apple and fennel salad with Manchego cheese, walnuts and Sherry dressing) that was crisp, light, refreshing, and very tasty.  

Our waitperson, Samantha, was knowledgeable and helpful, enthusiastic without being artificial in any way.  Based upon her recommendation ("I never eat veal, but this is my favorite thing on the menu!"), we ordered the Fricand√≥ de carilleras de ternera y pur√© de patatas al aceite de olive (Veal cheeks and morels with olive oil potato pur√©e).  OMG, she was right!  Rich, flavorful, melt-in-your-mouth lusciousness that was so sensual, so . . .,  so close to being over-the-top that, were it any closer, it would be illegal!

Recovering from this silky dish of richness, we moved on to the deceivingly simple sounding Trigueros con romesco (Grilled asparagus with romesco sauce), pencil-thin -- NO, eyebrow pencil-thin asparagus grilled to perfection with romesco that we could have eaten all night long.  Major yums!

Finally, we had Rape a la Donostiarra (Monkfish with garlic, Sherry and parsley oil).  Again, deceptively simple in name, but don't let that stop you.  Normally, I'm one of those people who don't "get" monkfish (aka "the poor man's lobster").  It's never seemed like lobster to me, and most of the times when I've had monkfish in the past, it's been overcooked and rather bland.  But this . . . THIS was OUTSTANDING!  Truly, the best monkfish I've ever had, and a dish I already want to have again!  Thinly sliced pieces of monkfish delicately poached (sous vide?) with just a hint of garlic and sherry, and a drizzle of parsley oil . . . this was THE dish-of-the-night, and the perfect dish to end our meal on!

Well, OK, with had Jos√© Andres' grandmother's flan.  This, too, was the best flan I've ever had in my life!

They have a great selection of Spanish wines, too.  (They have wines from elsewhere, but to be honest, I didn't look.)

An amazing dinner, and a place we will definitely be going back to!

This was the worst meal I've had in Vegas. There were a couple of things that were okay, but then a few that were just bad. Salty scallops, an odd taste to the Rossejat. I think the best thing that we had was the tortilla. I didn't even like my cocktail. What a huge disappointment from a place I was so excited to try!

To top it off, we were seated in a private room that had spotlights on each of the place settings, so it felt like we were in an interrogation room. Weirdly, those were the only lights in the room that couldn't be dimmed. 

I rarely leave bad reviews, but most people only have a couple of nice dinners while they are in Vegas, and I would be remiss if I didn't tell you to avoid this place. Womp.

My wife and I dined here on Sunday, August 28th at 7:30 p.m.  

We ordered three things: (1) "Fideua negra con pulpo" squid ink pasta with calamari and octopus paella, (2) the "Pulpo a feira Maestro Alfonso" boiled octopus with peewee potatoes, and (3) the "Costillas de cordero con salsa romero y alioli de miel" grilled lamb with rosemary sauce.  

They were out of all of them!

We settled on small plate "Jam√≥n serrano Ferm√≠n" while we decided what we were going to order next.  We inquired about a fourth dish, and he said they were out of that also.  The waiter wasn't much help.  We drank our sangrias (which were saturated with mint), paid the bill, and left.
Very poor form when you advertise a paella kitchen and specialize in paella and not have paella available during dinner time

This is an excellent Spanish restaurant, and rating it as that it gets five stars.  It is exactly what Jose Andres set out for it to be.  Now if you're not crazy about Spanish food, it might not be your cup of tea.  There are a lot of strong flavors, often coaxed out of simple ingredients.  Maybe they are to your taste; maybe not.  But if they are, it is well worth finding out, because a meal like this isn't easy to find this side of Madrid or Barcelona.

We went for restaurant week which, at Jaleo, meant a tasting menu.  Yes, each of the ten dishes served was a small portion, but that's how it is supposed to be.  Hey, have you never heard of the French Laundry?  Or even tapas?  I won't try to describe each dish, except to say that 8 of the 10 were absolutely first rate.  Strangely, one of the exceptions was the Paella, which really should have been the specialty of the house.
