The Paellas are being cooked with evident pride over an open fire oven in the middle of the restaurant, and I was looking forward to the dish.  Unfortunately, the rice did not have the crunchy-chewy texture that socarrat is supposed to have, and the (entirely) vegetarian ingredients were a bit mushy.  The other disappointment was the Sangria Ice dessert, which was extremely tart and not at all what you would expect when you take your first bite.  Well, hey, that's what happens sometimes when you have a tasting menu - you get something a bit unexpected.

The ambiance is obviously targeting fun, rather than than romance or class.  The room is pretty open, and the small tables are packed a bit tight.  The room was less than half full while we were there, but if it filled up it would have been pretty crowded and pretty noisy.  The wait staff knew their stuff, and they needed to since some items on the menu were probably unfamiliar to many patrons.  Our waiter took good care of us, and even with the multi-course tasting menu the pace of the meal moved right along.  Also, at $50 the tasting menu was a really good value.
Oh God! A true orgasm in my mouth! Amazing bruschetta! The octopus divine ! The jamom Iberico to die for! A true gem of a place !

This place is AMAZING! The service is excellent, the food is to die for and the ambiance is perfect.  I went here for my birthday and we had pan con tomate, croquettas de pollo, aparagus, fried zuccini, endives with goat cheese, morelo mushrooms, lobster tail paella with vermiccelli, garlic shrimp, monkfish, veal, lobster pomegranate seed salad and flan for my birthday dessert. The sangria was also very delicious, it had clove in it which was a different take on it. Not one of the dishes was just average and my aunt, who is a professional chef was eating with us and she was even impressed!

3rd level of Cosmopolitan.  Supposedly a famous chef, but I dont generally have any idea, as my wife picks these places.
We had a special tasting menu called "Jose's way". This included a chilled almond soup (very good), manchego cheese (so good, that we had to look up what this cheese was - found some online and bought it as soon as we got home); a very thinlyl sliced plate of iberian ham (so thats what people talk about); paella; and a few other things that I cant remember, except that they were very tasty. Small quantities, and not too filling. 
Its expensive, but the food is an experience that you cant get in too many places. 
I also took a wine pairing and was introduced to a few kinds of very expensive, and tasty wines, that I had never heard of before. 
So, overall, a good experience.

Overpriced and did not live up to the hype. We had probably 3 out of 8 dishes that were solid and the wine we ordered was just ok. Wasn't too impressed with the exploding olive but appreciate the work it took to make. Just thought the flavors couldve been accomplished in a more simplistic way. Plus, in comparison to real tapas in Spain, the cost just didnt seem worth it. 

The service was really good but really comes down to the food. Perhaps the recommendations made by our waitress weren't the best or maybe everything on the strip is mediocre and overpriced. Regardless, I mostly likely won't be back.

(3.5 stars actually)

Jaleo had excellent presentation and a trendy atmosphere.  The room was loud with many people dressed up in preparation for Marquee.  I was excited to try this place out, especially with how crowded it was.  (I usually figure if it's crowded, it has to have good food, right?)

mmm, the food was decent, but it did dispel my theory on crowded places.  Sad face.

So let's start off with a dish by dish play:

Pan de cristal con tomate
This is their bread with tomato sauce.  The bread came out and it wasn't that hot (perhaps it was their intent?  I'm not sure).  I guess I like my bread hot.

Chistorra envuelta en patata frita
Slightly spicy chorizo wrapped in crispy potato.  Okay, this was tasty.  The potato helps to add texture to the dish.  

Canelones de cerdo y foie con bechamel
This dish had foie gras in the center, which provided a rich and creamy flavor.

Lomo de buey con Valde√≥n*
Okay... here's my complaint.  This basically tasted like any random piece of meat.  It wasn't anything special.  Both the cooking and the meat quality seemed out of place.

Gambas al ajillo
The shrimp was solid in terms of quality, but the sauce was a little underwhelming.  

The sangria
This was really sad... it tasted like sprite.  I was expecting great sangria, especially at a tapas restaurant.  

So basically, a mix of good and mediocre dishes influenced me to be a little harsh.  Granted, this place is not a bad place to eat, but if you're expecting a taste bud exploding experience, lower your expectations.

I'm not too big of a fan when it comes to Tapas.  Don't get me wrong- it's just not my thing, but Jaleo definitely impressed with their creative offerings and fancy atmosphere!

Pros:
 * Elegant design with seating that can accommodate larger parties if need be. 
 * Creative tapa dishes 
 * Delicious food.  I liked nearly every dish ordered.
 * Friendly staff

Cons:
 * A bit overpriced, but that's expected.  Afterall, it is inside the Cosmo (there's an exception though:  secret pizza place).
 * Seating was a bit too close to one another.  Not much privacy that's for sure.
 
Overall, this was an interesting place.  They have tables outside of the restaurant (side of the hostess stand) that actually double as a Foose Ball table!  Everything we ordered was pretty good. 

Tips:
* A must order is the Veal cheeks and morels.  It was absolutely amazing!!
* Order the chicken fritters and be ready for an interesting surprise.  I don't wanna ruin it for you...all I'll say is that the presentation is one of kind!  
* Park / Enter through the East side elevators.  It takes you straight to the restaurant floors and Jaleo is conveniently right there =)

Came on a Saturday evening 6:15 reservation.  Place was only quarter full but got full by the time we left.
Waitress was nice but didn't come around often.
we weren't very hungry due to big lunch so we ordered 4 dishes for both of us and we were full.
-Octopus- 3 star (tender but slimy texture, flavor just ok)
-Shrimp- 4.5 stars ( tasty and good size shrimp)
-Skirt steak 4.5 stars (very flavorful)
-paella with Short rib and oyster mushrooms? 4.5 stars (flavorful but not the typical paella, meat kinda chewy but but tasty still). They only feature 2 types of paella at a time depending what the main feature is being cooked which can change during the evening.

Good Spanish restaurant,  located in the Cosmopolitan hotel. Tapas style restaurant with fun, live music.  We had most of the dishes.  My favorites were the scallops and vegetable paella. It takes 40min to make.  We had 2 orders of those. The vegetable paella is better than the chicken and rabbit. They offer several kinds of paella but only 2 per day.  Of all that we ate,  the dessert was the best.  We had several...flan, something on a hazel nut crust and coffee ice cream,  and sorbet.  So good!

Located inside of the Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas.¬†Chef Jos√© Andr√©s' Jaleo by Jose is a buzzy, modern tapas bar with an open-fire paella station. Most noteworthy is the happy hour at Jaleo. Guest can enjoy discounted Spanish wine an tapas from 4-7 pm during the week. ¬†Their "Sherry Hour" is most exceptional and provides diners 3 options of sherry ranging from dry to soft & sweet. Enjoy their Cava and discounted Spanish sangria's while you there.

A very important note.¬†One of Jaleos most popular items is Aceitunes Rellenas y acietunes 'Ferrante Adri√†'. A pair of olives stuffed with anchiovy and piquillo and Ferran Adria liquid olives. ¬†YOU MUST TRY THIS BEFORE YOU DIE. A little dramatic, but I will do what I must to ensure these olives are added to your order. Thank me later!

i REALLY liked this place. i love tapas so that may be it. 

i LOVE the diverse menu and all the great ingredients. i can't tell you everything we had since we ordered a TON of food. 

heres my best attempt to recall everything ordered:
-sardines on sliced toasted french bread - great
-chix croquettes served in a shoes - bleh
-paella which was beef and mushrooms - superb
-lamb ribs - im not a big fan of lamb but this was phenom
-i know we got like 3-4 more dishes but i can't remember. the paella was awesome though but ask for it ahead of time as it takes time and it varies. i also love the seating and lay out of the place. not stuffy at all

i really wish i got dessert so i could see what they did with that but i was sick. wait did i get dessert? i can't remember

JEANS: OK by far
ORDER: wait staff

michelle provided great service

Jaleo is a small plate/tapas concept in the Cosmopolitan Hotel. For the price of the Black Iberian pork, I believe I could fly first class to Madrid and go straight to the Mercado enjoying 15-20 such places for under $10/each. 

If you don't want to go to Spain, this is close. Very expensive, but a good variety of paellas and pork dishes which are authentic. 

Our service felt rushed and perhaps it was because there were not many occupied tables. 

2 people=$230

My friends treated me to a special dinner while we were in Vegas. I know what happens in Vegas is supposed to stay in Vegas, but... tell that to the 5 lbs I gained in 4 days. The new pounds certainly didn't stay in Vegas.

We feasted on:
1) squid ink pasta (more like vermicelli) with lobsters. The lobster was tasty, but it's the squid ink pasta that stole the show. I would've licked the pan clean if I hadn't been in public.

2) panne con tomate with anchovies. You don't like anchovies, you say? Are you scrinching your nose at the thought of anchovies? These are not the anchovies that come in a can. These are fresh, slightly salty, and give a nice depth of flavor to the traditional tomato toast.

3) Salad: fennel, walnuts, apple, and manchego cheese. A great start to our dinner. Would be good between the plates too, b/c it was kind of a palate cleanser. 

4) cheese plate: we got 1 creamy and 2 hard cheeses. I don't remember the names, but the creamy served with the fig raisin toast was by far the best one. you have to eat these cheeses with the paired garnish.

5) Paella: GET SOME. You don't come to a place with the only fire paella pit stand in the US and not get the paella. This is what you smell when you walk by this restaurant and why you came. You should come with a larger group so you can order a few paellas. Ours was a mushroom, roasted suckling pig paella. Mushrooms and pork were great, but again, I just wanted to eat the tender yet crunchy rice.

6) Dessert: My taste buds were done by this point; they had been overwhelmed by the above offerings. Or maybe the flan, served with creme fraiche and lemon sorbet, was too delicate to stand out after all the rich flavors that came before. (don't get me wrong. that plate was demolished).

I went to Jaleo the other day and it is a hip place to go. The ambiance of the place is a loud with great energy. I had no idea how playful the food could be. I had started with the sangria, it was tasty and I could not taste the alcohol.  I got to try to try sample lots of the small plates. 

Seleccion meats 2/10
Pollo Croquetas  7/10
La Serena Cone 5/10
Tortilla Patatas   4/10
Endivias Naranja  4/10
Bruselas Jamon    6/10
Gambas al Ajillo  8/10
Valenciana  3/10
Pan con tmate  7/10
Arroz Bogavante 7/10
Tarta De Manzana 7/10
Flan 7/10
Coffee 8/10

Came here on my birthday when it first opened and I was easily overwhelmed by the progressiveness.  It may have been my first foray into exquisite modern style dining.  It was the perfect place to begin eating in the upper echelon.  The service was fast and the atmosphere was up tempo.  

I had the Lobster Paella.  Phenomenal!  A whole lobster on your plate with cuttle fish & chorizo.  The spices were definitely shipped from Espana.  

La Sirena con membrillo was a small cone that tasted like some kind of creamy and slightly tarty cheese that I've never tried before.  

Salmon crudo huevas salmon cones were a trip.  A salty poppy crisp from a tiny little cone shaped treat.  It fooled you because it looked like a raspberry ice cream cone but had such an umami flavor that lingers and matures into something you'll remember fondly.

At the time there was a Sea Urchin dish that had a raspberry foam.  Wow now that was a first!  Creamy oceanic Uni mixed with a light and frothy pink sweetness.  Woah!  Hope they still have that on the menu..

We had some Salmon Cream Cheese Rangoons.  They liked to play around with what you're used to and make it otherworldly.  This place was amazing when it first opened.  I don't see many of these dishes on the online menu anymore? 

Another one not on the menu anymore was a braised lamb rack.  Savory and buttery tender perfect.  

There were Crab meat Stuffed Peppers.  Also some strange olive oil pur'e horderves.  The entire experience was mind expanding.  Your taste buds will never be the same.  Make sure to bring your checkbook and go big here.  Get all the exotic dishes you can translate.  Jaleo could be a truly unique experience if you are daring enough.

I've been here a few times. This place is excellent.  The venue itself is fun. I like being able to watch the paella being made.

The wine selection is great. I've never had a disappointing wine.

I've had a number of different tapas ranging from the paella (great) to chicken, fish, steak, and vegetables. They have all been excellently prepared and nicely presented.

I cannot rave enough about my absolutely FABULOUS experience at Jaleo! I must admit, organizing a group dinner for about 20 people in a city I don't live in sounded like a daunting task once my boss placed that duty in my lap. But I received phenomenal service from start to finish while planning and executing our business event at Jaleo, The Group Sales Staff at The Cosmopolitan were all very professional and organized, helping to ease the stress of pulling this whole dinner together in such a short amount of time. A big, huge "thank you" shout out to both Kelly and Rose!

And another big round of applause goes out to our server at Jaleo: Mary! She was fantastic and our whole group loved her. Great service, delectable eats, tempting adult beverages, fun ambiance, and the perfect setting for a group. I highly recommend this spot if you are planning a dinner in Vegas. We went with a custom menu that the group sales team put together, and our guests were all very pleased with the 13 courses (yes, thirteen different menu items for everyone to try out) Tapas style of course, but such a great idea to give everyone a good idea of what this restaurant was all about. The cocktails were flowing all night and food felt like it kept coming and coming! 

Below are some of my favorites of the evening that you have to try if you are dining at Jaleo:

The Bramble- best cocktail of all time! No for real, seriously amazing. Cinnamon infused vodka with a cranberry puree. 
Jamon Serrano Fermin- a perfectly flavored 18 month, salt cured Serrano Ham
Endibias con queso - the cutest little app you've ever seen with endives, goat cheese, oranges and almonds
Gazpacho- this was served shooter-style and had some kind of amazing dollop of creamy cheese on top (not sure exactly what it was) 
Croquetas de pollo - these little chicken fritters were delish. Served in a shoe which I wasn't too sure about, but really tasty nonetheless
Carne Asada- perfectly cooked and seasoned
Paella- this traditional dish is an "absolute must" when dining at Jaleo! They do some kind of crazy chant in the kitchen before these go out to the tables and it gets the whole restaurant excited. They brought it out on this ginormous skillet that took two people to carry it just to show us what it was. But then took it back over to the open kitchen to plate it for us. 
Flan - typically not my favorite type of dessert because of the texture, but this flan was so creamy and I really enjoyed it.

Can't wait to come back to Jaleo! And a big THANK YOU again to all the staff who helped me with the great execution of our group business dinner. CHEERS!

Love this place. The tapas is great and the service is wonderful. Our personal favorite is the caviar with the egg. Sometimes it is off the menu but on my last visit we were able to request and the chef prepared it. The Gin and Tonic from the bar was also exceptionally good. Great place for a fun tapas evening.

De-Lish!! Been here twice already and just now getting around to getting my experience to this review.  Yes, it is a great experience here and the food... So good..!  

We enjoyed how whenever a version of the paella was done, the chefs would announce it and the crowd of us in the restaurant would yell back, "PAELLA!" Pretty fun and the shrimp Paella was one of my favorites that I have had here.
The menu is in Spanish, so don't be hesitant to look at your neighbors and see what they are having and ask them about it. This openly social experience is probably an unintended surprise to the open concept that the designer had cause it gets strangers to talk and not be so introverted or locked into their phones. Or maybe not, but that is what we observed and experienced and I loved it the both times that I had gone.

The menu is broken up into sections, Apps, Fried Items, Charcuterie, (cured meats mainly), Cheeses, Soups, (this I did not try - but plan to), Salads, Specialties, Seafood, Paellas, Meat, large plates, and dessert.  My suggestion is go with a party of at least 2 or more and try to order from all of the sections. In the times that I have gone, we were not able to try the soups of the large plates - but all were still delicious. 

Notables for me were: 

- Patatas bravas 
- Shrimp Paella
- Jam√≥n ib√©rico Ferm√≠n
- Pollo al ajillo y ajo negro
- Carne de ciervo asada

I'm sure there are a couple that are missing but so far, these are go-tos for me. 

Should you decide to try this place, I hope that you all have a great experience like we did.

Unimpressed. The food was salty and pretty bad tasting. The only good thing about this place is that it's in the best hotel/casino in Vegas - Cosmo. So after you taste one plate you can quickly bounce out to any of the other restaurants which are all better - such as STK, Scarpatta or other. I would avoid this place - expensive and gross food with stale bread that I played table hockey with while I waited for the yucky food. Very disappointed that this is in the Cosmo, b/c everything else in this hotel is absolutely a 5 star experience, where Jaleo is 'Meh' at best.

When in Vegas; I always come here.  The food is great and the service is awesome.  Really enjoy their happy hour but also the paella is spot on and worth the wait.  A great place to socialize and I highly recommend their calamari and sliders.

Absolutely delicious modern twist riffing off of highly traditional Spanish tapas. Top notch staff, pouring high end cocktails and perfect wine pairings.

Definitely lives up to its name, though: It's loud!

If you're looking for avant-garde Spanish cuisine in the form of a passionately-designed tapas menu, then look no further once you lock eyes with Jaleo.  

Chef Jos√© Andr√©s' delivers, as promised, in this Cosmopolitan Las Vegas-based branch of the original Metro Washington DC location, which has earned respect as a local institution.   You might have caught a glimpse of the chef in the Travel Channel's Washington DC episode of No Reservations featuring his exclusive artsy haunt: Minibar.  The chef not only has an incredibly passionate streak for quality ingredients, but he truly shines in culinary innovation and personality while providing an undeniably eclectic ambience that perfectly compliments the menu.         

The spirit of Spain is infused into every detail without coming across with the superfluous kitsch one may discover at any Strip establishment.   While often busy, and almost impossible to have a quiet conversation, Jaleo offers a dining experience filled with enough energy to keep your attention without pushing you into sensory overload.
    
Jaleo, in short, offers a remarkable mixture of tapas, as well as the expected paellas, a noteworthy selection of Spanish wines, cocktails with character, and a kick-ass sangria.    

Additionally, you will be greeted by enthusiastic and knowledgeable staff with terrific, and timely, presentation.  Created in 1993 by Chef Jos√© Andr√©s, Roberto Alvarez, and Rob Wilder, Jaleo has not only made a name for itself in DC, but it is slowly coming-of-age as a formidable competitor in the Las Vegas dining scene.  Be warned, Jaleo packs enough fiery punch to knock out any other tapas joint in Las Vegas.   Bring your appetite, as the sensuous Jaleo aims to both satisfy and impress.

I was given 200 dollars by an overly drunk and frighteningly happy frat boy at a blackjack table at Harrah's at 6:00 in the morning.  I am not exactly sure how or why he gave me said money, but I remember trying to give it back and he consistently refused, eventually the dealer gave me a look that said "leave, before he starts losing and sobers up."  So I did.  But what to do with the money?  Well, 100 went into longer term savings, and 100 I decided to blow on a fancy dinner alone.  After wandering the strip looking for a worthy restaurant I stumbled in to Jaleo.
First things first.  Order a gin and tonic, they are amazing.  I was skeptical, given that it is a Tapas restaurant, but do yourself the favor and order one.  I also found myself drinking some wine that was good, but not mind blowing (like the G&T's).
The food is awesome, if you have not been to Spain before order a bunch of dishes from all over the place.  I always recommend paying for pork, and theirs is top notch, definitely the high quality stuff.  I like the Jamon Serrano, but find one that is in your price range and enjoy placing it in your mouth and letting it melt like butter.
Skip the Paella, it looks good and the fire is a neat little bit of flair but I wasn't impressed and found it to be the most overpriced item I ordered.  I can't really remember any of the other dishes I had, but everything else was good to great, with the Ham, and the Gin and Tonic being my stand out favorites and the Paella being good, but not on par with everything else.
I occasionally indulge myself in fancy restaurants and this place is high on my list in Las Vegas, I will certainly be returning.

I wanted to love Jaleo, and would rate my experience a 7.5 out of 10. It was quite loud and the acoustics were off, making dinner conversation strained. They only had 2 of the paella options available, out of 6 or so listed on the menu. The pork was quite gamey, but good. They have an authentic offering for nearly all areas of the Iberian peninsula, even Asturias was well represented with a delicate octopus and potato tapa. Any Spain aficionado will be pleased!

Horrible service. Ridiculously expensive. Not worth it.


We are not the type to complain about spending money especially when we knew that's what we were walking into but they made the experience incredibly unpleasant for our group of 7. Our waiter and waitress (they switched out mid visit) came to our table about 3 times to check on us within the hour that we were there. Two of our orders never came. One of my friends actually had to get up and complain to the manager and he responded very rudely. Asked for the check and the manager slammed it on our table. Ridiculous. Spend your money elsewhere. Where they make it worth it.

All I can say.... YUMMYYY!!! Ask your server for suggestions. I ate whatever was ordered and it was delicious. I love the setting of their setting and atmosphere, service was prompt or maybe because the group I came with was highly important but who cares. Hands down to Jaleo and the awsome food.

At $50 a person, I think it's fair to hold this place to a high standard. One of our dishes had literally spoiled, smelled like a barnyard floor, and had to be sent back. The chef admitted it had gone bad. Nothing we ordered attained a rarefied level of culinary excellence or elegance. The service was excellent, and I'm sure fancy people are going to continue spending piles of money here, but for this kind of money I won't be giving them a second chance. Ultimately uninspired.

We came back here for some Spanish tapas, food was still very delicious, it just they don't have any fish, people don't eat fish in Spain? A lot of meat choices, very few Vegetarian / Vegan and Pescetarian plates, so I couldn't order as much as I wanted, the choices were limited. But the plates I ordered were very very good! 

We decided to do small plates only, didn't want any Paellas. Started off with that famous Jaleo gin & tonic again, so sweet and refreshing, loved that ice cube! Hubby had a margarita drink, strong and yummy, two salmon roe cones for us, I just love that cone! Salty with a lot of flavors in one cone, amazing! 

Saut√©ed cauliflower, with chopped olives and dates: salty and sweet in one plate, unique taste, very delicious, loved it! 

Seared scallops, with romesco sauce: very tender with strong flavors, we liked it a lot.

Shrimp saut√©ed with garlic: sooooo good! The garlic in it was amazing, shrimps were tender and delicious.

Garlic soup: it came so late, don't know why? But right at the moment when hubby needed some warm soup, he liked it. 

Skirt steak from the famous black-footed ib√©rico pigs of spain served with toasted tomato bread, mojo verde and alioli: the portion was huge, good for 2 or 3 people to share, too bad I couldn't eat it, hubby loved it! Juicy, tender, great with the sauces came with it! The bread with tomato spread was so delicious! 

I had a Grey Goose martini twist after gin & tonic, the food was so good, the portions were not even small, especially that skirt steak, hubby couldn't finish it, we had it boxed, didn't want to waste a $60 plate. The tab was $200 ish. 

I like this fun looking restaurant a lot, colorful and playful, great service, great drinks, casual and relaxing!

What an amazing new restaurant in Vegas!

First things first- yes, prices are high in Vegas as it's a tourist location.  Honestly, if you go and visit, there are a lot of places you can go to keep it reasonable- you just have to find them.  :)

That being said, Jaleo isn't someplace I would put in that category.  I LOVE the food here, the atmosphere- everything about it.  For a foodie, it's totally worth the price- but if you're not, maybe eat a large lunch and try just a few plates and have a drink?  No matter which way you go, I highly recommend giving it a try.  Spanish Tapas is such a great way to eat.

Our waitress was amazing, and was extremely helpful in explaining how the menu worked as well as how traditional meals in Spain are enjoyed. We started off with the very confusing drink menu on their i pad- there were so many things listed, we got her advice and let her pick for us.  I had a glass of Cava (spanish sparkling wine) and my partner had two different glasses of spanish reds- all were right on par with what we said we liked. 

We ordered:
Chorizo Palacios-A slightly spicy cured pork sausage seasoned with piment√≥n and garlic
Sopa de ajo con huevo-Garlic and bread soup with a slow-cooked egg
Chistorra envuelta en patata frita-Slightly spicy chorizo wrapped in crispy potato
Gambas al ajillo-famous tapa of shrimp saut√©ed with garlic
Codorniz con salsa de romero y alioli de miel-Grilled quail with rosemary sauce
and honey alioli
Salpic√≥n de cangrejo-Jumbo lump crabmeat with cucumbers, peppers, tomatoes, cauliflower and Sherry dressing 

We also had some traditional muscles, and as someone who usually doesn't care for the texture or taste, I could have had only that for my whole meal and died happy! 

On this trip we visited a new place each night- and this was the winner!! a must try :)

Disappointing. We went for happy hour, which was listed in a recent article on Vegas happy hours and is shown on the restaurant's web site. We arrived at 5p to find an empty bar. We asked the hostess about happy hour, and she said, "We don't have happy hour. Oh, you saw it on the website? Yeah, I don't know why that's there, the manager knows about it." The happy hour pricing wasn't the driving force in our going there, but it would have been nice.

We were hungry and wanted a snack and a wine before dinner later, and we have been to other Jose Andres restaurants, including Jaleo in DC, so we went forward with our plan. 

Service at the bar was terrible. We had several different people asking us what we wanted and putting in our order, except they didn't actually put some of the orders in. The bar servers were nice about helping us choose wine and cheese, but were otherwise inefficient. We waited awhile for the cheese plate to come out, then the tomato bread never came. I finally asked one of the people behind the bar if we did order the bread, and she said, oh the other person doesn't seem to have put that in! So now our cheese plate is finished and we're done with our wine, and it's another 5 minutes for the bread to come out. The bread was amazing, but would have been even more amazing if it had been out with the wine and the cheese.

Normally we'd have ordered more food and wine, but the experience at this point was so disappointing, we bagged it and paid the check. $75 for two glasses of wine, 3 pieces of cheese, some glazed popcorn, and bread. We are big tapas fans, so it's not like we don't know that these things add up, and the quality of the food was great, but come on, that was crazy considering we didn't even get good service.

Julian Serrano at the Aria is soooooo much better. It has a broader menu, nicer people, and the service is great. Go there, not here.

Unsure how this place has good reviews. 
Incredibly noisy.
Portions are expensive and smaller than an appetizer plate. 
Too many good restaurants on the strip to bother stopping here. 
Will never return.

Oh my goodness!! Every tapa we tried was beyond delicious!!! It had a busy vibe but not in a bad way. The food was beyond great and we even got an order on the house! I wish I would have remembered what we ordered but there was probably about 10 different dishes brought to our table. We were late for our reservation but they still accommodated us so that was terrific. Food comes out different times so just be aware when you order something. We thought they forgot a dish but it just came out later but we warned ahead of time. Our waiter, Nelson was great and if I come back in I will  request to have him if I can! Very personable guy! Oh and the Sangria was tasty extremely tasty. Don't sleep on this place!

I really hate to give lower than 3 stars but in my opinion Jaleo flavors weren't all that amazing for very high prices, small portions and pretty bleh service. My bestie wanted tapas for her birthday and we decided on Jaleo since none of us had tried them yet. It was pretty easy to get a reservation for Thursday at 9:30. I was thinking it'd be a bit busier because it was leading up to fight weekend but nope! They had a normal steady flow of people. 
Ambiance is cute, a nice place to catch up with friends or family. The atmosphere didn't feel stuffy at all. However, I will say that the spacing between courses felt a little bit too long and when the food came out, all of them could have been a bit warmer. They all were lukewarm. 
As for service, our server was nice, however, he did not offer explaining the menu, did not ask if it was our first time or even talk about the portion sizes. The only thing he did mention was specializing in Gin & Tonic variations on an iPad lol which were $20 each! The menu is very extensive and a bit confusing since all the dishes' names aren't in English! I wish he'd mention what his favorites were. I also saw $55 & $85 chef tasting options available, which I'd like to come back to try.

C√≠trico Gin & Tonic $20: Oxley gin, Fever-Tree Mediterranean tonic water, grapefruit, lemon, coriander, mint. The birthday girl got this one but we all got to taste it and geeze, I've had better G&Ts from PT'S! Everyone agreed that no one could taste anything except for the tonic water. We really could not taste ANY of the supposed grapefruit, lemon, etc. And for $20? The flavor should be better than $17 specialty cocktails at the Chandelier Bar. 0/5

D√°tiles con tocino 'como hace todo el mundo' $14: Fried bacon-wrapped dates served with an apple-mustard sauce. These were okay, very underwhelming. I'd rather go to Firefly and have their bacon wrapped dates any day. The bacon tasted a little charred and the dates weren't sweet. The mustard sauce was okay, nothing special. 2/5

Mini pepito de ib√©rico* $8 EACH!: Spanish mini burger made from the legendary, acorn-fed, black-footed ib√©rico pigs of Spain with ib√©rico bacon. These were really good! Super flavorful, soft buns and very tender! However, at $8 EACH?! What?! They're not THAT amazing, expecially for how small they were. 4/5

Rossejat' negra con Cigala $27: Toasted pasta, squid ink, sepia sofrito, Norwegian lobster and alioli. This one was my "favorite" but again there were some big issues that shouldn't be in a $27 dish. Half of the squid ink pasta was burnt onto the pan that it came in, I know this definitely only had enough to split by 2 people but between the 4 of us, we got basically a tablespoon of squid ink pasta each. Also the body of the super skinny Norwegian Lobster was cut in half but left the claws with no cut so we couldn't even get in them! Flavor was alright but I'll go to RX Boiler Room for his squid ink entree instead for larger portion and more developed flavors. 3/5

Arroz con costillas de cerdo ib√©rico de bellota $36: Basically the Paella with the pig ribs. I was super excited for this one but was very disappointed. Rib meat was not tender, more on the dry and chewy side and as for flavor, meh. 2/5

Salm√≥n crudo con huevas de salm√≥n $5/cone: Salmon tartare w/ salmon roe on top. These were super good! 4/5

Overall, I still feel bad giving a not so great review after seeing so many people love this place but the whole experience for us was pretty underwhelming and forgettable for basically all areas: specialty drink, food, and service. Maybe we just came at an off night so I want to give this place another chance just for the tasting menus but it probably won't be anytime soon.

Never thought goat cheese and mandarin would taste so good and refreshing The chef is amazing and his creations are out of this world! This restaurant is very unique the calamari with squid ink aoli was to die for thank you Chef for last night!!! Love you will be back soon

Fun and Adventurous!
(and Expensive... but then all strip restaurants are)

This is more like a 3.5 star place.
The service is fantastic but the noise level is a bit too "energetic"... (aka Loud) so it makes having a conversation a bit hard.

If you can .... and have a group... reserve the private room... it's much more intimate and quieter in there.

We enjoyed a number of Interesting plates.

The white asparagus was quite lovely.... and light.  It was a good veggie starter.

The caviar and egg dish was very good.... rich.... but the caviar is not as rich as one would expect for this dish.

The cold garlic soup was different.... good... but different... the grapes off set the garlic part which is a good contrast.

The spinach was Very Good.... it had bacon and raisins in it... I know... raisins?  Yup... raisins.... loved it.   But then bacon makes everything taste better.... so the raisins were a nice counter balace to the salty.

The veal cheek was also good but not off the charts good like I was hoping.  I wanted melt in your mouth, eye popping good and it wasn't.

The "pigs in a blanket" .... sausage wrapped in a potato chip were good .... but not spectacular.  It was like a little weenie rolled in a potato chip.  

The empanada was more like a won ton filled with fishy cream.  Not what I expected at all.... we ate it because it wasn't horrible... but it wasn't all that good either.

Our favorite was the piquillo stuffed with crabmeat.... good flavor and texture. The crab was a contrast yet a complement to the piquillo.

For dessert, we had the Chocolate Flan... it was quite good.  Creamy not overly sweet nor overly rich.  It was a smooth, milky chocolate.  :)

Sitting down for a drink before celebrating a fun evening we were entertained my the bar tender. 
He was friendly, funny and actually appeared as though he wasn't just trying to make a tip.

We discussed different types of whiskey, tequila and a few others. Jovial and funny dude.
When our friends joined us the jokes and laughs kept coming.

I would have loved to dine here but the drinks were YUM and the entertainment even more.

Really enjoyed this place.  The bill was as expected and the Gin and Tonics are amazing.  Everything we had was great and service was very good.  Only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was that I was really looking forward to trying the paella but they only make two types every day and that day was only the vegetarian and chicken and mushrooms.

Food and alcohol deserve 4 stars - very standard classic spanish/basque tapas executed well, very creative and delicious specialty cocktails.

Ambiance and service deserve 0 stars - overly loud dining room, unnecessarily lazy staff and servers.

For the details - 

Firstly, Jaleo messed up my reservation.  I originally had a res for a party of 6 people @ 6PM on Friday.  I called 3 days prior to change to 8 people @ 7 PM.  I didn't get a confirmation call the day-of which I thought was weird.  Sure enough, they never changed the original reservation and since we were "an hour late" when we arrived, they had already given up our table.  They did seat us immediately but had to squeeze us into a table meant for 6 right at the front of the restaurant by the bar and hotel escalators.  Yuck.  And, as noted by many here, the main dining room is certainly loud.

I also think it's ridiculous that they don't answer their phones before dining service begins.  Having to wait til 8PM on the east coast to call and make (and then change) reservations was ludicrous.  This is probably also why they don't call you to confirm.

So, we were seated and the waitress came around to take drink orders and informed us that, in her exact words, "the kitchen is broken" and they were doing all the cooking on the grills in the middle of the restaurant, so there were a few dishes that weren't available.  She didn't specifically mention which, of course.

We got our drinks and they were all amazing.  The famous G&T, sangria, some gold sparkly drink, a drink with instructions on how to drink it (dip this into this, then put this in your mouth, then sip this, then do a dance...)

Now, I'm a tapas whore, and the menu at Jaleo is very much standard classic tapas, nothing really out of the ordinary.  So I go to order 6 of the usual suspects for my wife and I.  They couldn't make a single one of them.  Well, what can you make then?  "Well nothing from this side of the menu or that side of the menu."  So...let me try again...what CAN you make?

Wound up figuring things out and placing our order, and the tapas started arriving shortly thereafter.  Except the runners kept coming to my side of the long table, saying to me what the dish was, and then putting it down in front of me.  So I had to turn into the waiter, loudly screaming across the table to see who ordered each dish and then passing it down.  I finally got fed up around the 8th plate or so and started forcing the runners to do their job and figure out who ordered each dish so they could place it in front of the right person.  For.every.single.dish.  Ugh.

Also, there were a few dishes we had ordered doubles of that we never received.  

Thank god the food was good.  We probably ordered every dish that was available and none disappointed.  Winner of the night in my book was the lamb ribs.  Fall-off-the-bone delicious.  Other mentionables - patatas bravas were potato chips which was a neat twist, and the romesco sauce had an interesting smokey flavor.  Otherwise, as I said, pretty standard stuff all executed well.

- disappointing ambiance (a bit "mall" food court -like)
- poor service from hostesses
- all around a disappointing experience

At the suggestion of a friend, I booked this restaurant to celebrate a friend's 40th bday.  

We thought the ambiance was disappointing -- it felt a little exposed and like a mall food court.  Despite our open table reservation, there was No table ready for us.   The hostesses were obviously holding a table for some VIP group and wouldn't seat us there even though it was sitting empty and we were on-time for our reservation.  

The hostesses were rude.  We could tell they were talking about us after we complained about being seated in the bar (felt like being in the middle of a mall food court!)   Our waiter was wonderful, but the hostesses and bartenders all seemed cranky/unhappy.  

The food was good, but not exceptional.  There are a lot of great restaurants in vegas and I just cannot recommend this one. 

 If however you find yourself there, we loved the mushrooms, the traditional potato/egg dish, both the asparagus and the potatoes in maresco sauce.  My absolute favorite was the flank steak-- fantastic.  My advice?  Keep looking and eat somewhere else!

Such a wonderful experience, I strongly recommend the tasting menu and sangria are a must have. Chefs ring a cow bell and brings the atmosphere from mellow to lively!! Truly an experience to a culinary journey

A blast of yumminess in a sea of bland! Jaleo IS what it is cracked up to be! Been there twice in one month and have loved it more each time. The wait staff is informative and friendly, the food is amazing! 

We have sampled almost everything on the menu - from that yummy friend egg/caviar dish to the chicken croquettes served in a shoe - and we have not been disappointed! Try everything - the servings are perfect, the portions just right - and of course being tapas - you never leave feeling like you are stuffed to the gills - not like other restaurants where you have too much food served to you and you are stuck with what you got! my husband and I so enjoy the setting and the service - cannot wait to go back again! 

The only thing i would suggest is to turn the music down just a tad. Sitting across from each other, we have to almost scream to be heard. 

The prices are reasonable (filling dinner for two, 2 glasses of wine each and tip came to $130) and dinner for 4 of us was $280. 

Try it!!!! You will LOVE it and never understand why Tapas is NOT more popular everywhere!!!
Disappointing! Overpriced  and the staff was not welcoming at all. Do yourself a favor and don't go to this place.

First i want to say that this place is a toss up between 3-4 stars.  Me and 2 other friends ordered around 10 dishes between us and i'd say 2 of them were not very good, 2 were exceptional and 6 were pretty good.  Overall i think that's a win

The seared squid with ink sauce was tender and not chewy,  the mushrooms with mashed potatoes had this blue cheese puree in it that i thought was genius.  

The braised veal cheeks were not bad,  the pork and foie grais canellones could have done with more foie gras flavor,  the 3 cheese platter i selected was very sub par (maybe i just picked the 3 off the list that sucked? :P ).

The beer selection is extremely limited

The service was prompt, polite and overall 4 star worthy

The price was not too bad with it coming out to around 90 dollars a person for a total of 10 dishes and 6 beers.

David Oseas (GM) & his team took a zing care of us last night. We showed up as a group of 8 at 9pm and by 10:30pm we'd been through something like 6 courses of amazing food. Highlights included the ham, the steak and the gambas. It's easy to see why this place is popular.

WOW, tapas at their best.

So hard to pick from all of the great items.

Corkage fee was only $25 here, I was shocked. All of the items were around $12 and smaller plates. We had the Rabbit Paella which was delicious and a bunch of others.

Most notably was the chorizo, the endives, and the Gambillos Al Ajillo. It is really a causal atmosphere which I liked as well. It is not a high end stuffy restaurant. The kitchen is open to everyone and they had a ton of seating.

I lived in Barcelona for a couple months and these dishes were true to Spanish Culture. I will definitely be back. Did I mention the Service was amazing as well?

My absolute favorite dish was probably the simplest. The manchengo cheese with tomato on bread. WOW

With the multitude of buffets on The Strip in Vegas, it can be difficult to stray to other places when visiting for a weekend. However, for this birthday meal we wanted somewhere different to commemorate the special occasion. We were not disappointed!

The two of us had the chef's tasting menu with pairing and were impressed! Most dishes were absolutely delicious, notably the paella. Paella is my favorite dish, and the one at Jaleo is exemplary. Rich, creamy and flavor-packed. The cocktails are also very well prepared. 

Cons: The chef's tasting menu is too big. There are many, many items, most incredible, but some are too simple, lack flavor and totally miss the mark. For example; scrambled egg, flavorless flatbread pizza. Too much was being tackled.

Love this place! Whenever I go to Vegas I make it a point to come to Jaleo. Great cocktails and great food. Love the watermelon vodka cocktail. Also, not on the menu but they make the best espresso martini. Not sure why this place got bad reviews. Everytime I come here the food is excellent and the service is great. Tapas style food with good portion sizes. Delicious veggies, cheese and meat. yum! Worth the money.

Of all the restaurants we went to in Vegas, this one was our family's favorite (and we really liked and enjoyed ALL the places we went to!). We loved the whole "tapas" experience, and sampling a variety of dishes, the variety of tastes and food. 

Our hostess and server were unbelievably nice. Service was really attentive. 

We liked the open grilling/roasting pit where you can watch them roasting a piglet on a rotating spit (weird, but fascinating,) and a humongous pig's leg (it's like a mesmerizing car accident. You can't look away). There's something reassuring about watching your food being prepared. I like the transparency aspect of the kitchen, and hearing the sizzling and smelling the wonderful aromas.

We ordered many different dishes including endives & goat cheese (this was our favorite!), garlic shrimp, grilled chicken with mustard sauce, and a bunch of other plates. All were delicious and devoured. 

We loved this restaurant! I wish there were one here in Seattle; we'd be regulars! Next time we're in Vegas, we are definitely coming back here.
We had a most amazing meal at Jaleo.  I can't remember what we ordered but EVERYTHING was fantastic!  The service was great and they helped us pick dishes and each was delicious.

I loved Jaleo DC and I jumped on the opportunity to dine at Jaleo when I realized they're in The Cosmopolitan next door to The Aria where I am staying. However, it was a little different!

Menu looked identical but it wasn't the same. Some of the stuff I had in DC weren't here and the portion was super small. I remember dining in DC and was completely stuffed and our tab weren't that bad. It seemed the prices were way higher here.

The dishes were good but just really puny for the price. Our server was good but she kept recommending things that were astronomical in price and she got the manipulation down in getting you to believe you had no other choice or that was the right choice.

One of the most disappointing item she recommended was the hand carved jamon iberico. It came as dried puny sliced up ham at $35. It was so not worth it. I had the jamon on the bread before with crushed tomatoes in DC, it was so much cheaper and better. It felt like a snow job in this dessert heat. What a rip. 

Also, we wanted the seafood paella and our server kept saying that wasn't available until an hour later and the one available was the most expensive one $38 which we sadly ordered because we were starving!!! 

However, the croquettas, the spring vegetables with duck egg, chorizo wrapped in potato, boneless wings, and the sliders were delicious. 

Still, I can't give it lower than four stars as I'm truly a fan. I was just disappointed that I brought some people to dine here and we left kinda hungry and the tab was over $500 for sharable food people had no more than a bite of each. It was kinda embarrassing for me and I was hoping they weren't mad at me for having to blow 3 days worth of per diem dinner money here and were still hungry.

DC won.
Delicious!  The only reason why I gave it 4 instead of 5 is because the dishes tend to be very extreme... either too acidic or too fatty or too salty.

Walking into this restaurant is quite nice, the decor is nice and they are cooking paella over wood fire in the back which is nice to look at and leaves a great aroma throughout the whole place.  Unfortunately I do not remember all of the exact items we had when I dined here, but I know that almost everything we got was delicious.  I had two food problems when we were there.  First was the roasted pepper and eggplant tasted more bitter than roasted.  Second, In my opinion the grapefruit in the lobster salad was too strong and killed the flavor of the lobster meat.

The restaurant has been described as vibrant and fun but when we went there it was packed and a bit too loud to hold a conversation at our table without shouting.

I have dined at Jose Andres other restaurant The Bazaar in Beverly hills and for similar price I enjoyed the food a little better and the environment and total experience much more.
I thought it was just okay. The Sangria was really yummy and the service was extraordinary.. that's about it..
Everything here is great. I ate here 3 times in one weekend. Better Spanish food than anywhere I've eaten in Spain.

I went to Jaleo with a co-worker for dinner on Thurs, Feb 10, 2011. I have been to Bazaar (Jose Andres' restaurant in Beverly Hills) a few times so I kind of new what to expect. I would say I got pretty much what I expected.

The atmosphere is really nice. The Cosmo Hotel is very new and contemporary and Jaleo continues that feel. The restaurant is live and has a very fun, energetic atmosphere. There is an open-ness to the restaurant and it blends in with the rest of the hotel (so that you don't feel closed off).

The food (as with other Jose Andres restaurants) does not live up to the hype. The food is definitely not bad, but it is basically slightly above average. I love the tapas (small plates) style of eating, because you can try many dishes. And when you look at the menu, there are sure to be several things that look extremely appetizing.

The two of us had about 6 or 7 dishes. The cones filled with salmon sashimi and topped with salmon roe were very salty. I was expecting those to be better, they were just okay.

The Brussels sprout salad was pretty solid. We had a monk fish dish which was pretty good, it had a cilantro oil on it.

The bacon wrapped dates were very tasty. I have had bacon wrapped dates at many other restaurants, the difference here is that they were lightly breaded and deep fried. I though that was a nice touch. However, at other places bacon wrapped dates are stuffed with cheese (either a hard cheese like a Parmesan or sometimes a blue cheese). Here no cheese, and adding a nice Parmesan would kick it up a notch.

The veal cheeks were very good in my opinion.

We had a couple other salads including the lobster salad. Probably too much lettuce compared to the other goodies.

We also had the vegetable paella (which was the special) and it was pretty much vegetable paella. It was on the more expensive side (around $18) of the dishes and was not worth it. I would rather have had 2 more interesting dishes.

In the end, I would recommend this restaurant to others because the experience is worth it. The atmosphere and the unique dishes make for a fun time. Keep in mind, the dishes at this restaurant are not as "wild" as Bazaar where he uses several techniques some refer to as molecular gastronomy. But, the dishes are interesting and very palatable. Just don't go in expecting Michelin star quality food and you won't be disappointed.

Price is fairly reasonable for this type of setting. The dishes ranged from about $8 - $20 per dish. Typically looking at about 6 dishes for 2 people.

Enjoy.

Oh, Jaleo... you are great for people watching...

At the table in front of us was what looked to be a call girl and her customer for the evening. We spent some time trying to decide if she was of the "high end" variety and decided that she was not. She definitely looked bored.  To our right was a man in his 40s and a guy in his 20s and a guy who looked to be in his teens.  We spent the majority of our evening trying to determine the relationship here - was it a love triangle? Was he their gigolo? Who knows.. but that's what makes Vegas fun.  Other than that you had the typical bachelor party, a table with 20 dudes, and a table of 4 women in their 40s clearly trying to relive their youth.  

We chose Jaleo because we were planning to go to Marquee after dinner and they are both located in the Cosmopolitan Hotel.  We called from the pool earlier in the afternoon and were told that a table for 4 wouldn't be available until 9:45 pm. It seemed late, but we decided to show up at 9 pm and have a drink at the bar and hope the table opened up sooner, which it did (small tip).

From what I can remember, this is what we ordered:

Croquetas de pollo - Traditional chicken fritters
Mejillones en escabeche - Mussels marinated in Sherry vinegar
Chorizo Palacios - A slightly spicy cured pork sausage seasoned with piment√≥n and garlic
Patatas bravas - A Jaleo favorite with spicy tomato sauce and alioli
Canelones tradicionales de cerdo y h√≠gado de pato con salsa bechamel - Pork and foie gras canelones with bechamel sauce
Mejillones al Vapor - Steamed mussels with bay leaf, lemon and olive oil
Fricand√≥ de carilleras de ternera y pur√© de patatas al aceite de oliva - Veal cheeks and morels with olive oil potato pur√©e
Carne asada con piquillos Juli√°n - de Lodosa - Grilled skirt steak with piquillo pepper confit

Everything was pretty good, but nothing stands out as outstanding enough that I would say that you must order it.  The Patatas Bravas were - to warn you - just seasoned potato chips.  I chose the Canelones tradicionales de cerdo y h√≠gado de pato con salsa bechamel because of the "foie gras" component (you may or may not know that it is illegal in California and I needed my fix) but you couldn't even tell there was foie gras in there, which was disappointing for me.

Food was good, not great, and pricing is what you would expect for a restaurant in the Cosmopolitan (overpriced but at the same time, reasonably priced for where you are).

Not a bad choice, but not the best one.
The space is very nice. All the waiters were very friendly. The food was very good (and creative!) but the taste didn't wow me. The wine list was very expansive. Great for date night!

Fast food tapas! I've had wonderful tapas all through Spain and even here in the US. Jaleo is not wonderful.

The tapas sound good by name, but when you order something like the baby squid with white beans, it's almost all beans and no squid.  

Service was also minimal. I went with a client and our desserts came out 20 minutes apart. Not acceptable.

My recommendation, stay away.

Celebrated our anniversary here tonight! I was hesitant to try because of so so reviews, however we had a friend recommend so we decided to give it a try. So glad we did! The environment, food and service were a five star experience. They gave us the cutest corner booth that viewed the whole dining room. It was pretty quiet when we got there at 7, but by the time we left at 9:15 it was packed. 

We found a reasonable wine that was quite good and started with the bacon dates and chicken croquets. Both were good, but the waiter recommended the iberco (pork), which was melt in your mouth good. The 3 cheese selection was delish and paired well with the pork.

We also tried the potatoes, asparagus and lamb which were prepared well and had unique and bold flavors. We were hesitant to try the paella because we had such a poor experience at Julian Serrano's. ($60 baked rice). We gave it a try anyway and were not disappointed!

If you love Spanish tapas and paella then this is a must try!!!

My husband and I decided to branch out from eating at the Wynn for every meal during our Vegas vacation. We picked Jaleo at the Cosmopolitan because it had vegan options for me. When we arrived, we were greeted warmly and given a vegan and regular menu. The vegan menu itself was pretty small and was more of a vegetarian/vegan menu. But it's nice to see vegan options outside of the Wynn and Encore. I had the tomato bread, gazpacho, and an eggplant-based dish. I was bummed because there was a vegetable paella listed on the vegan menu, but it is only made to feed a large group so I couldn't order it. However, everything was delicious and my 3 plates made a full meal for me. I would rate the food 5 stars. The only bad thing was that it took over an hour to get our meals and the food came out at random intervals (to be fair our server warned us about this), so there would be times that one of us was eating while the other was not. At least there was some great people watching to help make up for it. I definitely recommend Jaleo for groups, but it's not quite right for a romantic date for 2 people (especially when it's hard to share food due to different diets). I'm not sure that we'll be back, but I'm glad we tried it!

Beautiful place with a great ambiance!! The tapas menu is extensive and everything sounded DELISH!!!! My best friend and I split the slider, spinach, and chicken. Everything was mouth watering!! The cocktail list is extensive as well with great offerings!! The hostess and waitstaff were are welcoming and warm!!

Half of the menu was great, the other half was good. Bacon wrapped dates were very good, the saut√©ed spinach very fresh and nice. The waiter did a good job of explaining the menu, but they seemed in hurry to get us out, several times different servers asked if they could take our plates.

One word: salty! The dishes seemed to get saltier and less edible as the meal went on. Generally the ambience is good - festive, well-decorated, signature cocktails and wines with tapas. The menu was bright and cheery and drinks are ordered by iPad. We'd had a massive brunch earlier in the day and so weren't starving, but did split a variety of vegetarian dishes. I noticed the non-vegetarian dishes seemed to be plated quite creatively (one served in a shoe, another served as little cones).

- Pan de cristal con tomate fresco - This was probably our favorite dish. Crusty white bread with a smattering of tomato and olive oil. The tomato was more flavored into the bread, rather than a hunk of tomato sitting on top of it. Good flavor and definitely not too salted.

- Setas en escabeche - These mushrooms were fine. Nothing to write home about. A bit on the saltier end, without enough other flavor.

- Coliflor con olivas y frutos secos - A dish that is usually one of our favorites. Nothing special about it. It was on the more edible side, but again, had too much salt. The over-salting even offset the nice flavor of the fruit.

- Espinacas a la catalana - We have a favorite tapas restaurant in San Francisco that makes this beautifully (Alegrias). Whenever I see this on a menu I think it'll be served like theirs - saut√©ed to perfection with raisins and pine nuts. This felt like a spinach salad with salt poured on. The spinach was not well-sauteed at all.

- For our last dish, we thought we'd ordered a combo of saut√©ed eggplant and onion. We got served some mix of what I believe was eggplant and a lot of cheese. Again, not in love with it.

While I didn't love a lot of the food, I did appreciate that there were many vegetarian items on this tapas menu. Generally, it was fairly reasonably priced compared to many other places in Vegas.

We stopped in at Jaleo for dinner one evening. Since we were not that hungry, we decided to order some Tapas.  We had the following:
Jamon Iberico - cured ham from Spain was absolutely delicious that we ordered a second round.
Manchego Cheese - four tiny slices that were pretty good. The cheese was firm yet had a buttery taste.
Gambas Ajillo - tender shrimp cooked in spicy tomato and garlic sauce.  The sauce was delectable; the shrimp could have been bigger.
Patatas Bravas - fried potatoes that came on a plate layered with spicy tomato sauce and each piece topped with aioli.  This dish was hit as well and filling.
We also had the Red Wine Sangria which was both sweet and had a bit of a kick from the wine. It was perfect.  For a moment, we felt as if we were back in Barcelona.  
Our server was great.  She checked on us periodically without being intrusive.
Overall the food was great and service wonderful.  The ambiance is more casual than some of the other fine dining establishments in the restaurant row.  It is very pricy and fortunately we did enjoy the Tapas. We would come back to try their Paella.

At a conference in Vegas.  The restaurant is located in the new swanky somewhat overdone Cosmopolitan Hotel on the Strip.  But what is not overdone on the strip?

The sangria was great.  Not your typical sugary sangria.  Almost a peppery taste.  We had 3 carafes so I'm assuming all liked it.

Food was good.  One dish was served in a shoe (yes a shoe).  The item tasted great, but the shoe was not a great presentation. 

Table top presentation here seemed to lack overall.  In Vegas you would expect over the top in this arena.  Some more work to be done with this. 

Our table was right next to the dessert action station and they were selling a bunch!  The chocolate flan is to die for.  There was a hot food action station too.  The paella was great.  That evening was rabbit and duck if I recall.  

Would I go back?  Theoretically yes, but there is so much on the Strip to try probably not.

Very noisy - difficult for a business dinner.

Awesome! Go for the best iberico ham and manchego... It's worth it! Love the red sangria. Paella was delicious. My boyfriend is a big meat eater and he loved the paella. Quote: "This is vegetarian food that I would eat."

This place is expensive, but what do you expect? It's in the cosmo and near a bunch of other great restaurants. I bet rent isn't cheap.  Aside from that the food is really great and the service is quite good.  This is one of my top 5 vegas spots. I recommend the experience as part of your Vegas culinary adventure lol.

Our last dinner during my recent Vegas trip. We went on a Monday night. Super easy to get same day reservations on OpenTable.

Drinks:
*Margarita donostiarra: San Sebastian style margarita with arbol chile infused blanco tequila, mezcal, bay leaf syrup, lime ($16)
*Sangria de vino tinto: red wine sangria ($12 glass)

The margarita was really good. I liked the kick from the chili. The sangria was a little too light for me. I wanted it to be stronger. Tasted almost like juice.

Food:
*Chistorra envuelta en patata frita: slightly spicy chorizo wrapped in crispy potato ($11)
*Ostras 'gin & tonic': five pacific oysters with lemon, gin and tonic ($18)
*Paella valenciana 'rafael vidal': a true classic of chicken, rabbit and green beans ($25)
*Croquetas de pollo: traditional chicken fritters ($12)
*Carne asada con escabeche: grilled hanger steak with escabeche ($22)
*Gambas al ajillo: the very, very famous tapa of shrimp sauteed with garlic ($16)

I wasn't super impressed with Jaleo. The paellas available the day we went were the two we didn't really want to eat. Kind of disappointing. Plus the paella was super salty. The chicken fritters were good. Nice and creamy on the inside. But having it served in a shoe kind of grossed me out. I know they're new, but it felt dirty. The hanger steak was good. Nice and tender. But it wasn't really carne asada. And the shrimp was full of flavor. I loved the sauce! Nice and garlicky.

I wanted more from Jaleo. I'm not saying our dinner was bad, but I wanted something more satisfying. Plus, I was really looking forward to trying their paella. Being able to choose from only rabbit and chicken or vegetarian was very disappointing.

Some good dishes, but most left something to be desired.

From the moment I stepped foot into Jaleo the vibe felt unauthentic to me. 

We were first sat at a booth that had hair and crumbs all over the seat. Our first waitress came over and I asked her for a sample of the freshly made pineapple juice and the price. She did not know the price. Five minutes later, our "next" waiter comes by drops off the pineapple juice and does not introduce himself or give us a price.

I did not know what to order. The whimsical descriptions were bothering me and made  none of the descriptions clear. Our new waiter gave us a few recommendations and we chose to start with toasted slices of uniquely crispy bread and saut√©ed spinach with pine nuts, raisins, and apples. What does uniquely crispy bread even mean? Anyways both dishes were overly salted. The bread was a rendition of bruschetta and tasted soggy. Spinach could have been good with the combination of ingredients but once again all I could taste was salt in my mouth. After these dishes, I decided to not order anything else off the menu. 

From the beginning the vibe was uncomfortable. Waiters and waitresses were standing around and talking while watching the dining room. The pig that they were displaying looked diseased. The whole experience was off putting and felt more like Jose Andres capitalizing on tapas being popular than trying to give an authentic Spanish food experience.

We tried a few things here. The ambience is great and cosy. The food was so so. Nothing special. The brussels sprout salad was meh. The croquets were a bit tasty, but paella and shrimp/garlic was so ordinary...

Check in was at 8:30, the service was good, but the wait time for our food was very slow. It was 6 of us so at first it was normal that they would bring out our food on separate  Times but when we would order seconds they would take for ever. In one sitting we would wait at least 30 minutes for our food to come our. The manager is someone that is higher level of the restaurant came out and apologize about our food taking long to come out. Food quality was ok, but for the price not worth it

This is the second Jos√© Andres restaurant I visit and I must say I was a bit disappointed. I made reservations for 8:45 and arrived around 8:30, the restaurant was quite busy but seating was quick at around 9. Once seated I ordered water and a Cuba Libre drink. 

The drink was ok, it wasn't chilled enough for my taste and it comes with a bottle of Pepsi which was warm. I ordered the Chicken Croquetas and they were wonderful. I also ordered the hangar steak medium rare but it came out medium well. I pondered back and fourth if I should send it back or not as I hate sending food back, but eventually decided that I should. The server was wonderful, she was apologetic, and send it back for them to cook make it right. She then offered some paella but I declined as it is not something I like. In the end the steak came out cook perfectly, and to finish dinner I had the flan which was delicious with its citrus spin. 

The server made it right in the end by not charging me for the steak which made up for the mistakes and the long time it took to get it back after sending it back. 

However, I will stick to Bazaar Meats in terms of flavor and overall experience.

First and last time - this is much more about me not being the ideal customer for this establishment. The appetizer chorizo sausage they brought out served at room temperature/cold was "ok" at best. Definitely nothing exciting and not recommended. The tomato bread was also "ok" - toasted bread with some tomato spread. Overall this tasted like Bruschetta and was loaded with vinegar (tons of sodium). So moving on and at this point they are 0 for 2. Next up was the soup in the glass cup which again was nothing to brag about. 0 for 3 - then there was the salad swimming in the sherrie vinaigrette - 0 for 4. Then came their signature meal the paella - so this was also not impressive. In simple terms it was more like burnt rice with an oily base and chicken. 0 for 5. All this for two people @ $90. I have had better meals at Panera.

Jaleo is hard to review.

On one hand all the food was awesome. Slightly salty, but really amazing. We literally just went down the entire list and ordered everything.

On the other hand, you are taking tapas that normally should be 1/4th the price and "upscaling" them. It's not exactly a budget friendly restaurant.

The staff was nice, and like I said the food was very good. 

If you are hungry, don't expect to be satiated. This is more of a tasting menu than somewhere you can feed your hunger.

It was a fun experience with the family. We decided to take our parent on their anniversary here for dinner. And we're glad we were able to try there food. Our servers were friendly and made our experience enjoyable. I'm sorry if I don't remember there names. But let cut go the chase here. FOOD! We had quite a few plates of food to try out. Unfortunately we didn't know that they only make certain paella everyday. But the day we went. We either had the choice of the Paella Valenciana 'Rafael Vidal or Arroz de verduras de temporada. But we chose the first one. It was a unique because we never had Rabbit before. But it taste just like chicken. We also order the dry-cured meat variety selection plate. It was very tasteful and they recommended to get it with the tomato spread bread. With was delicious. We also added the addition of the 4 years dry-cured Jam√≥n. Which had a very interesting taste to it. But none the less. It was still good. We also order the Squid ink pasta. Don't be fool by it color when it comes out. It was yummy. And our overall experience I would say they definitely earn the 5 stars.

I know that Jose Andres is a very talented and incredible chef, and this location inside the fabulous, newly opened Cosmopolitan will improve over time. I love tapas and Jaleo has done a good job at creating some delicious dishes.  Off the top of my head, the pan con tomate (tomato bread), endibias conqeso (endives with goat cheese, oranges and Almonds) and the garlic shrimp were wonderful...include the pitcher of sangria and the evening was a memorable one.

The only bad item was one they take some much pride in...paellas, and this evening they happen to feature the lobster paellas. The lobster was grilled to perfection and very delicious, however the paellas was very crunchy...possibly undercooked al dente-style. And nothing is worse than crunchy rice.  Sad, as I was really looking forward to this.

The server got extremely busy as the restaurant started to fill, but a host overheard our dissatisfaction and gladly offered to remove it from the final bill.

It gets real busy at 8:00, so unless you book ahead, you could be sitting outside watching others enjoying their meal.

Again, with a little more time to work out some kinks, and an opportunity to closely monitor the food quality, this will be a great place to impress friends.  Already The Cosmopolitan has built the visually-pleasing infrastructure.

upscale but not snobby, Jaleo is a great spot for venturing into the world of tapas.

the fried eggplants come out to be almost like zeppole, even drizzled with honey for additional sweetness. we had a goat cheese which was pretty good, but I can't recall which. the knockout meal was the rabbit/chicken paella (yes, a paella that I'd eat!) - a great contrast of flavors and textures.

of course, had to wrap it up with flan with cream and oranges to finish!

service was friendly, warm, and helpful

overall, it was moderately priced, and we left satisfied but not tummy-achingly full. I would definitely come back. and they're on Opentable!

Jaleo is excellent. 

Service - our waiter, Patrick, was all class and a cool guy. He created a nice flow with our dishes and kept our waters full and cocktails coming. He knew the menu well and this is one of those restaurants where that's important, cuz you're going to be ordering around 3 dishes per person. 

Food - I really liked the tapas style and we ordered - bacalao, piquillo peppers, chicken and mushroom paella, a sharp smokey cheese plate, scallops, and the Iberica Bellota Jamon. The paella was the best I've had outside of Spain and my grandma's house. My buddy and I almost wanted more, addictive stuff. The Jamon was crazy good. Those 2 dishes really stood out, as some of the tastiest things I've eaten in a while. The rest of the meal was solid, tasty and well executed. We finished with french toast topped with vanilla ice cream and apples. It was a delicious, please order it. 

Drinks - this place has the best gin and tonics you'll ever have, they have 5 different ones and the Citrico was my favorite. Order them, trust me. Also the coffee was really really good, my buddy, whose not a coffee guy, loved it. It comes out in a french press with hour glass type timers to let you know when it's ready, and it tells you when it's reached light/medium/dark roast. 

Price - worth it. 

Environment - it's a pretty fancy place, but feels fun and not stuffy. It's well decorated, as is every little detail in the Cosmopolitan, that place is so sexy. Perfect for dates. 

Go here, it's delicious.

After winning a small jackpot at cosmopolitan we dedicated our prize to this amazing dinner experience on Christmas eve dinner. We had their bellota paella, patas brava, white asparagus, shrimp in garlic tomato sauce, and the lamb ribs. Everything was made to perfection and tasty. Our server was amazing and very helpful in helping us ordering and accommodated us with two of the best desserts I have ever had on the house because according to him some of our dishes took a bit longer to come out. Will definitely go back and try more dishes.

Let me start by saying our server was great and the star rating has nothing to do with her, she gets 4 stars. 

The double star, and I'm being nice, is for the horrid "Tapas" style food served at this make believe small plates Tapas restaurant. Let's just say if I wanted to eat boiled potatoes dripping in oil, well..I wouldn't. Last time I checked Patatas Bravas are fried ...but what do I know?  

Yeah, it's busy...and swanky..but what isn't at the cosmopolitan? Save your money. Go somewhere else. Perhaps Capos...I'm sure they know how to make authentic italian.

An ok dinner experience.  The food was good, but...  I'm a big fan of tapas, but the portions are extremely small.  We were all hungry after dinner.  Sangria is good here.  With all the other Spanish and tapas style choices in Las Vegas, I would not return.

Jaleo is fun! Great friendly vibe, nice open dining area. And the food is great! Portions are tapas-size and enough for two people to share. If you're a party of 4 hungry adults, consider doubling every order. Comes up to about $80 a head (before tip) with one drink each. Not too bad considering the food is a blend of fine dining and molecular gastronomy. I often regard Jaleo as The Bazaar's little sister, with a more casual feel. 

My favorites:
-- The Ultimate Spanish Tapa (essentially a warm tuna and potato salad, but the tuna is out-of-this-world flavorful)
-- Grilled Whole Quail
-- Croquetas de Pollo (be careful, sometimes there are tiny chicken bones in these)
-- Coliflor Con Olivas Y Frutos Secos (saut√©ed cauliflower with dates and olives)

The chicken and rabbit paella (Paella Valenciana 'rafael Vidal'), which was the first paella in rotation that night, wasn't very  good, unfortunately. The ib√©rico de bellota pig paella that came next sounded a lot better, but we weren't going to order another one.

The $48 Fermin spanish ham platter came with barely enough meat for 4 people, as did the manchego cheese plate, which only had two slices of cheese! Hmph!

Service was friendly, but the pace was a bit slow at times.

This place has great ambience and speedy seating which makes it a great place to go when u've arrived at the Cosmo later in the evening. 

Service wasn't as prompt as I would have liked. We had to ask for our server multiple times and it seemed like maybe there weren't enough waiters on the floor to provide timely service.

The food is definitely on the salty side which wasn't favorable to me. We had the tuna, scallop, and shrimp tapas along with the sausage paella which was the only option besides the rabbit one.

I must say the scallops were the most delicious. Loved how they perfectly pan fired it with butternut squash paste. The tuna wasn't horrible but i didnt like all the sesame on it. It was overpowering and added additional saltiness. The sausage paella was alright. The pork was good but sausage was too much for me. By the time the shrimp tapa came out, i was all salted out. Could not eat another bite.

I had white wine which was delicious and the spanish toast at the end which was pretty good. Needed something sweet after all the salt. 

Didn't feel the greatest after eating here the next morning. I prob won't be back but it was a good place to try at least once.
I have never been a fan of brussels sprouts and now I'm a fan if it's peeled and cooked. Sooo good!  Get the saut√©ed mushrooms and egg cavier as well. These 3 were my fav.

Mouais bon... Premi√®re soir√©e √† Vegas et ce restaurant me laisse un petit go√ªt amer... Non pas que c'√©tait mauvais, au contraire, mais qu'on s'entende bien, payer 115 dollars tip included pour quatre assiettes de tapas, deux desserts, un verre de vin, une bi√®re, deux caf√©s et un pan con tomate, je trouve √ßa tout simplement hors de prix...!

Il ne faut quand m√™me pas abuser... 10 dollars les patatas bravas... compos√©es de chips recouvertes de ketchup et sauce piment√©e ? Hmm, comment dire... Ca fait un peu mal quand m√™me ! M√™me si le go√ªt n'√©tait pas si mal...!

Pourquoi je mets 3 √©toiles et pas 2, alors ? Parce que le cadre est tr√®s sympa, parce que c'est Las Vegas et qu'on √©tait content de trouver un restaurant pas trop kitsch et √† l'ambiance branch√©e sans en faire des tonnes. Mais bon, sinc√®rement pour ce prix l√†, j'esp√®re qu'il y a mieux ailleurs !!

Just experienced dinner here two days ago.  Service was led by this dude who thought he was hilarious.  He was entertaining for the first 4 minutes and then like nails on a chalkboard for the remainder of the meal.

Ask him for a gluten free menu?  He forgot.  Can I get another glass of wine?  Too busy comparing notes over in the corner with other wait staff.  

Food was so-so.  Chorizo came in little quarter slices...maybe 8 of them on a paper towel thing.  Cheese plate was good but ridiculously meager.  

On the plus side, sliders were great and suprisingly filling.  Shrimp with garlic was good.  Peppers stuffed with goat cheese was yummy.  Flank steak was also very good.  We particularly enjoyed the red peppers and eggplant dish.
