It kind of reminded me of the cream cheese won tons, but better!  The lobster paella had a very good presentation, but it was a little difficult to eat.  I wish they had pulled the meat out of the shell for us.  We were all dressed up to go out, so we didn't want to get down and dirty to eat that lobster.  The rice was nice and tasty, but we just couldn't fully enjoy the lobster.

We had to pass on dessert since we were way too full.  Service was good, and prices are reasonable.

Delicious!  My husband and I loved everything we had.  Maybe not worth the $20 for their specialty gin and tonic, but the food was outstanding.  Yes, it's pricey, but everything was in Vegas!  

As for the atmosphere it is lively and loud.  I wouldn't consider it romantic.

Excellent food, wine and service. However, if you do not like Spanish cuisine, then this is probably not the place for you. While it is not traditional, it's still Spanish enough; which for us is Heaven! Jose Andres is a genius and Jaleo is a masterpiece. We dine here every time we are in Vegas.

We went to Jaleo before my bf caught a flight to Asia and he wanted to get some solid food before his 10+ hour flight. Well, I went back to get one thing - Jamon iberico!!!  We decided to make it easier and went for a tasting menu "the Jaleo experience".  To me, as long as I could have some Jamon iberico I was the happiest human in a mile radius.  Paella with chicken, rabbit and green beans 'Rafael Vidal' was good as well as croquetas de pollo.  Maybe next time around I might want to try out more exotic selection like other reviewers did!

Very disappointing. I was expecting a lot better from a Jose Andres restaurant. It was very hit and miss. Some things were excellent and some were really bad. With all the choices in Vegas, I would not return.

Jaleo is one of our favorite restaurants in Vegas. We love tapas and they also offer many kinds of paella.

We always sit at the bar because we get great service and get to ask for suggestions. 

They change the menu but love their lamb and scallop dishes. This time we tried their air dryer chorizo and the mini pepito burgers.  This was also our first time trying the paella.  We had the chicken and mushroom. It was great.

We always have a Tempranillo with dinner.  Food came out quickly and bartenders were very helpful. 

We love watching them make the paella. Great atmosphere where the restaurant is.  There is a place to play pool right outside the restaurant. We will be back again.

Food and atmosphere were terrific but the true stand out - the gin and tonic. Easily the best G&T I've ever had in the States. Large ice cube (a must in a good drink) and perfect combination of good gin and a crisp tonic. At $20 a pop it is a splurge (funny, it only costs $14 at Jaleo in D.C) but worth the indulgence. 

As for the food, the tapas we ordered were all good. Chorizo and manchego cheese cut perfectly and flavorful. So too was the tomato bread.  The croquettes were as described ('a chicken pot pie in every bite") but I do wonder why it came served in a sneaker. No need for gimmick when you have food this good.

And, lastly, the service was spot on. Nice to have a server with an opinion. Trust the staff to lead your way and stretch yourself to try things you may not have in the past. 

Overall, great experience and would def. return.

My second time eating at Jaleo!!!  Sat at the bar this time and I have to say that I am so glad that we did.  Enjoyed it much more than sitting at a table.  The bartenders and staff were super chatty and fun and made some great recommendations on drinks - particularly the Gin & Tonics.  SO glad we found out about those!  They were yummy!

every year when I come to vegas jaleo is a must. the service, ambiance and of course food is always excellent. my favorites are the shrimp with garlic, chicken croquettes, pan con tomate & paella. on our most recent visit the manager erik went above and beyond for my dads birthday. thanks!

I really wanted to love this place and I tried to.  In fact there were a couple things that I did really like, but overall, this place missed the mark for me.  

We started with the pan con tomate, which was very good.  The bread was very tasty, as was the fresh tomato grated on top, then finished with a delicious olive oil.  

Next, we ordered the potatas bravas.  This dish was a complete fail.  Instead of the classic fried or boiled potatoes covered in a spicy pimenton sauce, this dish is a a bowl of potato chips that was emptied into a bowl and then two cold sauces squirted over the top.  The first sauce was a tomato based sauce with some paprika flavor, but seemed a little off.  The second sauce was a mayo/garlic aioli.  This dish was terrible.

Next, came the chicken croquetas.  These were pretty tasty, they had a nice creamy texture and good flavor.  They oddly came served in a shoe.

Then we ordered the Chistorra envuelta en patata frita.  This dish was little pieces of mildly spicy chorizo that was wrapped in a potato chip.  The chorizo was tasty, but being wrapped in the potato chip fell flat for me and I wasnt really impressed, not a bad dish though.

Next was the Chorizo casero con pur√© de patatas al aceite de oliva.  This dish was another that was pretty tasty and largely because of the chorizo.  The potato puree that it was served on was also tasty and had a nice creamy texture.  Where this dish turned a little south was in the cidre sauce, which did not taste much like cidre and instead more like Worcestershire.  The other element that was a little too much was the amount of large pieces of sea salt sprinkled on the dish.  This dish has promise, I just thought the execution was off.

Finally, we ordered the Mini pepito de ib√©rico and this was the highlight of the meal.  This is a burger slider made with iberico pork, topped with iberico bacon, a roasted pepper and a delicious aioli type sauce.  This little two bite slider was great and I should have made a meal out of just these.  However, at eight dollar a piece, that is an expensive two bites.  I am glad we ordered these last because they were the best item we had.

Overall, I think this place is using very good ingredients and doing some cool things with the traditional tapas, I just was not a fan of their interpretation of the things that I tried.  Also, this place is very expensive.  For the above mentioned tapas and one glass of sangria (which was very tasty), the bill was just over $100.  The ingredients are quality, but this cost for tapas is just crazy, no doubt because of being located on the strip and carrying a famous chef's name.  We will not be going back sans some special occasion prompted by someone else.

¬°Saludos a volver por la buena comida! With so many wonderful internationally recognized chef owned restaurants located on the Strip, we returned to Jose Andr√©s' Jaleo for a Spanish lunch. We had just arrived into Las Vegas only a few hours prior to our noontime reservation and we were excited for a taste of paella and other tapas.  

Our server, Jason, greeted us with friendly familiarity and described the lunch menu as an abbreviated or highlighted dinner menu that we were familiar with from previous dines. We started with cocktails and ordered their 3-course lunch special. Jason piqued my interest with a cocktail called "Con Membrillo" that was a Seasonal concoction of quince paste, rum, egg white and nutmeg. There were probably more ingredients in that cocktail that I don't just remember listing.  But, after a couple of smooth sips, I was transported to Madrid's Plaza Mayor in Fall. My husband ordered a Spanish beer, Estrella Damm Inedit Witbier to begin his "journey".  Meanwhile, our order of Jam√≥n Ib√©rico Ferm√≠n with picos arrived.  It was a small plate of porky deliciousness that melted like butter as soon as it hit your tongue. The paper-thin slices were paired with crisp "picos" or mini breadsticks.  We both ordered the Complete Spanish Lunch that was a 3-course meal. It started with Ensalada Verde (Bibb lettuce, red onions and sherry dressing), Gazpacho estilo Algeciras (classic chilled Spanish soup made with tomato, cucumber, peppers and bread) and Paella del Dia (today's special featured chicken and mushrooms). It was a value for its price at $26 per person. Jason brought out each course in a timely succession...we weren't in a rush and had the time to savor the flavors. The food was well-seasoned and we were seated to watch the chef prepare the paella over the open-fire wood burning grill. We liked Jason's attentiveness, efficiency and positive attitude.

Ok, so if you haven't gotten on the Tapas bandwagon, it's time.  

Ever since traveling to Barcelona a few years ago, I've grown to love tapas.  I simply like small plates in a great social atmosphere!  You can enjoy great cocktails & wine without getting overstuffed on huge, mammoth, super-size meals that is the norm these days.  

I really liked the selection of tapas here.  They had a great little shrimp tapas that was simply delicious (sorry name eludes me). 

Their wine selection was very good; lot's of light to medium bodied reds and refreshing whites to compliment most of all the plates.

The place was very, very crowded and unfortunately the service lacked a bit which is why the 3 star.  Could have been an off night for the service team or perhaps they werer simply overwhelmed by the number of people.

If yoiu want great atmosphere, good food and drinks, this is a good place.

enjoy~!

This place is really an amazing stop.  I was in Vegas for a bachelor weekend with my best friend and 4 other guys.  Be stayed at the Jockey club attached to this place.  After some careful planning prior to our trip to Vegas, we came across this place for dinner.  The food was amazing.  The chicken is so tender, and the staff seems very enthusiastic.  I have eaten a lot of tapas at different places across the country, but this is hands down the best I have ever had.  If your in Vegas in the cosmo or near bye.  Check this place out.

It will be difficult to put into words how wonderful the food was, but I'll try. When we first arrived we were greeted with kindness and a smile. We were taken to our table and immediately greeted by our wait staff and had drinks within minutes. We were already happy before the food even arrived. When we did have our courses, it was like the food was dancing in my mouth. From the jamon iberico, to the endives, to sliders, paella and back. It wasn't just a meal. It was experience. Chef Matthew means business. Eat here and i guarantee you and your palette will be pleased.

we had a veritable feast at jaleo during my last trip to las vegas. 

the experience was lovely! i had been to jaleo in dc and not been particularly impressed, but the vegas restaurant is a whole other story. i loved our experience.

it felt like we basically ate and drank our way through espana! yum. we started, por supuesto, with the sangria. which was wonderful. not overly sweet and filled with lots of fruit! we ate...well, alot. we opted for one of the cheese plates, which turned out to be an excellent choice- the cheeses ranged from hard to soft and in taste. we then moved to several of the small dishes, including a chorizo wrapped in a potato (!) and a paella tapa that really stood out. we left stuffed, slightly tipsy and happy. 

i have to make a special point to say that our waiter was awesome- he totally catered the meal to us, making great suggestions based on what we had previously. he was right on the money with all of his suggestions. though the atmosphere is a little lacking...it sort of feels like a mall restaurant, the food more than makes up for it.

Perfectly executed mushroom paella ( the only one ready at the time but we were delighted), Ajilon shrimp, lamb, and even the green beans were strange but familiar all at the same time. Similar to the DC Jaleo in quality but didn't hVe the special Minibar apps. Must have the Iberico Jamon( the one that's acorn fed). I'm not a gin and tonic fan, but because of the reviews of other Yelpers, I tried it and would order it again.  Needless to say we were stuffed.  We got about 2-3 tapas dishes for ea person plus paella and it was more than enough. 

Again, with this Jose Andres Restaurant and David Chang's Momofuku, the Cosmopolitan Hotel is a worthy destination in itself.
My only regret from Vegas is that I didn't discover this wonderful tapas place until my last night here.  Inventive flavors, exquisite presentations, and beautiful decor.  What's not to love?

First of all, let me just open this review with my frank question: I do not understand how in the hell people are not enjoying this awesome restaurant? 

After two evenings of fine dining on the strip, my BF told me he's had enough of it, and he wanted something more relaxing. After I was forcibly concurred with his opinion, I immediately cancelled our reservations with Jo√´l Robuchon and suggested tapas for dinner. Luckily, his highness granted my suggestion and told me to pick one that's good enough so I'll be able to keep my head. Of course, at first I was a bit dubious since I read tons of not-so-good reviews about Jaleo, and had Julian Serrano in mind. But then I thought to myself: I enjoyed China Poblano and SAAM (back in Los Angeles,) how bad can Jos√© Andr√©s' Jaleo be? As it turned out, I've made the right decision!!

The restaurant itself is conveniently located on the third floor of Cosmopolitan, which is where we were already staying at... We were seated promptly upon arrival (unlike Le Cirque...,) and our wonderful server Paul M. couldn't had been nicer. He's attentive, and made lots of knowledgeable suggestions throughout the entire meal. 

Since Jaleo is famous for its Gin and Tonics, Paul M. suggested "C√≠trico" to me, which was light and refreshing as he described. My BF opted for a carafe of red sangria, and every sip was heavenly accompanied with the citric taste. And if none of these drinks interest you, don't panic, they have their drink menu well organized on an iPad for you to pick.

As a given, neither me nor my BF understand Jaleo's extensive tapas menu, luckily Paul M. was there to save the day. Based on our palates, Paul M. made the following suggestions: "Vieiras con mojo rojo y polvo de almendras" (two large scallops served with mojo rojo sauce, seared to just the right point, very juicy and tender,) "Gambas al ajillo" (Garlic Shrimp, at first I thought it was going to be similar to China Poblano's "shrimp mojo," Paul ensured me they're total different dishes. He was right, very garlicky just the way I like it, ) "Croquetas de pollo" (chicken fritters, served in a shoe, I think everyone is talking about this dish here, need I say more?) Costillas de cordero Moruno (rack of lamb, we ordered it medium rare, though it came out pinker than we expected, it didn't stop me from picking up the bones and chewing the meat off. Yes, I did that at Jaleo inside of Cosmopolitan!! ) Mini pepito de ib√©rico (Spanish mini Bugrer, a personal favorite of mine. My first time tasting Spanish ib√©rico pig. Fattening, yes, but trust me, it's worth the risk of getting your arteries clogged up. ) Paella Valenciana 'Rafael Vidal' (Chicken and rabbit paella, personally I couldn't differentiate the rabbit from chicken, but the paella itself was amazing, crispy and brunt.) Bacon wrapped dates (this dish was actually deep fried and served on an alioli-like sauce, tangy and sweet,) flan (Paul highly recommended this creamy flan, and it's beyond any flans we've ever tasted before. I especially love how it's served with mango sorbet, wiped cream and tangerines. Believe me, it works! ) and lastly, the olive oil ice cream (the rich olive oil with grapefruit sorbet plus chunks of grapefruit, citrusy and creamy at the same time.)

The ambiance in the restaurant was just simply romantic yet trendy, not to mention "√©" the tasting kitchen is also located inside of Jaleo. I cannot wait until the next time when I visit Jaleo/Cosmopolitan again and try the famous √©!!

One of the best meals of my life.  My boyfriend and I went here for my birthday two years ago but I'm sure nothing has changed.

Place is very busy - so if you want it to be more intimate then maybe someplace else - but if you wanna go and enjoy people watching and enjoy amazing food come here!  My sister is moving to Vegas next year for two years at the Aria and so we'll definitely be here again!

We ordered cocktails - I got one with a sugared rim soo good! and boyfriend got a blood and sand.  Then we ordered about 15 plates of tapas!  I honestly can't remember everything we ordered but the lamb riblets and the monkfish were out of this world - the cheese and salads - the endive, goat cheese and orange salad were to die for, the sweet onions pine nuts and blue cheese! ugh soo good.

The bill was like $200 bucks but so worth it.  One of the best foodie experiences of my life! Now off the Bazaar in Beverly Hills.  Gotta save my allowance haha.

We walked in around 9pm without reservations and asked to be seated.  They told us there's a wait because all the tables are reserved.  fyi, only 1/4 of the restaurant is occupied.  Ten minutes later we're are seated and we order.  There's a list of different paellas on the menu, but the chef only has two on rotation each night, which they failed to tell us.  Whatever, not a big deal, we just want to snack a little

We order the sea urchin toast appetizer and chicken/mushroom paella. Both were SALTY, but that was expected with the sea urchin toast because it had ham. That aside, it has to be the worst paella I've ever had in my life, or at least in the States. This is the first time I've had paella served on a white dish, usually it comes on a pan. 

When we left, the tables around remained unoccupied. Now I understand why this place only has 3 stars.  Skip it.

Delicious food as always. Started out with thinly sliced fried eggplant with local honey drizzled on top. I will be attempting to duplicate this at home when we harvest eggplant out of the garden. 

Ordered the sausage and short rib paella. It was plenty for two. Sangria was very flavorful. Reasonably priced for a nice sitdown meal (not buffet) in Vegas

The bread with tomato spread is truly traditional Spain. It was SO good. Go - do yourself a favor and just get a snack, add manchego for added amazing flavors. Enjoy their sangria too, Madrid like and not too sweet. Great service at the bar too.

Jaleo is the archetypal Spanish experience, very simular to the dining in Madrid and Barcelona. The options were plenty so went with the tasting menu at 68 a pop. This includes 11 dishes and dessert.
Overall, the experience was very pleasant. The food was filling and delicious. Everything was unique. However, the servers were not too family friendly and did not accomodate us. The ambiance was not comfortable. I had to speak very loudly to be heard across the table.

Pricey. Happy hour is not really happy hour. It's half price for half the serving of food. We found this out upon ordering patatas bravas. It was cheaper to order the full size in fact. Service was great. Menu is HUGE. Nice vibe to sit and order a bit at a time enjoying the company you keep. Until the bill comes and your tummy and wallet are still a little empty.
The food is great but portions are really small, even for tapas. Come for the great wine and tastes but expect to be ready for a burger when you leave.

Very nice restaurant, good environment, friendly staff. We both had the Chef's menu (about 11 courses) and a pitcher of sangria. We didn't like that we could not see what the dishes were beforehand. The menu was not what we expected since Spanish food was not well represented and they generally didn't bring fresh plates and silver wear when we changed courses (expected in a restaurant of this level). On the bright side, Portions were very generous. The menu (Not in any specific order): 
- Gaspacho: not good, tasted too much like cucumber and not tomato
- Bread with tomato: amazing
- Manchego cones: very good
- Prosciutto grilled sandwich with Manchego and truffle oil - we did not enjoyed warm prosciutto and it mainly tasted like truffle oil only. 
- Spinach: simple but good
- Lomo: great
- Mussels: very good
- Blue cheese: french cheese, not Spanish
- Paella: fair
- Carne asada: good
- Dessert: very good!
Service was awesome. 
Sangria tasted too much like Cointreau. 
If we came back, we would order the chef's menu again.

Just got done eating at Jaleo and couldn't even wait to write a review. This place was just phenomenal. 

My husband and I were looking for a bite to eat but nothing too heavy. We scoped out the menu and decided to try it and I'm so glad we did. 

We were seated immediately and given some menus. We were only ordering a few things and a couple drinks. Our waitress was helpful in making suggestions and commended us with what we ordered which was quite nice. 

The drink menu is on an iPad which I found amusing. I had a glass of white sangria while my husband had the Clara which is beer and lemonade. He loved his drink. I wasn't as into it but it wasn't bad. I loved my sangria. A fresh new take with the cinnamon stick, dried apricot, and basil. 

Now onto the food:
Chicken croquettes - like a fried chicken pot pie. They were amazing. I just wasn't crazy about the presentation to be honest. Food in a shoe is just not appealing. 

Bacon wrapped dates - deep fried dates with this delicious apple onion mustard sauce, what could be bad about that?! It was excellent. 

Warm brussels sprout salad with grapes and Serrano ham - I loved the tang from the vinegar with the sweetness of the fruit and the salty bite of the ham. It was perfect. 

Slider-perfectly cooked meat, charred bread, caramelized onions, and bacon?! Best ever. 

Salmon tartare cone-my husband loved this bite. Especially the dill. 

Patatas bravas- the aioli and spicy tomato sauce worked well together and the potato still had excellent texture. 

Everything was delicious and paced well and all the staff worked together and we were never without food on our plates or water in our glasses. It was an excellent meal and the price was quite reasonable for the quality. I was very impressed!

Muy delicioso, elegante, y chevere! I greatly enjoyed the cuisine and the excellent service. My tastebuds were totally satisfied and I will be sure to visit Jaleo upon my return to Las Vegas...it was one of the highlights of my trip. Lovely ambiance and super Latin fusion.

This place was a nice discovery. The place was very entertaining. The energy is high, the menus were interesting and everything we ordered tasted amazing. Their goat cheese melted in your mouth, the shrimp was delicious, the potatoes were perfectly cooked and their beef was so juicy. Would def be back next time were in Vegas!

Jaleo. (4 stars).

"Jaleo: a lively dance of Andalusian origin, or the music or handclapping that accompanies it." - Google

For anyone who has watched Chef Jos√© Andr√©s on TV or met him in person, u can understand why he would call this restaurant Jaleo.

Chef Andr√©s is known the world over for his Spanish tapas & his jovial take on cuisines from around the world. Chef Andr√©s is also known as one of the first chefs (if not the first) to bring the tapas dining concept to America.

"Tapas: small Spanish savory dishes, typically served with drinks at a bar." - Google

¬°Salud! = Cheers!!

I love watching Chef Andr√©s on TV as he has such a passion & a desire to share his food with the world as well as learn the history & cultures of other countries so he can create fusion dishes.

Disclaimer: I have never been to Spain so I'm not an expert when it comes to Spanish food or tapas.

Luckily for us, our friend, once again came to the rescue & made reservations for lunch.

We had a hard time finding Jaleo, which is located in the Cosmopolitan on the 3rd floor because there weren't any signs on the casino floor. Well at least none that we could see??

After waiting in anticipation to try Chef Andr√©s' Jaleo... we did what any other visitor would do!!

We ordered the following:

Lunch like a Spaniard. (4 stars).

A great way to try more plates!!

For $25 per person (+$7 for paella of the day if desired), u can choose 1 item from 3 courses. This meal was a fantastic experience.

---

Ensalada verde con anchoas (Anchovy Salad). Whoa mama!! I loved this salad but it was verging on salt overload even for me.

I heart fresh anchovies & the dressing was bursting with flavor from the fried capers to the romesco garlic dressing & the Idiaz√°bal cheese, but the mixture was potent. Good.

I had to have a beer just to combat the salt intake... Wait, do I really need a reason to have a beer??

---

Tichi's Gazpacho is served cold & was incredibly refreshing! Having only had gazpacho once before, this version was light & packed with a flavorful blend of tomatoes, cucumbers, & peppers. Very good.

---

I have to say the Carne Asada (Hangar Steak) was the highlight of my meal.

The steak was extremely tender & seasoned perfectly with a sprinkle of sea salt. I'm still having dreams about this dish.

It was prepared perfectly.

When steak is grilled over an open flame, it takes on a smokiness that can never be duplicated with any other method of cooking.

Excellent!!

---

The Endibias con queso de cabra y naranjas (Endives) were so fresh & crunchy!

A great starter.

The oranges & almonds were a perfect touch. I thought the oranges would be sweet but they were subtle & juicy. Very good.

---

Gambas al ajillo (Garlic Shrimp). This could be where my extremely uneducated & amateur palate shows brightly... or is it dimly??

I really enjoyed the juicy plump deveined shrimp but the sauce which consists of a saut√©ed garlic sauce was a bit too pungent for my liking.

Since the garlic was simmering for a while, the garlic became soft & extremely sweet. I am used to a more savory garlicky flavor vice a sweet garlic flavor. Decent, but I would probably pass on this dish the next time.

---

Chicken & Rabbit Paella. The special of the day. The chicken & rabbit were tender & juicy.

I couldn't taste any gaminess with the rabbit which was nice.

I LOVE & SEARCH FOR PAELLA WITH SOCARRAT!! That crispy crunchy rice is so addicting!! Now it very well could be that I shared the BF's order so I waited for him to try it first... but my few bites were not exactly mine-blowing. The flavors were smoky & seasoned perfectly but the soccarat seemed to evade me.

My portion was, dare I say, just a tad bit "wet" in consistency. But still delicious.

I truly appreciated the paella being cooked over an open flame which is why I would still recommend the paella!

***

Chef Andr√©s has proved to me why he is an ever-present force to be reckoned with in the culinary world!

Absolutely amazing service & presentation.

If I could eat like this everyday... I would be even fatter!! But the 3-4 course meal was an experience I would like to have again & again!!

Lunch Like A Spaniard is definitely worth the price! Each dish was just the right amount of food to share & still leave satisfied!!!

I was absolutely mesmerized by the paella station!! It's such a "poetic" moment for me to see a dish I love so much be prepared in a authentic paella pan cooked over an open flame!!

To be able to taste the dishes of a renowned chef is always a great moment in my life!!

Volver√© = I WILL RETURN!!

Really a 3.5 but kind of overpriced for what you get IMO.  Also I didn't care for a couple of the dishes at all and I was annoyed that I had to keep flagging down the waiter.

Standout dishes:  Carne asada, lamb, paella with iberico ribs, chicken croquetas.

Their chicken was not very good and I wouldn't recommend that at all, and although I enjoyed the pan de cristal con tomate fresco, I sure as hell didn't think it was worth $12 a plate.  

Also I was annoyed they didn't have the salt foam margaritas that they have at the DC location.  

Overall, most of the food was quite good but everything was generally overpriced.

Super expensive and total rubbish food. Olives were too salty, Pork was dry and burnt, paella was too fishy, and server never asked how our food was.

Had to leave the chef a message:

The environment was ok but not the unforgettable ambiance for fancy dining. The food is of small portions unless you order from the large plate menus which is also small. The service was ok but I had to ask for my drink two different time from two separate waiters to get it. 

We had the Vieiras con mojo rojo y polvo de almendras which is the scallops dish. This was not very pleasant. Bitter and over cooked. I will never order this dish again and recommend no one eat this.  Not good at all. The Gambas al ajillo which is the shrimp and garlic dish was very delicious and packed with really great flavors. This was the main reason I gave this place any stars at all. The garlic was sooo good and the shrimp was perfectly cooked. We also had there Carne asada con piquillos 'Juli√°n de Tolosa'* which is there grilled banger steak dish.  It was perfectly cooked to medium temp and crusted.  The steak was juicy and really good. I just wish it was a larger portion dish. 

Overall the food was ok but I would not be returning to eat at this place. For the 4 small dishes we had and one fountain drink we paid $118.25. Way over priced for the small portions of ok food.

Jos√© Andr√©s restaurant Jaleo in Las Vegas, NV will truly give you a flavorful and exciting experience! The place is sexy and filled with an energy that will keep you wanting more!

Make sure to start off your meal with their Margarita Donostiarra. One of the best margaritas I have ever had! It's spicy and packed with flavor - but don't worry, it's not too hot! With arbor-infused blanc tequila, bay leaf syrup, lime and a sherry salt rim, this drink will kick start your flavorful ride the right way!

The menu is loaded with endless Spanish tapas and paellas options. One item that blew my mind was the mini pepito de ib√©rico, which is a Spanish mini burger made from the legendary, acorn-fed, black-footed ib√©rico pigs of Spain with ib√©rico bacon. Absolutely one of the best tapas i've ever gotten to enjoy! A soft buttery bun and tender meat this bite is filled with different flavors guaranteed to satisfy you.

With some of the best service I have ever had, the Jaleo team kept the food coming!

If you are looking for an energetic, fun and delicious place to eat make sure to visit Jaleo inside The Cosmopolitan Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, NV! The service will impress you, the food won't disappoint you and the energy is guaranteed to show you a flavorful and impressive time!

See my full review here: http://corkedandporked.com/2015/06/26/jose-andres-jaleo/

I was so very pleased with this restaurant, with 20 of my closest friends traveling to Vegas, trying to secure a reservation without mortgaging my house was a feat in and of itself. Lauren was so helpful in setting up a wonderful menu for us with a reasonable price per head. When we arrived, they were ready for us, complete wiht a tasting menu with my name on it (such a cute little surprise), we must have tried over half the menu. At first I was a little concerned that there would not  be enough, boy was I wrong! There was plenty of food,  and it was all delicious!!! They were even obliging to the 1 vegetarian (I had advised thm of this up front, with the hope that it would be worked out at the time without incident :( but a quick chat with the manager and it was accommodated) offering her a couple of additional dishes to replace the carnivorous ones. I would recommend this restaurant for both small and large parties. And it is in the beautiful Cosmopolitan, you can't beat that. I loved the chicken poppers served in the shoe! The bruchetta was excellent and the paella was out of this world good!  OLE!
The food and service was outstanding but I'm not a fan of tapas which our group was wanting to do. The atmosphere was bright abut very load which was annoying when trying to have conversation.

We dined at Jaleo for my husband's birthday a few days ago. the first test was the wine list - being from Sonoma, the Spanish names were not familiar.  Our waitress, Kristen, was extremely helpful and suggested a great Tempranillo.  We chose several tapas plates to share, and all were so flavorful.  My favorite was the roasted cauliflower with olives and dates - a dreamy mix of savory and sweet.   Second favorite was the Espinaca - a lightly sauteed spinach dish with raisins.  We finished the meal with a beautiful flan, accompanied by a citrus (mandarin?) sorbet.  The only critique would be the noise factor - as it is a very lively and busy restaurant.  Highly recommend this place and would love to go back!

Some very solid tapas offerings like bacon wrapped fig and papas bravas.  Very chic setting.

But, for all the hype, nothing blew our socks off.  With all the premier restaurants in Vegas, I'll be trying others or returning to others (Robuchon's The Mansion, Julian Serrano) before returning here.

Great tapas restaurant at the Cosmo!  This was my second time at a Jose Andres restaurant, the first being The Bazaar in LA, and have to say that it was a much better experience than the first.

We ordered:
- Jamn Ibrico Fermn: delicious, mild flavor
- Patatas Bravas: potatoes covered in aioli, they were just ok
- Croquetas de Pollo: delicious, a little creamy and they arrived in a shoe!
- Remolacha con Citricos: a refreshing beet salad
- Coliflor con Olivas y Frutos Secos: it was okay, strange that a cauliflower dish would come out last
- Espinacas A La Catalana: very nicely saut√©ed spinach
- Rossejat: interesting pasta paella, it seemed like small pieces of cut up lo mein
- Paella de Verduras de Temporada: delicious vegetable paella, I would highly recommend getting whichever paella they have that night
- Chorizo Casero con Pur de Patatas al Aceite de Oliva: I'm not a big fan of chorizo, but it was good and had a mild flavor
- Carne Asada con Piquillos Julin de Lodosa: delicious steak cooked perfectly
- Pan con Chocolate
- Flan al Estilo Tradicional de Mam Marisa con Espuma de Crema Catalana: my favorite of all the desserts
- Don't remember the name, but it was described as a french toast with apple, also delicious

Overall, the meal was very good - I can't say that either of my experiences at Jaleo or The Bazaar blew me away but between the two, Jaleo definitely takes the cake.  Our server was also very friendly and the atmosphere was light and not at all pretentious.
Amazing beyond words. The flavor of the gin n tonic oysters blew my mind. Other highlights were the imberico sliders and the foi grais chorizo enchiladas. I need to go back and try more stuff

I've been here many times in the past 6 years (my first visit was in 2011) and it's one of the most consistently delicious and hospitable restaurants on the entire strip. Hell, in Las Vegas for that matter.

DO get the tasting menu - it's an insanely ridiculous amount of food for a phenomenal value (don't quote me, but it's like 11 courses/tapas for $77 or something? Whatever, it's 100% worth it).

A few of my favorite dishes (descriptions mostly copied from their menu, side notes are clearly mine):

- Salmon tartare and salmon roe cone
- Cold-smoked pork, rosemary oil and black olive salt - this arrives under a dome filled with smoke - the presentation is as amazing as the flavor
- Fried organic egg topped with caviar 
- Ca√±a de cabra con higos - A soft, semi-sweet goat's milk cheese paired with raisin walnut bread and fig jam 
- La Peral con membrillo de peras y anacardos - sharp and creamy, mixed milk blue cheese paired with pear gel√©e and spiced cashews 
- Lomo ib√©rico de bellota Ferm√≠n - Smoke-cured acorn-fed pork loin
- Gazpacho - it has beets and goat cheese and it haunts my dreams
- Patatas bravas - A Jaleo favorite with spicy tomato sauce and alioli
- Croquetas de pollo - Traditional chicken fritters - beyond creamy and lip-smackingly delicious
- Canelone de Pollo - Canelone pasta filled with roasted catalan-style chicken finished with Manchego cheese and pine nut praline (share this or you'll never fit into your pants again)


And whatever you do, don't forget the pan con tomate - it's tomato bread that you'll want to eat every day for the rest of your life.

The wine list is expansive and varied and the cocktails are delicious. Watch out for the sangria and signature gin & tonic - both delicious, both just this side of deadly.

Visiting for business from New Jersey,  my Co-worker and I decided to leave the hotel for dinner,  but ended up coming back to hit Jaleo once we realized that it was a Tapas restaurant.  
We sat at the bar and delivery was super fast! The bartender was great at pointing out some of the most popular items.   The only thing we waited a little while for was the Paella, which we were pre-warned that it may take some time.   We had the lattice wraps south goat cheese and mandarins.   So unbelievably refreshing!  You wouldn't think those things would work together,  but it danced on you pallet!  Next up was the shrimp,  I forget the name of it,  but it came in this slightly spicy garlic sauce with bread.   Oh it was amazing!   Last up. .. Chicken and rabbit paella.   To.die.for!

I had a nice dinner here, but it is expensive for what it is. That being said, if you're willing to spend money, I would recommend it. The paella changes throughout the night, they feature gin drinks (oddly) but do have sangria but the one thing that I think you should go out of your way for is the ENDIVE SALAD. You may not be impressed by the look, it's pretty but not particularly flashy for Vegas, but it's truly fabulous. It might be the best thing I ate on the trip, scratch that, it WAS the best thing I ate.

After finally getting to Vdara, which I have a review for that on their page, I had to change my restaurant reservations from Sinatra to Jaleo because it was the only late night place i could get and it was very very close to me. Got to Cosmopolitan, which I love because of the atmosphere it produces. Went up the escalator to the restaurant level and walked over to Jaleo. Was seated very fast, but the restaurant wasn't very full being 9:45 on a Sunday night. Started with picking my drink from the iPad menu. Very cool by the way. Had the Sangria. I'm not a big wine guy, but I could get used to drinking this Sangria. For the food, I chose the Batter-fried shrimp with lemon mayonnaise and black olive salt. Very Very good. Next was the Imberico Ham which is probably the best pork product I have ever had. I can try to explain it but it's kind of hard at the moment because of the Sangria that night. Just go try it if you visit Jaleo. You won't be disappointed. Next were the mussels marinated in Sherry vinegar. The leftover marinade was great for the break they brought out at the end. They talked me into ordering the toasted break with the tomato spread on it. Very Very tasty I must say. This was my first Jose Andres restaurant i have been to, and it makes me want to try all of his creations. Might have to go back to Jaleo in July when I am back in Vegas.

I went here with a small group of friends for my birthday and we all ordered the tasting menu. I was completely blown away by the incredible flavors presented to us and the combination of foods. There was an incredible variety of flavors and techniques and I loved how each dish was explained to us as it was brought out. One fish had a scallop substituted for the salmon on the menu, but the scallop could not have been more perfect or delicious. I left feeling completely satisfied and can not wait yet visit this extraordinary restaurant again! And there was a paella pit! Even the simple sorbet and berries that rounded out the meal was absolutely divine. I've already recommended this restaurant to several of my friends and will continue to sing it's praises. Jose Andreas is a genius!

Well the food was amazing! From the Gambas Al Ajillo (Sauteed Shrimp) to the Bacalao Con Salsa Verde (Cod) everything was just muy delicioso! Oh and the seared scallop.. probably the best I've ever had. The Croquetas de Pollo was served on a shoe- yes a shoe.. like the ones you put on your feet. It was more unappetizing as it was amusing.  

The downside.. our server was a little too excited clearing up our plates after each bite even when there was still food on the plate! At first we all thought it was quite funny thinking "they must be running out of plates" but after awhile it just became annoying. I've never felt so rushed before! Granted tapas are served as a plate is ready but our last plate must have taken a good 20-30 minutes since the last plate. By then we weren't even hungry anymore! 

The ambiance was great.. the restaurant had a very hip and modern take on traditional Spanish styling very fitting for the Cosmopolitan. Would probably give it another shot next time I'm in town.. maybe then I can give it 5 stars!

Chicken croquetas in a tennis shoe. Wow. Ordered it 3 times. Wine was great and the scalllops, skirt steak, patatas bravas had great flavor. Great place to go with a group and have a good ambiance and service.

What a Disappointment
Jaleo in DC was one of our top 5 favorite restaurants.  We were going to be in Vegas for our 34th wedding anniversary and thought we would treat ourselves to a great meal, boy were we wrong.  A pet peeve of mine is patronizing a lovely expensive restaurant for a romantic dinner and being seated right next to another couple when there are plenty of open seats.  We had it happen and watched it happen several times while dining.  There were 75% of the seats empty yet couples being sat right next to another couple.  If the hostess is trained that way to ease the servers so there isn't so much space between tables she needs to be retrained as there were more idle servers, bussers and food deliverers than there were employees working.  We also saw the hostess attempt to seat an elderly couple on a bench seat where gramma would have to climb over big fluffy pillows to get to her seat.  Grampa asked for a different table and after a harumph and an eye roll were moved to one of the many many open tables.  We had reservations for the day we arrived in Vegas,  we got in and settled a little early.  We were hungry so arrived early to see if we could be seated early.  We were greeted warmly and sat immediately at a wooden table that had never been properly laquered and was sticky and had a peeling paint. Looking over the cocktail and beer menu should have been a warning sign.  The specialize in gin and tonics; several different gins and tonics available but not being gin or tonic fans that did not appeal to either of us.  At an upscale restaurant I expect a wine list of at least 10 offering in each category of wine.  Not 10 total wine offerings.  The wine I selected was good and I was happy with it. My husband is a beer snob and was hoping for a nice selection as well.  He was disappointed also.  They had 2 draught offering and the waitress had to check to see if one had been restocked.  They had 5 bottle offerings with one being an NA beer.  We ordered 6 different tapas as well as one of the paella selections; the cheese plate and chorizo plate were the only 2 that we would even consider reordering.  At $10 for a cheese plate I agree with many other reviews on YELP that it should have come with crackers or bread.  The stuffed calamari was tasteless and bland, the rabbit/chicken paella was also tasteless and dry,  the potato wrapped chorizo was crunchy-about all I can say as a positive. The grilled asparagus wasn't cooked long enough,  it had a nice green color but was not tender or tasty.  We left without having dessert, which is a first for us as we just couldn't take any more disappointment.  We predict Jaleo won't be around for our next Vegas trip, as I can't imagine anyone revisiting this restaurant after a dining experience there.

This place is absolutely un-believable! The food was impeccable as well as the spirits. The Spanish flare was great and not what I was expecting. Went with 4 people and told them to just keep bringing out the best plates they have until we were full. The Gin and Tonic presentation was amazing - nothing like I've seen before. Will be back for sure

Ate here at 10 pm after a long, annoying flight and it was close to perfect and really convenient. (We are staying at the Cosmopolitan, which is where it's located.) Good service. Solid food. 

Our waitress was very knowledgable about both the drink menu and dinner menu. Incidentally, the mixologist at this place specializes in gin and tonics. (Score! My fave drink). I started off with a delicious g&t that had mint, cardamom and some lemon in it. The wine menu is pretty extensive, as well, though they only serve Spanish wines....

Since Jaleo serves mostly tapas, we ordered 7 small dishes. The most fabulous of those were the stuffed endives, garlic shrimp and hangar steak. The only plate I didn't care for was some baked shrimp/noodle concoction that had an odd consistency. Overall, the atmosphere is super chill (comfy corner booth situation, dim lights, cool music) and we had a lovely experience. I would try it again.

My last visit to Vegas we stopped by Jaleo for a late dinner.  We were sat immediately and given an iPad to order our drinks....very cool.

We ordered a bottle of Wine and several plates of Tapas:
Pan con tomate - Toasted slices of Bread with Tomato $5
Chorizo Palacios - Spicy Pork Sausage $8
Arroz de pato 'Jean-Louis Palladin' - Rice with Duck Confit, Duck Breast and Foie Gras Cream $11
Patatas bravas - Potatoes w/spicy Tomato Sauce & Alioli $7

The Tapas were very good and full of flavor.

Overall, it was a great dining experience.

Return Factor - 90%

Excellent tapas. We did the tasting menu for one and added several dishes additional.  Everything was wonderful. The service is good as well

We actually arrived without a reservation and sat at a communal table but it was fine.  

The prawns in garlic were amazing as was the lamb. Great from start to finish.

Authentic Spanish cuisine that's bon a petit. We went for lunch this afternoon and it was marvelous. I did their Sherry flight paired with their paella feast and my tastebuds were in for a treat. Their paella is made in a big batch that can serve 8 typically. Seasoned delightfully, the mushrooms, chicken & rice are a great medley paired with a garlic aioli that's equally pleasing. Joe did the Tapas and he was equally happy with his selection.
Small portions. Food is ok. Won't be back anytime soon. Spent 300 for two people and we were still hungry after out meal. Hmmmmmmmn

Jaleo was our second stop during our Vegas restaurant binge, and unfortunately, it was pretty mediocre. We came here on a Saturday night, and the tables were about 60% full, but it took the waitress over 30 minutes to get our order in. The tapas then came intermittently, and was overall a mixed bag. From what I can remember:

The Good:
Pan con tamate
Most of its cured meats
Apple and fennel salad
Bacon wrapped dates

The Bad:
The lobster paella--the serving was rather small and the rice tasted like it was doused in salt
Garlic sauteed shrimp--was overcooked, not sure if it's the standard or an anomaly

Overall, Jaleo has a pretty fun ambiance, but if you come hungry, it'll take a lot to get full. And for the price, you can definitely find better offerings in Vegas.

Iv'e dined at many Tapas restaurants in L.A., even to Firefly in Vegas, but this is by far my new favorite. My sister and I went to Jaleo yesterday and had a visual and taste sensory overload. The ambiance is lively yet intimate, the food authentic yet familiar, and the desserts..omg, the Flan and the Pan Con Chocolate were out of this world. 
The best tasting tapas were:
1. Ajo blanco con cangrejo: Chilled almond and garlic soup with crabmeat and green grapes. -TRUST ME- Just order it and thank me later. 
2. Croquetas de jam√≥n Ib√©rico:  Traditional fritters with Ib√©rico ham and a bechemel cream sauce.  -Can't go wrong here!
3. Empanadillas de brandada de bacalao:  'Empanada' of cod brandade with honey.  -Oh so heavenly
4. 'Esqueixada':   Salad of salted cod with black olives and fresh tomato  -It's not really a salad, more like a dip that comes w/ rustic bread. This was absolutely spectacular, despite the fact that i'm not even a huge fish fan.
5. Canelones tradicionales de cerdo, h√≠gado de pato y trufas con salsa bechamel:   Pork, foie gras and truffle canelones with bechamel sauce. - It  tastes as good as it sounds.
6. Jam√≥n Ib√©rico de bellota Fermin:  Cured ham from the legendary, acorn-fed, black-footed Ib√©rico pigs of Spain  - We also got the cheese plate which went very well with our Sangria ;) 
7. Mejillones en escabeche:  Mussels marinated in Sherry vinegar - They serve it in a sardine can w/ olive oil and herbs..they melt in your mouth
8. Endivias con queso de cabra y naranjas:  Endives, goat cheese, oranges and almonds -  fun and refreshing 
9. Ensalada de coles de Bruselas con albaricoques, manzanas y jam√≥n:  Serrano Warm Brussels sprouts salad with apricots, apple and Serrano ham- its one of their most popular dishes...
They have a huge selection of Paella as well, but we were too full by then. 
Btw, their Sangria is stronger than you'll think!

We were staying in the Cosmo for the weekend and stumbled up on Jaleo for some lunch. The five of us gals grabbed a high top table and perused the menu.

We ordered:

- Jam√≥n ib√©rico de bellota Ferm√≠n 
-  Anchoas espa√±oles 
- Pan de cristal con tomate fresco  
- Ensalata Xato

The highlights were of course, the beautiful ib√©rico --salty, fatty, melt in your mouth. But the sleeper of the dishes was the Pan de cristal con tomate fresco. It was described as toasted slices of uniquely crispy and ethereal bread brushed with fresh tomato. "Uniquely crispy"??? But seriously, it was. Light, airy and perfect!!!

To wash it all down, there was lovely chilled cava.

Overall....it was pretty good but very pricey. I do adore Chef Andres but I'm not sure I'd come back to Jaleo.

What we ate and drank:

- Endive with oranges, almonds, and goat cheese - a great, refreshing first bite. Light on the goat cheese, lots of oranges, awesome flavor. 
- Fried squid with aioli - this was gone in a matter of seconds after hitting the table, and 4 friends were in a blissful, happy place. 
- White asparagus with lemon, thyme, Idiazabal cheese - asparagus was cold and crisp, but any lemon and thyme was overpowered by the cheese. Refreshing, but one of the lower impact dishes of the night.
- Veal cheeks with morels and olive oil potato puree - rich and heavenly. 
- Pork and foie canelones with bechamel sauce - again, simply decadent. 
- Vegetable Paella of the day - rice had nice toasty flavor, and vegetables were delicious. Tasty, but not mind-blowing.
- Sauteed wild mushrooms with potato puree - tasty but not mind blowing.
- Organic egg with caviar and caramelized onions - as you'd expect, runny and delicious, with grilled bread to sop it all up.

Prima tempranillo to drink, which was a nice complement.  A decent value for the price of the bottle, not great. Flan for dessert was good, not exceptional.

Service was good - water was refilled frequently. Waitress was a tad bit pushy and her recommendations were pretty vanilla - chicken croquettes, bacon wrapped dates, sauteed spinach... do we LOOK like we're from Topeka?  Decor was lovely though, and we were seated right up against the dessert plating station for an entertaining view of the pastry cooks. Would definitely love to try more of Jaleo in the future.

I'm a huge fan of Jose Andres, but Jaleo was not as impressive as i expected. We had a variety of the small plates and were very disappointed to feel so blah about them.  I have to say that we are all Spaniard and know what spanish food tastes like so had a good basis for comparison (or maybe it's a negative in this case).  

I'll start with the positives;  the cocktails are excellent and the wine selection is good.  The service and servers were all great (Thanks Kristin!).  No complaints whatsoever.

Now the negatives:

The biggest issue and by far most offensive was the tortilla de patatas clasica (potato egg omelette).  if there is one dish that represents spain unequivocably it is the tortilla de patatas.  This is the one thing anyone would expect to be good. this is the one dish every spaniard knows, every mom makes, and is on every menu as a tapa in every bar/restaurant.  Can't get more spanish than this.  What we got was a runny omelette the size of a tea saucer with two pieces of potato and one piece of onion stuck in the middle...literally that's all the potato there was. for an omelette it was fine.  For a tortilla it was tragic and we sent it back.  Anyone who's ever had or seen one would have done the same.  i hope management sees this and looks a little closer.

A few more dishes we had:
-There should have been more bread.  Was not impressed with the mini-baguette type of bread served. It was expensive and not nearly enough of it.
-The patatas bravas were fairly good and presented in a way that i never thought such traditional bar food could look.  Very tasty.  
-The octopus was boring!!  It was cooked to perfection and very tender which is a must for octopus, but pulpo should be flavourful and this was not.  it tasted as if it had just been boiled with a hamhock and put on the plate.  not good.  
-The stuffed olives and liquid olives were great. 
-The asparagus with romescu sauce were a mixed bag: the asparagus beautifully cooked but the sauce was hideous.  Again, another very traditional sauce that should have been great. 
-The stuffed red peppers were full of so much cabrales (bleu) cheese that no other flavours came through which was a shame considering how nice the peppers and sauces tasted on their own. Less would've been more in this case.  
-The scallops were cooked to perfection and absolutely delicious.  amazing! 
-The shrimp in garlic were very nice. Not enough bread to sop up the delicious sauce left at the end.

All in all, it was an ok experience, but I wouldn't go back and I wouldn't recommend it as a place to go for great spanish tapas. It's probably fair to say that if you don't know spanish cuisine you will enjoy this more than we did, so this may not apply to everyone.

I wouldn't return. The food wasn't as inventive, or put together as I expect from Chef Andres, perhaps we didn't select the best options. The portions were quite small, even for tapas. They all seemed slapped together too...when you are paying $15-30 a tapa I expect a bit of care...

We asked to switch tables after being seated directly behind a noisy server station. We asked the server if we could keep him and he said the new table would be "a little too far" what?? seriously?

We hadn't even ordered any food at this point, and then our new server came over, and with no introduction, or "sorry the other table was noisy, is this table better? she simply just said "do you want to add anything?" She seemed like more of an order taker than a server, with other tables around us too.

Overall, the servers seemed to be more into socializing with eachother, even the managers. We had a female manager circle around our table twice, and she asked a table of two older genteman twice how everything was, but never stopped by us once, or any other tables in the area, that we noticed. 

We felt like we were more at the Plant Hollywoood of Tapas....servers who seem to be interested more in eachother, or being somewhere else completely, and an air that we are just "tourists".  And food that is put together for the masses..

My husband and I have actually worked in a restaurant in Times Square, so I get the frustration of working with certain types of tourists, or especially foreign tourists that don't think they need to tip, or tip really poorly...but there are still tourists who appreciate dining, and superb service, and will tip for it.  We would have....

Jaleo is just one of those places you feel like more of an inconvenience to the staff...

After being a huge fan of Jose Andes' restaurant in DC called Zaytina, I was really disappointed with Jaleo. The food is mediocre at best and extremely overpriced for tapas (never felt this about their D.C. restaurant) and they are so stingy that they charge you $1 (without informing you beforehand) if you ask for bread (you will get a tiny roll if you do for that $1)...even IHOP wouldn't do that. I would avoid this place especially if you're expecting the same quality food and service that you do at Jose Andres' other restaurants.

I love the Bazaar at SLS.  I consider it to be one of the best restaurants i've ever been to! I was beyond excited to try Jaleo. It came highly recommended and I had fun imagining the crazy thing Jose Andres could do with Spanish tapas.

What we got was so disappointing! To start off, the ambiance of this restaurant sucks. It's loud and the chairs are super uncomfortable. It's not a "dressy" place at all, it doesn't even feel like a "nice" place. The people sitting next to us looked like they had come right from the pool and overall the vibe was super casual.  Service was spotty at best, except that 3 times they tried to take away our dishes when there were still several bites left. Excuse me!

The food was fine. It wasn't bad. There was nothing amazing or creative about this food at all, just your standard Spanish Tapas.  The only thing that was unique was the fact that they served chicken fritters in an old shoe. When we asked the waitress about the significance of the shoe she just said ," I get asked that so much. The only thing we can think of is that Jose doesn't like plates". It felt so gimmicky!  

For 2 people, I would order 5-8 Tapas to feel full. 


With the plethora of AMAZING other places to eat in Vegas and in the cosmopolitan hotel, Jaleo is not a place I would waste my time eating.


**EDIT** I asked Jose Andres on twitter why he served the chicken fritters in a shoe and he replied! Here is his reply:

1. plates are boring 2. dali served a dinner in hollywood to bob hope and others on shoes 3. by doing so people think 4.why not?
Went for the social hour seemed annoyed that we were there food was ok will not go back

Right off the escalator on the third floor of the flashy Cosmopolitan sits Jose Andre's Jaleo. We came here for an early dinner (victims of decided to eat here on a Saturday on the preceding Thursday - or perhaps the beneficiaries of this decision - more on this later).

The drink list comes out on an iPad, which is a bit precious. You can save your time and just order Jose's Gin and Tonic for your first drink - trust me, you won't be let down! Gin and Fever Tree tonic, presented in a wine glass containing exactly one spherical ice cube and garnished with juniper berries, a slice of lemon, and lemon verbena goes down smooth - what's not to like there? Nothing. 

As a party of six, we headed the waiters advice and ordered 2-3 items per person - a few at a time, starting with the pan con tomate and progressing  from there to meats and cheeses, on to vegetables and seafood, and finally to some meat dishes. We ended up ordering additional orders of a few items , such as the gambas al aljilio and the brussel sprout salad. These are items not to miss.  Other standout items include the olives (including 'liquid' olives, a simple delight of molecular gastronomy) and the secreto Iberico, which we ordered at the very land, when we were still just a little hungry - and ended up devouring. All of this food went perfectly with a well-priced Rioja.

Dessert was a bit of a hit and a bit of a miss. The flan tradicional was one of the best specimens of that dish that I've ever had. In fact, self proclaimed haters of flan were devouring it along with the rest of us. The cafe solo (espresso) is the best I've had outside of Italy. The big down was the apple tart - which wasn't really very apple-y or tarty. We could have done with out this.

This was a slow, pleasant meal. And the best part was that our early resevation allowed us to easily meet up with our other friends for a long night of drinking and dancing, without being too full, too late!

I was in Vegas for a conference in the Cosmopolitan and tried Jaleo for lunch. My wife and I had  "Lunch like a Spaniard!". For $25 each of us selected three tapas from a selected menu. Everything was delicious, specially the "Endivias", the "Gambas al Ajillo" and the "Vieiras con pi√±ones". We had flan for dessert. It was excellent.

We had the chefs tasting menu and it reminded us a lot of our travels to Spain. Overall most of the 12 dishes were winners but there were a few we didn't care for. One of the ones we were a little disappointed with was the Rabbit and Chicken Paella. While the rice was cooked perfectly, the chicken was over cooked and dry. Also, there was no socarrat which is my favorite part of a good paella. Overall it was worth the experience, but not a home run.

I was so excited to try this restaurant that our close friends that our real foodies had been telling us about for quite some time. We had a birthday to celebrate so it was the perfect reason to get dressed up and head to the Cosmo. The four of us were seated and I noticed immediately how loud it was, almost to where we couldn't have a conversation. There were lots of kids there as well so it isn't a place for a romantic date by any means. The wine list came on an IPAD which was cool until I saw that they only had Spanish wines by the glass. I had never heard of any of the them and had a hard time choosing. The waiter was friendly enough to suggest one based on what I like. When it came I did not like it at all. He brought me another to try and when I told him I thought it was corked he said it just had "barnyard" notes to it. Who the heck wants to drink a wine that smells like a barn? We ordered a meat sampler plates, some olives, ham croquettes, shrimp with lemon aioli and oilive salt. Everything was good, not amazing and the portions were so small even for tapas that we either each got one bite or had to cut something in half. We didn't even feel like we'd eaten anything after the first seven plates that I proceeded to quickly order 7 more. The mussels stood out but the paella was so bland and crunchy (underdone) that we had to send it back. We decided to leave before dessert and headed next door to Blue RIbbon Sushi because we know they have the best ginger bread pudding in the world. I don;t think this place lives up to Firefly which is just ok and no where near as delicious as Julian Serrano in Aria.

We came here for lunch on Father's day which turned out to be a great choice. We were greeted by a friendly hostess and had the opportunity to start with Mayla a waitress( I think that's her name) and she guided thru her favorite appetizers which included a great cheese  appetizer of 3 different types. In addition we added embutido appetizers which was excellent as we tasted different types of aged pork. The whole service staff was very attentive and made sure the waters were full and the sangria was flowing :)

We went early so they just started making Paella and at this point it was chicken,mushroom. 
We kept talking about ordering it as you must and they were running low. One of the managars( A male) overheard us and brought us the last of it complimentary which really took the dining experience up a notch! In addition we added the mini pepito de iberico and Gambas al ajillo.

We finished with a sorbet and Jose's famous glam which sealed the deal. 

All in all a fantastic memorable experience . Cannot wait To go back

Fantastic food, great service, crazy prices. I had three teeny courses with two glasses of modest wine, and spent almost 80.00. For one person. And I left HUNGRY!!

Jose Andres restaurants have the best gazpacho. Slam dunk every time...but like all tapas, the portions are tiny. :(

Can't believe I forgot to review this.  I was there when they opened first day last xmas.  We were fortunate to be there for their soft opening.  I loved the atmosphere, decor, and of course the food.  Definitely my favorite spanish tapas place in town.

Not sure why this place isn't rated higher on Yelp.  Sure, it's pricier than Firefly, and maybe even not as good, but they're two different animals.  Jaleo is just cool-looking, and they have some really unique dishes.  The paellas rotate daily, so I didn't get to eat the lobster paella I was hoping for, but the duck paella was pretty darned good.  And I'd never had monkfish before, either.  I don't even remember what else we got, but it was all deicious.  And the service was fantastic, as was to be expected at the Cosmopolitan.

We had dinner here on a Saturday evening. The restaurant was packed. I muist say that the drinks were outstanding and the food was very competent. Over and above this was a feeling of joy and happiness throughout the restaurant. We literally had a ball dining here and left happy. If you want to have great food and a wonderful time, this is the place to go!!!!!!

Food and service were very good.  Menu had lots of options.  The "tomato bread" is a must try.  When you read it on the menu, it will appear as a very simple dish, but as simple as it is, it was one of the best things we had.  The tomato-garlic soup was good for a few initial bites and then it just got to be a little too much.  Kind of tastes like a potato salad sauce with lots of garlic, imo.  The tortilla was really good, but a little more runny then I've traditionally had in Spain.  The fried baby squid were very soft, but the batter was not very crispy.  Perhaps its supposed to be like that, i just thought a crispier crust would've been better.  I would've liked to tried the rabbit and the octopus, but i was just stuffed.  Our waitress was very knowledgeable, the staff was very assertive and the hostess was very sweet.  I give it a solid 4.

I've spent a reasonable amount of time in Barcelona recently learning to understand the whole tapas thing, and to a lesser extent paella. There are a lot of "standards" that show up in every tapas place, in a good way. I've been fortunate to have a friend who is one of the few people whose palate I completely trust send me a few places when I was in Barcelona. They were all standouts. There is a magic to the red shrimp, or local langoustines, cooked up just hours after being caught that can never be duplicated anywhere away from the bay where they are caught.
Well, that was a long introduction. It's also everything that's right with Jaleo. They take the finest of Spanish tapas that can be reproduced at a level equal to, or better, than you will find in the best places in Spain, and leave out the ones that can't be duplicated properly. Skip the langoustine, squid, shrimp, and similar. Provide amazing tomato bread with absolute top quality Jam√≥n ib√©rico de bellota. Anchovies in olive oil, olives, and cheeses. After a few of those, get the paella that's as good as the best in Spain.
The room is very pretty, but loud. The service excellent. There was a number of nice wines with big markups instead of outrageous markups.
It was the closest we could get taking my adult kid and wife to Spain without having been able to take them there.
Ate here Friday night.  Good scene but everything else just ok, including service.

If you are looking for a "Bazaar experience," you will probably be disappointed.  Jaleo has a more casual atmopshere.  The food is satisfying but never reaches the next level of impressing your taste buds.

chorizo appetizer - tasty bite size sausage
fried egg with caviar - was expecting a lot more 
chicken fritters - serving it in a shoe is not creative, just odd
shrimp sauteed in garlic - not bad, a little too oily
fried dates wrapped in bacon - again, not bad

grilled hangar steak - probably the best thing we had, quite good

the salad and paella were also good.

Oh Jaleo, you bring out the worst in me.

I'm one of those eaters that: (1) has zero patience to read a menu, especially when most of it is in a foreign language; (2) if I can't decide what I want, I pester the server and neighboring diners for recommendations; and (3) knows exactly what I want and how I want it.  Jaleo, for better or worse, hits all four proverbial nails.

Jaleo's menu isn't the biggest, but there are a large number of dishes offered.  And most of it is in Spanish.  Unless you read the English description.  Well, as I said before, I have no patience to read every description to settle on a handful of openers.  Which sucks because we ended up with the cod empanadas, which, oh, btw, doesn't really have any cod in it.  It's basically a fish cream that's been deep fried in thin and crisp empanada shell with some honey drizzled on it.  You might like it and love it, but my friends and I could not stomach this to save our lives.  We Fear Factored the shmuck who ordered it as punishment.  Yes, he smelled like fish after that.  The menu doesn't suck if you read Spanish.  Or you have the patience to actually read everything.  Deal killer?  Nope, because...

...I pester people to give strong recommendations.  Sucks for everyone else except me!  Using this method, we stumbled across a ginfully good Gin & Tonic.  They ship their ice sphere (don't call it a ball) from their sister ship in LA.  Seriously.  The care and attention that goes into this one drink suggests that they care about all of their products (apparently even that cod cream).  Speaking of attention, the food in the shoe definitely grabbed ours, as we promptly ordered the delectable pollo croquetas (sp?) that occupy the footwear.  Those little morsels of what tasted like really good creamed chicken in a crunchy fried shell are really yum.  Another great recommendation was that we try their off-menu paella (I don't know what it's called because we said we'd take it before the server even described it).  To our surprise it was loaded with a whole lobster tail, a giant lobster claw (a bitch to break open), a few prawns and a few muscles.  Killer good that dish, but...

...not as good as the Iberico Short Rib Paella recommended on my first visit.  It was so rich and tasty that we wanted another plate.  I daydream about it.  I drool uncontrollably.  My second visit to Jaleo was specifically to have this dish again.  Upon sitting, before ordering drinks or even water, we asked for, nay DEMANDED this paella.  To which our humble server replied they were not going to be making it.  At all.  For the rest of the night.  Once the tears stopped, I pulled myself together with a wonderful Gin & Tonic, had some pretty good dishes (like the potato wrapped chorizo and roast quail) then went over to Blue Ribbon for oxtail fried rice to dull the pain...but that's for another review.  

Yeah, Jaleo, you've got a lot going for you.  Your food's mostly good.  But I think I need Rosetta Stone and some valium to get through the menu.  And you need to get some more damn Iberico short ribs for the best paella in the world!

Always a must when in Vegas.  Finally made it here for amazing dinner tasting menu (instead of our standard lunch time meal)  --- The 4 "waves" of food were all fantastic. "It's not suppose to be THIS good".  Even things you wouldn't normally consider trying, everything is exceptional ..,from the first to last bite. 
Can't wait to go for lunch for our standard iberico de belotta, gazpacho, Queso sandwich with honey, homemade potato chips, wine for me, gin and tonic for him! Service is always top notch as well!!! 
Can't recommend this place enough!!! Definitely a place to come back again and again.

Jaleo is pretty attractive with its red decor inside Cosmopolitan. 

First time trying Spanish cuisine so I didn't have much expectation. The place serves tapas style dishes, so it's best if each of your group orders 1-2 and all share. They have their paella made in the middle of the restaurant, so you can look at the whole process like a show. They only serve one type of paella for the day. We were pretty lucky to go on the day they served lobster paella.

Their lobster paella which was very delicious. Not overly salty or burnt like I've had at other places. The plate set up was vibrant in colors making my tummy growl. We also ordered their veal cheeks, which was very tender and juicy. I had this caviar and yolk bread spread too but it wasn't extremely impressive. It lacked flavors and textures.

Ho-ly crap. I don't understand how this place is still in business. The food was not authentic or good. We ordered 10 different items and I was only impressed with 2 and one of them isn't even a cooked item (jamon iberico - acorn fed).

Here's a break down of what we ordered:

Sopa de ajo - Nice presentation, but was esstientially turkey gravy. It was so salty and nobody wanted to eat it.

San Simon con garapinado de frutos secos - two slices of okay cheese and a little bit of nut brittle for $10 (LOL).

Jamon Iberico de bellota Fermin - one of the only two things I would eat again. This also came with a soggy slice of bruschetta for everyone which was gross.

Croquetas de setas - was suppose to be fried mushroom fritters. Didn't taste any mushrooms.

Coca con erizos de mar - the only other thing I would eat. Uni and iberico bacon on a slice of bread. Thank god their uni is fresh.

Costillas de cordero con salsa romero y alioli de miel - You can't even see the grill marks on the lamb. It was barely grilled to the point that you can tell they boiled it first in water and then put on some lame ass grill with no firepower to simulate grilled lamb. It was also not tender at all.

Paella Valenciana 'Rafael Vidal' - mushy rice with chicken bone bits that hurts your teeth if you're not careful when chewing. So much tomato sauce.

Arroz a banda con gambas - undercooked rice with this bad fishy shrimp taste.

Vieiras con piniones y PX - they should use whatever they used to grill the scallops in this dish to grill the fucking lambs. 

D√°tiles con tocino 'como hace todo el mundo' - nothing special. You can make this at home yourself and taste the exact same.

Honestly, this place is not worth even a tiny bit compared to what they are charging you per dish. Maybe if you wanted to try the jamon iberico. We left hungry and disappointed. Just go to taco bell and you will feel less hungry and disappointed.

The food is quite okay. The bread with tomato rub, lamb chops and piquello peppers are good. Some of the items were excessively salty. The thing that killed the experience is how every service staff was over eager to take away our plates and bowls. It seemed like they had to flip our table within the hour! 
We were eating here as a relaxing dinner before our show at Paris. However, the folks at Jaleo made us hurry up and leave! The tried to take away half eaten food bowls. 
Unlikely to come back:(

I'm going to try to speak about Jose Andres without hyberbole, but quite frankly, thats asking a lot.

I have dined at Jaleo three times now and its memorable and delicious every time. I love that theres even a hint of The Bazarre's molecular gastronomy phenomena woven in the menu. This was my boyfriends first Jose Andres dining experience and he said its one of the best he's ever had in his lifetime.

One dish that really stood out was the Olive Oil Icecream paired with grapefruit three ways (sorbet, sliced, and candied). It was the most well balanced dessert I've ever had the pleasure to try.

Thank you Jose for sharing your gift with the world!

It was our first experience with Jaleo.

The initial greet with the hostess was great! Super friendly and sat is immediately.

We were greeted by Eric who brought us water and would be right back to take our beverage order. It took exactly 9 minutes for him to return to take our first round. It was frustrating so we decided to order as much as possible.

I ordered the 2 cone of the salmon tartar and asked if there was any onions. He said there were shallots but would ask if it could be omitted. He never er came back!!! The salmon came out before our wine? I guess timing was off. We then wanted the paella but were limited to two options reasoning they like to circulate the menu. Ok? I'm def not ordering the vegetable paella!!! 

Anyways it got even worse!!! We order the clam dish 15 minutes prior to suffice for the paella. Eric then comes by to inform us they are out of it 15 minutes after ordering!!! I'm in to food industry and I'm pretty sure their time standard for a clam dish is less than 15 minutes! I was just over it at this point. I asked for the check hungry and aggregated. Thank god the cosmopolitan had many other food options. 

I def do not recommend this location and am extremely disappointed about the service.

I'm Spaniard.  This is perhaps the best Spanish food restaurant I have been to date in the US.  My list is not huge but it spans coast to coast.  Bravas were specially tasty.  Chorizo Iberico was great as well.  Lomo Iberico lacking a bit of flavor but still enjoyable.

Just perusing some of the reviews, I sometimes find it hilariously amusing at what people say they are upset about.  "I can't find it....too confusing....."  Really?  Good grief.

Jaleo was very good.  In fact, borderline excellent minus one total miss on a dish.  If you don't know, or are challenged like a few reviewers who "couldn't find it", it is in the Cosmopolitan, if I remember right, on the 3rd floor.  We took the very brilliant route of "reading the sign" that said what floor it was on and took the escalator up.  

The space is beautiful, as most new restaurants in the newer hotels are.  Our server was sleepwalking a bit, but the food made up for it.  

The salmon crudo and roe in a "cone" was a real showstopper.  Just delicious, and what we started off with (though we ordered 2 more).  We proceeded with some dry-cured Chorizo which was also really delicious.  The "bikini de jamon" were very tasty (little pressed sandwiches) as well as the chicken fritters which literally melted in your mouth.  The meal was really on fire until we hit the paella, which is supposed to be their specialty.  You basically take whichever one they are serving at the time, and ours was chicken and rabbit.  The bottom line is that the meat was severely overcooked.  If it had not been for the amazing dishes before, that would have been a catastrophe, but taken overall, the meal was still great.  

We had a monster caraffe of Sangria which was solid, but that is not what you should order.  You order your drinks from an iPad they give you, and the first one you see is "the world's best" gin and tonic.  The server played it up, so we thought what the hell.  We ended up trying all 3 and they were absolutely outstanding.  Really delicious stuff and a must try!

Overall, very solid.  Ignore the nonsensical reviews talking about "small portions" and outrageous prices.  I've said this in other reviews, if you walk into a Vegas restaurant in a newer Hotel looking for a bargain, you are just a little out of your comfort zone (how was that for PC??).  They are all stupidly expensive, and in any major city you can have as good or better for less, but this is Vegas.  So either expect it or save it from your dumb review.  

*Steps off soap-box*
