Wow where to begin?  The drinks were amazing and delicious as well as being unique.  The food was savory and yummy with some many great bites.  I think we tried one of everything.  Our favorite was the uni toast with bacon.  The chorizo roll ups were unbelievably good.  Ok fried whole lobster-yum.  And of course the jamon Iberico.

I'm puzzled by the low-ish reviews as well--by far the best tapas restaurant I've experienced--the only thing I can think of that was a little off-putting was the price, but hey, you're inside the Cosmopolitan on the Las Vegas strip, where $8 beers and $15-20 cocktails are pretty much the norm. Great fun, open atmosphere and scenery. Huge open fire pit in one corner with 3-4 full size paella pans on full throttle. Didn't get the chance to try the paella du jour as it included wild mushrooms, which one of my co-workers couldn't handle. Oh well. We ordered the pork sliders, gambas, black-garlic chicken breast, and hangar steak. All delivered beyond expectations taste-wise, and the presentation and service was great too. Just try not to go there with friends who ask for Chile Rellenos.
Omg this is a must try when in Vegas... every dish ignited a different part of my tongue.. some of my favs salmon cone- eggplant cone-  gin and tonic oysters-... one of my favs..

Ordered a lot of tapas plates, here's some of them.  (Or what's left of it). I love everything we ordered. It was my birthday dinner , I wasn't too hungry so this was the perfect place  to have an enjoyable, flavorful bites.

Food was good. Not outstanding by any means. The paella is way overrated. Too salty & the half order is barely enough for 2 people - not 4 as they said. There was no cuttlefish as advertised & barely any lobster meat. I won't be returning.

Jose Andres' Jaleo at the Cosmopolitan fuses traditional Spanish tapas with a trendy ambiance and confirms the celebrity chef still knows what he's doing.

Jaleo was our last dinner outing on a recent Vegas trip and it did not disappoint. The food was outstanding from start to finish. A trendy decor perfectly at home in the Cosmo proved to be the perfect setting for a style of dining that encourages a communal experience.

The menu spans multiple regions of Spain and showcases some of their most popular cuisine. Jam√≥n ib√©rico and paella are probably the best known dishes to an American audience but Jaleo's menu goes far beyond the staples offering a unique mix with something for every palate.

The Good: Jaleo's menu features a number of different paellas, but keep in mind that they rotate on a nightly basis, also make sure to order them early as they take 45 minutes to prepare. We opted for the vegetable paella which was packed with flavor. The rice was a perfect al-dente and had a nice bite to it. The portion was a bit on the small side so be sure to order 2 if you have a larger group. The Jam√≥n ib√©rico did not disappoint either. Sliced paper-thin, the fat marbled ham had a great saltiness finished with hit of acorn. Another standout were the Croquetas De Pollo (chicken fritters). They weren't unlike risotto balls I've had in the past with a molten cheese center. They were a nice balance to the bold, spicy flavors of the other dishes. Ultimately you really can't go wrong with anything on Jaleo's menu. We sampled about 10-12 dishes total and they were all outstanding. Be sure to start your meal with one of the restaurant's signature gin and tonics.

The Bad: Nothing bad to report. We did have to wait an extra 15 minutes past our reservation to be seated, but the friendly bar tenders took good care of us while we waited. The service was also a bit slow, but that's more attributed to just how busy the restaurant was. Make sure you book a table in advance.

Jaleo is a quintessentially Vegas dining experience. It's great for groups and the vibrant atmosphere and stunning food will keep me coming back.
Delicious and perfect late night dinner! Our server gave us the best selections. Try the original sangria, it's so light, not sweet and the easiest thing to drink!
yes, I paid $22 for a plate of ham. not just any ham, but jamon iberico. and it was good.

tapas?  I guess that means we need to order a lot of dishes?  is 20 dishes enough for 6 people?  we ordered so much food that the waiter asked if we would be able to finish it.  it helps that the meal was comped.  

before heading to the restaurant I did a little "yelp" research to see what's good and a definite must try.  jaleo has a HUGE menu.  honestly I don't really remember too much about this meal except for a few items that stood out.  the cold almond lobster soup with grapes was a hit at the table.  cold soup?  who would've thought?  their hot soup, don't remember what it was, was memorable also.  I remember it was too salty!  another hit was the kusshi oysters with gin and tonic.  again, how do they know that was a good combo?  did someone spill some gin and tonic on some oysters?  I really really loved it.  other than that, everything else was either average or just plain forgettable.  I do remember eating some kind of beef and the paella.  

overall, it was just an average dinner, nothing special.  the service was great, very attentive but it's vegas.  it's all about the service.  I guess I shouldn't really complain since the dinner was free.  if it was free I would come back.  if I had to pay I'd probably just hit the buffet.

Staying all week at the lovely Cosmopolitan Hotel and had a couple of really good meals (pool grille and China Poblano Chinese and Mexican place) before we gave what looked like an interesting menu a try at Jaleo. 
Felt utterly exploited at Jaleo. Overpriced plates for very mixed results, drink prices ($20) that would make a hip Manhattan bar sit up and take notice (for nothing special, I might add). 
We're getting reimbursed and I still felt jerked around and exploited. There are many better options within and nearby the hotel. Exercise those options! One bright light was the decor. That and an eggplant and pepper salad that we paid a ton for for two bites each but was very tasty.

My wife and I tried this place out along with a few friends for Restaurant week. The place looked great and the staff were very friendly. Service was pretty good as well. As for the food, I would have to say it was average or even below average for the price. The appetizers were delicious but when it came for the Paella, we were disappointed. It was seasoned perfectly but a little over cooked. Some of the rice was very hard. I'm not sure if this was caused by over cooking or poor quality rice but it was something that you didn't expect for a semi- fine dining experience.

Beautiful presentation, creative dishes, fun to experience, too expensive for the amount of food received. I shared a chocolate dessert that was insanely small and didn't even allow for sharing. Love the Cosmopolitan, love Jose Andres, love the concept. I even love tapas. But the portions need to increase to match the price.

I've been in semi-Yelp retirement since about halfway through this pregnancy, but Jaleo was so awesome, I figured they deserve a review.

It's inside the Cosmopolitan, so obviously, the atmosphere is pretty cool. The decor is very hip and it's a little loud inside. Our reservations were honored with no problems, service was prompt and efficient, and the plates were brought out in "ascending" order, as they should be. The wine list is shown to you on an ipad, which is kinda cool, or kinda trying too hard, whichever you think.

I thought the best part was that everybody in our party of four left happy. There were veggie lovers, seafood lovers, and meat lovers, and everybody raved about the food.

As far as I can remember, this is what we had (with english names):
pan con tomate with cheese (good, but nothing exciting)
chorizo (excellent)
endives with goat cheese (loved)
gazpacho (best ever - could have eaten way more)
chorizo wrapped in potatoes and fried (awesome - like a fancy snack food, favorite of the table)
chicken croquettes (very good - don't know why they came in a shoe and neither did the waiters)
egg with caviar and onions (very good, but I wish there were less onions - they totally overpowered the caviar)
veal cheeks with potatoes (awesome)
skirt steak (very good)
bottle of wine (don't remember what it was, but it was something none of us had ever had, recommended by the waiter)

Even with all that, our bill was less than $200!

I have been to Bazaar in LA and, while I found the concepts there very interesting, I much prefered Jaleo, and the prices are way cheaper.

We really enjoyed this place. We came here for a night cap and a few treats. The food was fantastic, we ordered the D√°tiles con tocino and Patatas bravas for snacks. Both were delicious and reminded us of our time in Spain - very authentic.

The service was also great. Our server was helpful and talked us through the cocktail and regular menus, describing the most popular items

The reason for not giving this place five stars, are the following:
 - The atmosphere is a bit too casual for the caliber. It felt like a fast food restaurant
 - There was a Gin & Tonic special for $20. It wasn't anything special.

Overall, great spot. Would come back for a quick bite any time!

tapas done right. We came here and shared a number of tapas dishes -- I can't remember them all, but they were all very well executed.

I had the pork pallea and it was fantastic. Service was great. Overall, great ambiance, service, and food. Try their sangria.. It's delicious!

I'm definitely a fan!

Amazing all the way around. The service was outstanding and the food was just incredible. I was in a party of 3 so we ordered up a bottle of wine and just indulged in some tapas adventures. Jamon iberico, octopus, shrimp paella, tomato bread, tuna dish with foam and squid ink pasta. Too many good things to say. The oysters with gin was not my favorite. I guess I am too simple and I only like oysters with lemon and tobasco. Either way, this place is a gem. 5 stars all day long!!!!!!!!!!

We come here a least once a year and it's always great. Food is fantastic, service is impeccable and the atmosphere is great. They suggest 3/4 tapas per person and it's the right amount. We loved the chicken crochets and the octopus. Sangria is ok and the paella of the day is a must try. 
We can't wait for our next visit

This restaurant deserves 4 stars- but we caught them three days after  opening and they are working out the kinks. It took us close to 1/2 hour to get our drinks. Very chic and modern lay out. One of our tapas came first and the wait staff is just out of sync. The lobster Pallea was out of this world and the calamari was excellent. The only miss is the fact that they don't give you any bread to soak up the delicious sauces. After the first round of traditional sangria we went for the white cava fish bowl which packs a good kick and is crisp and refreshing.  It went very well with the monkfish. On the other hand, the food was so phenomenal that after we were full, we saw a tapa dish at another table and still ordered it and desert. Lastly we ordered the flan and the tangerine custard came with a sherbet, whip cream and a couple of slices.  It was fantastic!!!
It is in the new Cosmopolitan hotel which is so high tech that you have a tough time finding the east valet, do yourself a favor and park in the west valet. East is a mess and took over 30 min to find our car.
Jaleo was amazing! When I saw the squid ink pasta I was a little scared but it tasted amazing! That and the carne sliders were my favorite!
Took a long time to serve us. We have to ask twice for water. I didn't even know why we ended up  eating here! Tapas are overpriced. Overall, this place sucks!!! And still hungry

Jaleo is a solid and positive dining experience. They have great drinks and a diverse menu that can satisfy a variety of eaters.

Chef Jose's tapas dishes are strong and excite the palate. We especially liked the ensalada Malaguan, the gambas, and the perfectly cooked scallops. The only minor disappointments were the patatas bravas which were a little too oily, and the skirt steak which was good but not as amazing or special as the other dishes.

The food here is to die for! A little pricey, but it is well worth it.  Our server was very attentive and very helpful since I have food allergies. Cocktails were also good. Try their sangria and spicy margarita.... Good stuff! We tried: Sliders, paella, Brussels sprout salad, chorizo roll, calamari with squid ink aioli was to do die for! We left feeling so full even though each dish was only a few bites.  If your in Vegas you should definitely try this place

Jaleo is located on the third floor of the sprawling Cosmopolitan hotel. It was packed when we arrived at 7:30 on a weekday and people kept streaming in. The focal point of the restaurant is definitely the large pit in the back where several different vats of paella and being made. (While we didnt, if you order a pan for the table the chefs shout out, and there is a large procession to the table in questions - quite a scene).

The menu is extensive, in tapas style and my family ordered a bunch to share.

We had:
Dry - Cured Chorizo: good flavor but was served with some pretty plain breadsticks.
Tortilla: a classic spanish omelette made with potatoes and onion, was delicious with great consistency.
Paella of the Day: traditional Valencian style with chicken and rabbit, rather than chorizo and seafood. I quite enjoyed it. 
Garlic Shrimp: served in a yummy, spicy olive oil. This one was gone in a flash and I even used the bread to soak up all the sauce.
Croquetas de Pollo: classic and delicious with a nice mustard sauce.
Chickpea Salad: my mom insisted on this one. She always wants to keep meals light, which this was. On the whole not bad, but you could tell it was not a speciality of the restaurant.
Aceitunas: while not my favorite, definitely the most unique dish of the night. Essentially olives two ways with a few olives stuffed with anchovies as well as 4 "liquid olives" which burst in your mouth.
Hanger Steak: enough said.
Chorizo wrapped in Crispy Potato: my only real disappointment of the night. Essentially tasted like a greasy spring roll. The chorizo tasted lower quality then the rest of the food overall and the potato had no flavor.
Flan: yummy end to the night with a light and airy flan pairing surprisingly well with cream and oranges and sorbet.

Service was a bit pushy but overall very polite. My parents were unimpressed that on the next table croquettes were served in a shoe, an actual black shoe. Seemed like an odd gimic, but then again, it is Las Vegas. Overall we had a nice meal, albeit expensive, paired with some good wine and cocktails. I probably wouldn't go back, but I also feel like it was par for the course for a hotel restaurant in an extremely touristy city.

We went here for lunch and ordered the daily paella.  It was amazingly delicious and we enjoyed seeing them make it over the open fire pit.  The lunch menu is limited so just a warning.  Dinner gives you all the options of the tapas.

On my Blog, http://shineandsparklereport.blogspot.com/   I just posted about how how to achieve those weigh loss resolution goals.  I should have mentioned Jaleo as one of those ways.

High quality, fresh, and tasty food is abundant here.  The egg tortilla was simply the best egg dish I have ever consumed in my life.  But the prices are pretty high for small portions.  I know you are supposed to share multiple dishes, but there isn't a whole lot in each dish to share.  Splitting with two people is ok, but with a larger group?  Forget about it.  Each dish really just has enough maybe 2-3 bites. 

I'd say that this place is great if you are not that hungry and want some tasty bites or want to lose a few pounds.  But if you are any normal level of hungry, your money is probably better spent somewhere else.
Big fan!  I love tapas because I can try a little bit of everything!  The food was great, the energy was fantastic and our service was superb.  What more is there to ask?

Since Jose Andres does not have a restaurant in NYC I was really looking forward to trying the restaurant.  I went with one other friend and we ordered just enough food for the two of us and shared everything.  We started with the sangria which  I loved.  The predominant flavor was cinnamon, but it was light enough to be very refreshing.  
We split the stuffed olives (with Andres' special olives- what a surprising texture).  We also had the Croquetas de Jam√≥n Serrano, the Empanada de bacalao, and the paella special of the day.  Everything was so flavorful.  I put a warning on the bacalao empanadas.  While I loved, loved, loved them- they might be too fishy for others.  

I look forward to going back with a group and trying more things.

Man. What a place. My party of 8 was able to get an 8pm reservation same day. We were excited. We were all VERY hungry when we arrived. We ordered 16 dishes. By the end, we were all just done and none of us were all that full. Jaleo takes small plates to a whole new level. Example: one slice of cheese with 2 slices of bread. That went far with the 8 of us....

We made the best of it and cut it into the tiniest pieces you have ever seen. 

I will say the waitstaff was fantastic. We ordered a squid ink item we all hated and even though we ordered it, they comped us since we did not like it. I appreciate that.

My dining experience here was terrible, mostly driven by our server who was extremely rude, short, not relevant, and talked down to our entire table. I will not return and would not recommend Jaleo. One of our party had a hair wrapped around the mini burger, not just laying on the meat...but wrapped around. This is not the wait staff or management issue. But the reaction is on them and needless to say they were not apologetic and our server again was awkward and rude about it. With so many options in the area I would choose elsewhere...for the service alone. A shame had high hopes that our party would be respected like paying customers with options. Food was great, but so is the food at many other restaurants....and the service ruins the food.

After going to e' by jose' andre's I had had a hard time letting myself go.  My mistake.

We had a friend who had a friend visiting form out of town and she is a foodie so we decided tapas is the way to go.  We choose right, I will not go on and on about what we chose because the menu does change.  We had an amazing server who could help us choose wine for our palates not for our food she actually had a very good knowledge of wines and it flavors, she choose mine perfectly and gave me the option to change later but I enjoyed it so much I didn't.  

Next is food being a newb for the front of the house we needed guidance we asked and she responded.  Boy oh boy did she respond well, every corse we asked about she told us yes or no or guided us to something we may like better.  We loved EVERYTHING the manager even came over at one point and we asked about the Porron http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porron      it is so much fun and so worth the money a definite must do!!!!!!!

We left so happy we were treated amazing, personable and approached in a way that we felt at home.

We will be back!

I was in Vegas for a conference earlier this week. My colleague and I stumbled across Jaelo as we were walking through The Cosmopolitan. Quite frankly we chose it because of the funky, interesting atmosphere.

But wow...the FOOD. Every single thing we tried was amazing...the garlic shrimp, skirt steak, veal cheeks...all of it. And the servie was great.

I would recommend and definitely go back again.

As mentioned by others the "Jose's Gin and Tonic" truly is a thing of beauty. It is Hendricks Gin, finished in a large Bordeaux style wine glass (or so it seemed) and poured skillfully over a spherical ice cube.. said to "keep the cocktail at an even temperature throughout the life of the drink" .. and so it did. Garnished with Juniper leaves and berries, it was really the most beautiful Gin and Tonic I have had.. (ive had many, many...)and at $17 a pop, you would want nothing less. 

This was not my first time at Jaleo, but it was definitely the most thorough meal I have experienced in the establishment. Usually a bite or two of a small plate or three, and I'm golden with cocktails and good company. 

This time it was all that and more with the addition of some fantastic roasted lamb and house paella.. which this night was rabbit, chicken and vegetable. Finished with the most excellent custard dessert served aside a citrus spuma and orange 'ice-cream'.. it was a perfect pairing with glass of 15 yr aged Spanish sherry. Couldn't have asked for more in the flavor department. 

You must be prepared to drop a hefty dime or two for all the small plates and large plates that create an experience such as I have described, but I do believe it is worth it. (Our bill was just shy of two Benjamin's) We were left with smiles on our faces and a great experience at a fantastically flavorful favorite on the Las Vegas Strip. Go Go Go!
This is such a fun place! The tapas were amazing. The paella was the best I've ever had. Definitely try the french toast dessert, the Paella, the shrimp and lobster fritter and the flan dessert!

Didn't eat  but sat at the bar and had a few apps.  Nick our bartender was so accommodating.  Didn't have a cocktail on the menu that was up my alley he made me something so tasty and was so friendly made my whole visit worth seeing the hotel.  The apps he recommended were noteworthy (grilled asparagus and endive with goat cheese).  CHOOSE THESE.  Love nick!

Really enjoyed this place.  There a good selection of tapas to choose from and the portion size of each isn't as small as you would expect.  My wife and I did 5 plates and we were good.  Probably could do 4.  Service was attentive and cocktails were solid.

During my stay at the cosmopolitan and spending over $700 a night to stay there. I decided that we should go to one of the hotel restaurants so that we could get a great meal. We got all dressed up. I approach the hostess to find out when we could sit down and eat a meal and she told me it was a three hour wait. Keep in mind there was only about 10 people in the restaurant and it seats over 50. I questioned it but She gave no explanation. Super rude

I love coming here.  My boyfriend does not take me very often but on occasion he will.  I love tapas and I'm a girl- I don't think I need to say more!  Most locals go to Firefly but after all that food-illness jazz on the news I will only be coming here for my tapas.  The ambience is very nice and if you're lucky you'll have an unobstructed view of what is going on in the hotel/casino.  The staff has always been friendly and given good service so no issues there.  I believe they change the menu a little bit around every now and then but last time I was there I loved some bacon-wrapped dates with cheese in the middle!!!  I also had some empanadas and manchego cheese.  I love everything tapas like I said!

Jaleo is beautifully artistic with a trendy atmosphere. You feel excited sitting there and wait in anticipation to try the food. 

So here's the food breakdown

Selection of all cheeses   18.
Pasamont√©s  Manchego, Idiaz√°bal, Murcia al vino, Garrotxa, Ca√±a de cabra, La Peral

     * Delicious! Came with Fresh Raisens on the vine, dried apricots and roasted almonds
---

Jam√≥n Ib√©rico de bellota 'Fermin'
Cured ham from the legendary, acorn-fed,Black footed Ib√©rico pigs of Spain   22

     * This was the best ham I've ever had. And it had better be for over $5 a micro-thin slice. All 5 pieces makes up one regular piece of bacon. That's one expensive piece of bacon!
---

Ajo blanco con cangrejo
Chilled almond and garlic soup with crabmeat and green grapes  12

     * This definitely took a bit of getting used to. I love vinegar, and that's a good thing considering that's exactly what this tasted like. Vinegar with Cream with little bits of fresh lobster and grape halves. 
---

Piquillo relleno de 'txangurro'
Piquillo peppers stuffed with Dungeness crabmeat  14

     * 2 pieces. This was pretty hearty. The peppers were nothing special but the sauce and crab were yummy. 
---

Gambas al ajillo
The very, very famous tapa of shrimp saut√©ed with garlic  10

     * 5-6 shrimp. AWESOME! Favorite so far

Trigueros con romesco
Grilled asparagus with romesco sauce  12

     * Nothing special. 5 spears of asparagus. Plain sauce
---

Huevo frito con caviar
A fried organic egg topped with caviar  16

     * This just tasted like a poached egg that you dip bread into. The caviar was so light you could not taste it unless you ate it seperately. 
---

Carne asada con piquillos Juli√°n de Lodosa
Grilled hanger steak with piquillo pepper confit  14

     * 7 slices, 3-4oz? Again, nothing special. Cooled perfectly.  
---

Canelones tradicionales de cerdo, h√≠gado de 
pato y trufas con salsa bechamel
Pork, foie gras and truffle canelones with bechamel sauce  14

     * This was absoloutely my fav after the shrimp. A bit salty but Mmm! Warm and hearty, the truffle flavor standing out. Delicious!
---

Lobster Paella 28

     * Total disappointment. The presentation was gorgeous, the Paella tasted like rice cooked in the juices of lobster, extremely salted. We left more than half of it on the plate. We ate the half tail and claw. 


I really wanted to try the Sangria but they do not sell by the glass, another disappointment. 

Overall it was fun, but you can have much better and cheaper food in NYC.

Reluctantly went here as I'm not a big fan of Bazaar in LA and some friends didn't care for Jaleo in DC.  I left delighted.  Service was great.  We had the pleasure of having Morgan wait on us, and she was an absolute gem.  Ambiance a bit noisy but that's to be expected for the location.  Food was out of this world.  Had the octopus, cauliflower, shrimp saut√©ed in garlic, lobster paella, jamon, Olive Oil ice cream and Spanish toast.  All extremely flavorful and delicious.  I would totally go back.  Sangria was good but not great.

This place is amazing! We had tapas elsewhere in Vegas but this is hands down the best option. Their potato dish is so simple but amazing and goes with absolutely anything. The fried eggplant with local honey is unique and fresh. Their sangria is also very refreshing and not overly sweet with a hint of mint which went very well with the other flavors. The chef's selection of various dishes sounds like a good deal but we went during restaurant week and the options were kind of boring with the menu they had. One of the best meals we had while visiting Vegas!

JOSE ANDRES in TOWN!!!! YAY!! I LOVE LOVE LOVE JALEO!!!!
Everything is DELISH!!!!
Only 4stars because the serive is a little slow!

I've been to two Jaleo restaurants previously (one in Washington, DC and the other in the DC-area nearby in Crystal City, VA).  I had loved my previous experiences but my experience at Jaleo in Las Vegas (located in the Cosmopolitan hotel) fell short of my expectations.  The food was mediocre and REALLY not worth the prices charged... 

I visited by myself during lunch before my friends arrived at the hotel for my friend's bachelorette party weekend.  I decided to get a nice meal and a drink to while away the time, since I got there extremely early (yay for flying in from the East Coast!).  I ordered a berry cocktail, which was nice, but a bit watered down and not worth the $16 it cost.

I went with their lunch special, which was $26 for salad, gazpacho soup, and paella.  I was hoping for something substantial, but the food was disappointing.  The salad consisted of a few pieces of lettuce with not much sauce or anything special to it.  The gazpacho soup was good, but small.  And the paella?  It took forever to come out (at least 20 minutes) and it was a TINY portion!  I was not full leaving the restaurant.

Service was decent (I was one of the only ones there because it was so early), but my server misunderstood me when I said I wanted tap water and brought out a bottle of still water.  He was nice when I described the misunderstanding and did not charge me for it - I really appreciated that and reflected my appreciation in the tip.

Overall, though the service was good, I did not enjoy the food. Total rip-off. I would not recommend this restaurant.  I will still visit other Jaleo restaurants in the future (in the DC area, where I live), but I would not visit the one in Vegas again.

Have been here twice in the past 18 months.  Most recent visit was last week.  Both meals were on the company dime, thankfully.

This is average, uninspired tapas style cuisine.  Their squid ink calamari is sickly pungent and raw (uncooked?), the paella was overly salty and was served on a white ceramic plate instead of a rustic skillet or pan.  The other 10+ dishes we had were forgettable and either lacked or bore too much flavor. 

Lazy, unenthused service (we waited 15 mins for the bottle of wine we ordered.  When finally asked, our server informed us the bottle was sold out.  No explanation regarding the time we were left hanging, no apologies, zero level of care).  That being said, some of their younger male wait staff were polite and professional.

Mediocre value, at best. Yes, this is the Cosmopolitan and an upmarket location - but if you are going to bend me over the barrel whilst I dine, at least serve me larger portions or improve the quality of your food. 

The best thing about this place was the fact they serve Estrella on tap.

Jaleo does not pass Go, does not collect any more of my money, does not receive repeat patronage.

A variety of tasty tapas. The lamb, chicken, Serrano ham, and vegetable paella were very good.  The sangria was especially good.  

The drawback is the fact that it pricey, and you'll spend a lot to get filled up.

Had a good dinner here and its worth trying but I probably wouldn't go back because.....hell, its Vegas and there are so many restaurants that I'd like to try.  There are really only a couple that are my "standards" that I always go to when I'm in town.  

I spent a little time in Spain and fell in love with Tapas, but to me, Tapas is also an atmosphere and this is Vegas and its trendy and not as enjoyable as being in a small bar in Spain eating some great Tapas that were just made.  I'm used to the menu being written on a small chalkboard or on the wall and not a fancy menubook or a wine list on an iPad.

Nevertheless, there are some great dishes here worth trying.
1.  Olives/liquid olives - the kalamata liquid olive concoction was fun and tasty and we laughed when the little olive balls popped open.  As long as you like olives, you should get these.
2.  Veal cheeks - if you are weary about eating these, stop reading this, turn off your computer, and go get a plain ol' burger you loser...these were really awesome.  One of the girls in our party got really upset when the waitress took the plate and there was still a little bit of potato and sauce left in the bowl.  Bummer.  We shared this with a group of four and it was perfect because given the richness, any more than a couple of bites would have been overkill and there was more food to try.  But I would order this every time I come to Jaleo.
3.  Ham fritters - delicious.  Why would you want to get chicken here?
4.  Bacon wrapped dates - I get these whenever I see them on a menu and they were great here.
5.  Skirt steak - reminded me of when I was in Spain because a piece of skirt steak, with some roasted red peppers, and frites was a staple meal.  Would have been happy if I didn't have to share this one.
6.  Paella - it was the lobster one.  They make one large batch(of varying ingredients) every 45 minutes or so, so you can get the one just made hopefully, or wait a short while and get some after some other tapas.  We started out with this and it was just okay.  I would just rather order Paella at a restaurant that specialized in that, so you get the pan and a chance at the socarrat, because it was a little cold and just tasted okay.  If you don't know what socarrat is, google it...its important.
7.  Chorizo - tasted good but not wowed.
8.  Bread with tomato and Manchego - okay, but would rather have just had some Manchego by itself.  

We did have a nice bottle of Albarino that ran about 100 bucks.  While Patatas Bravas is an absolute for me when I go out for Tapas, they don't make them the traditional way here and I appreciate our server letting us know that.  So we passed on those this time.

I would recommend swinging by for a little wine and a few tapas before dinner somewhere else(see above list/Top 5).  The restaurant smells fantastic which is almost worth a short visit in of itself.  Don't bother with the paella.  Save room for other stuff.

Wonderful second experience at Jaleo! Most authentic tapas in the US. Transports me right back to Spain through my taste buds. Makes me so happy!

Standout dishes: pan con tomate, gazpacho, jamon y quesos

Skip to save room: patatas bravas (not crispy, too much mayo), gambas (overhyped and overcooked)

Can't wait to go back!
Iberico ham from Spain was exquisite!  Paella was beautiful! And all the sinful drinks were perfect!

I am struggling to understand why this place does not have better reviews.  We have been there twice now and both times had our favorite meal in Vegas.  I grew up in Spain, and know Spanish food.  Every dish we had was really good, the sangria was great (not too sweet, but potent), and the prices were a pretty good value.  Our waitress was not only beautiful, she knew the food well and made great recommendations.  We began with the endive and orange salad, then had the seafood croquetas (best I've ever had), really tender pulpo a la gallega, paella de gambas (with a smoky rice with plenty of soquerat and 6 beautiful whole-heads on shrimp) and a chocolate cake.  Great atmosphere, great food, and pretty good price.  We'll be back for sure.

When you want unique tapas, this is the place to go!   We enjoyed

1) Ajo Blanco Con Cangrejo - chilled almond and garlic soup with crabmeat and green grapes    This coarse soup is very tasty; the grapes were thinly sliced instead of just a whole grape.  Highly recommend.

2)  Ostras 'gin & Tonic' five oysters with lemon, gin and tonic 
Be sure to slurp the wonderful tasting gin sauce before enjoying the oyster.

3)  Remolacha Con C√≠tricos
a salad of red beets, citrus, la peral cheese and pistachios with sherry dressing 

Tasty and a nice pallette cleanser between tapas....

4) pork and foie gras canelones with bechamel sauce 
Unique way to serve foie gras - and enjoyable.  Since we live in a state where foie gras is illegal, it was so fun (yet naughty) to enjoy such a fun dish. As mentioned by others they are like foie gras cannelonis.

5)  Bikini De Jam√≥n Ib√©rico, Queso Manchego Y Trufas
pressed s√°ndwich of ib√©rico ham, manchego cheese and truffles

The truffles makes this a unique smooth and enjoyable dish.

We enjoyed sangria with dinner.....

and then we had their wonderful cappuchinos and desert of 


    Pan Con Chocolate

    chocolate custard with caramelized bread, olive oil and brioche ice cream

Olive oil ice cream - yum, the best.  

This is our second visit to Jaleo and the food was as good and as unique as our first visit.  Our server was good, but not as wonderful as our first visit. Our first visit the server went out of her way to recommend and delight us with her recommendations for both alcohol and tapas to order.   

As such, we saved about $70.00 this 2nd visit......as we ordered fewer drinks and left with a little less alcoholic buzz.    We would have gladly paid that $70.00 for the same sever in the future....however.  She was amazing.

Stuck to what I know and like for tapas, and it was great. Wonderful protein binge - gambas, embutidos (made sure to get the bellota), quesos, chorizos, then added the papas and 2 types of asparagus.  Add a glass of Albari√±o and everyone was happy.
Loved the whole experience! The Embutidos with The Estrella Cerveza were the Bomb, The Paella Rocked! Dessert was Amazing, Flan is my favorite, creamy and not overwhelming sweet!

Probably some of the best food I've eaten ever. Seriously. There were 4 of us and we indulged by ordering probably close to 20 different tapas dishes. The bill was outrageous but worth every penny. 

A few highlights: 
- The croquettes were served in a sneaker. Yes, a running sneaker. Not sure why, but it was cool all the same.
- This place is in the Cosmopolitan which is a hip hotel in Vegas. This place may be trying to be a little too hip. It was too bright and felt like it was in the middle of a mall. You could see everyone walking by outside. Granted, it's in a Las Vegas hotel/casino so we knew there'd be some level of loud excitement surrounding us, just not so much. 
-   Service was good, but odd. We never really knew who our waiter was. It kept changing. 
- We did not eat one bad dish. Some were better than others, but none were bad.
- Bread was hard to come by. Tapas often had incredibly delicious sauces (the "mojo" for example) and it's a shame to waste that sauce. We asked for bread to dip and got 3 little tiny pieces (for $3). It was not enough bread, at all. We ordered a few more of them. This did not spoil our appetite one bit. 

A few of my favorite tapas: 
- Grilled asparagus with Romesco sauce - the Romesco was incredible
- Croquettas de pollo (my Cuban mother-in-law makes really good croquettes but these blew hers away!) Creamy inside, crunchy outside, so much flavor  
- Papas arugas - The mojo made this dish! Without it, this is basically just salted, boiled tiny potatoes.  Thanks to a duo of mojo's (verde and rojo) this dish delicious
- Warm Brussels sprouts salad - this had a really nice citrus flavor to it and was like no flavor combination I've ever had with Brussels sprouts before 
- Fried dates in bacon with an apple mustard sauce - like candy. Seriously. 
- Seared scallop with pine nuts - melt in your mouth good 
- Mussels vinaigrette - plump and juicy mussels with aromatic broth - another reason we needed all that bread! 
- Grilled hangar steak with mustard sauce and blue cheese - incredibly tender and great combination of flavors 
- Shrimp saut√©ed with garlic - it's a traditional tapas dish but it tasted better than any other version of this I've had before 
- Oysters gin & tonic - I can't eat raw oysters for a few more months but my tablemates raved about the gin & tonic sauce 

Just ok: 
- Pan con tomate with manchego cheese. Not bad at all, just not earth shattering 
- Jamon Iberico - it was from some fancy black footed pig in Spain. It wasn't bad but it wasn't all that great either. It was the most expensive thing we ordered that night  
- Homemade grilled pork sausage - I'm not a huge sausage fan in general (get your mind out of the gutter, THAT's not what I mean). This was not bad at all but just not one of my favorites  

I know there was more but this is all I can remember. We had no room for dessert. The 3 folks at the table who aren't pregnant polished off several carafes of Sangria and seemed very please with it, and with themselves.  We finished with coffee and each one came in it's own little press (Spanish press, not French I guess) and a timer to tell you when to "press". The concept was great but servers came over and pressed for us before the time was up. We were all disappointed that we didn't get to press our own. Silly for us to care, I know - but why bother giving you a timer and telling you what to do if they're just going to do it for you!  Damn good coffee though - even my  decaf (booo) had nice flavor.

Creative dishes, we had a little shoe with tapas.  It was very visually appearing including the fire pit and the managers with nice attire but really, if I really put my head into it, I would have gone home to my modern gastronomy and cooked for myself for a way cheaper price.   However, if you want to blow some cash to get some eye visuals, it is great to look at your food and leave hungry for more.  This place to me is for starving models that likes to eat with their eyes.

I came here with a group of friends for my birthday dinner. We had the 13 course tasting menu. 

Some initial downsides were: very crowded and has an "energetic" environment. It's difficult to get them to agree to a large dinner, and when they do, you have to do a tasting course. When you do the tasting course you have to sign a contract. If you sign the contract you guarantee the # of folks in your party.

In our case, half the table decided they didn't want to eat and so they walked out. This left me arguing with the F&B manager for the night, who produced a copy of the contract - that was oddly missing the page where I wrote that the size of the party could change (and signed off on by the F&B manager for the restaurant)

I seriously argued with this person for over 20 minutes going back and forth as to the best course of action, while all my guests sat waiting. On my birthday dinner. 

Eventually we reached a draw and decided to just eat. So the food started coming and it was actually AMAZING! It has been a minute so I forget ALL the courses but here are the ones I remember:

- the bruschetta w/ tomato - amazing. I still think about it. 
- dates w/ bacon 
- the paella of course

Unfortunately there were more issues...after the first 4-5 courses came out, we sat for 30 minutes without a single additional course coming. This was actually a good thing (wait and see). After pointing out to the waiter that no food was coming to our table, he went back to the kitchen and did something because orders started coming out, but not in the order on the menu. My guess would be that the kitchen fell behind on our table, got yelled at, and fired whatever they could get immediately. So props to them for getting things moving.

Dessert was delicious. The wine list was amazing. 

And, our F&B minimum was eventually adjusted due to the failure at the table. 

Following are my recommendations for this spot:

- it's too high volume for a large group. Come in smaller groups (less than 10) and order off the menu instead of getting a tasting menu.

- don't sign a contract because if things don't go your way, they'll be inflexible and refuse to work with you, even a little bit.

- if you do sign a contract then get the private room at least. 

I'm giving this spot 5 stars for the food and taking 3 stars away for the awful customer service.

Me and 2 friends had the chef tasting last night , it was unbelievable, every course was a trip to Spain 
Chef Jose really did a great job on this place , from the food to the decor  can't wait to go back 
And not to mention what a great thing he is doing for the people of Puerto Rico

We were a bit disappointed with Chef Jose Andres' China Poblano, so we didn't have high expectations when we ventured out to Jaleo on our last night in Vegas.  There was no need to worry!! This place was fantastic!!

We were seated immediately for our reservation and greeted by our friendly waiter, who made some great suggestions for the tapas style dishes.

We started with jamon iberico.....OMG...melt in your mouth, salty, nutty goodness of the iberico pig.  We were both in awe....we started to feel much better about our meal here after that.

We then had the liquid olives....how do they do that?  I think the liquid olives tasted more like olives than the actual stuffed olives that came with it.  Both were soooo good!

After that, we had the spicy chorizo wrapped in crispy potato...perfect combo.  Loved the flavor of the spicy chorizo...left a bit of heat but not too much.

My larger dish pick was the Rossejat....paella made with angel hair like pasta and shrimp.  There was ham in there as well.  Delicious!!  I especially loved the crispy edges that burned a little against the cast iron skillet.  It was served with some garlic butter sauce, which I dipped the shrimps in....just heavenly.

My BF's pick of the night was Secreto Iberico....the skirt steak of the iberico pig, which came with pan con tomate.  This was THE BEST pork dish we both have ever had.  It was so juicy, tender, flavorful....ok, I'm drooling just thinking about that wonderful piece of meat....mmmmm.  Pan con tomate was good too, but nothing compared to this piece of meat.  I think we'll be dreaming about it until the next time we can hit Vegas again.

Dessert - flan and some apple tart thing...can't remember the exact name, but also very delicious.  Apple and cinnamon wrapped in brioche with vanilla bean ice cream...so good.  Flan had a bit of a citrus taste to it but the consistancy was perfect.  

If you're anywhere near Vegas, go here and try the secreto iberico.  You will not be disappointed.  Skip China Poblano and head straight here to Jaleo...I wish we had, so we could've had time to have it twice!!!

Wasn't amazing. I've given everything about the Cosmo 4 stars so far because I was great.. But not amazing. Especially for the price. The server suggested so many things, even a great wine but they didn't deliver like he described. Verrryyyyy salty and the paella felt like it was leftovers warmed up. The cheese plate at the end was the only saving grace otherwise this would be 3 stars. It was artful and delicious. We had fun and the food was great but not what I wouldn't expected inside the Cosmo

One of the worst dining experiences of my life.  The food was absolute crap.  I have been at Jose's restaurants in DC and have really liked them.  However, the food at his Vegas place was inexcusable.  I have not sent a dish back to a kitchen in 20 years and at this restaurant, I sent two back.  One was inedible and one did not contain the ingredients stated on the menu.  The manager was of no help.  I did have some nice wine, though.

Highlights/lowlights 

1) really fun atmosphere
2) pricy for what you get, but that's Vegas
3) decent food

Came to Jaleo really late on Friday night with a co-worker. As you expect at a nicer Vegas restaurant it was super busy so we sat at the bar. The bartender was really nice and helped my co-worker and I pick out a few tapas. Prepare to pay between $14 and $30 per small plate, which is expensive for tapas but Vegas in General is expensive. I had a sparkling sangria coupon (woohoo!) so I ordered that. The drink was okay but like some other reviewers mentioned not as good as some of the other drinks I've had at other Jose Andres restaurants. We ordered a chorizo, and a shrimp tapa. Both were pretty good, unfortunately neither were as warm as I felt they should be but the flavor was great. We didn't do the paella which is a big deal here! I think how it works is they switch which paella they make every few minutes and when they switch the chefs ring a big bell and everyone yells "Jaleo!!". It was fun and you kind of felt like you were at a party! 

Overall, Jaleo is definitely worth a try if you are a Jose Andres fan and staying in the area but you could probably find a better tapas restaurant on the strip.
Amazing meal and always phenomenal service. This is my second time and I've done the tasting both times. It blows me away with such a great deal for the price.

This was one of the best restaurants I've been to in a long time. 

Started with one of each of the house specialty GIN cocktails which were to die for!!!!! $20 each. Ordered and received in less then 3 minutes. 

Started with the house special black foot ham at $35 an oz it was WELL worth it. Nutty, robust amazing! 

Chicken croquettes served in a shoe. Tasted almost like a chicken pot pie, but in a light breading. 

House chorizo wrapped in potato chips. 

Octopus served salad style and we loved it so much we had the octopus with potatoes too. One was boiled one was saut√©ed yet both seemed boiled. Still great. 

Oysters with gin and tonic... Yup. No seasoning needed. 

The house shrimp tapa, was a must try!! Sauce was some of the best I've ever had. 

Finished with the NZ lamb
 
 And the house pork dish which I expected a tiny bit more from, yet still some of the best pork I've ever eaten. 

Enjoyed a 06 red from Spain and fished with the flan. 

So why 4 stars. Well Jaleo you can thank the snotty little host EMILIA at the front with her sarcastic ugly attitude for that one. It was otherwise perfect. [there were 2 that night, the one who sat us was kind and polite.. Complimented my hair and outfit I asked her name I believe it was Jessica] I hope I didn't mix up the 2! 

A must try restaurant. 

Service was perfect. She knew everything. A tall blonde women with beautiful eye make up and a lovely smile! Thank you for all your suggestions.

I was very excited to get the chance to eat here. They have really good, authentic Spanish food like I had while studying abroad in Spain. Great atmosphere in the Cosmopolitan. Our waitress was excellent giving a very thorough overview of the menu and a good recommendation for a bottle of wine. She knew a lot about the restaurant's history and that of the chef. A nice touch was the custom drink list on an ipad left on the table; first time seeing that. 

The tapas themselves were very good. We tried an assortment of tapas, but did not have the paella. Next time, we will try that. I will definitely return next time I am in Las Vegas.

I was excited to try this spot as I'm a fan of the chefs other spots. But was disappointed from the moment I walked in (and probably should have gone with my gut).  Very few customers in for lunch. Servers still setting up. And then the big blow (but a fluke) - they had an out of control fire in their fireplace.  Ended up sampling 3 small plates. Didn't finish any of them. It's been a week since I was there and they are barely memorable enough to remember. I wanna say peppers. Maybe a cheese course. And super salty sardines or anchovies.

If you want to pay a lot of money for a little bit of food, this is the place to come. First time I tried a "tapas" place and probably will be my last. I get the whole idea, blah blah blah, but why would you want to pay MORE money for LESS food. The $8 burger was actually comical to look at. Maybe about one inch in diameter. Service was good, staff was friendly, location is great, food definitely was delicious, but not my cup of tea.

$25 three course pre-fixe for lunch. What a great deal for authentic Spanish cuisine. Tapas is the norm in Spain and the flavors here are authentic and tantalizing. This place is a must visit. Don't forget to order jamon. Real Iberico jamon is pricey but worth every penny. You have to have it. I have been to Spain half a dozen times and Jaleo reminds me of Spain.

I am a fan of Jose Andres and always look forward to his cooking. 

The food was great, the service was good and the atmosphere was light and outgoing. The Sangria was very good and refreshing.

Chistorra envuelta en patata frita were tasty and a good starting dish. I would NOT order the papas bravas becasue they were not what i excpected. They are more like lays potato chips. 

The garlic shrimp aka  Gambas al ajillo were amazing with the perfect blend of flavors. I totally recommened them. 

Needless to say the PAELLA is a MUST. Its very rare to have good authentic paella so dont miss out. 

I cant help but laugh everytime people say  that the portains are small. They are not small, they are Tapas......I enjoyed my expernice at Jaleo and had fun order all kinds of dishes.

Located in The Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas. this tapas place is not as good as its east coast counterpart in Washington DC.  That being said this place is still pretty great. The menu is in constant flux, and I mean that as a good thing, there always is something new, and sadly something great is no longer there. So the method is if you see something interesting on the menu order it, for it may be gone tomorrow. But fear not it will most certainly be replaced with something equally interesting, so make sure you come back and try that before it too is gone, such is the circle of life, or in this case the circle of tapas. Live it up you are in Las Vegas for cryin' out loud!

Delectable food (don't miss the lobster and shrimp fritters), but the portions are too small. 
Yeah, yeah, I know. This is encountered a lot in higher-end restaurants, but we're world travelers and have eaten in the finest spots from NYC to Paris, and Jaleo is a little stingy on their portion sizes.
The service, however, is impeccable, and the handcrafted cocktails are among the finest we've had on the Strip.

I've been lucky enough to eat here twice on seperate occassions.  The food is consistently very good. I took some friends and my husband most recently. This place is perfect if you are looking for a nice relaxing dinner. This is a place you go if you want to take your time to have dinner. I recommend you order 2 plates per person and a piyalla for you to all share 3 plates if you are really hungry. It's a really great expierance to have in Vegas.

I liked the food, the attitude of the waitress and the overall experience, but this place is very average for the money you pay. For instance, I didn't feel like there was anything special about the appetizers. Their main rice dish was really good though, and I'm craving it right now.

Typically, in Vegas you pay a lot more for the same stuff you could get anywhere else, but sometimes you feel like, oh I might as well spend a few bucks more and get something excellenter. If that rambling makes any sense.
So delicious! There were so many veggie choices. We stopped in for a drink and a few plates mid afternoon. Perfect choice for snacking.

A fantastic meal with fantastic company. Why did it take me so long to try Jaleo and when can I return?

Loved the lively vibe of the restaurant. We were able to watch food like the delicious paellas be prepared with the open kitchen concept. Our waiter was great. He was attentive and conversational. Suggestions and menu information was given, but he was never pushy. 

The menu is tapas style so it's meant to be shared. This was perfect since my friend and I always share anyways. Everything we ordered was great. Paellas rotate daily so from the menu there will be two paellas available each day.

*D√°tiles con tocino 'como hace todo el mundo' (Bacon Wrapped Dates)- a burst of so many delicious flavors, the frying added to the level of flavor, the sauce on the plate was great with the perfect mere hint of mustard
*Vieiras con piniones y PX (Scallops)- perfectly prepared, the raisins and pine nuts on the plate paired so well with the sauce on the plate
*Gambas al ajillo (Garlic Shrimp)- one of my favorite plates, the sauce in this dish could be eaten alone, served with bread so that you can enjoy all of the great sauce
*Carne asada con piquillos 'Juli√°n de Tolosa' (Hanger Steak)- well seasoned, tender steak with a great pepper on the plate
*Paella of the Day (Short Rib & Mushroom)- highlight of the meal, the whole dish had amazing flavor and I loved the combination of short rib and mushroom
*Pastel Crujiente- absolutely amazing, the mousse was light and airy with the perfect amount of chocolate and coffee flavor, the crunchy hazelnut crust on top was rich and delicious

The menu is large and features a variety of proteins, cured meats, cheeses, paellas, and more. You could dine here over and over with new dishes to experience each time.

At first glance it is a very nice venue.  Very modern clean and we were greeted with a smile. Reviewing  the menu, it is in Spanish with an English explanation of what the dish consists of.  The names are a bit long even for me, a Spanish speaker . We were reviewing the menu with limited  knowledge of the restaurant and culture. 

Out Server Eric  failed to ask if this was our first time at Jaleos and didn't really bother to explain any specialty or popular items.  So we proceeded to order somewhat blindly .  We ordered two glasses of wine , the tuna tartare, the pork loin and chorizo clams. We really wanted the paella but were told we only had two options. We opted to not order the paella as we were looking for a seafood paella .  

Our tuna tartare comes before out wine. When we received the tuna tartare it was rather underwhelming, two very tiny cones. The pork loin was very thinly sliced . Once we were done with the first two items we were told they didn't have any clams available . At which point we decided to get the check and proceed to a different restaurant.

It could be that we didn't order the right items, but the experience over all was less than memorable .  With the prices on their menu and small portions ( yes even for tapas) we were expecting to be blown alway and Jaleos didn't deliver this time .

Exquisite Spanish tapas! High quality ingredients with attentive service. We feasted on a few dishes including the manchego cheese slices, scallops, montaditos (not on menu) and mixed paella! Ended with a flan and an espresso. On the pricy side but enjoy the food and experience! Will be back!

Overall: this place was very Vegas-y, in the sense that it had great decor, great service, and interesting food, but you definitely paid for it all. The restaurant is tapas-style, and they had a pretty wide selection of choices. Since we were a big group though, the waitress suggested that everybody pick 2-3 tapas, or she could put together a menu for us to showcase the menu. We opted for the latter option.

The food that came out was definitely interesting and generally tasty, and of a decent variety. But, being tapas, there was about one bite of everything for each person. In the end we got a good number of different tapas (needing about 2 or 3 of each to feed our table of 8). I really liked the bacon-wrapped dates, the (lamb?) ribs, and this one dish with some kind of spread with an underdone hard-boiled egg that you put on bread. I was less impressed with the paella, the shrimp, and the bruschetta-like dishes. The restaurant also claims it has the world's best gin and tonic...and while it was tasty and really well-done, I wasn't crazy enough about it to want a second one.

All in all, the food was fine, but the high price tag just didn't seem to correspond to how much I enjoyed the food. I actually think the 8 of us could've spent less and gotten more food that, on average, we were happier with at a steakhouse in the Cosmopolitan even...

Excellent food. We had probably 12 to 14 dishes and some were as good as anything I've ever had. It is a very unique menu and you can easily stray outside you culinary comfort zone and be pleasantly surprised at every turn. The veal cheeks, jamon iberico and spinach salad were off the chart good. There wasn't anything I wouldn't be willing to try here (High praise).

The service was good and the waiter's recommendations were all spot on. The only lag was before dessert and it was unnecessarily long. It was "can we go and just skip dessert" long. Glad we didn't because dessert was great too.

The biggest knock was where they sat us. We had a large party and they sat us outside the restaurant in a foyer area. The people watching was great but it was really loud and you felt like some drunk stranger was going to walk up and grab something off your plate.

Other than that, this was a 5 star experience.

Big smiley face.

Eat before you go. Tapas is a miss communication. Portions are very small. More like hors d'oeuvres. Left  hungry. Not even enough to share. Three items for 25 dollars. So after paying 60$ total I was pretty disappointed.  Frankly there are better dining options in the hotel.

The product that they are claiming is jam√≥n ib√©rico de bellota is definitely jam√≥n ib√©rico, but it is not de bellota. Bellota is made from pigs that were only fed acorns, and their jam√≥n definitely tastes grain-fed. It's also a tiny portion. Don't shell out $35 for it.

Their other dishes are inspired by traditional Spanish plates. In my opinion, they fall very short of their mark. If you're looking for authentic tapas, look elsewhere.

I can't say much about the ambiance either, dark and very loud. Las Vegas is full of great restaurants -- do yourself a favor and go find one.
This place is ridiculously good. Our waiter Donnie did all the ordering for us. Everything was just as delicious as the next. Mouth watering flavors and textures. The veal cheek was to die for.

This is one of my favorite restaurants and I have been here so many times...I love the Bazaar in LA and that's how I found out about this restaurant, as I'm a huge fan of Jose Andres. 

The food is usually consistently good and the last time I was there it left a bad taste in my mouth and figured maybe someone who cared at the restaurant would maybe read:


To starts...the server was pretentious and rolled his eyes at me asking for something different. (I know difficult people who order, and I'm not one of them. I think I asked for no onion.. Something that wasn't a big deal...). I always order their expensive ham. The stuff from Spain that is ridiculously priced but so delicious.. I always say what the hell. 

Well, most normal servers bring extra bread when you ask for extra bread... This server literally ended up charging me like 15.00 for every few pieces of bread they brought... After over $45.00 extra dollars w tax..I HAD to say something on principle. 

Well, apparently this is 'bread from Spain..' (I don't even know wtf that even means... Unless they're literally overnighting loaves of bread in from Spain... Doubtful). And Also the server let me know that I didn't clarify when I said, "can you bring extra bread for the table," I wasn't specific enough, etc'. 

I say.. Ok fine... Side note: after the waiter and manager continued to make me feel like no one else in the world could EVER make this mistake...not even flinching or offering to take any of the $45.00 Spanish bread off the bill- I debate in my mind if I should just let it go... Or again on principle.. Explain to them why they NEED to understand where I'm coming from or at least pretend to.. Because when someone orders extra bread for the table... The server SHOULDN'T presume that what is meant.. Is that they want the special Spanish bread that is $15.00 an order!!! Am I right or am I VERY right??? (At the risk of already being dubbed, that table w the annoying white girl who won't stfu about her bread... I just decided to go all the way and let them hate me... I was too far in to stop..)

So, I tell them that the last several times I've been here... My servers just act normal about it... See I'm spending like $80.00 on a few pieces of ham alone... And bring a few extra slices of bread.. Of their 'Spanish' bread... I told them this and said... I don't care what bread you bring... Just not the kind that costs $15.00 for 4 slices that you ring in 3X on my bill. The manager basically reiterated that I was incorrect for feeling any 'kind of way' about this, reminded me the bread is from SPAIN!! and made me feel like an even bigger jackass for continuing to say something. 

Let's say I was 100% wrong about this.. (Doubtful, but still..) .. They should make me feel like I am totally right cuz I'm the customer. Now... I've worked in so many restaurants and NEVER ever gave any clients or customers attitudes because that's just not the way this world works. The customer is and should always FEEL like they are right. 



After this, the passive aggressive manager showed me that he removed my Spanish bread from the bill...Then preceded to send over 3 baskets of their house bread when the meal was over, to make me feel like an even bigger jerk. The bread baskets were literally on top of one another with the black book check also on the table. 

I am not a fan of people giving restaurants 1 or 2 stars based on poor service if the food is consistent. And that's why this mark isn't lower. It should be a 1 star but the food is usually great. My problem with this experience is I wouldn't even classify this event as someone having a bad day. They repeatedly had many chances to make this bread fiasco just go away... And they enjoyed flexing their 'power' and making me feel bad/ awful about the entire situation. I used to go here once every 3 months... I haven't been back since this happened and don't intend to, as I can find equally great food with amazing service else where. Food for thought.

It's Vegas...it's Cosmo so my expectation to spend money is high. However, we are a table of 4 - we are over $300 into our bill and are leaving hungry. I'm too hungry to continue this review and need to stop writing before the other three people at my table will steals food from my plate. Avoid if hungry.

The food at Jaleo is delicious and incredibly flavorful. The dishes are very reminiscent of the tapas I ate in Barcelona. There wasn't a weak dish but we had our favorites: bread with tomato, shrimp with garlic, and pork sliders. We also had the jamon iberico, chorizo wrapped in crispy potato, paella with pork, and spinach.

The kicker is how small the portions are for the price. The paella was $36 for a tiny plate (hardly enough for 2 people) and even the bread was $12! Overall, we liked the energy and food, but question the value.

We came here to dine for my friend's bachelorette dinner.  However, we did not have the best dining experience.  First of all, everything was overpriced, even for Vegas, and especially for the quality of service and food.  Every item we got was showered in salt.  

Here's what we ordered:
Chicken and mushroom pallella- chicken was very dry 
The scallop and skirt steak- both way too salty
Garlic shrimp- lots of broth and not a lot of shrimp.  

**We asked for more bread (they gave us 2 little pieces) to eat with the garlic shrimp and they said they could not because they only had enough bread for their orders.  
The waitress even said "I'm embarrassed I don't know why they can't give you more bread"

Just comes to show they are not about the customer service.  I come to Vegas about 10 times a year and I have yet to have an experience such as this.  Needless to say, I will not be returning.
Beautiful space. Below average food for above average prices. Come for the ambience, not the flavors.

Okay, if you have read my reviews of Jose Andres' other restaurants, you know I consider him some sort of crazy, manic food genius.  So it won't come as any surprise that we thoroughly enjoyed our meal at his Vegas outpost.  Much better atmosphere and vibe than his DC restaurant by the same name, although nothing can compare to the culinary madness of his Hollywood outpost, Bazaar.

As other reviewers have commented, the plates are small, and the prices are a tad on the high side.  But as usual with Andres, the dishes are creative, the presentation is beautiful, and the ingredients are outstanding.

The pan con tomate was very authentic and the bread was great.  The seleccion de embutidos (various Spanish hams and sausages) was of course amazing (you can't screw up good chorizo or jamon iberico de bellotas).  The bacon wrapped dates were a very nicely done rendition of this Spanish classic.  The olives two ways (a la Feran Adria) are always a delight, especially the molecular liquid olives, and this version featured a black olive, very different from the green olive versions we have had before.  The high point of the entire meal may have been the veal cheeks, slowly braised until they were fall-apart tender, and served with some creamy mashed potatoes and a couple of lovely home-made potato chips.  The gambas al ajillo was the only dish we didn't enjoy - too much tomatoes (we prefer just garlic and oil).  The wine list is outstanding, and we had a couple of excellent Spanish reds with our dinner.

As always with Andres, an outstanding meal and a wonderful experience!

My tapas experience went only so far as Filipino tapa at home.  Did you know that it's not the same thing?  I didn't until I moved to Vegas. The tapas at Jaleo were culinary creations.  We tried the bacon wrapped figs, the shrimp, the ham, the bread, something else I cant remember, but they were all great.  My friend ordered everything for us because I was new to tapas. She's been to Spain - I didn't even know tapas originated from there - and she said that Jaleo served authentic tapas. Makes me want to go to Spain.  We also ordered sangria which was like fruit punch - I wanted bottomless refills. 

I often find that the best food is often not listed in the menu, and such was the case when we were given a complimentary special dish from the chef.  It was this mushroom/mashed potato dish that is now on my list for one of the best things I ever ate.  

The best is the scent of the food diffusing into the air from the grill and cooking station in the dining area.  We wanted to sample everything cooking on there, but I wouldn't have been able to eat out for the next two weeks had we done that. Jaleo is pricey, but everything was well worth the price.  I definitely would be coming back here next time I'm in the mood for authentic tapas (not the Filipino kind) and some gooooood sangria.

Had a wonderful time at e.   It's a separate table for 8 and it's quite an experience.   From prawns, to un√≠, to foie gras, to wagyu steak, to flan, each entry is better then the next.    The use of detail and dry ice makes each dish an experience.   Not cheap, but recommended if you want a food experience.  I did not do the $150 wine tasting but did enjoy the sangria.

This was an amazing stop while out in Vegas on a work trip.  There was a group of 4 of us who decided to come here for dinner.

The tapas were a fantastic option and offered lots of choices.  Here are two of my favorites:
                Endibias - this dish was full of flavor, light, and refreshing.  List 
                of simple ingredients put together for some amazing flavors.

                Berenjenas con meil - this was pure sweet and salty combined.  
                The eggplant was thinly sliced so it came out like a chip with 
                the batter making it lightly salty.  They then drizzle honey over 
                the dish to give it some sweetness.  The balance was amazing.

Some of the other items we tasted that were also very good: pan de cristal con tomate (like bruchetta, but more like tomato spread), shrimp paella, vieiras con piniones, and calamares romana (they were out of the ink alioli so we had garlic alioli instead).

We did not opt for a cocktail so can't review that area, but the service 
perfect.  We received our food at different times (as expected) but was still paced out where we didn't have too much food on the table all at one time.

Great place to have a wide variety of food for dinner that is delicious!

We ordered the 'Chef's Special' Paella Chicken & Mushroom thinking it would be a great dish to share.  Turns out the meal was mainly flavorful rice with a few dots of mushrooms and only enough for one person to eat.  We saw no evidence of chicken whatsoever.  My alcoholic drink was watered down and in the wrong size glass.  The wait staff were over attentive to the point where it was intrusive.  A sports game was playing in the background which was tacky and distracting.  The lamb chops were tiny but flavorful but the display plate was whisked away before we could finish the sauce.  The desert was delicious but small.  We spent over $100.00 for a small amount of food and it just wasn't worth it.

Needless to say we will not be coming back.

While in Vegas for CES week my hubby and I decided to mix business with pleasure and had date night.  I chose Jaleo as I was in the mood for tapas. 

We started with a carafe of their featured cocktail - Sangria, of course!  The sangria had a nice blend of fresh fruits and it wasn't overwhelmingly sweet. I don't particularly like sweet sangria so this was very easy to drink.

For food we started with a Manchego Cheese Bocadillo.  It reminded me of the baguette sandwiches in Paris.  The flauta bread wasn't too tough or crunchy which was great but this was my least favorite item of the evening.  We also ordered Patatas Bravas and it was 5 stars all the way!  The potatoes were crisp yet soft.  The spicy tomato sauce and alioli complemented the potatoes nicely.  Next came the Gambas al Ajillo which was basically shrimp saut√©ed in garlic. Great tapas dish!  We were still hungry so we decided to order 2 more dishes.  After perusing the large menu we went with Carne Asada and Chistorra Envuelta en Patata Frita.  Sounds fancy but it's chorizo wrapped in crispy potato.  These final 2 dishes were amongst our favorite!  I also adored the presentation of the wrapped chorizo. (see pics)  Our top pick of the evening was the Carne Asada which arrived last.  Our server didn't ask how we wanted it prepared but it came out perfectly to our liking - medium to medium rare.  The skirt steak was extremely flavorful and juicy.

TIP: Make a reservation as it can fill up quickly!  We went on a weeknight but being that it was CES week they were very busy.  Lucky for us, I made reservations on OpenTable so we were seated quickly.

After 7 years, this place has hardly changed.  Chef Andres' food remains tasty, and many of the standouts from my previous meal remain on the menu including the chicken fritters served in a shoe as well as the delicious cold soups - who knew gazpacho could be some creamy!  One thing I should say is that this place is known for Gin & Tonics and there are three very nice versions here.  As in my last visit, the only real disappointment was the paella - I think a proper paella needs to have a crispy rice component, alas this paella was just too soggy.

Just had lunch here, I order Salmon that after 20 minutes all the other food was served, and it never was served, the managers explanation was that they got to many people at once... If you are in the restaurant business, you are at a high end hotel that has conventions all the time, and your response is that CLOSE the dam business down

I read multiple reviews about salty food but I overlooked them. I mean, how bad can it be?  Surely they must be reading these reviews and adjusting. 
And I like food a little salty, it's probably just some oversensitive people. 
Unfortunately, the bad reviews were right and the paella was inedible. Even the greens were incredibly salty. 
I never return food but had to make an exception. Also, chicken and mushroom paella?  That's the best you can do in a tasting menu?  Not worth it.  I want something that I can't make myself for dinner. Disappointed.

Celebrating cousins 40th birthday! We were a big group of about 30 and it's always difficult if not impossible to please everyone in the table.  But this place assembled servers who knew exactly how to handle folks like us.  It was like an assembly line where each tapas were positioned proportionately on every table so everyone had a generous portion (to see our prize fixed menu pls see copy of our menu).  As our dinner begins to wind down everyone felt well-fed and satisfied. 

The restaurant, the service, and their tapas was really good! The servers were all attentive and knowledgeable about every kind of tapas being served.  The only snag, however, I will note is their Paella, which was supposed to be the centerpiece of our meal.  This fell short in the very essence of Spanish recipe, it lacked the paella taste.  I think saffron might be helpful in enhancing the taste and bringing the true character of this paella dish.  Their take on this dish is on the bland side and perhaps the rice is not the Bomba paella rice which is more suited to paella dishes.  

AMBIANCE: REALLY NICE
FOOD: ALL TAPAS WERE TASTY except the Paella
SERVICE: THUMBS UP

Overall I will give it another try and I'll be specific on the type of Paella we wish to order.

One of the best restaurants I've ever been to! Tapas is that small plate stuff so I was nervous to try it. The cool thing is that the food came right away. There were two different paellas; one had rabbit so that was awesome. 

I ordered a salad with grapefruit, onion, blue cheese, and pine nuts. That was a unique combination I wasn't expecting to like so much. Grapefruit sucks alone so that helps. Cheese always helps.

Ordered some blue cheese, pear, and cashew as well. The pear was like jello (without the Bill Cosby voice).

Other things we had were the spicy potatoes (okay), garlic shrimp, but my favorite was the (fried) bacon wrapped dates. Only in America you take a fruit and ruin it's nutritional value.

4.5


  1 star for trying to scale and find this spot in the clusterfuck of the Cosmo in HIGH heels!!!!!

 So I've been wanting to come to a Jose andres establishment for a long ass time! We made last minute rsvps and they told us the place was booked by one party and if it was ok to dine in the "lounge" area. Were like sure  no problem.  So we get to the Cosmo and this whole fuggin place is CF! The valet area sucks because the signage confuses the ish out of you. Anywho there was a concert going on and this meant more of a crowd than usual, im assuming. Finally we found the place. One thing im not feeling about these hotel eateries, is the feeling of being in some high end food court. All these places next to eachother and you can people watch the hell of whats going on. Its like a mall for real.

  So tip toe over to the hostess desk and they tell us to wait a little and the wait was a little to much for me but the hostess was soooooooooo nice. I must say the staff here are top notch! When we were seated at first I was not feeling this area with straw type chairs and large wooden communal table. It was so uncomfortable but it was what it was. My inner prayers were answered because one of the lovely hostesses told me about the rich folks that booked the whole damn place were leaving YAY! She walked us to our new table and walking there she said we were nice people, im thinking no you guys are!!!! They were so nice and sweet. The best hostesses I've ever encountered!

 So now were in those comfy booths. Im sippin on an adult shirley temple and pic a rum and coke with an ice ball. We start scaling the menu and some of the things I wanted the PIC didn't , like the Bikini De Jam√≥n Ib√©rico, Queso Manchego Y Trufas , he basically called that a ham sandwich and why should we get that LOL. Ok find we didn't get it. So we started with the goat cheese stuffed peppers.  Those were so BOMB but I wish they served 4 of those crack peppas instead of two. Grrrrrrr.  Next dish was the veal cheek with these CRACK mashed potatoes. The potatoes were like silk! Not one lump. Just velvet.  Ordered the garlic shrimp and those were tasty but didn't look like the pics I've seen of this dish but who cares this was good. Next dish was this sausage mushroom stew type dish and that was tasty as well. Very good sausage dish and I love mushrooms!!!!!  One dish that was a lil iffy was the fried chicken wings with this black ink moussey thing brushed around the inside of the dish. That ink stuff was salty blah!  The fried chicken was good but not black peeps good hehe.  One downer is not being able to order the paella of your choice for a small party. You can order what they're making that moment which sucked because I wanted the lobster paella!!!! Not the chicken rabbit one!  Next time I'll show up with a party of 5 and Ill get that damn lobster paella!!!!!!!
