We opted for tapas as the hubster and I love sharing and tasting a bit of this and a bit of that. So Jaleo it was for my love's first dinner of his birthday weekend. 

The pan con tomate is just like my bro-in-law makes when we visit him in Spain. Just wonderful and light. And YES, they make pulpo right; we were beyond ecstatic as we miss Spanish food and had to skip our trip this year. 

It DOES tend to feel like you're eating inside a mall, which means little to no ambience but the food is delicious and love that they have all sorts of gin-and-tonics.

Service was prompt and friendly. Check was hefty, but we thought it was worth it.

Thanks, Jose! Keep making good food, we'll keep coming back.

Went to this restaurant on the first night it opened.  Jose Andres stopped by our table to say hello. That night was my introduction to spanish tapas, which I have been addicted to since then.  Been there several times since the opening night and have had a great experience every time.  For tapas, the menu here  is pretty extensive.  Have tried most of the items on the menu and loved them all. Must have the sangria - it is amaaaaazing.

This was our last meal of the year. Spanish tapas restaurant that's a bit on the salty side, but overall was fine. Service was fine, nothing special. Loved the trio of hams and warmed brussel sprout salad. Mini burgers and chicken fritters were salty. Fritters served in a shoe...a retro Nike that's never been worn, we were told. Frankly they could do without the shoe preso - doesn't add anything nor does it fit the vibe of the restaurant, since they don't do anything else that's goofy like this. Nothing to really write home about. It's one of those been there once, don't need to go again.

I feel bad on giving this a bad review but the quality is NOT worth the price! It is extremely over priced and I found some of the dishes to be very very bland. I have been to Spain many MANY times, and the food compared to the food in Spain is very different. I have not tried their paella which is supposed to be the special so I might go back just to give it another try. However you get the same quality food by goinng to firefly at 1/3 of the price.

I saw Anthony Bourdain's parts unknown and he had a segment about the owner and the sub restaurant in Jaleo called e and I said wow when we come to Vegas we should eat here.  So I made reservations through open table but some of the reviews really scared me and I also told the staff it was our anniversary.  Me and my wife did the tasting menu and I had the wine pairing. My wife had the gin and tonic drink I am not usually a wine drinker but wanted to try the experience.  They started us off with the famous Iberian ham and cheese which was amazing and I can't remember all the dishes they were so much but the highlights for me were as follows:  The Iberian ham they have us generous portions of that but I loved the cheese also and wish we had more than two pieces.  The blood sausage was unique I had never tried it before.  Interesting flavors and the sauce accompanying the blood sausage was excellent.  The wines accompanied with these meals so far were ok for me I tried to meld the wine with the meals but for me they did not work well.  The watermelon salad was very good but I hate goat cheese with a passion lol my wife liked it a lot.  The gazpacho I did not enjoy i could not taste much of anything.  The paia was a bit of a disappointment the rise tasted way too oily and we were hoping for seafood but got rabbit and chorizo sausage on the side.  The rabbit was cooked perfectly and I had never had rabbit in my life.  The chorizo sausage was amazing and dish also came with spinach salad that tasted good also.  The wine pairing with this meal also was ok for me also.  By this time we were both very full and it was time for dessert.  The dessert was amazing amazing amazing amazing.  It was a chocolate cake and ice cream with a piece of fried bread I'm not sure what it was made of and olive oil was sprinkled on top of it which I think was an Amazing touch.  The best part of everything with this dish was the wine omg I was in heaven it was rich and filled with so many flavors.  The wait staff was wonderful our server was great and at the end of our meal they brought out a little bowl of ice cream with a candle to celebrate our anniversary.  Overall a wonderful experience come here with an open mind and heart.  It is a culinary and artistic experience.  If you want big dishes and chicken parmigiana go to another place.  My only wish was that paia was not as oily as it was.

This is a very sexy looking restaurant.  Cosmo is already a sexy hotel so it's no wonder it is located here.  Used to work at a tapas place so I was already familiar with the cuisine and let me just say, it doesn't get better.  Had some lamb that was just roasted for about 12 hours or so on a spit right there in the dining room.  Shrimps, mushrooms, cannellonis that were just velvety delicious.  It was all just amazing.  Dessert topped it off with chocolate, crumbles, mousse, and evoo.  My server was informative but not overbearing, which I appreciate.  That and my cousin was very cool company. Definately want to go back and have another awesome meal here.

I came here with my co workers for dinner and it blew my mind. We started the night with a bottle of red wine and a flask of sangria. We ordered the chef's choice. I don't even know half the stuff that came out but everything was amazing. One of the exotic food that blew my mind was the chicken liver? It looked like they melted cheese on top of it or something but it was really tasty. Tiny portions but somehow I left really full. I felt like I've tasted a little bit of everything. I would definitely love to go back to this place.

Prices are very high and the plates are small- but it is so good!
My favorite thing by far is the Pan De Cristal Con Tomate Fresco, which is toasted bread with a very flavorful tomato sauce on top. It's addictive. The best place to sit is at the island bar, where you get to see them make appetizers and most seafood plates.
If you are really hungry and want a lot of food, but don't like high prices, this is not a place for you. But, if you want a small meal full of flavor and don't care about the price, then you should seriously consider coming here once in your life.

Another Jose Andreas restaurant we had the privilege to try on our short Vegas trip.  Its Spanish fare served tapas style.  I like the feel of the atmosphere which felt festive to me.  There is a small bar area to the side which is where we sat and towards the back is a large open fire which is used for cooking.  I like the fact the bar doesnt have thousands of different types of liquor, its more simplistic but has all the necessities.  They have a handful of specialty gin and tonics which my girlfriend insisted we try (she had been there before and was impressed) and they tout as the best Gin and Tonics you will have have.  We ordered the Citrico and the Hierba. They were not wrong, these were the best Gin and Tonics I have personally had.  The taste of each was simply amazing.  Foodwise we had the Paella Del Dia, the Chorizo ib√©rico de bellota Ferm√≠n, and the selection of Cheese de Jose.  Everything was very fresh and had wonderful taste.  This is a restaurant I look forward to revisiting next time I am in Vegas.

The food was actually bomb again smaller smaller tapas and what normal top it should be played at but the food was delicious and I would go again for maybe a date or if I had one of my girlfriends who are into that Spanish style come and see me.  Overall pretty boring but great great customer service!

The. Best. Spanish. Restaurant. In North America. Period. You have to try the bread with fresh tomato (bread comes fresh from Spain every morning), all the tapas plates are amazing, the paella pops, and the olive ice cream is to die for!

Jaleo has a fun atmosphere and the food/drinks were great! I ordered the Jaleo Brambla and I'm convinced is the best cocktail I have ever ordered - Cinnamon infused vodka, pressed apple juice, orgeat, lemon, concord grape syrup. Try it, it won't disappoint! 

All of our food was excellent. We ordered Paella Valenciana (chicken, rabbit and green beans), Espinacas A La Catalana (saut√©ed spinach, pine nuts, raisins and apples), and Coliflor con Olivas y Frutos Secos (saut√©ed cauliflower with dates and olives).  All of our dishes were great and I highly recommend the paella!
The menu looked delicious but the taste was just OK.  All the iberico stuff tasted well like regular pork.  I have had iberico in Spain and the taste of their iberico was out of this world.

Finally made it to Jaleo.... after all this time.  
Sad to say that I was very disappointed. 

The restaurant had a great vibe.  It was promising.. then our waiter came.
Because I've looked this restaurant up on Yelp.. there was one particular item that I really wanted to get.. so I pulled it up on my phone and showed our waiter.
He seemed.. bored first of all.  When I showed him what I wanted, he just kind of nodded and said the name of the dish and walked away.  I guess since we weren't ready....

We finally placed our order - about 5 tapas.
I don't recall other than the Salmon Roe Cone and the Chicken Fritter thing that was pretty good and was served in a shoe... no clue why.

Here's what I remembered from my non-eventful dinner..
1. Shrimp in Gambas  - ehhh kind of rubberty
2. The fried stuff - Good but nothing that I couldn't get at any mediocre restaurant
3. Service - Waitier was not engaged.  Told me at the end of the meal if I didn't like my anchovy dish I should have told him in the beginning... well... I'm sure he noticed that the dish was barely touched when he dropped off the other tapas.  But I do give him props for taking it off my bill.  

Sooooooo all in all.. I should have stuck with my fav.. Julian Serrano.
Jaleo... Not worth it.

PS.. I left "hollow" but didn't want to try any more of the food since every single one was just kind of eh!

The tapas were ver tasty and ver expensive, but good in comparison to the paellas. The different type if paellas were not near as authentic as it should. Prefer Juan Serano for spanish foo, at the Aris
Very impressed with this place, our server was amazing. The tapas were incredible and loved the sangria!!!

I still can't over the fact that our food was served IN A SHOE. 

I've been to several of the Cosmopolitan restaurants (Beauty & Essex, Momofuku, Scarpetta) and they are all outstanding, but sadly Jaleo doesn't match up. 

I sat at the bar and ordered from their tapas menu (2 for $20 during happy hour.) I literally couldn't stop laughing when the server put a shoe in front of me with my food (croquettas de pollo) inside. Maybe it was cool and trendy to use unconventional plating a few years ago, but now I just want my food served on a plate. I also ordered the flauta de jamon y queso, which was like a long skinny sandwich. Also tried the pescado frito, or fried swordfish, which only came with one small piece. Both of those were served normally, and not inside clothing items. 

Despite the shoe, the food was actually OK, but not amazing. I would definitely recommend the margarita, it was smoky, spicy and delicious.

I tried too many things to list, but overall I'm shocked it doesn't have better reviews.  Almost everything I had was very good to great.  My theory is that people who don't usually do much fine dining plan to come here as their special meal in Vegas and are disappointed by how much it costs.  I think the food is overall impressive, and right on par with comparable restaurants in the Area.
Was so bad in every way, tried the chef  tasting menu, had four plates at one time, the food was nothing special, maybe nice to u whants quantity over quality. Never caming here again for sure.

Our dinner at Jaleo had hits and misses and all in all, it was quite mediocre.

I really enjoyed the paella that used short thin noodles instead of rice. It was very flavorful and filling. The sausage wrapped in thin potato slices and fried was disappointing - greasy and salty, but no depth to flavor at all. The smoked-cured ham was very good, especially with wine, since it was fatty. The steak was alright; nothing to write home about.

With the prices that Jaleo is charging, this is a pass unless you have a big group, then in which case, you'll have a great time, like the very loud and obnoxious table of rowdy women sitting 20ft away.

I think this was probably the first time I actually had tapas and I loved it. Since I didn't know much about the menu, I left a lot of the ordering up to my dinner companion. Everything we had was quite good and the prices on bottles of wine weren't completely unreasonable. 

There was one outstanding dish that thankfully ended the entrees; Canelones tradicionales de cerdo y h√≠gado de pato con salsa bechamel. In case you can't translate that, it was pork and foie gras cannellonis with bechamel sauce and sliced black truffles on top. It was to DIE for and not nearly as heavy as the description may lead you to believe. We even managed to have just enough room for some traditional flan with a light mango sorbet. Perfecto!

Our server was great, very personable and helpful and only gave us her personal recommendations when we asked. It's a pet peeve of mine when servers say "oh, that's really good" about every single thing you order or they try to get you to order something in which you have zero interest. The only reason this isn't a 5 star is because it was a trendy Vegas spot on the weekend and so it was packed and loud (even at 10:30pm when we got there). The prices are high, but it is Vegas; I'm actually surprised we didn't end up paying more.

I never get to fully enjoy any restaurants on the strip but because it was Restaurant Week, I figured this would be the best opportunity. I've been wanting to try Jaelo for their Paella, as a friend had recommended it. The pre-fix menu consisted of Tichi's Gazpach, which was a very refreshing summer soup; it was chilled! Ensalada Verde Con Achoas & than the main entree of Paella; chicken & mushroom. I love the flavors of latin food so I of course had to compliment my meal with a beverage; the sangria! It offered the perfect amount of fruity-ness yet refreshing with their basil in it. As Jaleo is known for tapas, in addition to our order we had to at least try another dish or two. We tried the cured chorizo and their version of brushetta. The chorizo is highly recommended; definitely small bites but the flavor was amazing and a little kick as well. The brushetta, well its a bit salty for my liking and would probably pass on this. But my main dish, the paella. It reminded me of a rice bowl with protein and veggies mixed in. I've never had paella before so I am unsure the flavor I was hoping to capture. However, the production and presentation is worth it in the end. They cook this in the open flame right in the open area towards the back. Once completed, bells are ringing and people say PPPAAAEEELLLLAA! 
Loved the open concept of the restaurant; very hip and trendy. Bar area offers a great atmosphere to mingle with the locals/tourist alike. It is also a great area to people watch as the restaurant opens towards the open foyer.

I LOVE their SANGRIA!!! My friend and I shared the half-carafe, which was about 2 glasses each. I don't know what sangria is "supposed" to taste like, but this one was really good. Like spiced fruit punch for adults.

This was my first time at a tapas place. We were having a late dinner (like 10:30pm-midnight), so we didn't want to stuff ourselves. With lots of helpful suggestions from our waiter, we ended up ordering (my english translations):

-Chicken fritters: 5 pieces served in a shoe. I thought it would be like popcorn chicken, but they had a creamy filling with a chicken pot pie taste

-Beet salad: yummy, refreshing, surprisingly filling. Beware the super strong blue cheese.

-Carne asada: this came out a little late. Meat lovers, specifically those like my roommate who love all-you-can-eat bbq, may be disappointed by the tiny portion (cut into about 6 strips). It's really delicious and quite flavorful though, worth savoring every tiny bite.

-Chocolate hazelnut cake: By this point, we were a little tipsy, so I can't really remember much. The praline ice cream on the side was the best.

We ended up paying $36 per person. Not bad for Vegas! Plus, we were surprisingly STUFFED (maybe from the sangria..) The atmosphere is very modern and hip, as is the rest of the hotel. I would definitely come back here with a larger group for a girls' night out :)

We had an amazing dinner at Jaleo tonight. 
So many yummy dishes. The lamb and the shrimp were highlights but everything was very good including the open fire cooked paella. We were happy that we also added a shared salad to our dinner. Service was perfect. Definitely coming back for more!

I ordered the croquetas de pollo. It was great until the last piece. A big chunk of chicken and was NOT tender at all. Damn. That was disappointing. So, I told my server (STEVE) about it and gave.a simple explanation why it wasn't a cooked correctly and he responded with a condescending "okaaay" (AKA okay, I get it, calm down". I was calm. He asked, "do you want me to bring you another one?". What he SHOULD HAVE said was, " sorry about that, et me get you a new one". He lost tip right there. Geez. Some attitude on this one. Lousy first time experience. Could have been a four-star review. Replacement order arrived and I was not chraged for the order. Thank you.

I've been here twice before but sorely disappointed with their food. I love the decor and ambience of the restaurant, and the servers have been very friendly and attentive. However, their food is pretty awful. Their food is Spanish tapas but their quality is far from authentic Spanish flavors. For example, if you order a Tortilla Espanola, you expect thinly sliced potatoes covered in eggs served at room temperature or even chilled. At this joint, they brought a piping hot omelette with eggs half cooked, so when I cut into it, the eggs were completely runny. While the seafood paella looked great (they came around to show us the pan when it was ready to be plated), it lacked flavor and had very little seafood (mostly rice). We ordered several other dishes but everything was pretty bad. For the price, it was a complete rip off and terrible food experience. 

I gave this place two tries and unfortunately, I won't be coming back here again. There are plenty of other restaurants in Vegas.

This is inside the Cosmo in Vegas and a little different than his other Jaleo locations or at least DC.  This is very Spanish and a tad more upscale.  It is mostly small plate tapas so good for sharing.  Great service.  Food comes as it is ready, not as ordered which is typcial for tapas.  Great options for meat, veg, seafood.  YUM!!  Enjoy!

Love this place and have come a few times. This time we came for my Birthday to try the paella. The hood broke the day before and as a result we could not order paella. It would have been nice to have been notified in advance since our reservation was so late we could not find anywhere else to eat dinner. Disappointing!

I can't begin to tell you how awesome this experience was. I have Celiacs (gluten intolerance) and I just told the sommelier John , to order whatever but of course glutenfree. Well most of their menu is naturally gf but the taste and service is out of this world!

Love this place! I come back every time I'm in town and I'm never disappointed. The gazpacho and paella are highlights. Service is always quick, friendly and attentive. I come here for a quick, casual meal and sometimes even for a tapa or two as a snack between meals! This is my favorite Jose Andres restaurant in Vegas

A shoe-in for being one of the most flavorful restaurants in Las Vegas!  Very confused by the 3.5 star rating. This place is awesome!

The food is so flavorful and well prepared. We had the pappas bravas, endive salad, chicken croquetas, and braised rabbit. The endive salad with goat cheese and grapefruit was AMAZING. I wanted another plate of it. 

We got the chicken croquetas for the novelty of the shoe presentation. They were yummy but the least yummy of the other items we ordered. I think they were $12. A fun photo op. Like the story behind it too. Apparently they had to design special shoes for the DC restaurant after concerns over cleanliness from the health department. (Kind of ridiculous because the food doesn't touch the shoe at all.)

The rabbit was tender but the skin had a nice crunch to it. We polished off allll the pappas bravas off in under 3 minutes between the two of us - they were so good!

I had a glass of cava and my boyfriend had a sherry flight that he seemed to really enjoy. 

The service was very attentive. The manager came by to check in too. 

The Cosmopolitan has such great restaurants. You could eat an amazing dinner every single night of your stay by never leaving the property. Just make sure you hit Jaleo up for something different that isn't your typical steakhouse or over-pretentious attempt at French cuisine. 

I would repeat this dining spot when in Vegas next.

Lunch Like a Spaniard
This $25 lunch lets diners pick 3 tapas from 3 different sections of the menu.  The first section has gazpacho and various salads/veggies.  The second section has fried items including Patatas Bravas and croquetas.  The third section has shrimp, chicken, chorizo, and beef selections.  You can add one of the featured paellas of the day for $7.

For my three items, I chose:
- Manzana con Hinojo y Queso Manchego (sliced apple and fennel salad with Manchego cheese, walnuts, and sherry dressing).  I've had this kind of salad at another tapas restaurant and I liked it here just as much as the other place.  The combo of apple and cheese is refreshing and light.
- Croquetas de Pollo (traditional chicken fritters).  This dish comes out in a hiking shoe, Chef Jose Andres' take on fast food.  Super fun and the croquetas were delectable.  I think there were four in the shoe, but I could have eaten more so maybe bring me a pair of shoes next time.
- Mini Pepito de Iberico (Spanish mini burger made from Iberico pigs and Iberico bacon.)  The menu states that these pigs are legendary, black-footed, and acorn-fed, but all I know is that it was one tasty little slider.

Our party of four also shared an order of the veggie paella and ended with the flan, which I would think are two dishes you should eat in a Spanish restaurant, verdad?  Happy we ordered them to complement our meals and so were our stomachs.
We arrived at noon on Saturday with reservations, however, the restaurant was empty since it had just opened.  A nice, open space, you can see staff making the paella in large pans.  Our service was excellent throughout and the tapas came out at a nice pace.  I would highly recommend this lunch for the ambiance, price, and fabulous tapas.  For a first experience at a Jose Andres restaurant, I am one satisfied customer.

Super excited to try this restaurant & wine pairing for Restaurant Week 2016.  The food looked delicious but was subpar.  Never happened at any other restaurant, especially in Las Vegas, but my party of 3 all left hungry. Not a little hungry, hungry that we drove to another restaurant & had another meal.

Having been to other tapas restaurants, I understand the concept of tapas being small plates, but not leaving hungry.

Restaurant Week really disappointed with this.

For those complaining about portion size, that's what the carafe of sangria is for. Keep drinking until you don't realize you've paid $12 for two slices of blue cheese (that you realize was worth it before the buzz kicks in). 

The ambiance is a very relaxed atmosphere, with the staff welcoming to the trendiest of clientele as well as to the fanny-pack-toting tourists. There are 3 kitchens, including one huge wood fired stove for the paella (which is absolutely divine, worth the 45 minute wait). If you're not sure what to get, the staff asks you about your tastes to give you solid recommendations.

Here's what we had with our sangria:
- watermelon salad (trust, you'll never look at watermelon the same)
- the blue cheese, pear and raisin plate
- the lomo (which was so good we had it twice)
- the garlic shrimp (also had a second round, and dipped just about everything else we ordered in the sauce)
- embutido (by itself)
- embutido (on bread with cheese - a nicely salted pork pizza)
- the paella with ribs (they only make two types a night but you can order one of the others if you're okay with ordering a huge pan for your table)
- chicken fritters which looks like coquettes but tastes like chicken pot pie, served in a shoe (yes, that says shoe - it's the chef's homage to a famous athlete)
- flan (super good, I'd come back just for this)
- chocolate mousse 

Everything we had was incredibly well seasoned, with no one taste overcoming the other flavors. Yes, the portions are tiny, but it invites you to try multiple dishes with your dinner companions (and to have more sangria - go with the red over the sparkling).

So why does this review get only 4 stars?? Our Campers shoe was only a loafer. They brought someone else's chicken fritters in a cool looking high top. Totally got gypped! (I'll probably change it to 5 stars when I sober up; thank God for auto correct)

Hats off to the amazing staff and chefs at Jaleo!!! #moresangriaplease

Lord, this place is expensive. A small plate of ham and cheese and several drinks and I was set back over $100 with tax and tip. That said, were I feeling wealthy or out to celebrate, I'd come back again.

Andres does one thing: take great ingredients, present them simply, and charge handsomely for the privilege. 

I had the $38 Iberico acorn-fed ham. It was wonderful to try, very marbled and definitely with a distinct nutty flavor, the cheaper selections are no less delicious and I'd order them again over this one.

The bartender steered me away from the "world's best G&T"--not so incredibly special. But beautiful.

I had quite a pleasant experience at Jaleo and am a little shocked at its current rating for how good the food was (service too!). The one star is coming off on price alone. Yes, it's the Vegas strip, but no, it's not fine dining food. Get over yourselves, Jaleo.

Jaleo is a Spanish tapas restaurant and I was delighted to see so many authentic Spanish dishes on the menu like patatas bravas, enasaladilla rusa, tortilla, I could go on and on. I studied in Spain during college and I will say that Jaleo is about as close as I've seen to authentic Spanish cuisine in the states.

I was dining solo on this visit, so I sat at the bar and was fortunate enough to have dinner during happy hour. I tried the cava sangria and didn't love it, but it was sangria, so it was still pretty good. If I were to order again, I think I'd try to red sangria or the sherry.

I ordered the coca happy hour appetizer along with the gazpacho (based on reviews. The coca was decent but the gazpacho was OUT OF THIS WORLD. Seriously, it was delicious. It didn't have the acidic taste/flavor that I'm used to and was a bit lighter (did it have cream in it) than typical gazpacho. I also ordered the cono salmon and the aceitunas (both liquid and stuffed olives). If you haven't had a liquid olive before, it is quite the experience. I don't want to give the surprise away, but it would be a shame if you went here and didn't try them. I didn't quite care for the liquid olives, but it was awesome to finally try one.

As far as atmosphere goes, they nailed that one. In addition to the real wood fires burning in the back of the restaurant under the paella pans, they also have comfortable seating and fancy glasses for the cocktails. 

If I get the chance to stop back in soon, I'll aim for the lunch menu, which looks much more reasonably priced. The happy hour specials were decent too for drinks.

We have eaten at Jaleo several times, however not in the past year.  The service seems to have gone just a bit downhill since our previous visit.  First, let me say the food was good, and I have no complaints at all on this.

The problem was, we first ordered a pitcher of Sangria.  Our server came back, and took some tapas orders, and virtually all of them came before our Sangria. Before the paella arrived for our final course, a few ordered diet Cokes, and they did not arrive until after we were done.  Most other drinks arrived in a timely manner, and the food came out very quick.

I will return, but will hope for a bit better service.   We have a wonderful night, and our whole party enjoyed the food, and the experience.

We had high hopes for Jaleo because we have been following the chef, so we were disappointed by the adequateness of the food. We found it to be bland and uninteresting. However, maybe we ordered the wrong items. Also the venue is not so nice as it looks onto what appears to be a food court - or at least that is how it looked. Drinks were pretty good though.

My fianc√© and I went to grab a bite at Jaleo to nurse our wounds after a thorough beating at the blackjack table. This place had a nice ambiance and the sangria was spot on - light, fruity, and a plenty. The staff was also friendly but eek! Those were the only good things about this place.

Way to add insult to injury by making everything SUPER SALTY! This is some kind of ironic Vegas joke to put (actual) salt on our wounds, our bellies, and gouging us.

Items that were ordered with their online menu descriptions (5 total): 

1. Chistorra envuelta en patata frita "Slightly spicy chorizo wrapped in crispy potato": chorizo was underwhelming. Presentation looked like a tiny hot dog wrapped in a greasy potato chip. Probably didn't help also that it was served in a mini fry basket.  I had to have my fianc√© eat the rest. 

2. Gambas al ajillo "The very, very famous tpaa of shrimp saut√©ed with garlic": Wow. I don't know why they put an emphasis on "very". That must mean that it's very very good right? Wrong. It was just okay. Each shrimp got progressively saltier. They provided a cute bread loaf with the dish, but I didn't want to dip it in the greasy juice. That should have been our first warning sign. Also - please spell "tapa" right on your website, Jaleo. 

3. Arroz con costillas de cerdo ib√©rico de bellota "Made with the ribs of the legendary, black-footed ib√©rico de bellota pigs of Spain": these legendary pigs from Spain must have been raised in a tight space and didn't eat much. They were 95% all fat and bone. Mushrooms were decent, but over salted. This paella was probably not the worst dish of the night, so we ended up eating most of it. 

I'm not going to get into too much detail on the last two dishes: mushrooms with creamy sauce and a lentil dish with pork (not located on their website...coincidence - I think not!) because we sent those 2 back. They were incredibly salty and surpassed the threshold of the benefit of the doubt - yes we turned into those people! The wait staff was apologetic and tried to offer us free dessert; they even told us these two dishes have had mixed reviews in the past. I'll give them credit for at least being honest and accommodating. 

3 salty meals and 1 half carafe of sangria later, we paid $110.17 including tip. These are good buffet prices people! I'd rather try my luck at the tables.

3.5 stars.

Came here with a group of 8 people and we got a private room in the back, away from the really loud main dining room.  The ipad drink menus were probably more trouble than it's worth.  The paper dinner menu is pretty extensive and we relied on the waitress to make some selections for us.  In the end, the food's overpriced and just alright but the lobster paella really saved the day. We had:

Chips and tomato paste. Meh.

Tomato bread with three selections of jamon. Iberico's the best.  Tomato bread was take it or leave it.

Chicken fritters that came in a shoe. Gimmicky but the fritters were good.

Fried eggplant. Very good.  Nice and crispy.

Brussel Sprout salad. Citrus-y and delicious.

Shrimp in a little pan. Since I'm allergic, I refrained. But the table had good reviews.

Lobster Paella for 8 people. It was the piece de resistance! Two waiters carried in a huge copper paella pan which cooked all the paella for 8 people. The lobster was wonderfully done and the rice was loaded with flavor. If we didn't eat this, we'd probably leave hungry!

Grilled Iberico pig - excellent.

Panna Cotta with citrus sorbet - excellent.

Jaleo was an great meal and we had a good time laughing and pointing at the chicken fritters in the tennis shoe. I think I would've been pretty disappointed if it only sampled 2-3 tapas, so dining with a large group provided a good selection for us. I liked my experience but would not come back again.

Oh, and that $17 gin and tonic. It was very good indeed.

When I first walked by this place, I thought it was called "Jaleel" and I was excited that "Family Matters" star Jaleel White (aka Urkel) had opened his own place.   I just imagined finishing a terrific dinner, looking down at my empty plate and saying "Did I eat that?".

Alas, it's actually called Jaleo but it's still a terrific place.  So while staying at the Cosmopolitan, a friend and I at here.  Here's some of what we had....

Cheeses, all very good:
Idiaz√°bal
Pasamontes Manchego
Ca√±a de cabra

Other food items, all very good:
Patatas bravas
Lomo de buey con Valde√≥n (hangar steak)
Pulpo a la Gallega 'Maestro Alfonso'(octopus)
Garlic soup

For dessert, we also had the gin & tonic fizz sorbet (very good) and a tasty flan.  I had some drink that was called "blood and something" but I can't remember what the something was (it was in Spanish) and my pal had wine which he enjoyed. 
 
It's a lively place that's kind of loud, but very fun.  Service was excellent so that's what pushes it to four stars for me.  To be honest, the food was fine but at the price point, I should have been blown away.  The service makes up for that small bit of dissonance.

In closing, did I eat that?

From a vegan perspective is this place is an excellent option on the strip, the waiters are very knowledgeable about what menu items are vegan as well as which can be modified to be vegan - they were even careful to give us the right bread.    Everything was an absolutely delicious culinary experience and there was more than enough dishes to choose from.  The line and crowd in front made us concerned that it would be uncomfortably packed and too close for comfort inside but that was not the case at all - its busy but very comfortable and great service.  Extra tip - definitely get the gin and tonic.

I love Jaleo!

What a whimsical celebration of flavors!  There are too many to name all but in my experience there are some stand alone superstars.

1.  Pan Con Tomate, a simple dish that has unbelievable flavor!  I got mine with anchovies.

2.  Jamon Iberico Bellota, the legendary pig of Spain at its best.  I love cured meats and the quality of this product is amazing.

3.  Huevo Frito con Caviar,  fried organic cage free egg with caramelized onions and caviar.  The toasted rustic bread puts it over the top!

4.  Endivias.  Promoted as a staff favorite and I get it!  It is the perfect tapa!  Sweet, salty, soft, crunchy.  I had it as a palate cleanser, but it could have been served at anytime and still would have been great!

5.  Jamon Croquettas.  Nuff said!!!!

6.  Gambas,  a simple saut√©ed shrimp dish.  But hey, I believe that simple done well is a testament to greatness!

7.  Braised veal cheeks,  OMG!  My server told me that they feel bad for anyone who doesn't try this.  I'll agree with that!  So tender that you can cut them with a spoon.  Also the Morels and olive oil potato pur√©e don't hurt either.

8.  Secreto Iberico,  the secret is out!  This is the best cut of meat in Vegas!  Pork steak that is tender like filet.  It's like I went to bacon heaven!


Food great!  Service, on point and friendly.  Jose's gin and tonic is just wow!  Plus a great selection of Spanish wines that don't hit your pocket like other places on the strip!  I will definitely go back and let my friends know!

Thank you Jose!

Good food, but seriously over priced with horrible service.

Went to Jaleo with a group of 10 people. We started off by ordering a bunch of tapas. They are all very good, but came out ridiculously slow. We were all sitting there asking where the damn food was. Then when stuff finally started coming out, it came literally one item at a time. Again, there were 10 of us, and these were small tapas plates, so only half of us would get literally one bite of food and that was it.

Then we decided to get a paella. They have 5 paellas on the menu, but only 2 of them are available on any given day. The night we were there, they had one vegetarian paella and one that had rabbit. I'm not a fan of rabbit and others in our group were incredibly opposed to ordering rabbit, so that left us with one paella option, the vegetarian one. For a place as expensive as Jaleo, to have that bad of a selection is completely unacceptable.

They do get 2 stars instead of one because the food was good, but the service, selection and price will definitely prevent me from coming back. There are other tapas restaurants in Vegas that are just as good, but with better service and selection for less.

We came across Jaleo on our 2nd night in Vegas and I was so glad to have found a tapas place. Although my husband was a bit hesitant at first, since the menu's a bit overwhelming for a newcomer, we were pleased with our choices. We especially liked the Paella with shrimp and squid, with an amazing & intense mix of flavors. The warm Brussels sprouts mixed with apricots, pears, & jamon was a perfect blending of a dish! As a kid, I hated Brussel sprouts, and this dish definitely turned me into a fan. Perfect portions & great food to be shared!

Loved this place! Great ambiance, great drinks and food. We had a party of six all with different dietary restrictions and preferences and each waiter and runner were on point with that info, explained each dish and impressed us. 

Go there!!

Was here for a girls weekend.  Stopped in to Jaleo for some Tapas.  Ambiance is very loud. We got lucky and got seated in a private room because there were 10 of us.  Service was great EXCEPT from our main server.  She was a total biatch! She got annoyed when we didn't order a mass amount of alcohol. Sh!t, with the prices we had to pay in this restaurant, we couldn't afford alcohol.  She recommended the pork paella.  It was not very good at all!!! The pork was just spare-ribs with bones in it.  It was very difficult to eat because the meat was not tender so you had to rip it off the bones. The rice was uncooked!  We mentioned this to the waitress and she made some excuses and said that is how it is cooked.  Then she dismissed us by saying "sorry" very sarcastically.  

Bottom line, if you guys like your rice cooked, DO NOT order the paella!!! It is NOT good.  Everything else is okay, just okay, not delicious.

I'm a total fan of Jose Andres restaurants, but I have to honestly say that Jaleo was kinda disappointing. This was not the best and does not compare to his others like China Pablano or Bazaar both food and experience wise. The tasting menu offered about 9 or 10 dishes to try, the most impressive thing was the very first. It was an appetizer of a special toast with fresh tomato spread, not tomatoe chunks, but a spread. It was so crispy, and not the "scratch the roof of your mouth" kind of crispy, and light. I would come back just to have this bruschetta for breakfast! 

I liked the cheese and 18 month old prosciutto pairing, would've been perfect with a few olives. The chilled apple soup was also nice, refreshing like gazpacho. The other dishes lacked flavor and some portions were too big to carry on with. The calamari and paella seemed to be served in full portions. It was practically enough for 3-4 people for a tasting menu. I hate to waste food. The cauliflower with olives and dates were fantastic, but I do wish our server had suggested us to eat them all in one bite. I steered away from pairing a date with cauliflower and olive, but eventually brought myself to try it. Had our server suggested it, I would've done it instantly. Sometimes it's nice to be explained how to eat such peculiar pairings in a dish. The quality of the food was on the table, I really liked the quail, but the flavor was not. The service could've been better overall on keeping a better eye on our table and cleaning it. They didn't change our plates until halfway through the meal and they were already pretty dirty after three dishes. The non-alcoholic drinks took a while/felt forgotten. I wouldn't come back unless it's for their bruschetta.

We arrived this past Sunday night at 615pm and it was half full...30 minutes later the place was packed and the dining scene was on. Jalmon Serrano as an opener was smoothly cut and the taste spoke for itself. Brussel Sprout salad, seared scallops and some Pappas Argula were all nicely presented and tasty.
Carne Asada in nice thin slices and shrimp in some garlic sauce were outstanding too. The quality of the ingredients used here at Jaleo are simply superior to Spaniard restaurants I've dined in around the Socal area. Service was rapid and helpful..we'll be back.

Came here a couple of times.

Highlights were the carpaccio, which wasn't overly smoky and came with some rosemary crackers and the eggplant cone with anchovies on top, and I'm not a huge fan of eggplant.
Shrimp and lobster croquettes were ok, nothing to write home ab out.  Sauce was a little heavy, overall slightly bland.

Came with 5 of my friends and since we are all from Hawaii we think we are food critics. We instantly started translating stuff in to our language, like sea urchin...we said oh uni! Ha ha but it was good, had bacon-it was a no lose situation. The garlic shrimp was amazing. We tried 2 paella dishes and they weren't that great, it didn't have that crunchy bottom that you get in Spain. We did have some type of noodle that reminded me of Filipino pancit-we all loved that one! The cheese dishes were misleading-we thought it would be like a fondue--it was a couple pieces of cheese and jam ha ha. We all enjoyed it. I'd go back if I had company in town, but wouldn't make the drive from Summerlin for it.

Out of all the restaurants in Las Vegas, I think that Jose Andres has picked a very nice spot to set up shop.  From the beginning the atmosphere at the Cosmopolitan Hotel is flashy yet not overly commercial.  The restaurant has a great external appeal, with an open eating area, mostly white decor and big chunky tables for seating in the overflow area.

The wait staff seemed young and a little under experienced.  We got shifted wait staff within the first 10 minutes of being in the restaurant and the young lady we were left with was bubbly, yet didn't know quite what she was serving as in experience.  She also had a painfully short attention span and would walk from the table without warning.

The wine list was heavy on $100+ bottles with a scattering of under $100 bottles.  We opted for a $48 bottle since we didn't need anything expensive and the bottle was still excellent.  If you go, don't bother with the American wines, as those are priced way above the $100 mark per bottle and for a casual tapas meal, IMHO you don't need to spend the money when most of the wines on the list are probably good selections.

We started with a board of all the cured meats, which included both the iberrico hams, the chorizo, serrano and pork loan.  We paired that with some manchango cheese which all together was great with the bottle of wine we were enjoying. And the quality of meat was a good amount for two people to share.

Next we had the salmon roe cones, which looked like a borrowed dish from Thomas Keller's French Laundry with a play on the ice cream cone.  The cones had salmon roe on top and filled with crab, which was tasty, but the roe didn't really stand out much.

We then had the egg topped with caviar, which was spectacular, but it wasn't the egg or the caviar which made it, but the caramelized onions under the egg made it a home run.  All together it rocked, but if it didn't have caviar on it, I don't think you'd notice a difference.

Then came our seafood tapas, we had the shrimp and scallop dishes, which were both excellent and cooked perfectly.  Out of the two, the shrimp was the clear winner, and if I did it again, I'd get two of those rather than the scallops.  

Our last tapas was the veal cheeks, which were served over mashed potatoes, which was like a braised short rib without the unnecessary fat.  Very tasty, but I'd like a little finishing salt on it to bring it home and cut the richness a bit.

After it was all said and done with we signed the not so expensive bill with a couple expressos which was absolutely a great finish as the expresso was very smooth and went well with the whole meal.

I really want to give a zeros stars, only because we can't share a item on the menu....  Its bull you can't share with your partner when on a diet or ex... So I really want  to give ZERO stars. It's very inconvenient and very rude to tell a customer you can't share a meal or plate your forcing people to pay more then what you guys provide.... I really love the cosmopolitan but it's making me think twice....  So zero stars...  please for future customers Don't go very expensive and unworthy to hear from a server to tell you that you cant do something... So rude so a company.  Cosmopolita shouldn't affiliate them selfs with this restaurant.

I wish this was better! Very loud restaurant which could be fun if the food and drinks were okay. We had the tasting menu and everything was just... below par. Our drinks were weak and all I could taste was sugar. Each plate brought out was boring and lacking flavor. I feel like I'd rather go to firefly than come back here and pay three times as much.

This might be the favorite of the many great restaurants I ate at in Vegas. The space is beautifully appointed, the food was perfect and beautifully presented and our server, Andrew, was the best. He was especially helpful when it came to making suggestions. 

We started with a pitcher of the sparkling white sangria which is prepared table side and has fresh raspberries and blackberries along with some citrus fruit in it. Only the berries find their way into your glass which was nice. 

We had chicken croquettes served in a sneaker, quail, chicken with a garlic sauce, patatas bravas, and empanadas for the table. All were good, the empanadas being the only one we wouldn't have reordered had we gone back. They were good, but everything else was better and we'd swap out to try something else. 

Andrew was fun and attentive and made sure to pop a candle in our exchange students chocolately good dessert; we were celebrating her 1/2 birthday.

Awesome, awesome, awesome.

I was expecting so much more from this restaurant.  There were a few hits - the caviar fried egg dish was amazing as well as the crispy pasta with aioli and shrimp, but the octopus was inedible and everything else was just ok.  I expected to be wowed but walked away having spent $300 and it was just ok.

I have never been a big fan of Jaleo in DC and Bethesda, Maryland but perhaps I need to revisit those places.  Jose Andres has hit a grand slam with this place.  I only had a chocolate flan dessert and some cafe con leche with rum, but what a dish!  This place reminds me of the energy in Las Vegas before the fall of the stock market.  It is filled by beautiful people and high energy in the Cosmopolitan Hotel.  The open pit restaurant with the paella is something I am dying to try.  This place is a winner!!!

We came here for fancy dinner night and Jaleo did not disappoint.  High quality tapas, Jose Andres style.  For four people we ended up ordering an assortment of 9 tapas; they all ranged from good to excellent.  The chicken croquettes were the stand out item of the night and it is served in a shoe.  Delicious and whimsical!  Other highlights for me included the paella, the chicken breast, and jamon serrano.  Our waitress was super helpful and the food came out pretty quickly but was spaced out pretty well.  We were too full for dessert.  Our bill came out to about $200 (including a pitcher of sangria we all shared) which was not as bad as we expected for how good the food was.  A solid meal I wouldn't mind having again.

Great establishment. Nice atmosphere. Trendy. Depending on where you sit, you can have a great people watching opportunity.

The quail with apple puree was excellent as was the olive oil ice cream. Our waiter suggested a dish that was a flower petal with a clementine and almonds on it that also was exceptional, but I'm not sure what the name of it was. The Citrico cocktail is perfect for a hot Vegas day - the gun carries the grapefruit & mint flavors very nicely.

Definitely allow for a nice long leisurely dinner so that you can enjoy your meal the way small plates were intended. We ate 6 plates for 2 people.
I had a great experience here in January at dinner. Just tried to eat there for lunch and the menu is very limiting. No vegan options at all. Very unfortunate and overall service attitude was poor.

If you want Tapas this is the place to go.  The menu is overwhelming so I suggest you do what I did...tell the waiter what flavored and food you like and how much you want to eat and let him/her do the rest and you won't be disappointed. The portions are small, so for two people you can do at least 6 different items. High recommend you give this place a try.

Honestly, not my fav. The portions are beyond small. They're tiny!

The mussels weren't great. No extra broth at all so they weren't moist. Comes with one slice of bread and if you ask for more they'll charge you. Really? Yes, really. 
This restaurants took small plates to a whole different level. I'm talking bite size small. 

My favorites were the Garlic shrimp and Pan De Cristal Con Tomato Fresco.

Fast food tapas 

Really expensive, 500 for 3 people and we didn't splurge at all 

Food very average at best, service was slow and inattentive for the price paid. Very loud too

Arrived on a Wednesday to a packed house at Jaleo. We were seated within 10 minutes of our arrival. We were then given an IPad to review the drink list. We didn't see our waiter again for 15 minutes. Note, you can not order your drinks from the IPad. Our waiter finally appears and takes our drink order. Literally another 15 minutes goes by before we got our drinks. I watched tables that were seated after us get their water, drinks and first courses by the time we got our drinks. Ordered the "infamous" gin and tonic and my friend got a specialty whiskey drink. The gin and tonic is just that. A gin and tonic, not sure what all the hype is about. The whiskey drink was far superior. We ordered the following dishes for our meal. 

Chorizo w/fried potato - I personally liked the dish because I'm a sucker for chorizo but no one else cared for it. 
warm spinach and pine nut salad - boring and tasteless
Seared Scallop - Overcooked 
Grilled skirt steak - Ice cold by the time we received it but had decent flavor
Apple and fennel salad - Probably the best dish of the meal but it's a salad!
Chicken fritters - Fried with mushy chicken in the center 
Shrimp skewers - Greasy 
potato and onion fritatta - We did not order this dish but it came to our table anyway and we ate it because we were so hungry. Decent, but I could make it at home. 
gin and tonic oysters - Did not eat any, but I hear they were pretty good. 

Overall the service here is really lacking, we were all done with our drinks half way through the meal, were never asked if we wanted another. The food is mediocre and not worth the price. We all left hungry and disappointed. 

Way overrated.

First things first: MANAGEMENT please have a chat with the Cuban guy. He has no right to talk down to the "new guy from Senegal". Such unprofessional and racist comments should not be tolerated.

Food here was very good (not great), a few of the dishes were a little on the salty side, but for the most part everything was good 8/10. 

Also if you're charging $30 for a cheese plate please put more than 2 ounces of cheese on it.

There is a reason this place has 3.5 stars and it ain't the food its the service.

Daniel our server wasn't really around other than to take our order and try to up sell.

Omg why do people complain so much? How is it possibile that I have been here literally over 20 times and always had an outstanding experience?


I love this place! This is CONSISTENTLY EXCEPTIONAL

It was an experience eating at Jaleo, but it is not somewhere where I will return to in a while. They serve small portions(tapas) and they also have paella which is traditional Spanish rice dish (the one we had was lobster, but i believe they have diff. kinds). The food was STRICTLY OK, but just the experience was worth trying at least once. The egg with caviar was the best dish we ordered there. We also ordered rabbit, but I definitely am not a fan of, but my boyfriend enjoyed it. The seating was kindda weird for us because the table next to us was less than a foot away so there was no privacy whatsoever.

We got a table for 6 right outside of the restaurant which was fairly removed from other tables but I didn't mind, especially considering that we were a walk-in and they fit us in on a Friday night.  They bring pan con tomate to the table to start which was delicious.  We ordered plates of olives as well as their prosciutto plate which came with four different types of meat.  The chorizo was to die for.  The olive plate came with olives stuffed with anchovies as well as this bizarre kind of emulsion, it was kind of a liquid olive in a transparent skin.  It was definitely different.  We ordered various small plates to share.  Everyone loved the octopus and potatoes.  The squid is served over black ink and was probably the largest small plate that we got and it was really good.  We got goat cheese stuffed red peppers, which were delicious but I think the goat cheese was mixed with some sort of blue cheese.  I ordered the cod salad, which is raw cod marinated in some sort of vinaigrette and served with olives and oranges, it was so good! My friend got the steak and loved it.  We ordered a serving of paella to share.  They make two paellas every night and alternate between which one is ready to be served.  The two paellas they were serving that night were a pork paella and a vegetable paella.  The vegetable paella was ready to be served when we got there so if we ordered that one we would not have waited, but we ordered the pork instead and it came out at the end of our meal which was totally fine.  We drank sangria the whole time which was $50 for a carafe but we each got at least one glass out of it.

Our server was excellent, she was very prompt and seemed busy but we got everything we ordered in a timely fashion.  She was also incredibly knowledgable and could answer every question we had about the menu.  Our bill came out to around $450 for the 6 of us (including a 20% tip that we asked her to add), which included two sangria carafes.  I think the food alone was somewhere around $280.  I loved this place and would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for tapas in Vegas.

eh, this place is in the cosmo hotel and i didn't enjoy it that much. 

the most interesting thing was that the fritters (i think that is what it was) we ordered were served in a leather sneaker. a gimmicky conversation piece that wasn't that neat. i'm still trying to figure out the connection.

it's way too bright in here. the place is bright white and red. not very intimate.

finding the bathroom is like a maze. my friend asked a waiter where it is and he insisted on showing her because it is tricky. 

the waiter we had was disinterested and unable to make recommendations. curious.

we order the sangria and it was "eh," but incredibly strong. a bit spicy, which was interesting. i preferred the plain vodka soda i ordered.

i left hungry in spite of my party of three ordering lots and lots of tapas, but didn't mind because i wanted to keep looking slim in my tight dress (girrrrls, you know what i mean!). i honestly cannot remember the names of all the things we ordered, or any haha.

there are better places equally costly to check out while in vegas...skip jaleo and go there lol

I don't understand why this does not have higher reviews. We dined at Botero, Milos, STK, The henry, & the mexican/chinese place inside the Cosmo and none compared to Jaleo.

We made a reservation the same day and got there a little late. We were told to wait at the bar and we only waited a short amount of time. We were seated and the management charged my fiance's phone as it was dying which was a nice gesture. The waiter was not extremely friendly and didn't really aid in us making the decision of what to order but hey, it's a tapas place.

I didn't particularly like the sangria but my fiance LOVED it. I had champagne instead. We had the shrimp/squid paella, "famous" garlic shrimp, my fiance had some sort of chicken tapas, cold spanish soup, and the bread with mariana sauce lightly coated on top.

They were all delicious especially the paella. It was unique and quite tasty. On the way out the manager stopped and complimented me on my outfit and struck up a conversation with us. It was really nice and the other waiters were super friendly while we were walking to and from our table.

The ambiance was amazing!!! It was soooo lively especially late at night. We were looking for something super lively and I'm so glad we came here! The bill was also extremely reasonable. We only ordered like 5 tapas for both of us and it was enough. Out of all the restaurants that we dined at on our stay in Vegas this was definitely the best. Don't read the other reviews, just go and check it out!

Four stars only because it was SUPER expensive! We had a group of 5 and each of us started with two choices. Two gals ended up needing to order one more entree. The atmosphere was fun and not stuffy. We'd go back in a heartbeat!

GROUP FAVORITE: Espinacas A La Catalana (Sauteed spinach, pine nuts and apples)

RUNNER UPS:
*Chistorra envuelta en patata frita (Spicy chorizo wrapped in crispy potato)
*Gambas Al Ajillothe (shrimp saut√©ed with garlic AND it comes with bread)

They also gave us complimentary Croquetas De Pollo
(traditional chicken fritters). They were excellent but also rich, so you'd want to share them.

This place is awesome - I'm not sure what some of the other reviewers are talking about! The gin and tonics are the best we've had (she had the herbed one and I had the Jose's) and the food was terrific. Our waiter recommended several dishes, which were great, and we decided to get others as well. The lamb was a standout - as was the scallop dish with mint pea pur√©e. We had about 5 small plates and two desserts - it was the perfect amount to fill us up before our show. I would highly recommend Jaleo!

Visited her for a business lunch! What a great experience, wait staff explained the tapas style menu and recommend a few starters. We had Many different palettes at the table, vegetarian, no seafood and no spicy and we were able to accommodate them all. A few stand outs were the paella and gambas al ajillo. The atmosphere is beautifully decorated and  all and all it was a great experience. For Vegas it was not over priced and the quality of the food is worth it. I'll be back!

Tapas, yes, I know means small/little dishes, but I think they took this to the extreme. Where are all these reviewers from? Were they blinded by the lights on the Strip?!? Because, I could barely see the food on the plate.

The main issue I have with Jaleo is the small portions. $7 for a plate of potato chips with red and white sauce drizzled, my coworkers make this at lunch in the lunch room, its called lays with sirracha and onion dip drizzle. We ordered to our hearts content but our stomachs were far from filled.

Don't get me wrong, I understand quality over quantity, but if you really break it down, give me an endless supply of the minuscule tapas, so small I can barely remember what I ate, I still wouldn't come here. The plates are small (yes for the 4th time in this review, not sure if I got my point across), but the quality of the tapas are not even that great or anything spectacular. The entire dinner, I couldn't stop thinking about the cup-o-noodle I purposely didn't eat because I didn't want to spoil my appetite, bad move. 

This place is not good for groups, seeing as you have to order at least 3-4 orders of each tapa to feed a table of 9-10. One star for the creative serving style, putting deep fried bacon covered dates in a shoe, fooseball tables doubling as a dining table, and decent service is about all there is to rave about here. There's no reason to eat here when superior "foodie-esq"restaurants with big name chefs are a dime a dozen in Vegas.

A MUST stop for Restaurant week 2018! Make sure to talk with Mario about the wonderful wines he picked to be paired with the menu. As lifetime locals we will definitely be recommending Jaleo to friends and out of town guests.

Small plates.  Yummy flavor.  Bacon wrapped dates, fried......dessert with bacon.  Carne Asada, addictive.  They had a brioche with jamon, manchego cheese and a truffle butter.  Think of it as what a grilled cheese sandwich will be when it gets sophisticated.

And a flan for dessert that was just the perfect flan....the whipped cream and sorbet complemented it with a subtle glow of flavor.

I'd go there again in a heartbeat.  Absolutely on the must go to list in Vegas.  Forego the hookers, you'll talk more about this meal afterwards, even with the guys. It's that good.

I've tried to go to Jaleo for dinner twice before, but neither happened.  I wish I hadn't pushed for a third try, because this meal sucked.  I would've given it one star, but one thing we had was really good, so it gets an extra star.  

My favorite foodie friend and I were both in Vegas on a Friday night, so decided to go to Jaleo.  He has been to the one in DC before and liked it, and I like Jose Andres food, so we were both excited.  

We were sat promptly, and the waitress came over a few minutes later.  She gave a whole canned speech about the menu (which is something I hate)...and gave us the iPad wine list.  There are some relatively good priced wines and of course lots of spanish options, so it started out good.  

She finally came and took our order, and we got a few things from each part of the menu, including the Paella Valenciana.  She told us they would group our items from the kitchen light to heavy and stage them to come out 1-2 at a time.  Great.

However, that wasn't the case.  We got three things within like 2 seconds of each other.  The first things were 1. Pan con tomate (Toasted slices of rustic bread brushed with fresh tomato). this was adequate.  not quite the traditional way, but tasty enough; 2. Some tiny green olives stuffed with anchovies and "liquid black olives". this dish was $14 for like 5 small green olives.  total rip off and i know anchovies are salty, as are olives, but this dish was too salty to eat...and yes, i've had them both together before and it doesn't need to be that overly salty; 3. tortilla de patata (Spanish omelet with potatoes and onions).  i'm about to get married, and this is one of the dishes on my menu, which means i've tried about 20 tortillas from caterers over the last few months, and this version was the worst i've ever had.  previously, i was shocked by how bad some of the caterers versions were of this dish, but this dish was twice as bad as the worst.  first of all, she asked us if we wanted it well done when we ordered it.  this is not a question that should be asked.  it's supposed to be a simple dish:  onions and potatoes sauteed til tender, add egg, let form til set completely.  that is it.  we got it and it was wet, and runny, so not even well done like she asked if we wanted it.  it was also super thin, with only like one layer of potato.  it was so gross we didn't finish it.  

So then we flagged her down and said we wanted to slow it down a bit, since everything so far had been rushed to our table. This was a mistake, because from then on it was supperr long wait for everything.  She told us then that our paella was ready, and we said oh no thanks - we want to wait until the end for that dish, since it's most like a "main course".  This is after she told us the kitchen would structure it light to heavy for us, so delivering paella with the first few things made no sense.

The next dish was Ensalada rusa (a salad of potatoes, imported conserved tuna and mayonnaise).  This was "okay", but not great.  It was much better than it looked - It was covered with foam.  It looked like my cat threw up on it.  I'm not a foam fan.  But the potatoes were cooked well, and the tuna was tasty.

The next dish was the Seared scallops with romesco sauce.  The dish arrived and was pretty enough to look at.. However,  both our scallops had grit.  This, is not good.  Neither of us finished our scallop (the dish had two) and we called the waitress over to tell her they were gritty.  She apologized, but didn't seem to really know what that meant. 

Then we got the last dish before our paella...the veal cheeks with whipped olive oil potatoes.  This is the only reason the restaurant got 2 stars.   This dish was really good.  Looked good.  Tasted great.  Very tender veal cheeks.  The potatoes were fluffy bites of heaven.  Very very good.  This is what I expected every dish to be like, but sadly, it was the only good dish.

So now we are excited to try the paella.  i guess i was still holding out hope it would save the meal?  but the waitress comes over and tells us that they're out of the paella.  What?  We ordered it an hour ago.  They had it.  You tried to serve it to us at the start of the meal, we said we'd wait...and now you're out of it??  She offered us a different paella, at double the cost of the one we ordered.  We said, no thanks.  And were super unhappy about it.  We were both still hungry, but didn't want to try anymore crappy food, so asked for the bill.

We got the bill, and the damn scallops were still on it.  We called the manager over to complain (we've both been in the biz for years, and if someone complains about a legitimate quality issue, that should NEVER be on the check).  So we explained that they were gritty and shouldn't be on the check.  He apologized and claimed it was an oversight and took it off the bill.  

Overall, a disappointing meal and I'll never go back.  It was so overpriced and only one thing was good.  Sad, sad, sad.

very good dishes we took all.

ham w/ tomato sause bread is absolutely good as same as his main restaurant "Bazaar " in Beverly Hills. 

i was surprised thing was coquet on shoe!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

food is goood as "Bazaar" but price is soo nice.

only $200 per two. ( if there, double price)

i'm sure i will be back there when i go to las vegas

My experience here on a Monday night was not that bad. The food was pretty good albeit overpriced, even for Vegas. Our waiter was friendly albeit clearly trying to push as many plates on us as he could. The highly recommended $20 gin and tonics basically tasted like tonic water, but I suppose were higher quality because they were served with a spherical ice cube. If I had been paying I probably would have given this place two stars given how not impressive it was for the money... It's tough for me to give less than three though because nothing we ordered wasn't decently good. I can just think of a thousand more places in Vegas to spend the money and many more tapas places in nyc or even LV that are better.
Great atmosphere, nice food, great portion size for Tapas, staff is extremely awesome, very sexy uniforms, got to see the most expensive leg of Proscuitto explained to us by a local chef from Kihei!

Absolutely wonderful experience!!! Impeccable service, great flavorful food, nice atmosphere!!! Happy hour menu was nice as well as the items from regular dinner menu. Our waiter was very attentive, always there when we needed him, but never overwhelming, very professional. Overall great experience, can't wait to be back.

The food was only average for a place that should be 4 stars or better. The real bummer was the level of service. The waitress not only forgot to order some of our food, when she finally did, she got it wrong. The portions were small and only mildly tasty. 

I love Tapas restaurants and I really liked the Cosmopolitan Hotel but I will never go here again. T

The best part was the place was so busy, we couldn't get in without a reservation the night before! We should have just passed all together!

I have died and gone to Spain.

OK, the bad reviews are due to either going in the first few weeks of opening (in which all restaurants have issues) or having never been to Spain and experiencing real tapas.

This is the first time I have gone to a Spanish tapas restaurant in the US and had it taste like the flavors I tasted in Spain.  The food is amazing and prices are actually quite reasonable considering 1. it is Vegas and 2. the prices would be the same in Spain but in Euros.  If you compare it to some of the restaurants nearby then you would realize the price to food ratio is actually quite good.

We ate there 3 out of the 4 nights we were in Vegas because it was so good and even though we live in a foodie town we can't get great Spanish tapas.  Some of our favorites - the oyster "gin and tonic", gaspacho, chorizo fried potatoes (chistorra envueita en patata), tomato bread with manchego cheese, ham selection, lobster paella, and seared lamb ribs.  We also enjoyed the brussel sprout salad, lobster salad, garlic soup, and rossejat (fried pasta), 

We loved everything except the raw salmon crudo (which was overpriced and lost it flavor buried in olive oil and pine nuts), the clams with lemon - which were not special and had some sand in them, and the croquettes which were the best we have had but we are not lovers of croquettes.

If you know Spanish tapas, you must try it.  If you don't, still try it but you may want to ease in with the items most Americans would love - seared lamb, garlic shrimp, croquettes, brussel sprout salad, and try some hams and cheeses.  Enjoy!!!!

Oh, and don't forget the Sangria!

This place just does it right. We sat in the library and had an amazing amazing meal. I went with my dining colleagues who love food as much as I do and we all could not believe how much food came out and how wonderful it was. The staff the service the quality was all first rate. If you have the opportunity to dine at Jaleo, jump on it you will not be disappointed. I have been at all of Jose Andres restos here in Las Vegas. The last one the crown jewel will be E'.  The iberrico jamon bellota was off the chart. The desserts were flavorful and refreshing !  Can't wait to go back.

Food: The gazpacho was nice and herby. The paella had a pleasing hearty flavor. The hazelnut chocolate dessert was decadent. The apple tart had saffron which gave it a very unique and interesting taste. Unfortunately, I felt that some of their other dishes had taste combinations that were a bit awkward.

Service: Friendly, attentive, prompt.

Ambience: Lively, clubby

My wife and I were excited to try this place based on the menu. Unfortunately, it was probably one of the worst service I've received in a restaurant. The server did not look happy at all. We had four dishes and kid you not, they came out maybe 15-40 minutes apart. There was no joy eating there. 

We weren't told until 20 minutes after we had ordered a dish that the computer was down and our orders didn't go through. 

Another kicker- the group next to us came in after us, they ordered a lot more food and all their orders came before ours.

This was the first time I had ever had dinner at a "high-end" restaurant.
It was more like a food tasting party than a fulfilling dinner. All the dishes came in small portions but were very pricey. 
The oysters are amazinggg. The preserved raw ham was really good, we had two different kinds, one was from a vegetarian pig, and the other was from a pig that freely ate all sorts of things. We also had the hot dogs which were not like regular hot dogs but tiny ones that were burnt to perfection. We also had the fried rice with rabbit, I am not a big fan of rabbit so I did not exactly enjoy that dish, but everybody else did. 
For dessert we had the mango pudding and the vanilla bean ice cream with olive oil. They gave really small portions but it was beautifully crafted and nicely put together on the dish. And I enjoyed everything and the experience for the most part. It was truly an authentic high end Spanish cuisine. 
This is also in the new building called the Cosmopolitan in vegas, the place is wonderful and amazing.

JALEO (at the Cosmopolitan)
September 2012

Jaleo is part of chef Jos√© Andr√©s' Washington, D.C.-based empire, and the second of his restaurants with that name. His Las Vegas offerings also include √© by Jos√© Andr√©s (a paean to molecular gastronomy) and China Poblano (Chinese and Mexican).

***The Menu***
There are pages of tapas, so take your time perusing the list. When I went, there were a couple of specials; check with your server. Paella is available, either as a single serving of the daily special, or as one of several available if ordered for six or more people. Lastly, a caveat: while a few of the tapas are small, many are nearly entr√©e sized.

***The Atmosphere***
It's a large, open space, brightly lit. There are many hard surfaces, making Jaleo a fairly noisy place; contributing to this is moderately to loud music. All in all, pretty much what you'd expect from a restaurant located in the Cosmopolitan. I ate at the bar. It seats around 15 people; the full menu is available. The bartenders, dressed all in black, are very friendly; my bartender was glad to discuss not only the drinks, but the menu.

***The Food***
I asked the bartender whether I should order a couple of items at a time, or everything at once. He suggested I might as well order everything at once; since there were several cooking stations, dishes would tend to appear slowly, over a period of time. That's what I did, and that's what happened. In no particular order, here's what I had:
**Ensaladilla rusa con at√∫n en conserva, with optional trout roe. Yeah, this is just glorified potato and tuna salad - but it's really good potato and tuna salad. The chunks of tuna were a lot firmer and moister than Starkist; dollops of flavored mayonnaise were a nice touch; the optional trout roe was tasty. This was one of those entr√©e sized tapas.
**La Serena con membrillo (La Serena cheese and quince paste cone). Think of this as a tiny ice cream cone (one large or two small bites), filled with a creamy cheese and quince paste. If you're familiar with mango paste, quince paste is very similar - perhaps slightly less sweet with a slight amount of bitterness. I'm not sure why, but I really enjoyed this one.
**Fricand√≥ de carilleras de ternera y pur√© de patatas al aceite de oliva (veal cheeks and morels with olive oil potato pur√©e). Two large chunks of cheeks were soft and rich - just the way veal cheeks should be. Just as rich were the whipped potatoes. I liked this dish a lot, but you have to like meat that is soft and fatty.
**Bacalao (salt cod; off menu special). My bartender recommended this dish. It was a special they started serving the night before. The dish consisted of a generous chunk of salt cod. Slightly chewy and salty, I liked both the texture and flavor. Accompanying it was some rich mayonnaise or aioli or some such thing. If this is still available, it's worth ordering.

***Summary***
The Strip now has two high quality tapas bars: Jaleo and the nearby Julian Serrano. I've only had one meal at each, so it's difficult to say which is best, but I'd give the nod to Jaleo. I enjoyed my dishes slightly more, and the atmosphere is a little more upbeat. However, they're both winners.

***The Bill***
The meal was about $60, plus drinks, tax and tip. This will vary a lot, depending on what, and how much, you order.

I'm not sure how to start this out. Because after leaving I'm extremely biased in a negative way. I get the whole "tapas" trend with a small plate sharing vibe. But a good tapas place MUST balance pricing with food quality. We get its not about portions at a place like this. But when the SUPER small tapa plates quality is lacking and the price is sky rocketed I'm going to have to complain. Nothing was "to die for" This place charges at a rate of a high priced steak house, for an 8th of the food and disappointment. Maybe I was a little to hungry to be doing this review . So I have to add the service was excellent and you could tell the server understood the disappointment, it's not there fault a bit. But final line this place is a rip off. Go 100 steps to any other direction to get a well balanced meal.

The Iberico Ham. The cheese plate. The mixed cured meats. The spinach (Wow!). The grass fed Ribeye. The service. All of the above deserve five stars. I go back over and over. This is a fun location where you can enjoy watching the kitchen work, or watch the people walk around in front of the restaurant in the casino/hotel. I must admit some of the review I give Jaleo is due to the Cosmopolitan Hotel having _so_much_art_ installed all throughout. It is essentially a modern art gallery at the base of a hotel with a casino and fine dining throughout.

TIP: There are better options in the Cosmo...and Vegas. 

While working PAINWeek, my company was searching for a place to accommodate a party of 5 at 2:45pm on a Thursday, during the Exhibitor's lunch break. This was the only restaurant that could accommodate our ravenous crew without a wait. 

Unfortunately, for a restaurant in Vegas, the service was subpar. While we got our water right away, after the waiter introduced us to the menu, it took him at least 15 minutes to return to our table to take our orders. We guessed that this was due to placing the orders of two larger party's who sat down before us, but we finally flagged down our water boy to see if he could hurry our waiter along. 

We all settled on their $25.00 3-item lunch special...but nearly every item (minus the specialty of their homemade daily paella) left us underwhelmed. The choices were unconventional, almost experimental but the portions were also very small, even for tapas. My "mini burger" was akin to half a Krystal burger and, while packed with flavor, was memorable only for its extremely petite size. I also ordered the garlic shrimp (their most popular menu item and if I had to guess that's because it's the most recognizable combination of food.) Everyone else got a mini skillet brimming with oil and garlic sauce to dip the accompanying breadstick in...except for me. And while the shrimp was tasty, it wasn't mind-blowingly delicious.
