I was shocked at the steep prices of their regular menu items ($17-20+ per plate,) and I certainly would've been annoyed at the quantity vs quality, if wasn't a company meal. 

The decor is bold colors and mosaic tiles, a swankier version of what you'd expect in a Spanish theme restaurant, but it's nothing luxurious or overtly unique.

If it's you're only option, (like it was ours) you best not be a picky eater, otherwise, I'd strongly recommend going somewhere else. Either way, you're likely to still leave hungry and unsatisfied.

When going to Jaleo, you need to remember the following things (and if some of the other reviewers had, they might have had a better experience):

1. This is Vegas. Everything is overpriced. The sooner you realize that, the sooner you can accept it, move on, and enjoy yourself. Considering everything on the strip is overpriced, Jaleo really isn't that pricey.

2. You're at a TAPAS restaurant. Everything is small plates. That's the point. Don't expect a huge, Hash House portion of jam√≥n ib√©rico and croquetas, and you won't be disappointed. The whole idea is to order a bunch of small plates and share among friends. It's social! It's fun!

3. This is a a Jos√© Andres place. Andres is into molecular gastronomy and generally screwing around with food to make it fun, playful, whimsical even. Croquetas in a shoe? Bring it on! And please, like the health department would let them use worn shoes? Come on.

I went for my birthday dinner with my best friend, and it was awesome. I'll admit I have a bit of a culinary crush on Jos√© Andres, so I was preconditioned to love it, but it really was great. Loved the sangria, the croquetas were practically orgasmic, the dates were magical, and that was hands down the best damn flan I've ever had in my life. And I'm a big girl--I've had my share of flan over the years. The patatas bravas aren't traditional--they really are like thick chips--but they still taste like the real thing. 

None of these things is necessarily "revolutionary", but they're really effing tasty.

Our waitress was great, but the kitchen staff forgot about one of our dishes, so it took forever. (No matter, I'm a fan of the slow meal.) Another busser brought us someone else's croquetas by mistake, but our waitress let us have them anyway. "Well, someone screwed up, but they're on the house, so enjoy!" The kicker is that in my mango sorbet, I found a tiny piece of plastic that came from the container they stored it in. Lucky for Jaleo, I'm pretty hard to piss off in a restaurant. I told the waitress, she brought the manager over--the GM, not the shift manager, he explained what happened, I said it was cool (I'd also had a fair amount of that delicious sangria), then when we got the check, they'd knocked off a more than decent portion of it for all the tiny hiccups.

Hiccups aside, it was a great meal. I'll be back, but with more people so we can try everything on the menu. It's casual, but classy. Definitely a fan!

Yes, so this place is quite good. But, It's definitely not a "must-go-back-or-ill-die" type of place.

Pan con Tomate- 5 star (Hate bruscetta but this is a good situation)
A selection of all their Spanish cured meats:  I had 5 different hams and chorizo. I only like two a lot. Personally didn't like Iberico Hamon in Spain so this is personal preference.

Endives w/ goat cheese - 4.7 star
Patatas Bravas (potato chips w/ spicy tomato sauce) -  3 star
Croquetas de Jamon (ham croquettes) - 5 star 
Gambas al Ajillo (Garlic shrimp) -  2 star (black poo strings weren't removed. was rubbery. Flavor was bland. It said "very very famous" so i ordered. More like very very typical and plain. 
Pulpo a la Gallega (Boiled octopus w/ pee wee patatas) -  2 star 
Lightly battered eggplant w/ molasses -  5 star (tastes like sweet potato)
Canelones stuffed w/ pork and chicken w/ bechamel sauce -  2 star. Was too heavy for me.

Food was soooo delicious!! My family and I tried lots of dishes which were all great but our favorite was the paella. It was soo soo good, it might have taken 45 minutes to prepare but the wait was TOTALLY worth it. Don't be intimidated by the rabbit in the paella, it tastes great.

This was our second time to Jaleo. It is pricey for small plates but they are good.  Great choice of Tapas, the Iberrico ham is excellent and worth trying since it isn't available in every tapas restaurant. Everything is perfectly prepared with great presentation. The staff is great, very helpful with assisting you make decisions.

Where to start? My husband LOVED the gin & tonic's here, but not because of what you would think. The circle ice cubes won his heart. He in fact loves them so much we now have molds to make circle ice cubes at home. Only they are not crystal clear like Jaleo's are, so we fail.

I did enjoy this restaurant. It was fun, unique, and the food was great. The only issue I have is that we spent about $150 (did include alcohol), and we were not full when we left. I'm a big eater, and tapas apparently are just not my thing. Unless of course it includes an entr√©e afterwards.

The food was very good though. Every dish (with the exception of one), was amazing. The fried bacon-wrapped dates were amazing, and the paella that we ordered was fabulous. The one thing that fell short for us was something our server suggested, that ended up being a bag of chips (seriously - and a fun-size bag of chips at that), with a ketchup-y sauce drizzled over the chips. 

I did like the presentation of most of the tapas, one even came in a shoe! The atmosphere is very fun and unique, I also love that you can see the food being cooked. We ordered a porrone of spiked cider, and that was fabulous! 

Overall, the price is what got me. For Vegas, it's actually not that bad. But for me, if I spend that much money, I want to leave full.

Unbelievable. Several items were actually not eatable. The wine pairing was awful.
Gelato to tart to eat. Cooked onions to sweet to eat. Steak not seasoned at all.
The best thing was bread with stewed tomatoes on it, if that tells you anything.
Hard to believe it was so bad but believe me it was. Not sure what the people who gave this good rating got to eat, but I sure didn't.

Our night at Jaleo was a harmonic convergence of great food, great friends and great fun. Our reservation for six turned into a reservation for four. We called in the afternoon to advise them of the change, but couldn't reach a human so we mentioned it upon our arrival, which wasn't an issue. The restaurant itself is very loud and it opens into the even louder second floor of the Cosmopolitan, so leave Grandma and Grandpa at home, because they won't enjoy the noise level.

The prices are usually noted as being on the expensive side, but four of us ordered everything that we wanted, including alcohol, and the bill came to exactly $200.  Every dish was great. One of them we ordered a second time because the first one was so tasty. Really helpful service. I advised of my allergies only once, and had no problems all evening. We didn't feel rushed in the least, although the place was packed the entire time that we were there. 

Highly recommended for a really fun night out on the strip.

Best Spanish food I tasted in the US. It was like being in Spain. Their pan con tomate is to die for.
Their chicken croquetas is amazing too.

This is a great place for Spanish Tapas, fine dining as well. All though it was all cooked exquisitely, the flavors were a bit bland. I must admit that the chicken items were all delicious, but the rabbit tasted a little dry and was nothing to rave about. It was incredible how they made few ingredients stand out in simple yet delicious dishes. Our special paella's of the night were Chicken and Mushroom as well as a unique paella made with fadello noodles. The fadello paella was one of my favorite dishes of the entire night. The carne asada was also beautifully cooked as well as seasoned thoroughly. The tomato bread was another one of my favorites because the bread stayed crispy while the tomato topping was fresh and not overwhelming. The final thing I suggest is the cheese platter, the Spanish Brie was incredible and the rest was just as great. The service was formal and kind as well as quite accommodating.

Friday night 3/23... they did not honor their private room reservation we made 6 months in advance which we called a week prior to reconfirm. We had 3 March birthdays flying in to celebrate together and we were told this place would be a fun hip place to go to celebrate. Hip yes, fun... well, due to the fact they bumped us and lied to us, it wasn't going well. Later we found out "Cosmopolitan Executives" were in the room and they didn't "leave in time". Again another lie, they were still eating main courses. I'm sure this doesn't happen often, but the fact is, a place such as this pride themselves in excellent service and on this night, they failed and lied about it too.

What a great restaurant experience.

Pan con tomate y queso Manchego; olives two ways; jamon Iberico de bellota Fermin; ajo blanco; traditional Spanish tortilla; chistorras fritas;  piqullos rellano with crab; veal cheeks; traditional flan with Clementine sorbet.

Sangria and cava to wash everything down.

Fantastic, unobtrusive service that came with great recommendations on drinks and food.

Would eat here every day if I had the opportunity.

We had some great overpriced tapas, service was outstanding until it wasn't, and the decor and comfort of the place was suspect.

Let's start with the layout.  there were tables with uncomfortable chairs, or these long couches which went around the restaurant.  The couch things were comfortable if you were sitting back having a cocktail, but not so much if you were trying to eat a meal.  NOT a deal breaker, but weird.

The food -- some of it was great, some of it was ok, all of it was overpriced.  They had a specific vegetarian menu which was really nice.  Made it easier to find the veggie options on their extensive menu.  My friend (the vegetarian) had a goat cheese endive salad which which was divine.  A "warm" spinach salad, which was totally average and these weird eggplant things which were tempura fried and drizzled in honey, which she thought was good, I thought were a complete throwaway.  Three little founds of eggplant, almost tasteless but sweet from the honey for $9.00.  We both agreed it would have been better as a dessert.

I ordered piquillo peppers with a bit of iberico pork lardon, which was probably the best value on the menu.  $6.00 and completely tasty.  But definitely better to split and because of the pork I didn't have a person to share with.  I also ordered a cauliflower, date, olive dish which was divine.  My big splurge was Iberico Pork - which I thought was going to be roasted, but was in fact cured.  It was fine, it was good - but it was $35.00 an ounce.  For $35.00 I want a little more than some dried ham.  It came with a side of tomato bread, which I didn't know when I ordered it.  I HATE tomatoes.  I tried the bread, but I just couldn't do it, so I asked for some plain bread.

When the bill came, I was charged $12.00 for the bread.  TWELVE DOLLARS.  

I asked the waitress, who had been stellar to this point, and she said they charge the same price for bread with or without the tomato  TWELVE DOLLARS.  

She apologized for not telling me, and I told her I never would have paid TWELVE DOLLARS for bread.  (seriously, 6 slices of french type bread.) and she said she'd see what she could do.  Two seconds later, she was back with the full bill. 

Did an an order of $12.00 bread ruin my experience?  Yes, yes it did.  What a stupid thing to upset a customer over.  

Oh, I also had a $12.00 sangria.  It was adequate.  There's a place in Winters, I get a superior Sangria for $7.00.  

Caveat Emptor.  Would I eat here again?  Before the $12.00 bread, yes.  After the $12.00 bread.  No.  I hope it was worth it.
Love Jose's restaurants! Great small plates and sangria!

This is a fun restaurant to go to with a large group. The ambiance and service were great and the food was imaginative.  I liked all the small dishes to share and for the most part everything was delicious.  We asked the waiter to bring us a variety of tapas so we tasted a lot of items and most were very good.  The presentation of one item in a shoe was very unappealing and the pork was tough.  Otherwise fantastic,  colorful and fun.  Our bill with drinks was over $100 per person so be prepared.

I really wanted to like this place. But the food is meh the service is worse. Nothing worth ordering again. Wine was average. And it is so loud you have to shout to be heard. Honestly it's a pass all around

We walked in for lunch and had a great experience. The staff was great and we were seated immediately. The prices are steep for what amounted to be mediocre tapas but the flan was one of the best desserts I've ever had in my life.  I think it has a lemon foam and some kind of Spanish sorbet. I'm still trying to figure out how they made it taste so amazing.  Judging by the complexity of the dessert I'm sure the dinner service is amazing.

Don't go to this place expecting to feed your tummy. The portions are horribly small and EXPENSIVE for what you can get at other places.

Fancy place but it sucks!!!

Save your money and go to the Wynn instead!

Really bad service. Had to wait almost one hour for a table after being told it would take half an hour. Then after we set we waited a long time to be able to order drinks and then food. My plate came after my friend's plate so I had dinner by myself and one of my friend's plate never came. Had a "paella" that was nothing but fried pasta with very few microscopic shrimps. Overpriced for the size and quality of the food. Would not come back.

I keep coming back here every trip out... sure we have had one dumb waiter and this last time a real "witch" but the food is consistently delicious and the vermouths they have are amazing and something you cannot find elsewhere. Their "stinky cheese", the pricest cheese on the menu and the jamon iberico, also the pricest meat on the menu..... gotta live a little and order them. Worth every penny. Everything we tried has been delicious, freshly made and of the best quality. Very well done and enjoyable. Their happy hour has a great price on the vermouth tasting and the atmosphere is great, I enjoy relaxing and watching them cook. Check it out if you are at the cosmo.

This place is FANTASTIC. One of the best meals I've had in vegas. Upon first glance the menu was a bit confusing as it was rather extensive and most of the headings were in Spanish, but after a thoughtful explanation of the menu from our server we knew just what to order. 

We started with cheeses that 1) came out of the kitchen almost instantly and 2) were exceptional. The next dish which our server described to us as similar to a carpaccio but made from pork came out with a really unique presentation and was just as delicious. 

We then sampled the fried lobster and crab fritters which my husband says "changed his life"... he may have been exaggerating but they were amazing. 

Lastly we had the skirt steak entree which was served with an aioli that I couldn't get enough of and the steak was cooked perfectly and jam packed with flavor. 


Unfortunately after all this we were far too full to sample the dessert but exceptional food and service...will definitely be back on our next trip to Vegas!

Very good! everything was tasty and fresh. Great location inside The Cosmopolitan. Service was perfect. Had the crab soup, gaspacho, king crab with caviar, crepe with pate and shrimp al ajillo. Overall, great dining experience!

The dessert was outstanding: olive oil ice cream with fruit. Holy moly!

The service and cocktails were great, but the food was not good. There were too many dishes comprised of large globs of mayo which is nasty. Other items such as sliders seemed very greasy and limited flavor. This felt more like bad diner food.

Delicious! Best meal we had in Vegas!

Fav dish: surprisingly.... white asparagus 

-1 star for leaving smelling like a campfire.

Deliciously fun experience! Live and energetic feel!  My boyfriend took me here on a date.... we started with their specialty gin and tonic.... followed by a selection of tapas chosen by our server as a sampler menu. I loved everything we had! Great mix of flavors and textures, such a fun experience and element of surprise letting the server make recommendations and choices for us.

This was my second time here, and quite possibly my last. I'm a fan of Jose Andres' restaurants, but the food tends to be a little hit-or-miss. I really like Bazaar out in LA, but the hit-to-miss ratio was considerably less favorable at Jaleo. Nothing overwhelmingly great, but the lobster salad was good, as were the gambas con gabardina, and the endive with goat cheese. The pan con tomate with anchovies and the the bacon-wrapped dates were both ok, although nothing spectacular. And we should have stayed away from the patatas bravas, which for some strange reason consisted of a bowl lays potato chips squirted with sirracha and mayonnaise. 
The real killer for the evening was the service. I realize dumb people have to work someplace, but do they all have to be assigned to my table? The bus boy kept awkwardly climbing over us or shoving himself between us trying to take our dishes and glasses when we clearly still had food and pitchers of sangria in front of us. At one point he practically tried to take the fork out of my date's mouth mid-bite. An I once had to slap at his hand to keep him from taking my plate. He's very lucky he didn't catch a fork to the hand. The waiter was really no better, and screwed up our order at least 5 times. It's 3 days later and I'm still waiting for my gazpacho. I also recommend checking your bill before putting your credit card down, as our waiter screwed that up, too.

I just come here for the Gin & Tonics and the amazing service.  I've never been a fan of the tapas, but the attention to detail and crafting of the cocktails make this place a must-do for your Vegas (or DC) trip.

All great tapas. Pricey. And I only complain about prices when the portions are small. But look up the definition of Tapas. Bocaditos might be more appropriate. 

If you have the money to burn, come.

My favorite part was when the hot waiter poured a lemonade/Spanish beer mixture into my mouth. ;-p

You can never go wrong with Sangria. I was slurring my words by the second cup.

This is definitely the place to be pre-Marquee.... or heck even post-Marquee.

Oh and the lobster paella was okay. My mom's is better. But if you don't have the luxury of having a Spanish mother, then you'd probably enjoy theirs. Just get the damn full lobster because we ordered the half and I was left yearning.

Fabulous small plates dining.  The menu was quite extensive with a large number of dishes.  At first we were overwhelmed with the descriptions and possibilities, but our server (Magaly) was fantastic. She gave us a rundown on all of the various sections of the menu.  Ultimately, we asked for her recommendations which were perfect. Each dish was superb.  We loved toast with a marmalade jelly and goat cheese -and- the bacon wrapped dates with a crusted coating.  These sound a bit crazy but they were wonderfully delicious.  We couldn't have enjoyed the meal more.  Special thanks to Malagy.

Reservation was at 8:45 for 6 of us, two hours later we are still here only because they forgot about 3 of our orders. Service wasn't consistent, the food was okay, some dishes were good like the chicken and mushroom paella, the steak was disappointing along with the pasta with shrimp. Everything was on the salty side. The drinks were at least good, I had some smokey chili margarita, the sangria was good as well. The manager at least did acknowledge that our food took a while and brought out one free appetizer. Overall I won't be back here anytime soon.
Rediculoisly salty. Service was good, but nearly all of our dishes tasted overly salty

Fantastic restaurant located in the Cosmo. 
We enjoyed Jose's Way, a delectable sampling of different dishes. Started with almonds and goat cheese. The salt and savory was delectable. The creamy cheese was enhanced by the salty crunch of the almonds. Followed by air bread wrapped in cured ham and tomato foam, an explosion of delicate flavor. Next came imported breadsticks with cured Spanish sausage, which was sublime. 
Next came cod fritters with honey aioli. Crisp on the outside, soft and fluffy inside, with a sweet, delicious contrast from the aioli. This was followed by king crab salad with salsa Rosa. It was a lot for, refreshing and delicious dish. 
Roasted peppers with goat cheese: the slightly sweet, fire roasted peppers contrasted nicely with the tang of the goat cheese. 
The shoulder cut of a Spanish pig was served with mustard aioli, cilantro aioli, and lavender stems. The meat had a nice crisp finish and was tender and juicy, and the sauces contrasted one another nicely. 
We special ordered our favorite, rabbit and chicken paella, a delicious house made rice dish. They feature a different paella every night. 
This was followed by a green salad. 
For fun, we also ordered fried chicken fritters, which are served in a shoe. Cute and delicious! After the variety of meats and sauces, the salad, with its tangy vinaigrette, tasted light and refreshing. The roasted pine nuts added a satisfying crunch and a rich flavor. 
Finally for dessert, a cherry, sherry Grenada with a vanilla, olive oil ice cream. 
When you come, be sure to ask for the server Darian. He is friendly, personable and knowledgeable. He makes wonderful recommendations and know a lot about each dish and all the varieties of wine. 
This is definitely worth the price, the atmosphere is great and the service is outstanding. A must see when you are in Vegas.

Do yourself a favor and order the bacon-wrapped figs, some Serrano ham and a selection of cheeses. This is a terrific way to start out your evening and all go great with a terrific selection of beverages. Their house gin & tonic is made with Hendrick's. Enough said!
Very disappointed.  Paella dishes were small.  Everyone in our party left still hungry and went elsewhere to eat a second time.

I cannot for the life of my figure out why Jaleo has such a low yelp rating. It is one of my favorite restaurants in Vegas - consistently fantastic food and service. Incidentally, my other favorite restaurant in Vegas is China Poblano, so maybe it is a Jose Andres thing. 

Yes, it is expensive. No, this should not be a surprise. Jose Andres is an award-winning chef. The menu is posted online WITH the prices listed. This is Vegas. The price you pay, however is 100% WORTH IT. 

I am one of those restaurant patrons that asks a lot of questions (What's your favorite dish? What's the most popular? Would you choose __ or __? How is that prepared? What's that dish over there?) and the waitstaff always answers my questions without any attitude or annoyance. They're friendly and fast. 

It is loud. Every 45 minutes or so they ring a bell and yell "Paella!" when the paella is ready. They are accommodating of groups, so large groups of people who have had too much sangria can get quite raucous. But it's also fun. Barcelona is loud. Barcelona is raucous. This is not a white-table-cloth restaurant, so don't expect that type of atmosphere. They have a foosball table as a table.. it has been my dream to one day be seated there, but I'm beginning to wonder if you maybe have to ask when you make the reservation. 

Now the food....

Pan de cristal con tomate fresco - tomato bread - sounds simple, but is remarkably delicious. Reminds me of bruschetta, but with a crispier bread that doesn't hurt your teeth when you bite into it. 

Jam√≥n ib√©rico de bellota Ferm√≠n - fancy ham - comes with tomato bread. I am not a major ham connoisseur. I am amazed at how they can slice it so thin (by hand!). 

D√°tiles con tocino 'como hace todo el mundo' - bacon wrapped dates - not my favorite bacon wrapped dates around

Croquetas de pollo - chicken fritters - I was worried this would be fancy chicken fingers. Instead, it is like a pot pie wrapped in a mozzarella stick. SO GOOD. Ultimate comfort food. I wish I could eat this once a month (if you know what I mean ;)). Also, it comes served in a shoe (a Camper shoe, to be precise), which is fun. 

Salm√≥n crudo con huevas de salm√≥n - salmon / roe cone - I really liked the cone part, but roe is so salty, so the overall effect was pretty salty. Good, but salty.

Ensalada de bogavante con c√≠tricos y escarola - lobster & frisee salad - comes with a generous portion of lobster. I do not like frisee, but my mom loved this dish. 

Coca con erizos de mar - uni toast - comes with a LOT of uni. Although, now that I'm writing this review months later, I don't really remember anything that special about it. 

Rossejat - noodle paella - SO GOOD. Definitely a must-order. 

Rossejat negra con cigala - squid ink rossejat - also really good, but I like the regular rossejat better. I don't know how they get the inside of the Norwegian lobster to such a creamy consistency. Be careful about letting this touch your lips, it will stain them a lovely shade of grey. 

Canelones tradicionales de cerdo y h√≠gado de pato con salsa b√©chamel - pork & foie gras canaloni - the ultimate indulgence. Really rich and creamy. If you are lactose intolerant, you might have a stomach ache after, but it is so worth it. This is such a rich and heavy dish, if you order this I recommend maybe selecting one item fewer than you would have. 

Other notes - 
I recommend the white sangria over the red. 
They do NOT have a full menu at lunch.

Our first time here at Jaleo and I must tell you, during this RESTAURANT WEEK this restaurant was completely packed! There were so many booked tables on a Tuesday night, But the very upside to this experience was our waiter MAXWELL and his table assistant EDGAR. From the beginning of our night, it's been a pleasure. We started off by sitting on a section where the a/c is blowing right directly on our table so we respectively asked to be moved to a more warmer section were the a/c wasn't blowing right above us. EDGAR, was very quick and helped move us and also MAXWELL was there to move us as well. My husband and I ordered the "Restaurant Week" menu while our son had the grilled hangar steak. Maxwell was very prompt in talking to our son on how he likes his steak made and if he would like it better if the sauce was on the side. Max was always checking on us and making sure that our experience was excellent, and it was! EDGAR, who also knew that our son was cold due to the fact that he forgot his jacket, helped his chill come to an ease. He came by and gave my son warm glasses from the dishwasher just so my son can hold something warm. With this gesture, it really made me feel that these employees are very helpful and innovative. He kept checking on our son to make sure if he's comfortable. I will surely come back and try the rest of the menu that wasn't on "Restaurant Week" because the 10 course meal we received were amazing! Our favorite were the chilled gazpacho, hanger steak, and their Sangria. Though the price is high, it is a real Spanish Restaurant there's nothing more authentic than this restaurant and it's in Las Vegas so people should just get used to it. Las Vegas knows best of the best.

Cons: 
The service wasn't 5 start. They tried but you would expect more from this. Waiter could have explained the dishes better and staggered the food a bit more. 
The table space is very crammed and not the most comfortable. They can definitely rearrange the tables and space better. 

Pros: 
We ordered the Chefs Pairing so we didn't know what was coming. We got to taste options that we otherwise would not have ordered and were pleasantly surprised. Great experience. 
Some of the food was very simple yet tasteful. 
Each plate was very interesting. The plating was also very beautiful. 
Dessert was amazing!! We had the gin sorbe with berries and agave syrup. The gin foam was oddly amazing. 
The arroz con leche dessert was also very indulgent and delicious. 

Overall this place was a good vibe and atmosphere with amazing food. Easily recommended and will come back soon.
